Project_Title: Security and Mobility over the Global Information Transport Platform
Project_Description: The term global information transport platform (GiTP) refers to multiple wired and wireless communication networks such as the Internet, cellular networks, wireless networks, vehicle networks and so on. A massive amount of information is distributed over the GiTP every day, including sensitive data like financial and business transactions. Ensuring security across multiple networks economically is essentialâ€”but very challenging. Researchers at the University of Waterloo, the University of Ottawa, Queenâ€™s University and McMaster University will investigate and develop new technologies to guarantee security without compromising flexibility and usability. This new technology will be commercialized in partnership with indus
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project_Title: Imaging for Cardiovascular Therapeutics (ICT)
Project_Description: Once a sudden killer, cardiovascular disease is being transformed into a chronic treatment challenge. At the same time, because of our greater understanding of atherosclerosis (hardening of the arteries), prevention is becoming a realistic goal. As a result, new therapies are emerging aimed at better diagnosis and treatment, but their full potential remains to be exploited. Convinced that Ontario is well-positioned to play a major role in developing, implementing and evaluating cardiovascular therapies, particularly imaging therapies, researchers at Sunnybrook Health Sciences Centre  propose to bring together Ontarioâ€™s three centres of excellence in cancer research (Ottawa, London and Toronto). Using their ties to industry, the researchers will develop better tools to diagnose, monitor and treat cancer using approaches, based on imaging technology (creating images of the body or parts of it

Project_Title: Centre for the Control of Emerging Contaminants (CCEC)
Project_Description: Emerging contaminants (ECs)  is a term encompassing thousands of compounds released into our water system daily, including drug residues, personal care and cleaning products, industrial chemicals and even â€œnewâ€ compounds such as nanomaterials. Some of these pass virtually unchanged through wastewater treatments, which were never designed to remove them, and emerge in municipal drinking water sources. Itâ€™s a growing concern for Canadians, yet the risks are poorly understood.  Through the new Centre for the Control of Emerging Contaminants, an interdisciplinary group of respected water scientists, industry and government will focus on emerging contaminants in water, wastewater and residuals (biosolids). Specifically, the centre will develop and test new technologies for measuring, monitoring, controlling and removing ECs in current and next-generation wastewater treatment sy
Keyword: water, wastewater

Project_Title: Self Powered Sensor Networks
Project_Description: A wireless sensor network consists of a number of distributed devices that use specialized sensors to monitor physical or environmental conditions, such as temperature, sound, pressure or motion, at different locations. Wireless sensor networks have a wide range of applications including monitoring, tracking and controlling (for example, traffic monitoring, object tracking and nuclear reactor controlling). Still in their early stages, thereâ€™s an opportunity for the commercialization of a family of products that take advantage of their potentialâ€”and thatâ€™s just what researchers at the University of Toronto intend to do. Working with Motorola, they will develop and commercialize the technologies necessary for the deployment of large-scale wireless sensor networks, including sensor hardware, software and energy capture, conservation and storage technol
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Keyword: climate change

Project_Title: High Efficiency Silicon Photovoltaics
Project_Description: Photovoltaics is the direct conversion of solar energy into electricity and itâ€™s becoming an increasingly important technology in the production of sustainable energy. While silicon offers one of the highest photovoltaic energy conversion efficiencies, is stable, readily available and environmentally friendly, cost remains a stumbling block to its use. Researchers at the universities of Toronto and Waterloo, together with ARISE Technologies of Waterloo, will concentrate on developing high efficiency, cost effective silicon photovoltaic solar cells.  The researchers will develop and integrate a set of â€œthin filmâ€ technologies that will lead to a prototype, with the ultimate goal being the creation of a photovoltaic manufacturing base in On

Project_Title: SciNet:  Enabling Future Science Today
Project_Description: The SciNet consortium is a group headed by the University of Toronto and involving 10 affiliated research hospitals. Using world-class high performance computing systems, the scientists will concentrate on groundbreaking research across a wide range of disciplines, including aerospace, biomedical engineering, bioinformatics, climate modeling, cosmology, and genomics. SciNet will be available to researchers anywhere in the province via the Optical Advanced Network of Ontario (ORANO). Highly skilled technical analysts will work closely with researchers to develop and optimize the sophisticated algorithms (finite lists of well-defined instructions for accomplishing specific tasks) and performing techniques required to take full advantage of these high performance computer clusters with thousands of processors. Expert systems administrators will ensure that the various computer systems are operated to optimum capacity.
OIA_AREA: Development and creation of investigation spots

Project_Title: New Technologies for Ginseng Agriculture and Product Development
Project_Description: Despite its history of cultural use and medicinal claims for everything from baby gripe to impotence, ginseng continues to be controversial. In fact, thereâ€™s little agreement on the active chemical constituents of ginseng and little evidence to support traditional health claims in part because of variations in ginseng quality. Thatâ€™s a problem for Ontarioâ€™s ginseng industry, which is a major world-wide producer of high quality ginseng. A new network centred at the University of Western Ontario will bring together researchers from a number of universities and colleges with Agriculture & Agri-Food Canada, the Ontario Ginseng Growers Association and the Natural Health Product Inudstry. Taking advantage of recently developed technology, the network will develop a unique Ontario ginseng variety with predictable quality, safey and medicinal properties and develop new value-added Ontario branded giseng pro
Keyword: rural

Project_Title: The International Regulome Consortium
Project_Description: Launched in 2004, the Ottawa Health Research Instituteâ€™s International Regulome Consortium (IRC) is an ambitious, Canadian-led international research effort.  It brings together over 66 investigators from 34 institutions in 12 countries.  Its focus is mapping gene regulatory circuit boards (similar to electrical circuits) â€” the next crucial step in genome research.  The findings will help to identify targets for drug development and new therapies for currently untreatable disease.  The requested resources will extend and translate IRCâ€™s research findings through new faculty, technical positions, core facilities and a multidisciplinary training program for the next generation of biologists specializing in this field.  A multi-level commercialization program will strategically identify and protect intellectual property.  There will be added value via targeted research.  IRCâ€™s work with partners (e.g., MaRS) will commercialize and exploit IRC research f

Project_Title: Pre-competitive Development of Chemical Probes for Epigenetic Targets; A novel paradigm
Project_Description: A â€œchemical probeâ€ decodes a proteinâ€™s role in a cellâ€™s biology.  It is used to assess whether the cell protein is a diagnostics or drug treatment target.  Highly effective chemical probes are not widely available.  The reason is:  industry increasingly depends on academia to identify and validate cell protein targets while academia depends on industry on the chemical probes it needs to do this work.  The University of Torontoâ€™s Structural Genomics Consortium (SGC) will partner with GlaxoSmithKline in a public-private partnership to solve this paradox.  Industry medicinal chemistry expertise will be applied to an important problem in academia (a major paradigm shift).  The focus will be the pre-competitive development of chemical probes to study the role of proteins involved in epigenetic (changing gene function without changing DNA) signalling.  Epigenetic research is central to cancer and other diseases, and to stem cell biology.  The projectâ€™s output (15 chemical probes and training highly qualdisciplinary personnel) will put Ontario researchers and companies in an excellent position to discover drugs and develop diagnostics programs.

Project_Title: The National Centre for Audiology: Developing and advancing hearing technologies
Project_Description: Conservative estimates suggest that at least 10 per cent of Canadians suffer from hearing impairment, with the number growing rapidly with age.  Restoring hearing (via a hearing aid or cochlear implant) works well for many, but not all, hearing-impaired listeners.  The National Centre for Audiology (NCA) at the University of Western Ontario is a world renowned centre for research in hearing, hearing disorders, and hearing technologies.  NCA, working with Ontario partners in hearing technologies industries, will work to bring new technological possibilities to the hearing care sector.  The proposed research will develop technologies that are capable of making sounds audible, understandable and of high quality, improve surgical success rates and make listening possible in optimal and difficult listening environments.  This project will increase Ontarioâ€™s recognition as a world leader in the hearing and communication industries, including creating a more integrated hearing technologies presence in Ontari

Project_Title: The Western-CIGI-BRIC-Ontario Project
Project_Description: In managing its economic interests, Ontario must take into account the rapid shift in global economic power and activity towards the quickly growing economies of Brazil, India, Russia and China (BRIC).  The University of Western Ontario and the Centre for International Governance Innovation (CIGI) at the University of Waterloo will address issues that affect critical industries (e.g., creative industries, health, bioscience) and related policies in the four countries.  Through collaborations and partnerships in Ontario and in Brazil, Russia, India and China, the project will produce major benefits for private and public sector decision-makers, including new economic analysis information, and the identification of Ontario policy and commercial opportunities.

Project_Title: Mobile Health: A New Frontier in Wireless Technology
Project_Description: Diseases, illness, injuries and premature death have enormous direct and indirect costs.  Health care costs are growing at a faster rate than provincial revenue growth.  Emerging technologies like MEMS â€” Micro-Electro-Mechanical-Systems â€” (combining computers with tiny mechanical devices like sensors and valves embedded in semiconductor chips) have the potential both to improve the productivity of heath care services and to benefit Ontarioâ€™s medical device industry.  The University of Waterlooâ€™s proposed research will investigate how to apply new technologies in remote health monitoring and drug delivery systems.  The findings will benefit patient care, be immediately applicable in Ontarioâ€™s strategically important medical device industry and the development of intelligent medical systems in the future.  Training highly qualified, multi-disciplinary people will enhance the provinceâ€™s global competitiveness in the wireless, MEMS, information technology and health scien

Project_Title: Integrated Molecular Pathology of Targeted Cancer Therapy in Lung Cancer
Project_Description: Lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer death in Ontario. The University Health Network proposes to establish the Integrated Molecular Pathology, Pharmacodynamic, Pharmacogenomic and Proteomics in Lung Cancer (IMP4-Lung Cancer) program in collaboration with several key industrial partners in Ontario and abroad.  Instead of the more commonly used cancer â€œcell lineâ€ models, the UHN team will place patient-derived tumour xenograft (from one species to another) models in immunodeficient mice.  This will make it possible to closely and directly establish and maintain the clinical disease state.  UHN will build on its long-term relationship with IBM to develop an information-based medicine platform.  The research promises advances that will achieve true â€œpersonalized medicineâ€, leading to improved quality and reduced cost of lung cancer diagnosis and more effective treatment.  The project will bring significant economic benefits to Ontario through reduced health care costs.  It will further strengthen thceâ€™s internationally recognized leadership position in the research and development of personalized- and target-based cancer therapy.  The proposed program will also provide a training environment â€” unique and unparalleled in Canada â€” for youth and scientists to train for positions in industry and aca

Project_Title: Flexible Transparent Electronics: Transformational Technology for Display Industries
Project_Description: Thin-Film Transistors (TFTs) are used to create high quality flat screen displays (e.g., computer monitors).  TTFTs (transparent thin-film transistors) are an important development in the emerging field of transparent electronics where wide band-gap semiconductors achieve invisible circuits.  TTFTs have the potential to bring radically new approaches to issues like automobile navigation systems and solar energy generation.  This integrated research program will link Ontarioâ€™s established leaders in technology commercialization with the University of Waterlooâ€™s leading flexible electronics experts.  Their focus will be on transforming TTFT technology to create transparent, flexible, large-area electronic devices.  The resources/expertise combination positions the project to achieve an ambitious goal of establishing TTFTs in a broad market.  There will be significant benefits for Ontario and Canada and the potential for local industries to have a competitive edge in the international marketp
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project_Title: APECS: Advancing Photovoltaics for Economical Concentrator Systems
Project_Description: The world-wide marketplace for high efficiency photovoltaic concentrator technology is growing at 30 per cent per annum.  This technology delivers more power at lower cost because it uses a lot less semiconducting material to convert light into power.  This technology is key to creating cost-effective and efficient solar powered electricity generation that will enable widespread adoption of alternative and green energy.  The University of Ottawaâ€™s cross-disciplinary team has a goal of establishing high efficiency concentrating photovoltaic (CPV) systems as an economically-viable technology for grid-connected solar power generation.  The research team has set an aggressive target of enabling $2/W concentrator system cost, and $0.07/kW-hr grid parity.  The proposed program will contribute directly to improving the environment and reducing non-renewable resource dependence.  The research will develop highly qualified and skilled personnel at the college and university levels, plus outreach activities through t Adventures in Engineering and Science program.
Keyword: climate change

Project_Title: Novel strategies for enhancing oncolytic virus-mediated cancer therapy
Project_Description: An oncolytic virus infects and breaks down cancer cells but not normal cells.  It is a type of targeted therapy.  Ottawa Health Research Instituteâ€™s Program in Cancer Therapeutics (PCT) plans to exploit its expertise and its industrial partnersâ€™ experience to discover better oncolytic virus genotypes and virus and drug combinations to improve human cancer treatment.  Most of the proposed research aims to complement the process development work that Jennerex Biotherapeutics Inc. (an industrial partner spun off from earlier PCT oncolytic virus discoveries) is funding.  The ultimate outcome from these studies will be clinical trials and subsequent marketing of effective products.  PCT has a 20-year history in training research personnel (graduate students, post-doctoral fellows, undergraduate honours students and coop students).  Its 15 year-old â€œLetâ€™s Talk Scienceâ€ program reaches high school students in

Project_Title: MESSAGEs: MEdia-Server and Support for Advanced Gaming Environments
Project_Description: Gaming technology has many significant applications in many sectors:  the entertainment industry; educational, industrial and government training; education and services development and testing.  Combining high mobility and high performance has great potential in mobile wireless handsets, automobile technological systems and other applications but there are major technical and creative challenges.  Through MEdia-Server and Support for Advanced Gaming Environments (MESSAGEs), the University of Ottawaâ€™s proposed research will identify solutions to these challenges, with a team of leading Canadian researchers from diverse fields and private sector partners.  There will be commercial opportunities for Ontario companies in mobile games, interactive entertainment, health information, education and other applicatio
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project_Title: Therapeutic biomaterials for regenerative medicine
Project_Description: Imagine a world where transplant patients do not wait for a donor and where a single injection repairs hearts and knees.  This University of Toronto project is intended to bring regenerative medicine closer to the clinic and to lead this transformation in medicine.  Novel biomaterials, â€œtherapeutic polymersâ€ (Theramersâ„¢), unique to Rimon Therapeutics and Ontario can be used to repair and regenerate diseased tissues without using cells, drugs or soluble factors (e.g., repairing non-healing chronic ulcers).  These materials potentially have a shorter time to market than devices with cells or drugs.  If realized, this would provide Ontario with a significant competitive advantage in realizing the economic benefits of this revolution in medicine.  There is a market opportunity of potentially $3 to 5 billion in product sales (with >$1 billion in revenue to Rimon/Ontario).  The first products from the research are expected to generate revenue in

Project_Title: Project Ã†GIS â€“ Integrating Accessibility into Emerging
Project_Description: The Ontarians with Disabilities Act, 2005 demonstrates Ontarioâ€™s strong commitment to equal access.  Innovative research and development of inclusive ICT is needed to help meet that commitment.  Indeed, there is a growing worldwide demand for ICT products and services that are accessible to people with disabilities, especially given rapidly aging populations.  The internationally recognized Adaptive Technology Resource Centre (ATRC) at the University of Toronto is an essential participant in a large international research network, Ã†GIS.  ATRC and its partners will undertake research to support an Ã†GIS project to develop an Open Accessibility Framework.  The framework is aimed at making desktop and mobile devices and internet applications accessible to people with a range of disabilities.  The ATRC and its Ontario partners will play a critical role in establishing, developing and user-testing the framework.  An Open Accessibility Everywhere Group will live beyond the project lifetime, bringing together endrs and developers to continue ICT accessibility initiatives.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project_Title: Thellungiella Stress Genomics for Sustainable Crop Production in Canada
Project_Description: Ontario crops grown for food or bioenergy production must be increasingly resilient to bad weather.  This will ensure a safe, high quality, and sustainable agriculture industry for the province.  McMasterâ€™s research focuses on a highly stress-tolerant native plant (Thellungiella salsuginea) that is closely related to the canola plant.  It is able to grow in cold areas where there is little water.  The research will identify genes in this plant that are associated with stress-tolerance.  In collaboration with its industry partner, Performance Plants Inc. (a successful Ontario based agriculture biotechnology company), the university team will be able to transfer traits to economically important crops in Ontario to increase their tolerance to drought, cold, etc.  The industry partner has tested and implemented the technology and commercialization path for the projec
Keyword: bio-economy, rural, climate change

Project_Title: Certification of Safety-Critical Software-Intensive Systems
Project_Description: There is an urgent need for tools and methods to certify critical, often safety-critical (e.g., pacemakers), software systems in the biomedical, financial, and nuclear industries.  McMaster Universityâ€™s team will research and develop tools, methodologies and product-focused approaches to achieve this.  The universityâ€™s industrial partners will commercialize the research products.  The proposed research will establish Ontario as a world leader in the increasingly vital area of software certification.  It will train a significant number of people, creating a critical mass of expertise in the development and certification of safety and mission-critical software in Ontario.  The work will directly benefit the targeted biomedical, financial, and nuclear industries (which are critical to Ontarioâ€™s economic future), and potentially others such as the automotive ind
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Keyword: nuclear energy

Project_Title: Ontario Preclinical Imaging Consortium
Project_Description: Scientists, drug companies, and clinical researchers are struggling to better understand how changes in the genes make people more or less susceptible to disease.  The Ontario Preclinical Imaging Consortium (OPIC) at Sunnybrook Health Sciences Centre ties together the research activities of a large and success group of imaging researchers from across Ontario.  All are concentrating on developing noninvasive imaging tools to quantify development and disease in small animal models of human disorders (e.g., cancer, arthritis, cardiovascular disease).  OPICâ€™s vision is a pre-clinical pipeline â€” from basic investigations of genes to assessing experimental treatments.  It will push candidate treatments and therapies to the next level of human clinical trials to benefit patients everywhere.  Expanding Ontarioâ€™s imaging research capacity will help Ontario-based academic and industrial groups (including pharmaceutical companies) to be internationally competitive in advancing new products through preclinical and al trials.

Project_Title: Genomics Approaches to Mitigate Fungal Threats to Crops
Project_Description: In 2006, the total farm value of Ontarioâ€™s major crops was close to $2.7 billion.  The economic value of the provinceâ€™s forests and trees clearly affects its tourism, land value and timber harvest.  Fungal and fungal-like plant diseases have the potential to impact these sectors severely.  Trent Universityâ€™s proposed research will create databases to provide knowledge on how fungal and fungal-like diseases are able to overcome crop resistance or become more virulent, causing epidemics.  The fungal species for study include those that cause Wheat Leaf Rust, Wheat Stem Rust and Common Smut of Corn and the fungal-like pathogens are those that cause Sudden Oak Death and Damping Off.  Understanding the impact of genetic variation on disease development will greatly improve the chances of developing sustainable means to combat these pathogens and protect Ontarioâ€™s field and greenhouse crops, and forestry
Keyword: rural

Project_Title: Nanomaterial-Enabled Products for the Ontario Manufacturing Sector
Project_Description: Nanotechnology (or molecular manufacturing) is a branch of engineering.  It deals with the design and manufacture of extremely small electronic circuits and mechanical devices built at the molecular level of matter.  This research program will support the formation of the University of Torontoâ€™s Centre for Nanomaterials in Manufacturing Innovation.  The proposed research is Canadaâ€™s first targeted program in the area of applied nanomaterials (a leading nanotechnology subfield) to create new high-tech products for Ontarioâ€™s manufacturing industries.  It will produce innovative products unavailable anywhere else in the world.  The program is a collaborative effort involving 11 of Ontarioâ€™s most successful university researchers in applied nanomaterials from the University of Toronto and McMaster University, with nine participating companies providing cash and in-kind support.  The Centre will create a unique interface between the research community and Ontarioâ€™s manufacturing industries and investment.  There will be training for a large number of postdoctoral fellows, graduate and undergraduate students and initiatives to help young people understand nanotechnology.

Project_Title: Sustainable Bedrock Water Supplies for Ontario Communities
Project_Description: Over one million people in Ontario depend on bedrock aquifers (underground beds or layers of earth, gravel, or porous stone yielding water) for their water.  Under the Ontario Clean Water Act, 2006, communities must develop Source Water Protection Plans to ensure safe water supplies.  However, there are gaps in scientific information about bedrock aquifers that limit the scope of the plans.  Research by a 13-member multidisciplinary team from three Ontario universities (Guelph, Waterloo and McMaster), in collaboration with Quebec, German and US organizations, will improve the scientific basis for expanding bedrock aquifer use, designing aquifer protection and clean-up of abandoned industrial/commercial lands to achieve secure and sustainable municipal drinking water supplies.  The City of Guelph will be a â€œfield laboratory.â€  The project will produce new technologies, commercialization opportunities, highly trained engineers and scientists, international competitiveness of Ontario-based companies, and outh education.
Keyword: water, wastewater

Project_Title: Genomics for Agricultural Sustainability
Project_Description: Increasing demand for food in developing nations like China and India, diminishing supplies and rising costs of fossil fuel energy, and global climate change are putting unprecedented stress on agricultural productivity.  Corn is a major crop in Ontario, worth over $1.5 billion to the economy annually.  The University of Guelphâ€™s research, with its industrial partner Syngenta, will focus on maize plantsâ€™ ability to use nitrogen-based fertilizers more effectively and use water under stress conditions.  Since nitrogen-based fertilizers are a major pollution source, reducing their use will lessen environmental impacts.  The research will identify genes that control plant growth and alter their activity to specifically target traits to improve the plant.  Genomic information gained from studying maize can be transferred to other important grain crops, such as barley, rice and wh
Keyword: bio-economy, rural, climate change

Project_Title: Proteomic Technologies for the Study of Rare Cells
Project_Description: This project builds on a unique technology, termed the proteomic reactor, to respond to one of the major challenges in the field of proteomics:  the efficient processing of samples. Improvements to this technology will provide better proteomic results for routine proteomics samples as well as allow the study of the proteome of single cells. The goals of the project are to (1) develop different proteomic reactor formats for stand-alone processing of protein mixtures (2) use microfabrication technologies to develop better proteomic reactor and different surface affinities on planar chips (3) demonstrate the application of these devices from microgram levels of proteome samples all the way down to single cell analysis, and (4) to develop turn-key kits that will be the basis for training.

Project_Title: Multiplexed MicroRNA Detection on an Electronic Chip
Project_Description: Investigations into microRNA - a class of nucleic acids discovered only a little over a decade ago - have led to a new understanding of how an individualâ€™s gene expression reflects his state of health.  This project will build a platform technology ideally-suited to quantifying microRNA expression levels. In contrast with existing methods, the technology proposed will cost under $10 per assay and will only require 1 hour of operator time and an additional 1 hour of measurement time, and will provide the sensitivity needed to work with samples already available in tissue banks.  This technology will provide a novel and practical platform for genomics research in Canad

Project_Title: Software tools to simplify gene function prediction
Project_Description: This project will build computer software to help overcome two barriers to progress in genomic and proteomic research: i) the average biologistâ€™s inablity to use advanced genomics technology, and ii) expensive and time-consuming collection and analysis of genome-scale datasets. For the average biologist, a user-friendly website will be built through which they can make predictions about gene function using all available genomics and proteomics data. For the functional genomics researcher, it will incorporate a decision support system that enables evaluation of various data collection strategies by comparing the data quality and novel information content of preliminary data with published genomics, proteomics and gene function data. Both of these tools rely on the same underlying software architecture, which will be freely available over the web. To ensure that our software tools have a maximal enabling impact on a diverse biological user community, we will develop and disseminate extensive user training resrces.

Project_Title: Massively Multiparametric Flow Cytometer Analyzer
Project_Description: The goal of this project is to develop and with DVS Sciences to commercialize an instrument that can measure the concentration of up to 100 different biomarkers on individual cells at rates of 1000 or more cells per second.  This technology will trigger a new era of diagnostics that will allow diagnosis of disease based on populations of individual cells and their biomarker signatures.  For instance, such technology may enable diagnosing cancer reoccurrence which is thought to be triggered by a small population of cancer cells frequently resistant to traditional cancer treatment. The instrument consists of a flow cytometer that introduces cells at high rates into a mass spectrometer analyzer.  For each injected cell, the mass spectrometer will then detect and analyze up to 100 different specifically designed diagnostic reagent molecules that can simultaneously bind to cell surface biomarkers.

Project_Title: Automated Three-dimensional Phenotyping of Mouse Embryos
Project_Description: This project will develop new technology based on imaging and automated computer analysis to visualize embryos and compare them to the non-mutated embryo. Three-dimensional images will be generated using magnetic resonance imaging because of its capability of seeing soft tissues. An alternative imaging strategy based on optical 3D imaging will also be investigated because it potentially has better resolution and unique tissue sensitivities. For both of these imaging modalities, sophisticated computer analysis will be developed to compare images of an embryo with a single mutation to the reference embryo, and as a consequence, point out the regions of difference.

Project_Title: Environmental Barcoding Through Massively Parallelized Sequencing
Project_Description: The assignment of a DNA barcode involves the analysis of variations in the sequence of a select region of a particular gene, mitochondrial cytochrome c oxidase I (COI) in each species. Using these DNA barcodes, it will be possible to identify any organism, be it juvenile or adult, male or female, large or small, from only a tiny piece of tissue. All DNA barcodes are stored in the Barcode of Life Data Systems (BOLD), which is used by all international barcode campaigns in the Consortium for the Barcode of Life (CBOL). The Canadian group, led by Dr. Paul Hebert and funded through a Genome Canada Competition III project, are leaders in this field and have contributed many of the records in BOLD. This technology development project, the first application of the information contained in BOLD, will expand the current protocol from single sample analysis and develop new informatics tools to enable the analysis of mixed biotic samples, allowing â€˜environmental barcodingâ€™ and biodiversity monitoring of any environml sample.

Project_Title: Technologies for Methylome Studies
Project_Description: It is now believed that tissue-specific expression is achieved by the epigenetic regulation of genes via processes such as DNA methylation. This project is dedicated to development of new technologies for genome- wide DNA methylation, or methylome, analysis, and will combine two powerful technologies: targeted deposition of extended groups of biopolymers on DNA, and the application of microarrays. The new technology may significantly contribute to our understanding of development, tissue differentiation, aging, among numerous other important questions of the life sciences. Even more importantly, the genome wide DNA methylation studies may allow for the identification of unique and informative signatures of common human diseases, such as cancer, diabetes, schizophrenia, multiple sclerosis, among numerous others
Lead_Research_Institution: Centre for Addiction and Mental Health

Project_Title: High-Efficiency Low-Cost Solar Cells
Project_Description: The sun is an abundant source of clean energy, but in a global energy market of $9 trillion a year, solar accounts for less than $50 billion of it. Why? Because todayâ€™s technologies for harnessing the sunâ€™s energy are either efficient and costly or inexpensive and inefficient. University of Toronto researcher Dr. Edward Sargent aims to change that by creating the worldâ€™s first low-cost, high-efficiency solar cell. Heâ€™s using a technology known as â€quantum-size-effect tuningâ€ to tap into a broader spectrum of the sunâ€™s rays, the key to improving solar efficiency. His technology promises to help Ontario realize its clean energy goals, and position the provinceâ€™s alternative energy industry as a global leader in the production of cheap green en

Project_Title: High-efficiency spray-formed metal foam heat exchangers for high temperature energy conversion and recovery
Project_Description: Every form of energy conversion needs high efficiency heat exchangers to recover energy that escapes as exhaust. But because heat exchangers must withstand both high temperatures and corrosion, they are made out of refractory materials, which are difficult and expensive to form. University of Toronto scientist Dr. Javad Mostaghimi has developed a novel â€œnear-net-shapeâ€ forming technology for fabricating lightweight, low-cost, high efficiency heat exchangers. It is technology that could revolutionize heat recovery and help Ontario-based manufacturers capture a larger portion of a market that industry analysts predict will be close to $13 billion by 2
Keyword: climate change

Project_Title: Bark Bio-refinery: Green Adhesives and Bio-based Foams from Bark
Project_Description: Ontarioâ€™s forest industry is being challenged as never before by a strong Canadian dollar, a struggling U.S. economy and soaring materials and energy costs. University of Toronto researcher, Dr. Ning Yan has an intriguing solution to transform the sector into a global leader in the emerging bio-economy. Dr. Ning Yan and Dr. Mohini Sain are leading a multi-disciplinary team that is developing an innovative bark bio-refinery process. This process will turn bark biomass, a waste residue with unique compositional characteristics, into high value, eco-friendly adhesives and bio-products with large market potential. Their research also has significant implications for Ontarioâ€™s two largest sectors: automotive and chemic
Keyword: bio-economy, climate change, rural

Project_Title: Novel Xylanase/Microalgae Aggregate and the Photo-bioreactor System for its Cost Efficient Mass Production
Project_Description: Ontario farmers may soon see big savings when they buy animal feed, thanks to research underway at the University of Ottawa. Dr. Jason Zhang is developing a new photo-bioreactor system for the cost-competitive mass production of a new feed additive product, xylanase/microalgae aggregate. The additive will greatly improve the level of nutrients in feed, enabling farmers to decrease the amount they feed their animals. Dr. Zhangâ€™s research also has applications for other areas as well, including the food, renewable energy and environment industrie
Keyword: climate change, rural

Project_Title: Novel approaches to treating chronic neuropathic pain
Project_Description: Pain is a nearly universal human experience. More than 2.5 million Canadians experience debilitating pain that impacts their quality of life and costs the Canadian economy billions of dollars a year in lost productivity. Dr. Michael Salter aims to translate recent academic discoveries made at the Hospital for Sick Children into new treatments for chronic pain. Using novel molecular targets, Salter and his team are developing innovative classes of drugs to prevent and treat chronic pain, offering new hope for pain sufferers here and around the world. In the process, he will establish Ontario as a world leader in pain research and help build the foundation for a pain-relief industry in the province.

Project_Title: The George Brown College/Evergreen Brick Works Applied Research Green Innovation Lab Experience (ARGILE)
Project_Description: Cities are responsible for approximately 75 per cent of all the energy we use and the greenhouse gases we emit, with buildings accounting for nearly 40 per cent of that. To achieve urban sustainability, new technologies and building techniques must be developed to re-construct our cities. That is the goal of research being conducted by Dr. Christopher Timusk and a team of students at George Brown College. Using selected buildings at the historic Don Valley Brick Works site in the heart of downtown Toronto, the team is developing cost-effective, sustainable, durable and healthy renovation and retrofit techniques aimed at making old buildings more energy efficient. What they learn will help Ontario-based companies become world leaders in the construction of products and processes of the future â€“ and Ontario cities leaders in urban sustainabili
Lead_Research_Institution: George Brown College of Applied Arts and Technology
Keyword: climate change

Project_Title: Development of products to reduce burden of care at home
Project_Description: In the near future, more families will be able to provide homecare safely for their loved ones, thanks to research being conducted by Dr. Geoff Fernie at the Toronto Rehab Centre. Dr. Fernie and his team of research engineers, computer scientists, designers and clinicians are working with caregivers to identify what is needed to help with physically demanding tasks, such as lifting and toileting, and to ensure that the products they develop are practical, easy to install and affordable. With the number of seniors and disabled people growing here and in other developed countries worldwide, Dr. Fernieâ€™s research is timely and will provide a definite advantage to Ontarioâ€™s assistive devices indus

Project_Title: Ontario Consortium for Adaptive Interventions in Radiation Oncology (OCAIRO)
Project_Description: Radiation therapy is used to treat 50 per cent of all cancer patients. It is a proven cancer treatment that will soon be even more effective. At the University Health Network, Dr. David Jaffray is leading a team of researchers and industry partners from across the province and around the world who are developing â€œadaptive radiation therapyâ€. This new approach, which involves creating hardware, software, imaging and database systems, will enable oncologists to adapt radiation to each individual patient and their response during the course of therapy. The goals are more effective outcomes and a better quality of life during and after treatment. This research will also build on Ontarioâ€™s international reputation in the field of radiation th

Project_Title: Green technologies for nano-engineering of new butyl-rubber products
Project_Description: Butyl rubber, a high quality synthetic rubber, is most commonly used in tire inner liners and other sealant products because of its elasticity, and high impermeability to gases and liquids.  While Ontario has always been a leader in butyl rubberâ€™s research and production, Dr. Leo Lau of The University of Western Ontario is now pushing the frontier for its use by surface engineering new types of butyl rubber that can be used in the pharmaceutical and medical industries, with potential applications also in the food and electronics industries.  Moreover, he is using innovative processes that cut down the environment loads in manufacturing these new products.  Dr. Lauâ€™s research is of great interest to Ontarioâ€™s chemical industry and promises to help Ontario keep its leading edge in the growing polymer m

Project_Title: Advancing Nanotechnology: Development of Novel Scanning Probe Tools for Applications in Atomically Precise Fabrication, Characterization and Metrology
Project_Description: Nanotechnology has the potential to create many new products with a vast range of applications. But the science cannot advance without the tools to accurately see, control and fabricate new materials and devices at the nano-scale. Developing those tools is the goal of research being conducted by Dr. Raafat Mansour at the University of Waterloo. Dr. Mansour and his team are leveraging recent engineering developments in scanning probe microscopy techniques and micro-scale scanning probe instrument to create the next generation of nano devices. These devices will help Ontario industries ranging from automotive to biotech to information and communications technologies gain a competitive edge in a market that is expected to reach $2.5 trillion by 2015.

Project_Title: Retinal Oxygen Saturation, Blood Flow, Vascular Function and High Resolution Morphometric Imaging in the Living Human Eye
Project_Description: More than three million Canadians suffer from severe vision loss, a figure that will increase dramatically over the next decade as baby boomers age. Vision loss robs individuals of their quality of life and costs the economy an estimated $15.8 billion a year. While the majority of vision loss is preventable, better tools are needed to combat the pending epidemic. At the Universities of Waterloo and Toronto, Dr. Christopher Hudson and his team of researchers are developing retinal imaging instruments that will allow the early detection and improved management of the three most common causes of age-related vision loss: macular degeneration, glaucoma and diabetic retinopathy. His research will not only help reduce health care costs, it will position Ontario as a leader in ocular imaging R&D and lead to new opportunities for Ontarioâ€™s ophthalmic device secto

Project_Title: Next Generation Web Approaches and Tools
Project_Description: The World Wide Web has revolutionized the ways we connect with people: how we buy and sell, meet, work, govern and even create. Experts agree: the next generation of web technology promises to be even more powerful and transformative than the existing one. With our expertise in ICT, Ontario has an unprecedented opportunity to define, build and deploy the services that will form the foundation of the next generation of web-based applications â€“ and that is the focus of research being conducted by Dr. Donald Cowan at the University of Waterloo. His work aims to keep Ontario â€“ and Ontario ICT companies â€“ in the lead in a sector thatâ€™s changing
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project_Title: Multi-platform Digital Media Enabling Technologies
Project_Description: The entertainment industry is changing and quickly. Digital media producers are being challenged to manage the creative process efficiently from concept through to delivery, while using multiple technologies (e.g., live action, animation, 3D special effects) on multiple platforms (e.g., film, television, Xbox). Led by Dr. Tamer Ozsu, a team of researchers from the University of Waterloo and the Sheridan Institute of Technology and Advanced Learning are combining their expertise to develop new technologies to facilitate workflow. It is groundbreaking research that will enhance the bottom line for producers, while establishing Ontarioâ€™s reputation as a global leader in enabling technologies and the production of digital conten
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project_Title: Privacy and Security in Mobile Ad Hoc Communications and Embedded Systems
Project_Description: From cell phones to digital audio players to global positioning systems, mobile ad hoc communication and embedded systems are becoming an indispensable part of our daily lives. They have a wide range of applications, including emergency response, disaster relief, teleconferencing and automated toll-payment,  and practically limitless future applications. But their rapid development is raising serious privacy and security concerns that current technologies cannot solve. At the University of Waterloo Dr. Guang Gong and her team are focused on developing new security solutions for current and emerging ad hoc communication and embedded systems. It is research that will give Ontarioâ€™s ICT industry an important competitive edg
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project_Title: Centre for Innovation in Information Visualization and Data Driven Design (CIV/DDD)
Project_Description: Every day, humanity produces reams of data in every field â€” but as the data grow, the challenge becomes delivering the best analysis to solve real-world problems. Researchers at York Universityâ€™s newly-created Centre for Innovation in Information Visualization and Data Driven Design, led by Professor John Tsotsos, are collaborating with a team of researchers at the Ontario College of Art & Design to develop the next generation of data discovery, design and visualization techniques. Their work will make it possible to see underlying patterns, processes, and relationships within data sets in ways that are more intuitive to users while suggesting new research directions and training tomorrowâ€™s knowledge workers. In an increasingly competitive business environment, this research promises applications and insights to every ind
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project_Title: Improved Utilization of Co-products from Second Generation Biofuel Industries for the Production of New Industrial Bioproducts
Project_Description: With governments worldwide focused on reducing greenhouse gas emissions, there is growing interest in the role biofuels can play. But food-versus-fuel concerns are prompting greater focus on second-generation biofuels (ones made from non-food crops) and the co-products (lignin, hemicelluloses and crude glycerol) that are created during production. These co-products are currently undervalued and underused, something University of Guelph researcher Dr. Amar Mohanty aims to change. He has assembled a multidisciplinary team from four Ontario universities that is developing new technology to use co-products as well as  switchgrass and miscanthus to design value-added products for applications in the packaging, manufacturing and automotive sectors. This research will not only ensure the productive use of all components of biological feedstocks, it could well transform Ontario into a biofinery hub and open up new markets for Ontarioâ€™s agricultural and biofuel industries as well as pulp and paper industri
Keyword: bio-economy, rural

Project_Title: Phaseolus Genomics for Improved Bio-Product Development
Project_Description: The common bean is considered to be the nearly perfect food: it is high in protein, fibre and complex carbohydrates and it contains cancer-fighting antioxidants and vitamins. It also represents great potential for Ontarioâ€™s agri-food industry, which is what University of Guelph scientist Dr. Peter Pauls is focused on exploiting. By producing a draft genome sequence for bean and developing molecular markers, Dr. Pauls plans to accelerate the development of improved bean varieties, ones with enhanced disease resistance, healthful qualities and consumer appeal. He is also investigating nutraceutical and biofilm bio-product applications for beans. His goal? To increase Ontarioâ€™s share of the more than $11 billion a year global industry and open new mark
Keyword: bio-economy, rural

Project_Title: Quantifying sensorimotor function and dysfunction
Project_Description: The brain is the most complex â€“ and least understood â€“ organ of the human body. It supports all aspects of sensory, motor and cognitive function, but determining just how it performs these functions remains a major challenge for neuroscientists. This challenge fascinates Dr. Stephen Scott. The Queenâ€™s University researcher is using robotic, eye-tracking and virtual reality technologies to unravel how the brain functions, and how neurological disorders affect these processes. His work could lead to better neurological diagnoses and treatments, providing new hope for people who suffer from neurological and psychiatric disorders â€“ and could give Ontarioâ€™s life sciences sector a competitive advantage in the growing field of neurological di

Project_Title: User Interface Technologies for Non-Planar & Flexible Displays
Project_Description: If Queenâ€™s University researcher Dr. Roel Vertegaal is right, the computers of tomorrow wonâ€™t be anything like todayâ€™s computers. Not only will they be able to take on flexible forms â€“ for example, pop cans with browsers displaying movie trailers or digital paper e-book readers that can be folded up and tucked into a pocket â€“ they will respond to our direct touch and even change their shape to better accommodate data. Fundamental to the development of these next generation computers is the â€œorganic user interfaceâ€ and that is the focus of research being conducted by Dr. Vertegaal at the Queenâ€™s Human Media Laboratory. Dr. Vertegaalâ€™s work promises to revolutionize human-computer interaction â€“ and, the process, create an entire new computing
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project_Title: Ontario Network for Advanced Medical Imaging Detectors
Project_Description: Detecting and diagnosing medical problems accurately and at the earliest stage of disease is critical for effective treatment and recovery.  Imaging devices play a key role in achieving those goals. However, current medical imaging devices, originally based on technology developed for use in other fields, have been limited in their effectiveness.  At the Ontario Network for Advanced Medical Imaging Detectors, Dr. John Rowlands (Founding Scientific Director, Thunder Bay Regional Research Institute) is leading a team of innovative researchers who are working closely with industry to develop and commercialize a revolutionary, new generation of solid state detectors for a variety of biomedical applications. Their approach is to identify strategic technological solutions for specific biomedical applications and to develop imaging devices which are optimized for these applications. This will change the face of imaging devices and will provide higher quality images without increasing the cost and radiation dose

Project_Title: Green Intelligent Transportation Systems
Project_Description: University of Waterloo researcher Dr. Amir Khajepour believes the future of the auto industry will include intelligent, eco-friendly electric cars, and he is not alone in that belief. Industry analysts predict that by 2030 the majority of vehicles sold in North America will be electric [1]. But the shift from gasoline-powered to electric cars will affect everything from the design and manufacture of the vehicles themselves, to the supporting infrastructure they require - and that is what interests Dr. Khajepour. He is leading a multi-disciplinary team of researchers who are addressing the entire green transportation paradigm, from the vehicle and vehicle intelligence, through power generation and distribution, to the effects of electric vehicles on traffic flow and infrastructure. The team's research will help keep Ontario at the forefront in the highly competitive green auto industry now taking hold in North America.

Project_Title: Development of Massively Multi-parametric, Single Cell Proteomic Diagnostic Tools
Project_Description: Last fall, a Toronto research team, led by the University of Torontoâ€™s Dr. Scott Tanner, unveiled a first-in-class cell analysis instrument. Capable of determining up to 100 biomarkers in individual cells, the CyTOF Mass Cytometer will make it possible for doctors to diagnose disease and monitor treatment more effectively than they could before. Dr. Tannerâ€™s team, along with researchers from international centres that include Stanford University and the National Institutes of Health, is building on this made-in-Ontario technology to develop and commercialize diagnostic and therapeutic products that will set new standard-of-care benchmarks in hospitals and clinics around the wo
Keyword: Genome

Project_Title: BEEM: Bioproducts and Enzymes from Environmental Metagenomes
Project_Description: The pressure is on to transform our fossil fuel dependent economy into a bio-based one. Success will depend on our ability to find ways of turning plant-based materials into high-value products, while minimizing the release of carbon dioxide and other contaminants into the environment. At the University of Toronto a team of scientists led by chemical engineer Dr. Elizabeth Edwards is using gene sequencing to find ways of harnessing microbes, natureâ€™s recyclers, to transform, reuse, recycle and remediate by-products and contaminants from industrial and agricultural processes. In particular, they are concentrating on developing processes to prevent the harmful environmental impacts of biorefineries, which will be fundamental in the shift to a bioeconom
Keyword: bioeconomy, climate change, rural, Genome

Project_Title: Application of Genomics, Systems Biology, Chemistry and Physics to Neurodegenerative Disease
Project_Description: More than half a million Canadians suffer from neurodegenerative diseases, a number that will double in the next 15 years  as baby boomers age. These diseases are  massively debilitating and there is no cure for them. While researchers have established that a significant feature of the diseases is the accumulation of misfolded proteins in the brain, which activate signalling pathways that cause brain cells to die, attempts to identify these pathways have been inconclusive. Today that is changing. University of Toronto neuroscientist Dr. Peter St. George-Hyslop is leading a consortium of multidisciplinary investigators from Canada, the U.S., the U.K., Europe and Asia who are combining strategies to identify these pathways and develop innovative diagnostics and treatments.
Keyword: Genome

Project_Title: Protein Complexes in the Epigenetics of Human Disease and Stem Cell Fate
Project_Description: The development and maintenance of any organism is determined by a set of chemical reactions that switch parts of the genome on and off at strategic times and locations. The study of these reactions â€“ and the factors that influence them â€“ is called epigenetics and University of Toronto biochemist Dr. Jack Greenblatt is one of the worldâ€™s leading researchers in the field.  Recognized as a research all-star by Sciencewatch.com,  Dr. Greenblatt is focused on â€œcrackingâ€ the epigenetic code to better understand how genome disruptions can trigger diseases. What he discovers could lead to the development of new drugs that would manipulate epigenetic pathways to treat cancer, neurological disorders and other serious
Keyword: Genome

Project_Title: Cardiovascular Biomarker Discovery in Disease and Development through Predictive Precision Proteomics (CBD3P3)
Project_Description: Cardiovascular disease is the leading cause of disability and death in Canada.  While dramatic improvements have been made in treating the acute stages of the disease, treatments for chronic heart disease have been less successful, primarily because it is usually diagnosed too late when symptoms occur. Led by Drs. Peter Liu and Gordon Keller, a team of internationally recognized investigators from the University Health Network, the Hospital for Sick Children, and the University of Toronto, is combining their expertise in proteomics and genomics, stem cell biology, tissue engineering and adult and pediatric cardiovascular medicine to address this challenge.  The goal is to develop new screening and diagnostic tools to identify patients in the early stages of heart disease, and determine the most effective treatment for them â€“ work that could revolutionize the way cardiovascular disease is treated in futur
Keyword: Genome

Project_Title: Autism Spectrum and Associated Neurodevelopmental Disorders: Genomes to Outcomes
Project_Description: Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) is a lifelong neurodevelopmental condition. People with ASD have difficulties with communication and social interaction, and exhibit unusual patterns of behaviour, activities and interests. The burden of ASD on Ontarioâ€™s population and health care system is significantâ€“ and the number of new diagnoses is rising. All of this makes finding better diagnoses and treatments a research priority. The Hospital for Sick Childrenâ€™s Dr. Stephen Scherer and McMaster Universityâ€™s Dr. Peter Szatmari are leading a team of researchers from across Ontario who are working to identify the genes that make some people susceptible to autism. Their work promises to develop diagnostics and treatments assisting thousands of families in Ontario and wo
Keyword: Genome

Project_Title: International Barcode of Life project
Project_Description: When most of us think of barcodes, we think of those little black marks on packaging that are scanned at the checkout. Not Paul Hebert. He thinks of DNA barcodes. In fact, the University of Guelph biologist is well known in the scientific community for his discovery of DNA barcoding, which uses a specific section of genetic code to differentiate and identify species. His goal is to barcode every species on the planet, and he is leading an international research alliance involving investigators in 25 nations to do just that. He and his team at the Biodiversity Institute of Ontario are gathering barcode records, building the informatics platform needed to store the information and to use it to identify species. His research has a wide range of practical applications, from food safety to ecosystem bio-surveillance and will, before long, lead to the development of a hand-held barcoder that will allow anyone to identify any organism anywhere.
Keyword: Genome

Project_Title: Functional genomics of solid tumors for discovery and development of new biologics and biomarkers
Project_Description: This year, 65,000 Ontarians will learn they have cancer and 28,000 more will die from the disease, with cancers of the lung, colon, pancreas and ovary responsible for more than half these deaths.  Chemotherapy and radiation are still the most commonly used treatments for these cancers, but with mortality rates remaining high, safer and more effective treatments are needed. Drs. Bradly Wouters and Benjamin Neel at the Ontario Cancer Institute are leading a collaborative team of scientists from the University Health Network and the University of Toronto. This team is linking newly developed patient derived tumour models with state-of-the-art genetic screens, next-generation genome sequencing, and high-throughput synthetic antibody development to accelerate the discovery, development, and validation of novel cancer therapies and biomarkers. Their work promises to position Ontario as a leader in the field â€“ and capture a portion of the $50-billion-plus worldwide cancer treatment marke
Keyword: Genome

Project_Title: Molecular and Genomic Diagnostics to Improve Outcomes in Lung Transplantation
Project_Description:
The Toronto General Hospital has an impressive record when it comes to lung transplants: it was the first centre to successfully perform a single and double lung transplant, and they have also used artificial lungs to prolong life as a bridge to transplant. This team is also the first to repair donor lungs outside the body using anti-inflammatory therapies and gene therapy. Despite these successes, there is much to be done - five year survival after lung transplantation is only 50 per cent â€“ primarily because of donor lung injury or recipient rejection.
Dr. Shaf Keshavjee is leading a team of scientist-clinicians who are working to develop diagnostic tools to predict post-transplant lung function and rejection after transplantation. 
There are currently no diagnostic or prognostic products available that can quantitatively assess the suitability of donor organs for transplantation. The current research initiative will develop novel and accurate diagnostic strategies for donor lung injury and for the predictn and diagnosis of recipient rejection. .
The ultimate goal is to successfully develop the diagnostic strategies and to translate them to the clinicâ€”if effective, these approaches would lead to significantly higher donor lung utilization rates, reductions in post-transplant complications, and subsequently better quality-of-life outcomes for transplant patients. These tools will improve success rates and help assure Ontarioâ€™s continued global leadership in the field of lung transplantat
Keyword: Genome

Project_Title: Functional Oncogenomics for the Discovery of Cancer Drivers and Unique Subclasses (FOCUS)
Project_Description:
Canadaâ€™s awareness of the importance of funding cancer research was brought to the
forefront by Terry Fox, himself a victim of osteosarcoma. However today, many
teenagers here and around the world are living with â€“ and dying from â€“ this serious
form of bone cancer. The 5 year survival rate for osteosarcoma has remained
unchanged at 60-80% in the last 20 years, while for patients who present with
disseminated disease the overall survival rate is only 11%. Dr. Rama Khokha would like
to change these statistics. The University Health Network researcher has already
determined that mice can be made completely resistant, or more susceptible, to bone
cancer by targeting specific genes. Now, Dr. Khokha has assembled a team of
investigators with expertise in cancer genomics, oncology, and comparative pathology
who are working to understand how these genes affect the development of
osteosarcoma in multiple species. Their goal is to open up new frontiers for research
and treatment of this devastating c
Keyword: Genome

Project_Title: The Genetic Interaction Atlas (GIA): charting the eukaryotic cell
Project_Description: While human genome sequencing projects have revealed the massive catalogue of genes, biomedical researchers are now faced with a formidable challenge: how to assign functions to the thousands of uncharacterized genes, and how to use this information to understand how genes interact to determine cell function in health and disease. That is the goal of research being conducted by Dr. Charles Boone at the University of Toronto. His Genetic Interaction Atlas (GIA)  will use robotics, software, and molecular biology to discover the function of each gene, and determine how genes act in concert to specify the cellular programs that control development, differentiation, and even aging or disease. The ultimate goal of his research? The development of gene-based cancer therapies.
Keyword: Genome

Project_Title: Understanding the assembly and function of dynamic signalling networks in complex diseases
Project_Description: Communication is key to success in every aspect of human life, from our personal lives to our work relationships. The same is true for communication at the cellular level.  When communication is good, cells work well and keep us healthy. But bad cellular communication weakens our immunity and causes serious diseases, including cancer. How cells grow and communicate with each other â€“ and how and why communication goes awry â€“ has fascinated Dr. Tony Pawson for more than 25 years. Today, the Mount Sinai Hospital cell biologist is a world leader in cell signal transduction, the way in which cells control one anotherâ€™s behaviour through chemical signals. He is advancing our knowledge in this area, which could lead us to more effective cancer
Keyword: Genome

Project_Title: Molecular pathways of reprogramming - from discovery to novel therapeutics
Project_Description: On March 1, 2009, Dr. Andras Nagy made headlines with a research breakthrough: a new way to create stem cells from other cells of the body.  The technique involves  reprogramming adult cells back to their embryonic state, and the breakthrough earned Dr. Nagy the distinction of being selected for the first annual Scientific American Top 10 Honor Roll â€“ the only Canadian to be honoured.  Now the renowned geneticist is heading a team of stem cell experts from Ontario, the U.S., Japan and Europe who are using reprogrammable mouse cells from Dr. Nagyâ€™s lab at the Samuel Lunenfeld Research Institute  (SLRI) to develop a molecular profile of the process of reprogramming. This research will bring us a closer to having stemcell-based therapies for such diseases and conditions as spinal cord injury, stroke, macular degeneration, diabetes and Parkinsonâ€™s di
Keyword: Genome

Project_Title: Cancer Gene Encyclopaedia (CGEP): Computationally optimized characterization of cancer genes, proteins, their structure, function and interactions
Project_Description: Toronto Drs. Igor Jurisica and Gary Bader are leading an international research team from 20 institutions in eight countries that is compiling a unique encyclopedia. Unlike the encyclopedias most of us are familiar with, this one will provide an integrated database for systematic characterization of cancer protein, their interactions and pathways. Called the Cancer Gene Encyclopedia, it will be a world first. By making it possible for scientists to identify new cancer â€œtargetsâ€, it will transform cancer research and, ultimately cancer care, improving the outcome for patients with lung, prostate, breast, ovary and head and neck cancers, cancers with some of the highest mortality r
Keyword: Genome

Project_Title: Pest genomics and plant breeding in a sustainable agricultural pest management
Project_Description:
Spider mites are a major agricultural pest affecting greenhouse crops (tomatoes, aubergine, pepper, cucumbers, courgettes, roses, chrysanthemum, carnations), annual field crops such as maize, soybean and sugar beet, and perennial crops like alfalfa, strawberries, grapes, apples and pears in Ontario and worldwide. 
The spider mite damage of Ontarioâ€™s agricultural crops is rising every year, because mites have developed a resistance to pesticides. Dr. Miodrag Grbic is tackling the challenge of controlling these mites. The University of Western Ontario biologist heads an international consortium of scientists with expertise in genomics, bioinformatics, genetics, biochemistry, population biology, plant breeding, pest control and sustainable agriculture. Using new â€œhigh throughput â€œ genomic resources, the PEST-GAP consortium aims to develop environmentally sound pest control strategies, including crop breeding for mite resistance. This research will lead to more sustainable crop production, help preserve oural environment and increase Ontarioâ€™s competitiveness in innovative technologies
Keyword: water, wastewater, rural, Genome

Project_Title: Ontario Consortium for Regeneration Inducing Therapeutics (OCRiT)
Project_Description: Regenerative medicine is an emerging field that focuses on repairing and replacing damaged tissues and organs using the power of human stem cells which have the ability to change into all other cell types that make up the body. This field is already enabling the repair of bone, cartilage, and heart defects and has the potential to treat incurable, debilitating diseases and injury such as spinal cord damage, Parkinsonâ€™s disease, and leukemia. At McMaster University, Dr. Mick Bhatia has already made several important advancements in human stem cell research and its applications and he is committed to making Ontario a leader in human stem cell-based drug discovery. Dr. Bhatiaâ€™s focus is on identifying chemical means to activate the regenerative process of stem cells and develop new medicines able to repair the damage done by cancer and other tissue/organ related disea
Keyword: Genome

Project_Title: NorCOMM2: Functional genomics tools to drive stem cell & regenerative medicine research in Ontario
Project_Description: Most human disease involves genes. So one of the greatest challenges that lie ahead for medicine is to identify what every human gene does to determine what diseases arise when each of these genes goes wrong. This new knowledge can be applied to discover cures or treatments, particularly in the areas of stem cell and regenerative medicine. This is a challenge that Dr. Colin McKerlie takes seriously. He is a phenogenomics expert whose dream is to help develop gene and cell-based therapies to prevent and cure disease and he is using mice â€“ or mice models more precisely â€“ to do it. Having already created mice with genes that can be disabled or eliminated by genetic manipulation â€“ â€œknockout miceâ€ â€“ Dr. McKerlie is focused on developing new research tools that put mice genomes to work to teach us how to instruct cell development in the lab for use in serious illnesses of childhood and chronic diseases such as diabetes, obesity, heart disease, cancer, and psychiatric conditions. He and his team hope to ser to the era of personalized medicine.
Keyword: Genome

Project_Title: Cardiovascular Repair using Enhanced Stem-Cell Therapy (CREST)
Project_Description: Over the past 40 years, there has been remarkable progress in the treatment of cardiac and vascular diseases. But many patients still suffer from irreversible damage and are forced to live with the consequences.  The goal of the CREST program is to give these patients with cardiac and vascular disease a new lease on life. Dr Stewart, the CEO and Scientific Director of the Ottawa Hospital Research Institute, is working with the University of Ottawa Heart Institute as well as several groups in Toronto, to develop innovative technologies to enhance the regenerative potential of adult cell therapy strategies, and apply these approaches to important clinical problems such as the prevention and reversal heart, kidney and lung damage. He is leading a team of researchers with expertise in stem cell biology, biomaterials and innovative cell imaging technologies who are developing the next generation of stem cell-based therapies for cardiovascular repair and regeneration. This research offers new hope to the more than 70 million North Americans living with heart disease.
Keyword: Genome

Project_Title: Assessment of Risk for Colon Tumors in Canada (ARCTIC)
Project_Description: While colorectal cancer is the second leading cause of cancer death in Canada, it is highly preventable. If caught early it has a 90 per cent chance of being cured â€“ which is why the Ontario government launched Canada's first province-wide screening program in 2007.  But screening programs are expensive, costing the province close to $200 million a year, and they are unpopular with patients. For these reasons, Ottawa Hospital Research Instituteâ€™s Dr. Brent Zanke is working to develop a simple clinical test that will determine who is at greatest risk. The test will combine an individualâ€™s genetic predisposition to colorectal cancer with environmental risk factors like age, history of smoking and body mass index to come up with the personâ€™s lifetime risk of developing the disease. By enabling doctors to focus on those with the greatest risk, the test will save time, money an
Keyword: Genome

Project_Title: Integrated low-cost, real-time monitoring of Ontario recreational and municipal water sources
Project_Description: At McMaster University, Dr. Herb Schellhorn and colleagues are developing and commercializing inexpensive, next generation sensing systems to monitor water quality. These systems, which will be able to detect virtually any known contaminant, will test water quality on-site and use wireless networks to alert public officials of any problems. With water quality a worldwide issue, the economic potential for these new systems is enormous.
Keyword: sensing systems, bioinformatic markers, micro-/nano-technology, information fusion, real-time monitoring, water contamination, water quality,  remediation

Project_Title: Innovative Combined Treatment Technologies for Remediating Contaminated Groundwater
Project_Description: Contaminated industrial and commercial sites here and abroad represent a serious threat to the environment. Redevelopment of these sites can produce significant environmental and economic benefits. However, redeveloping these sites is a challenge because current cleanup techniques are expensive and time consuming. At the University of Toronto, Dr. Brent Sleep and his team are developing innovative water treatment technologies to restore these properties, research that will help to put Ontario companies at the leading edge of the fast growing site redevelopment market.
Keyword: water treatment technologies, groundwater, hazardous chemicals, brownfield, urban sustainability

Project_Title: Biofiltration as a Pre-treatment to Reduce Membrane Fouling
Project_Description: Membrane technology â€“ where water is passed through a polymer or ceramic membrane to separate it from contaminants â€“ is a recently emerged water treatment option that is considered one of the best water treatment options available today. The University of Waterlooâ€™s Dr. Peter Huck is focussed on making this technology more effective and less costly by developing a â€˜greenâ€™ biological filtration pretreatment for membranes. This will help Ontario membrane manufacturers secure a larger portion of this growi
Keyword: biofiltration, fouling, membranes, drinking water treatment, desalination

Project_Title: Advanced Water Analytics for Emerging Critical Needs in the Water Monitoring Industry
Project_Description: The primary focus of Professor Pawliszyn's research program is the design of highly automated and integrated instrumentation for the isolation of analytes from complex matrices and the subsequent separation, identification and determination of these species.  Currently his research is focusing on elimination of organic solvents from the sample preparation step to facilitate on-site monitoring and in-vivo analysis.  Professor Pawliszyn is also exploring application of computational and modeling techniques to enhance performance of sample preparation, chromatographic separations and detection.  An additional area of his interest involves the development and application of imaging detection combined with microseparation approaches.
Keyword: water analysis, sample processing

Project_Title: Genomic Medicine: Translating disease gene discovery to clinical care
Project_Description: This project aims to develop and deliver genetic characterization of two debilitating autoimmune diseases and broadly-applicable computational tools to accelerate disease gene discovery and the integration of genetic/genomic knowledge into healthcare.
Keyword: genetic characterization, autoimmune diseases, computational tools, gene discovery, genomic, healthcare

Project_Title: Synthetic antibody program: novel therapeutics and reagents
Project_Description: This program will develop state-of-the-art synthetic antibodies that will target proteins involved in the progression of cancer.  These antibodies will be used as tools to understand the molecular basis of cancer and will also be developed into clinical candidates as potential cancer therapeutics.
Keyword: synthetic antibodies, proteins, cancer, clinical, cancer therapeutics.
