It will promote holistic research on integration, quality assurance algorithms, and novel materials to effectively commercialize AM in tooling, energy and health sectors.
Keyword: Additive Manufacturing, 3D Printing, Industry 4.0, Laser Powder-Bed and Powder-Fed Additive Manufacturing Technologies

Project_Title: Eco-friendly nano PV energy system
Project_Description: A micro photovoltaic energy system with storage capability and load management will be innovated, achieving smart grid compatibility, energy availability at peak demand, significant energy efficiency improvements, cost savings in green energy generation and transmission, and economic, social and environmental benefits to Ontario.
Keyword: Solar energy, photovoltaic energy, green energy, energy efficiency, energy conversion, point-of-use energy generation and storage, residential PV systems

Project_Title: Pharmacogenomics Technologies and Patient-Centred Approaches for Enhancing Drug Safety and Effectiveness
Project_Description: We aim to demonstrate that an innovative Personalized Medicine-based healthcare model, developed by our team, can be implemented hospital-wide and that the resultant integrated model is adoptable, cost-effective, and scalable for Ontario and beyond.
Keyword: Pharmacogenomics, Personalized Medicine, Adverse Drug Reactions

Project_Title: New Technologies for Hearing Assessment and Treatment
Project_Description: Today's hearing tests were developed in the 1940's, when we knew much less about hearing than we do today. These test are not sensitive to certain kinds of hearing disorders. This project will develop better hearing tests, and apply these to better hearing aid fittings to help Ontarians get the most from their hearing.
Keyword: Hearing, hearing assessment, hearing loss, hearing aids, integrated knowledge translation, medical device development.

Project_Title: Improving the safety, efficacy and economics of future stem cell therapies
Project_Description: Human pluripotent cell lines with special focus on diabetes and its associated morbidities for: 1) cost effective cell manufacturing for disease modelling, drug screening and toxicology testing, 2) eliminated risk of malignancies post transplantation, and 3) universal cells for any patients.
Keyword: Pluripotent stem cells, diabetes, drug screen, differentiation

Project_Title: Precision Cancer Biology: a discovery engine for Precision Medicine
Project_Description: This proposal seeks to build a new platform to discover tailor-made cancer therapies based on the genetic makeup of individuals. At its core, we will use the revolutionary technology of CRISPR/Cas9 to search for the Achilles' heel of cancer cells. The research will help Ontario expand its biotechnology sector, train and retain highly qualified personnel, and ultimately improve patient care.
Keyword: Cancer, Genomics, Proteomics, Structural Biology, Drug Development

Project_Title: Analysis tools, measurement techniques and systems for mitigating severe accidents in CANDU nuclear power plants
Project_Description: In this proposal, robust and real-time monitoring tools and systems will be developed to overcome obstacles in implementing effective severe accident management programs in nuclear power plants. Innovative solutions from this project will enhance the nuclear industry's capability in dealing with severe accidents, while boosting the revenue and creating jobs for the equipment suppliers in Ontario.

Project_Description: This program will develop commercially viable millimeter wave intelligent radios technologies, key enablers to novel complementary terrestrial radiocommunication and satellite communication infrastructure critical to the shift into a truly digital society and to successful deployment of disruptive applications such as autonomous vehicles.

Keyword: Digital pathology; diagnosis; image analysis; image search; image classification; machine learning; deep learning; image captioning; virtual peer review; consensus

Project_Title: Development of disruptive anaerobic technologies for waste diversion and resource recovery
Project_Description: We aim to develop cost-effective, biological/thermal hydrolysis-enhanced, microbial electrochemical cell-enhanced anaerobic digestion technologies to recover resources from sewage sludge and food waste, creating a waste-to-energy technology for Ontario.

Project_Description: This project aims to develop and commercialize innovative plastic packaging from recycled, renewable and industrial waste-stream feedstock to reduce landfilling, pollution and GHG emissions.  Sustainable packaging is essential to a Circular Economy and will disruptively impact Ontario's economic, environmental and employment outcomes.

Project_Description: Physical activity is fundamental to human well-being, but exertional intolerance is very common in the aging population especially with heart disease. Project_Description: The present proposal uses robotic, eye-tracking and other advanced technologies and the expertise of several Ontario-based companies to unravel how the brain participates in sensory, motor and cognitive functions and how neurological disorders impact these processes. Project_Title: Childhood Asthma and the Microbiomeâˆ’Precision Health for Life: The Canadian Healthy Infant Longitudinal Development (CHILD) Stu

Asthma is the most prevalent pediatric chronic disease affecting 1 in 4 children in Ontario, with nearly 1 in 3 Ontarians developing asthma in their lifetime. Our research project will address two major challenges in pediatric asthma; the lack of accurate prediction tools to identify at-risk infants and lack of effective prevention.

Project_Title: Deciphering the genome biology of relapsed lymphoid cancers to improve patient management
Project_Description: Unfortunately, 60% of patients suffering from lymphoid cancers experience recurrence after initial treatment. Our project aims to implement novel biomarker assays for such patients, enabling informed treatment decisions, improving patient outcomes and reducing cost in the health care system.
Round: Large Scale Applied Research Project - Round 002

Project_Title: Care4Rare Canada: Harnessing multi-omics to deliver innovative diagnostic care for rare genetic diseases in Canada (C4R-SOLVE)
Project_Description: C4R-SOLVE is a national initiative that will identify the genetic cause of unsolved rare disease and improve access to clinical genome-wide sequencing for diagnosis. This will impact care for >100,000 Ontarians living with rare disease and may save the Ontario health system $10M per year.
Round: Large Scale Applied Research Project - Round 002

The tools will ensure that only patients benefiting receive costly drugs and have strong societal and economic impact on patients, their families and the Ontario health care syste

Project_Title: Microbiome-Based Precision Medicine in Inflammatory Bowel Disease
Project_Description: Ontario has one of the highest rates of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) in the world. This proposal will dramatically improve IBD management by empowering physicians to use the right drug at the right time for the right patient, resulting in improved quality of life and significant cost savings.
Round: Large Scale Applied Research Project - Round 002

Project_Title: UCAN CURE: Precision Decisions for Childhood Arthritis
Project_Description: A rapid detection, low-cost blood test to predict: 1) which child with arthritis needs advanced drugs, 2) which drugs work best and 3) when the drugs can be safely stopped, thus defining the best and most cost-effective way to treat childhood arthritis, limit adverse events and reduce the economic burden.
Round: Large Scale Applied Research Project - Round 002

Project_Title: Tackling Childhood Brain Cancer at the root to improve survival and quality of life
Project_Description: Our goal is to improve survival and quality of life for children and young adults with brain tumours. Our research will enable health care providers to increase treatment success, while decreasing the burden of survivorship on patients, their families and the Ontario health care system.

Project_Title: PEGASUS-2 - PErsonalized Genomics for prenatal Abnormalities Screening USing maternal blood : Towards First Tier Screening and Beyond

Project_Title: Personalized Risk Assessment for Prevention and Early Detection of Breast Cancer: Integration and Implementation
Project_Description: The goal is to provide evidence to support transition to cost-effective risk-based prevention and early detection of breast cancer within the Ontario health care system. Women will face less invasive cancer treatment with fewer complications and improved quality of life and survival, thereby reducing both the economic and clinical burden.

Project_Title: CReSCENT: CanceR Single Cell ExpressioN Toolkit
Project_Description: We will develop software resources and assemble data so that the international scientific community will have broad and timely access to a variety of single-cell data as well as standardized tools. This project will develop a web-based portal to visualize and analyze large and complex genomics datasets and thereby identify targets for novel biotechnologies.

SYNERGx will be designed for mining large in vitro screenings of drug combinations to optimize experimental screens of new cancer models.

Project_Description: The proposed project aims to develop software for more sensitive protein measurement with a new mass spectrometry method. The software will facilitate the discovery of new biomarkers currently below the detection limits of existing methods, and ultimately lead to early disease detection and diagnosis.

OIA_AREA: Research and study of the functioning of the human body

Project_Title: BridGE-SGA: A Novel Computational Platform to Discover Genetic Interactions Underlying Human Disease
Project_Description: Human genetics is on the verge of being revolutionized.  We will develop new and innovative human genome analysis tools to explore how genes interact to produce normal or diseased states in human cells, essential information for advancing personalized medicine.
OIA_AREA: Research and study of the functioning of the human body
Keyword: Human genetics, human genome, gene interactation, personalized medicine

Project_Title: Computational Tools for Data-Independent Acquisition (DIA) for Quantitative Proteomics and Metabolomics
Project_Description: Quantification of proteins and small molecules is critical to understanding cellular behaviour.  Our Ontario-led international team will develop a software workflow for accurate, reproducible, and large-scale analysis of these molecules by mass spectrometry for both discovery and clinical samples.
OIA_AREA: Chemical and biological experimentation for the future
Keyword: proteins, small molecules, cellular behaviour

Project_Title: NanoString nCounter Vantage 3D Platform-based Complementary Diagnostic Tests for Precision Medicine in Pediatric Cancers
Project_Description: Childhood cancer researchers at the Hospital for Sick Children are partnering with cutting-edge technology company, NanoString, to develop novel complementary diagnostics. Ensuring that Ontario will remain at the forefront of precision medicine and creating a skilled work force in clinical diagnostics.
Keyword: precision medicine, clinical diagnostics

Project_Title: Developing Prophylactic Virus-Vectored Vaccines for COVID-19
Project_Description: This research aims to develop a vaccination strategy for COVID-19. By developing avian avulavirus (AAvV-1) and adenovirus viral-vectored vaccines expressing the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein as a target antigen, researchers will test these vaccines in mice to identify a way to induce robust protective mucosal (respiratory, gastrointestinal and urogenital tract) and systemic immunity. Mucosal immunity plays a significant role in preventing pathogens from getting into the body. Systemic immunity clears any pathogens that bypass mucosal barriers. After optimization, these vaccines will be evaluated in a hamster challenge model at the National Microbiology Laboratory in Winnipeg.
OIA_AREA: Research and study of the functioning of the human body
Keyword: immunology, virology, vaccines, infectious disease, public health

Project_Title: Control of COVID-19 outbreaks in long term care: A randomized controlled trial of chemoprophylaxis to control outbreaks of COVID19 in long-term care facilities (CONTROL-COVID).
Project_Description: The frail elderly are disproportionately affected by COVID-19. Interventions are urgently needed to prevent and control outbreaks at long-term care homes. This research will use clinical trials to test the efficacy of different chemoprophylaxis regimens to protect elderly residents of long-term care homes from COVID-19.
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development
Keyword: Nursing Homes, Elderly, Vulnerable Populations, Prophylaxis, Outbreak Management, Infection Prevention and Control, Clinical Trial, Clinical Epidemiology, COVID-19

Project_Title: The RAPID COVID study â€“ Application of Point-of-Care COVID-19 Testing to Optimize Patient Care, Resource Allocation and Safety for Frontline Staff
Project_Description:
This study will determine the role of point-of-care testing (POC) as a tool to improve care of COVID-19 patients and conserve resources. A major obstacle facing hospitals during the COVID-19 outbreak is the inability to quickly diagnose who is infected with the virus. Delayed test results could mean that patients, who ultimately test negative, are treated for days utilising resources that could be better deployed elsewhere. An immediate diagnosis of COVID-19 among carriers could provide more expedient treatment, prevent clinical deterioration and help health care workers avoid unnecessary risk of exposure. 

 In collaboration with Spartan Biosciences, which has developed a novel point-of-care 45- 
 minute bedside COVID-19 test, and a team of specialists from six centres in Ontario, this research will evaluate the efficacy of POC testing to determine when, how and to who it can be applied.
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development
Keyword: Point-of-care COVID testing, Hospital Triage, Resource conservation, Cardiac procedure wait list, Surgery wait list

Project_Title: Assay development for SARS-CoV-2 sero-surveillance
Project_Description: This study will provide a better understanding of the immune response to severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), the virus that causes COVID-19. This approach aims to measure the level and/or types of antibodies induced by SARS-CoV-2 infection in the blood of acute and convalescent patients. In addition, measuring these antibodies in the saliva of asymptomatic infected subjects identified through contact tracing will provide insights into what the early immune response to the virus looks like, and how this may correlate with clinical outcome. This knowledge, as well as the development of a robust serosurveillance platform, represents a powerful weapon in our fight against COVID-19.
OIA_AREA: Research and study of the functioning of the human body
Keyword: COVID-19, Sero-surveillance, Immunology, saliva, IgG, IgA

Project_Title: Rapid Identification of immunogenic and T cell epitopes to enable serologic testing, passive immunotherapy, and epitope vaccine for COVID-19
Project_Description: To curb the COVID-19 outbreak caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus, researchers are looking to solve three critical challenges as quickly as possible - detection, treatment, and vaccination. This project will address these challenges by developing a point-of-care blood test to identify infected individuals, including those without symptoms, devising strategies for the production of virus-neutralizing antibodies to treat the severely ill, and identifying viral epitopes to inform epitope-vaccine development.
OIA_AREA: Chemical and biological experimentation for the future
Keyword: COVID-19, SARS-Cov-2, neutralizing antibody, immunogenic epitope, serologic test, passive immunization, T cell epitope, peptide array, mass spectrometry, vaccine

Project_Title: Use of Inhaled Anesthetic-Based Sedation in Ventilated COVID-19 patients: novel approach to shorten duration of ventilation, preserve intravenous sedation stocks, and improve survival.
Project_Description: Through a randomized clinical trial, this project aims to better understand the efficacy of inhaled anesthetic-based sedation to treat COVID-19 patients who require ventilation. This research could reduce the duration of mechanical ventilation, alleviating the stress on ventilator capacity; spare the use of intravenous sedation agents that are in short supply; and reduce mortality from COVID-19. If found effective, inhaled anesthetics can be quickly deployed in the fight against COVID-19 since they are safe, inexpensive and readily available.
OIA_AREA: Research and study of the functioning of the human body
Keyword: COVID-19, Intensive Care Unit, Mechanical Ventilation, Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome, Sedation, Inhaled Anesthetics

Project_Title: Clinical Research on the Therapeutic Benefits of Annexin A5 in Severe COVID-19 Patients
Project_Description:
There are currently no proven therapies to treat COVID-19. In the most severe cases, the disease is complicated by sepsis acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), and multiorgan failure. Sepsis is a life-threatening condition caused by the body's response to an infection. While the body normally releases chemicals to fight an infection, sepsis occurs when the body's response to these chemicals is out of balance, triggering systemic inflammation that can damage multiple organs. Many critically ill COVID-19 patients develop sepsis 1-2 days before ARDS, suggesting that sepsis is a major contributor to the development of organ and respiratory failure. 

 This clinical trial will examine the effects of Annexin A5, in treating critically ill COVID-19 patients who develop sepsis. Annexin A5 is a human protein that has potent anti-inflammatory, anti-apoptotic (cell death prevention) and moderate anticoagulant (blood clot prevention) properties. The ultimate goal of the trial is to use Annexin A5 to treat sepsis and prevent respiratory and multi-organ failure.
OIA_AREA: Research and study of the functioning of the human body
Keyword: COVID-19, sepsis, annexin-A5, inflammation, multi-organ dysfunction

Project_Title: A Randomized Open-Label Trial of CONvalescent Plasma for Hospitalized Adults With Acute COVID-19 Respiratory Illness (CONCOR-1)
Project_Description:
CONCOR-1 is a clinical trial that will collect blood plasma from individuals who have recovered from COVID-19, known as COVID-19 convalescent plasma. Convalescent plasma contains COVID-19 antibodies, proteins that help fight the virus. Convalescent plasma will be injected into patients currently fighting the infection, to test whether this is an effective treatment for the virus. This clinical trial will enrol patients 16 years of age and older admitted to hospital with COVID-19 and who require supplemental oxygen for respiratory illness. 

 Partners include 60 hospitals across Canada and three hospitals in New York City, the Canadian Blood Services and HÃ©ma-QuÃ©bec and the New York Blood Center
OIA_AREA: Research and study of the functioning of the human body
Keyword: Convalescent Plasma, Blood Transfusion, Passive Antibodies, COVID-19, Novel Therapeutic, Critical Care

Project_Title: Multivalent antibody scaffold to deliver an exceptionally potent and broad antiviral against SARS-CoV-2
Project_Description: This project has the potential to develop a unique antibody-based molecule for protection and treatment against COVID-19. Molecular technology will allow these researchers to decipher the vulnerabilities of the virus with the goal of developing a potent and broad antiviral that neutralizes SARS-CoV-2 and prevents associated COVID-19 symptoms.
OIA_AREA: Research and study of the functioning of the human body
Keyword: Antibody therapeutic, SARS-CoV-2 neutralization, broad specificity, high potency, protein engineering, in vivo efficacy

Project_Title: Cellular Immuno-Therapy for COVID-19 induced Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome: the CIRCA-19 Trial
Project_Description:
Through a series of trials, this research will rapidly evaluate the safety and efficacy of using mesenchymal stromal/stem cells, or MSCs, to help treat patients with COVID-19 related acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). Up to 25 percent of all patients admitted to hospital require admission to an intensive care unit, and as many as 40 percent develop severe difficulty breathing due to ARDS. 

 In total, 27 patients will undergo three sequential trials. The first trial, called the Vanguard study, is designed to quickly determine the optimal dosing strategy of MSCs derived from bone marrow to treat patients experiencing ARDS. The next two trials will use the optimal dose of cells determined by the Vanguard trial, but will administer MSCs derived from the umbilical cord, which is an abundant and readily available source.
Keyword: COVID-19, Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome, Mesenchymal Stromal Cells.

Project_Title: Food Retail Environment Surveillance for Health and Economic Resiliency: FRESHER Ontario
Project_Description: The Food Retail Environment Surveillance for Health & Economic Resiliency (FRESHER) project is a rapid response to the widespread closures of, and modified operating conditions for, many retail food outlets. The FRESHER project will examine the economic and social impacts of COVID-19 in Southwestern Ontario by identifying what businesses modified their operations, temporarily closed or permanently closed during the outbreak and how the outbreak has affected businesses and their employees. This study will help inform policies and programs that will maintain Ontario's food security, incentivize economic growth during the recovery period, and improve resiliency among businesses during future pandemics and emergencies.
Keyword: Food environments; Urban planning; Local economic development; Health geography; Geographic information science; Labour market analysis; Policy

Project_Title: Co-creating innovative strategies to address the wellbeing of older persons and their healthcare providers during the COVID-19 pandemic
Project_Description: Most deaths from COVID-19 have been among the elderly population in Ontario. This study will examine how the care of older persons has changed during the pandemic and how these changes are affecting the mental health and well-being of healthcare providers. It will also identify innovative strategies providers have developed to overcome these changes. Findings will provide informationto improve the care for older persons during the crisis while protecting the health and well-being of frontline workers caring for older persons.
Keyword: gerontology, nursing, public health, health science, social science, sociology, psychology

Project_Title: Canada's COVID-19 Pandemic Response and Impact in Low Income and Homeless or At Risk for Homelessness Populations in Ottawa Canada: A mixed Method Study
Project_Description: Vulnerable populations face numerous social and health inequities that are exacerbated during times of crises. Lessons learned from previous public health crises suggest that inappropriate communication strategies jeopardize risk reduction for vulnerable populations. The objective of this research is to measure the impacts of COVID-19 public health emergency response efforts and communication strategies on Ottawa's low-income, homeless or at-risk for homelessness populations. The findings could help inform public health messaging strategies and pandemic approaches for vulnerable populations.
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development
Keyword: Homeless, At-risk for Homelessness, Health Justice, Public Health, Messaging, Health Literacy, Physical Distancing, Equity

Project_Title: Research and Deployment of Rapid High-Throughput Diagnostic Testing for COVID-19
Project_Description: This project will increase Ontario's COVID-19 testing capacity by deploying robotic liquid handling technology, specimen pooling, and efficient sample preparation, while reducing biological risk and ensuring reliable results. The Disease Diagnostics & Development group in the Research Institute of St Joe's Hamilton (RSJH) is collaborating with the Hamilton Regional Laboratory Medicine Program (HRLMP) and other clinical laboratories across the province to quickly develop, validate, and deliver high-throughput, COVID-19 testing, with the goal of testing up to 6,000 samples per lab daily.
Keyword: Coronavirus detection, High-throughput, automation, Rapid diagnosis, robotics enhanced

Project_Title: A prospective, observational research study on the diagnosis of COVID-19 infection from stool samples of children and adults.
Project_Description: Through the development and use of a novel test to diagnose COVID-19 from stool samples, this team will assess up to 4,500 stool samples collected from outpatient clinics, emergency departments and inpatient wards across eight major Hamilton region hospitals and clinics. This work will improve COVID-19 disease detection in children and adults who lack respiratory symptoms, are asymptomatic, or are presumed to have "recovered" from past infection. The researchers hope to expand COVID-19 testing options across Canada and ultimately, better identify patients who carry high risk of community transmission than traditional respiratory testing alone.
Keyword: Stool samples, Laboratory testing, Pediatrics, Adult medicine, Community prevalence, Public health, Asymptomatic, Technology development

Project_Title: Novel Coronavirus Antiviral Drug Discovery Using High-Throughput Screening
Project_Description: Using a novel bio-sensor that detects drugs that disrupt the attachment of coronaviruses to cells, this research will test approximately 1,200 approved drugs to better understand their potential to prevent viral infection in cells and their ability to block the interaction between COVID-19 and its receptor. A second phase of this study will attempt to identify novel antivirals from a small (>220,000) molecule library.
Keyword: Antiviral, drug discovery, coronavirus, COVID-19, high throughput screening, small molecule, biochemical assay

Project_Title: Toolkit to Prevent COVID-19 Transmission among Persons with Dementia in Long-Term Care
Project_Description: This research team will develop, implement and evaluate a Dementia Isolation Toolkit for long-term care homes to support the compassionate, safe and effective isolation of people with dementia and to improve the implementation of infection control protocols in these centres. Researchers will design a series of tools to provide methods and approaches for isolating people with dementia safely and without compromising their dignity and personhood.
Keyword: Long Term Care; Geriatric Psychiatry; Dementia Care; Clinical Ethics; Infection Control; Technology in Clinical Care; Implementation Science

Project_Title: The Impact of the Coronavirus Pandemic on Children with Medical Complexity Technology Dependency: A Novel Research Cohort Study
Project_Description: This study addresses how to effectively manage pediatric patients remotely by identifying the barriers and facilitators of virtual clinics. COVID-19 is placing strain on families of children with medical complexity, medical fragility and technology dependency. Many of these children are dependent on life sustaining technology such as tracheostomy, home mechanical ventilation, and/or enteral feeding tubes. Though accounting for less than 1 percent of all children in Ontario, this group is at increased risk of multiple and prolonged hospitalizations and poorer health outcomes. Normally, these children are seen at a hospital to address their multiple complex needs, however due to COVID-19, all in-person clinic appointments have been replaced by virtual clinics. Parental satisfaction with virtual clinic healthcare teams will also be assessed using a quality improvement tool developed for this study. This research has the potential to advance virtual medicine, beyond COVID-19.
Keyword: Complex Care, Pediatrics, Medical Fragility, Technology dependent, Quality improvement, Patient-reported outcomes, telemedicine, Virtual Clinic, COVID-19

Project_Title: Protective immunity in individuals infected with COVID-19 â€“ SID# 242672
Project_Description: The goal of this research is to determine the makeup, concentration, strength and viral properties of anti-SARS-CoV-2 antibodies to provide insights into the immune response of individuals infected with COVID-19. Working with Dr. Arnold (CONCOR-1 study on convalescent plasma therapy), this team will use samples from recovered patients to test whether antibodies exist, and if they are able to bind and neutralize the virus. This research will determine whether immunity is longstanding or if it wanes over time; and will inform researchers how immune-based treatments work to fight off the virus, including convalescent plasma or future vaccines.
Keyword: Immunology, Virology, immunization, diagnostics, antibody, antigens, affinity, infection, pandemic, public health

Project_Title: Interferon Lambda for Immediate Antiviral therapy at Diagnosis (ILIAD): A phase II randomized, open-label, multicenter, trial to evaluate the effect of peginterferon lambda for the treatment of COVID-19
Project_Description: Researchers will evaluate the drug peginterferon-lambda (PegIFN-) in ambulatory andÂ hospitalized patients with mild to moderate COVID-19. Peginterferon-lambda has already been used to treat other viral diseases, such as hepatitis B and C. This research will shed light on whether it improves the ability of individuals to clear the virus that causes COVID-19
Keyword: Interferon lambda, innate immunity, epithelial cells, COVID-19, SARS-CoV-2, ambulatory, hospitalized

Project_Title: N95 respirator disinfection to protect front line health care workers during the COVID-19 pandemic
Project_Description: N95 respirators are designed to be single use, but by extending their lifespan this project could assure more protection of Ontario's front line workers. The researchers will create a system that will provide a low-cost decontamination process for safe re-use of N95 respirators during the COVID-19 pandemic. To extend the N95 respirator supply, the project will validate two forms of thermal disinfection (dry heat and humid heat). The system will be tested within 30-60 days in a large Toronto hospital, and, once validated and approved, could be scalable Ontario-wide as needed.
Keyword:
N95 respirator, NIOSH/CDC, Health Canada, SARS-CoV-2, personal protective equipment (PPE), COVID-19, quantitative
filtration efficiency, disinfection (viral), Occupational Health and Safety

Project_Title: Adaptive Immunity andÂ Outcomes of Convalescent Donors after COVID-19 Infection
Project_Description: This national study of plasma donors who have recovered from COVID-19 will address immune response,Â duration of protective immunity, clinical factors andÂ host genetics contributing to the variability of immune response to the virus. The researchers will also study long-term outcomes from COVID-19 infection to help define therapeutic strategies for COVID-1
Keyword: Convalescent plasma; immune response; neutralizing antibody; case-control; data linkage; biobank

Project_Title: Development and Validation of Flexible Medium Throughput Solutions for COVID-19 Diagnostics
Project_Description: As workplaces reopen, extensive molecular screening will be vital to identify asymptomatic and presymptomatic individuals. To maintain safe work environments, this research will evaluate methods of diagnosing COVID-19 including point-of-care methods that will be adaptable to nasal swab, saliva and saline gargle testing. The researchers will also develop standard operating procedures for these tests, based on rigorous clinical standards.
Keyword: SARS-CoV-2 RNA detection; RT-PCR; LAMP; RCA; HDA; Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs).

Project_Title: The Antithrombotic Therapy to Ameliorate Complications of COVID-19 (ATTACC) Trial: A multinational randomized, adaptive, controlled clinical trial â€“ support for personnel at the international Clinical Coordinating Centre in Ontar
Project_Description: In partnership with hospitals from across Canada, the United States, Brazil and Mexico, researchers will test a blood thinner called heparin, which may also have anti-viral and anti-inflammatory effects, for its effectiveness in treating COVID-19 patients who require ventilation. This trial has the potential to reduce mortality and need for mechanical ventilation in hospitalized patients with COVID-19.
Keyword: Anticoagulation, COVID-19, thrombosis

Project_Title: Ontarioâ€™s response to COVID-19: balancing trade-offs and improving outcomes for all Ontaria
Project_Description: Using the COvid19 Resource Estimator model, which is already extensively used by decision-makers and hospital administrators to support capacity planning and public health interventions, researchers will forecast COVID-19 case numbers under a range of re-opening scenarios and examine the effects of these potential cases on the Ontario acute care system and on short- and long-term health outcomes for COVID-19 and non-COVID-19 patients. This research will help to optimize mitigation strategies that balance healthcare system capacity, population health and broader societal outcomes, including the economic impact.
Keyword: Infectious disease epidemiology, public health, clinical epidemiology, medicine, computer science, mathematics, health services research, economics, health policy

Project_Title: uWaterloo MCU Research Proposal: How to re-open Ontarioâ€™s economy without causing a resurgence of COVID-19
Project_Description: Researchers will develop a mathematical model of COVID-19 transmission that can identify strategies for re-opening the economy without causing a resurgence of COVID-19. The model will use available demographic and epidemiological data from provinces and important features such as spatial and age structure, to create detailed maps of COVID-19 rates by province. The model will project cases, hospitalizations and deaths under different approaches to re-opening the economy.
Keyword: Epidemic modelling; transmission modelling; agent-based simulation; non-pharmaceutical interventions; school and workplace closure; physical distancing

Project_Title: Proposal for validation of a new SARS-CoV-2 diagnostic test enabling safe, at-home collection and increased provincial testing capacity
Project_Description: This project will test the efficacy of saliva-based sample collection to diagnose COVID-19 in patients in an effort to improve testing capacity across Ontario. Recent data suggests that saliva samples are more sensitive for SARS-CoV-2 detection compared to nasal swabs and this procedure is less invasive and can be self-administered at home.
OIA_AREA: Chemical and biological experimentation for the future
Keyword: Diagnostic testing capacity at-home saliva specimen sensitivity accuracy SARS-CoV-2

Project_Title: Methylene blue-mediated photodisinfection for SARS-CoV-2 in the upper respiratory tract
Project_Description: This project will test symptomatic and asymptomatic individuals with known SARS-CoV-2 diagnoses to asses whether a process called photodisinfection (PDF) using methylene blue, a medication and dye, can identify and destroy pathogens to clear SARS-CoV-2 from the upper respiratory tract.
Keyword: Photodisinfection, Methylene Blue, SARS-CoV-2, RTqPCR, Infectivity, Anterior Nares, In Vitro Validation, Clinical Cohort, Prototype Testing

Project_Title: Development of multiple vaccine candidates for SARS-CoV-2 and evaluation of safety and efficacy in animal models
Project_Description: This project aims to evaluate the safety and long-term protection of two vaccines before advancing them to human trials. The study will test the duration of protective vaccine immunity in both small and large animal models and investigate whether vaccinated animals that are infected with seasonal coronaviruses have adverse immunological reactions, leading to worse disease. The data generated from this proposal will help determine the optimal vaccine to advance into human efficacy trials.
Keyword: COVID-19 vaccine, Adenovirus-vector, DNA plasmid, animal model, pathogenesis, serology

Project_Title: Development of high throughput, inexpensive and scalable testing to detect SARS-CoV-2 antibodies using home blood collection kits and a fully automated ELISA antibody assay.
Project_Description:
To address the need for widely available testing for past COVID-19 infections, this project will develop a "home" blood collection kit to provide a high volume, inexpensive, accurate and easy-to-use test for SARS-CoV-2 antibody detection. The development of an inexpensive and simple antibody test has the potential to be rapidly scaled up and be readily available to very large populations of Canadians.

Volunteers will have repeat blood antibody testing 3 and 6 months following the initial test to provide data on their past COVID-19 infections, the incidence of new COVID-19 infections and if immunity exists.
OIA_AREA: Chemical and biological experimentation for the future
Keyword: Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA), health care workers, immunoglobulin, disease prevalence, disease incidence, home blood collection devices, acquired immunity

Project_Title: RdRp as a Promising Target to Identify Lead Compounds for the Treatment of COVID-19: a Rapid Structure-Based Approach
Project_Description: This study aims to identify new therapeutics and existing drugs that could be reused for the treatment of COVID-19 infections. Using supercomputers and advanced computational chemistry techniques, Dr. Poda and collaborators at Sunnybrook Research Institute will focus on finding drugs that can stop the virus from replicating in the body by targeting the virus' key polymerase enzyme. This approach will allow scientists to rapidly advance new COVID-19 treatments.
Keyword: COVID-19 therapeutics, live coronavirus replication, q-rtPCR, RdRp polymerase inhibitors, oral bioavailability, drug repurposing, structure-based drug design, high-throughput virtual screening, high performance computer cluster, ADMET.

Project_Title: Canadian COVID-19 Emergency Department Rapid Response Research Network â€“ Ontario Sit
Project_Description: This project aims to develop a provincial registry of suspected and confirmed COVID-19Â patients in emergency departments across Ontario. Through a collaboration involving emergency departments across Canada we will also be contributing data to a national registry. The registry will support the development of clinical decision rules to improve screening procedures, diagnostic studies (e.g. swabs and imaging), therapeutics (e.g. intubation) and the selection of patients for discharge or admission. This project is designed to improve care for patients treated during the COVID-19 crisis and will also support planning for future pandemics
Keyword:
Emergency medicine
Infectious disease
Registries
Clinical decision rules
Long term outcomes
Quality of Life
COVID-19

Project_Title: Ontario Healthcare Worker Seroprevalence of anti-SARS-CoV-19 Antibodies (COVID-19 Antibodies in Ontario Healthcare Workers)
Project_Description:
Healthcare workers have a critical role in the pandemic response to COVID-19 and are at risk of infection. The objective of this study is to assess the prevalence of anti-SARS-CoV-2 antibodies in a population of healthcare workers and describe the change in SARS-CoV-2 specific antibodies as the pandemic progresses. The research will also track the antibody response in those who are infected with COVID-19 and if possible, evaluate the impact of antibody presence on subsequent reinfection.

This research will shed light on the incidence of infection and risk factors for infection in healthcare workers from hospitals across Ontario.
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development
Keyword: COVID-19, seroprevalence, serology, Healthcare Workers, Infectious diseases, immune response

Project_Title: Natural Evolution of Serum Antibodies in Children and Adults with SARS-CoV-2 and Household Contacts
Project_Description: This project will provide insight into how COVID-19 spreads within households, following the World Health Organization's recommendation to survey antibody testing of children, non-hospitalized adults and household contacts. This study will explore the differences in antibody response in children, as well as differences in initial symptoms by age and sex. This will be done by measuring the number of antibodies within a person's blood (four times over a period of 12 months).
Lead_Research_Institution: Children's Hospital of Eastern Ontario Research Institute Inc.

Project_Title: An optimized clinical lab COVID-19 diagnostic test incorporating host transcriptomic responses for predicting disease course and healthcare system utilization.
Project_Description: By analyzing nasal swabs used for testing COVID-19 patients, this research aims to understand how individuals respond to the virus upon diagnosis. This study will better identify and treat patients who are at risk of developing serious complications and provide predictive capacity for hospitals to efficiently prepare and allocate resources for optimal patient health.
Keyword: Diagnostics, transcriptomics, host innate immunity, epithelial cells, clinical samples, machine learning, electronic medical record/EMR

Project_Title: AbSyn Technology for Identification of Synergistic Cancer Targets
Project_Description: AbSyn is a unique, Ontario-made platform that combines functional genetic screens with synthetic antibody development to enable high-throughput identification of antibody-genetic interactions that could lead to synergistic cancer therapeutics.
Keyword: functional genetics, cancer therapeutics

Project_Title: Beyond the Genome: Transcriptome Based Diagnostics for Rare Diseases and Cancer
Project_Description: We will create a RNA based diagnostic platform for rare diseases and cancer. Our platform will impact the health and well-being of Ontarians by increasing the success rate of genetic testing in children with rare diseases and cancer.
Keyword: diagnostics, rare diseases, cancer

Project_Title: Interactome mapping of disease-related proteins using split intein-mediated protein ligation (SIMPL)
Project_Description: We will develop a high-throughput, universal method for protein interactome and drug-screening, and apply it to cancer-related proteins. Benefits to Ontario will include company expansion, job creation and retention of HQP, improvement to health, investment income, and enhancement of Ontarioâ€™s reputatio
Keyword: protein interactome, drug-screening, cancer-related proteins

Project_Title: RapidAIM: A technology to rapidly assess the effects of compounds on individual microbiomes
Project_Description: Develop the first fully automated high throughput microbiome screening platform including hardware and software. The strategic value to Ontario will come from commercialization, applications to identify the effect on individual microbiome of drugs, prebiotics and other compounds, and training of HQP.
Keyword: microbiome

Project_Title: Development of a digital microfluidic platform to identify and target single cells from a heterogeneous cell population for lysis in an ultra-low volume for non-invasive prenatal diagnostics
Project_Description: We are developing a new digital microfluidic technology that will allow physicians to perform a simple, non-invasive prenatal genetic test. This technology allows for the isolation of fetal cells from PAP-smear-like samples that can then be used for genetic testing, replacing invasive tests such as amniocentesis.
OIA_AREA: Chemical and biological experimentation for the future
Keyword: prenatal genetic test

Project_Title: Environmental DNA ("eDNA"), meta-barcoding and transcriptional profiling to improve sustainability of freshwater fisheries and fish culture
Project_Description: For the first time we will be able to answer basic questions about Ontario's freshwater fish: Which fish are where? How many? Are they healthy? The answers will allow management of Ontario's threatened fish stocks (including commercially and recreationally important ones (to help them survive and thrive).
Round: Large Scale Applied Research Project - Round 003
Keyword: DNA, meta-barcoding, transcriptional profiling, sustainability of freshwater fisheries and fish culture

Project_Title: FISHES: Fostering Indigenous Small-scale fisheries for Health, Economy, and food Security
Project_Description: To develop and apply genomic approaches in concert with Indigenous Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) to address challenges and opportunities related to food security, knowledge advancement, capacity building, and Commercial, Recreational, and Subsistence (CRS) fisheries by Indigenous Peoples in Canada.
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development
Round: Large Scale Applied Research Project - Round 003
Keyword: genomics, Indigenous, food security, fisheries

Project_Title: Broad-Range Disease Resistance in Greenhouse Vegetables
Project_Description: Vineland has partnered with the University of Toronto to create new varieties of greenhouse vegetables with broad-range disease resistance. This innovation will reduce crop losses by more than 25% for Ontarioâ€™s growers, thereby increasing their competitivenes
OIA_AREA: Development and creation of investigation spots
Keyword: Disease resistance, greenhouse vegetables, crop protection, genomics

Project_Title: Genomics Driven Engineering of Hosts for Bio-Nylon
Project_Description: Demand for green bioproducts produced from sustainable raw materials is increasing due to customer preference, carbon pricing, and environmental concerns. BioAmber Inc. is partnering with the University of Toronto to deploy bio-based technologies that is capable of converting agriculture and forestry wastes into the materials required for nylon production in an economic and environmentally friendly manner. The successful commercialization of this technology will allow BioAmber to invest in new production capacity that will bring new jobs to Sarnia and further cement Sarniaâ€™s reputation as a biotechnology hu
Lead_Research_Institution: Governing Council of the University of Toronto
Keyword: bioproducts, agriculture, forestry, waste, nylon, biotechnology, genomics

Project_Title: Targeting fungal stress responses to provide first-in-class treatment for drug-resistant fungal pathogens
Project_Description: Resistance to current antifungal drugs has a devastating effect on human health.  This proposal is focused on developing a therapeutic solution that will revert and prevent the emergence of resistance, which will improve patient outcomes and build economic value and scientific expertise in Ontario.
Lead_Research_Institution: Governing Council of the University of Toronto
Keyword: fungal genomics, pathogenesis, drug resistance

Project_Title: LINCS: Linked Infrastructure for Networked Cultural Scholarship
Project_Description: The Linked Infrastructure for Networked Cultural Scholarship will connect disparate datasets with meaningful links to provide access to a vast digital cultural record. Tools for data conversion, linking, contextualization, analysis, and visualization will make the Web smarter for researchers and the public.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project_Title: i-BALSAC: a multisectorial infrastructure for high resolution mapping of the French Canadian population. (i-BALSAC : Une infrastructure multisectorielle pour une cartographie haute rÃ©solution de la population franco-canadienne)
Project_Description: The proposed i-BALSAC multisectorial platform will integrate genealogical, genetic and geographical data with analytical tools to provide opportunities for cutting-edge research on social evolution and on the identification of genetic risk factors and their utilization in treatment and prevention strategies.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Keyword: DÃ©mographie, gÃ©nÃ©tique humaine, gÃ©nomique des populations, biologieÃ©volutive, gÃ©ographie, histoire sociale, population franco-canadienne, QuÃ©bec,gÃ©nÃ©alogies; Fichiers de population, Ã©tat civil, donnÃ©es gÃ©nomiques, SI

Project_Title: Data Analytics for Canadian Climate Services (DACCS)
Project_Description: This project will make access to climate data cheap, quick, and efficient for scientists across Canada. Climate scientists will use DACCS to publish their data and analysis tools, allowing other scientists to run these tools â€œin the cloudâ€ and avoid time-consuming mistakes when designing their own analy
Keyword: Climate services, data analytics and visualization tools, workflows, impactmodelling, remote sensing; WPS, cloud computing, containerized applications, automated deployment, HPC

Project_Title: The Cancer Genome Collaboratory
Project_Description: The Cancer Genome Collaboratory is a unique cloud computing facility preloaded with more than 500 TB of publicly available cancer genomic data. In this phase of the project we will deploy research tools for high quality, uniform analysis and interpretation of tumour genomes and clinical information.
Keyword: Cancer genomics; Cloud computing; Data sharing; Global Alliance for Genomicsand Health; Protection of patient privacy; Bioinformatics; Genomics; Software development for high performance cloud compute

Project_Title: Canadian Consortium for Arctic Data Interoperability: Advancing Arctic Research through Connected Data Infrastructure
Project_Description: The Canadian Consortium for Arctic Data Interoperability, a multi-institutional group of scholars, public and private sector organizations, is developing an integrated Research Data Infrastructure to enable data sharing among existing infrastructures to address societal and economic needs.
Keyword: Artic, environment, culture, system science, information sharing; distributed, interoperable, open, scalable, API, analytics, visualization, maps

Project_Title: Field Validation of Technologies for Anaerobic Benzene and Alkylbenzene Bioremediation
Project_Description: SiREM, located in Guelph, ON, and the Universities of Toronto and Waterloo are partnering with other institutions to demonstrate and commercialize bioremediation cultures and associated monitoring tools to more effectively clean-up sites in Ontario that are contaminated with petroleum, and in particular with the carcinogen, benzene.
Keyword: bioremediation

Project_Title: Integrating genomic approaches to improve dairy cattle resilience: A comprehensive goal to enhance Canadian dairy industry sustainability
Project_Description: The current project looks to satisfy increasing demand, and ensure the global competitiveness of Canada's dairy cattle industry both on-farm and in exporting Canadian dairy genetics, while ensuring overall sustainability by creating a dairy cattle resiliency index for genetic improvement of cattle.
Round: Large Scale Applied Research Project - Round 003
Keyword: dairy cattle, genetics

Project_Title: BeeCSI: â€˜Omic tools for assessing bee heal
Project_Description: Honey bees are crucial to Canada and Ontarioâ€™s agro-economy, yet beekeepers and regulators are unable to diagnose why 26% of colonies die each year. Our team will develop state of the art diagnostic tools and guidelines on how to apply these tools in bee management. Our work will ensure the sustainability of Ontarioâ€™s beekeeping industry and generate a direct profit of $9 Million per year to Ontarioâ€™s beekeepers and greater than >$50 million per year in enhanced productivity of Ontario cro
Round: Large Scale Applied Research Project - Round 003
Keyword: bee management

Project_Title: 4D wheat: Diversity, Domestication, Discovery, Delivery
Project_Description: 4DWheat will harness Diversity, advance Domestication, enable Discovery, and expediting Delivery of new sources of genetic variation to enhance genetic gains in wheat. Next-generation sequencing, gene editing technologies, and digital imaging will be applied together with bioinformatics solutions to fully capture diversity in wheat breeding. The GE3LS research will not only quantify the current and future value of wheat genetic resources but will also examine regulatory networks to promote their utilization using new breeding technologies. The outcome of our research will increase genetic gains for the ultimate benefactors: Canadian wheat producers and all Canadians through associated economic spinoffs.
OIA_AREA: Chemical and biological experimentation for the future
Round: Large Scale Applied Research Project - Round 003
Keyword: wheat, genetics, sequencing, gene editing technologies, digital imaging, bioinformatics

Project_Title: Stopping Enteric Illnesses Early (Sentinel)
Project_Description: In order to improve detection of contaminated foods and therefore improve Canadian public health, PHAC plans to implement, within 3 cities (Guelph, Winnipeg and QuÃ©bec city), a new system based on the monitoring of sewage wastewater and social media data, allowing faster detection of foodborne outbreaks

Project_Title: Accelerating and Automating mHealth Innovation for Ontario
Project_Description: To commercialize technologies and develop multidisciplinary HQP in the field of mobile health. To enhance healthcare in Ontario by creating innovative solutions using mobile and leading technologies via Co-Design, Model-Driven Engineering, the Internet of Things, Wearable Computing, Augmented/Virtual Reality, and Machine Learning.
Keyword: mobile health, Model-Driven Engineering, healthcare, advanced health technologies

Project_Title: Anti-apoptotic gene therapy for the treatment of retinal diseases
Project_Description: Significant Innovations inÂ Gene tHerapy for theÂ Treatment ofÂ EyeÂ Disease (SIGHTED) programs are focused on developing general therapies that will be effective in multiple retinal diseases, irrespective of the underlying cause.Â  We will use gene and stem cell therapy to target diseases of the photoreceptors and retinal ganglion c
OIA_AREA: Research and study of the functioning of the human body
Keyword: retinal disease, gene therapy, stem cell therapy

Project_Title: Integrated Approaches to Characterize, Detect, and Treat Contaminants of Emerging Concerns (CECs) in the Aquatic Environments of Ontario
Project_Description: Contaminants of Emerging Concern (CECs) are a significant threat to Ontario's aquatic ecosystems. Our multidisciplinary team will develop novel commercial technologies that will create jobs and economic benefits. Ontario will be recognized as a global leader in clean water technology.Â Â
Keyword: Emerging contaminants, rapid detection, water treatment, wastewater treatment

Project_Title: 3D Ultrasound and Multi-Modality Imaging for Personalized Medicine
Project_Description: A highly experienced and accomplished team with a long history of inventing and commercializing three dimensional ultrasound (3DUS) and radiation detector-based medical imaging systems are collaborating to develop unique solutions to solve poorly met unmet needs for the diagnosis of prostate cancer, breast cancer and uterine prolapse.
Keyword: image-guided interventions, multi-modality guided biopsy

Project_Title: CyPreSS: Software Techniques for the Engineering of Cyber-Physical Systems
Project_Description: Cyber-Physical Systems (CPSs) comprise highly connected physical and software components that monitor and interact withÂ  the physical world, such as a smart grid or a traffic control system.Â  This project will develop novel tools and techniques to meet the design, deployment, scalability, performance, operation, and security challenges of CPS
Keyword: Software Engineering, Cyber-Physical Systems, Requirements, Middleware, Cloud Computing, Security

Project_Title: Antimicrobial Stewardship Solutions for a Sustainable Ontario Dairy Industry
Project_Description: Pressure is mounting to address antimicrobial resistance. For Ontarioâ€™s $1.8 billion dairy sector, solutions start on the farm with sound science-based approaches. This research will improve responsible use of antimicrobials in the dairy industry, through educational outreach and by validating alternatives to antimicrobial
Keyword: Antimicrobial use, sustainability, dairy, epidemiology, stewardship

Project_Title: Sustainable poultry production in the absence of antibiotics
Project_Description: The imminent ban on antibiotics as feed additives is expected to have dramatic impacts on profitability of the Canadian poultry industry. Therefore, there is a pressing need to find alternatives to antibiotics. We will use genomic science to employ the poultry microbiome to prevent diseases, enhance food safety and maintain global food security. Â
Keyword: Microbiome; Poultry; gut health; Probiotics

Project_Title: Transforming pathology using artificial intelligence to improve patient outcome and hospital efficiency
Project_Description: The project uses artificial intelligence to develop infrastructure and work-flows for digital diagnostic pathology, facilitate transformational changes in the detection and treatment of disease, improve patient safety, and thus promote sustainability of the Ontario health system.Â
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Keyword: Artificial intelligence, digital pathology, imaging

Project_Title: Characterization, Prediction and Control of Flap Noise Sources from Aircraft
Project_Description: Aviation is a strategic economic sector for Ontario and Canada. However, noise emissions from aircraft are an important risk to the continued growth of the industry. This research will develop technologies and methodologies for the reduction of noise emissions from aircraft.
Keyword: Aeroacoustics, Aeronautics, Airframe noise

Project_Title: Innovative and Cost-Effective Micro/Nanocellular Foaming Technology for Sustainable Lightweight Applications
Project_Description: A fundamental understanding of the foaming mechanisms of polyolefins will help develop an industrially viable and cost-effective foam technology, which will significantly improve the global competitiveness of the Ontario plastics manufacturing industry in the high-value markets of packaging, automotive, construction, and other sectors.
OIA_AREA: Chemical and biological experimentation for the future
Keyword: Micro/nanocellular foaming, Polymer processing, Crystallization

Project_Title: iCity 2.0: Urban Data Science for Future Mobility
Project_Description: The iCity 2.0 project aims to improve accessibility and mobility, in support of heightened economic productivity, quality of life and environmental sustainability in Ontario advancing the design of urban transportation systems and local â€œcomplete communities
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development
Keyword: Transportation, mobility, modelling, planning, sustainability

Project_Title: All-Weather Autonomy: Securing Ontarioâ€™s Leadership in the Self-Driving Revoluti
Project_Description: Self-driving cars must work in all weather conditions to be of use to Ontarians. This project will tackle the autonomy challenges presented by adverse weather, and will secure Ontarioâ€™s position at the forefront of the automotive industryâ€™s autonomous transformation for years to c
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development
Keyword: Autonomous Vehicles, Robotics, Adverse Weather

Project_Title: The Fibrosis Repair Team
Project_Description: The Fibrosis Repair Team unites world-class basic and clinical scientists to conduct hypothesis-driven multi-disciplinary collaborative research that will deliver a deeper understanding of the mechanisms that underlie fibrosis, fibrosis biomarkers, and antifibrotic drug screening platforms (Fig 1).
Keyword: fibrosis, matrix, biomarkers, drug platforms

Project_Title: Empowering Ontario's Transportation Sector with Electrochemical Solid State Energy Storage Batteries
Project_Description: The project aims to develop innovative electrochemical energy storage materials and solid state batteries to produce safe, advanced electromobility for transportation and potentially for dispatchable renewable energy from solar and wind. These cleantech technologies provide critical solutions for alternative energy.
OIA_AREA: Development and creation of investigation spots
Keyword: Electrochemical energy storage batteries; solid state batteries; sustainable energy; electromobility

Project_Title: Freedom in Black Expressive Culture
Project_Description: This innovative research aims to increase employment and professional advancement for students, artists and public- and private-sector organizations in Ontario engaged in the field of Black studies by developing a methodology that involves all these parties and the general public in the creation, analysis and dissemination of research findings.
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development
Keyword: Black studies, Black expressive culture

Project_Title: TRIA-FoR: Transformative Risk Assessment and Forest Resilience Using Genomic Tools for the Mountain Pine Beetle Outbreak
Project_Description: TRIA-FoR aims to develop knowledge, tools and strategies to anticipate and mitigate spread-risk potential of mountain pine beetle, and improve the resiliency of our forests and the people who depend on them.
Round: Large Scale Applied Research Project - Round 004
Keyword: genomics, forestry, beetles, outbreaks

Project_Title: Optimizing a microbial platform to break down and valorize waste plastic
Project_Description: We will develop enzyme- and microbe-based platforms to recycle plastic into chemical building blocks.
Round: Large Scale Applied Research Project - Round 004
Keyword: genomics, chemical, plastic, recycling

Project_Title: BIOSCANâ€“Cana
Project_Description: BIOSCANâ€“Canada will sustain Ontarioâ€™s global leadership in developing DNA-based species identification systems by developing the laboratory protocols and informatics capabilities required so high-throughput sequencers can reduce analytical costs and enable the large-scale biosurveillance needed for environmental protect
Round: Large Scale Applied Research Project - Round 004
Keyword: genomics, environment, dna, biosurveillance

Project_Title: Canadian BioGenome Project
Project_Description: In collaboration with Indigenous People, federal and provincial organizations and other conservation and wildlife groups, we will identify and create high quality reference genomes for 400 Canadian species where this information will aid in conservation planning and implementation. At least a quarter of the species will be from Ontario, chosen due to their economic and societal value to the province. The resultant genomes will be freely available, in a user-friendly platform so that researchers and end users can immediately make use of the data to develop genome- based tools and policy recommendations that support biodiversity conservation in Ontario.
OIA_AREA: Chemical and biological experimentation for the future
Round: Large Scale Applied Research Project - Round 004
Keyword: genomics, species, conservation, wildlife

Project_Title: Lowpass Genomic Instability Characterization as a Comprehensive Cancer and Germline Diagnostic Assay
Project_Description: World-renowned cancers researchers at the Hospital for Sick Children and Mount Sinai Hospital will combine expertise in paediatric and adult cancers, and will partner in developing the first of its kind comprehensive diagnostic test that will enable precision medicine for patients across Ontario.
Keyword:
Molecular diagnostics
Precision medicine
Low-coverage genome characterization
Laboratory developed test
Genetic predisposition syndromes
Immunotherapy Microsatellite instability Copy number variations Tumour mutational burden Mutational signatures

Project_Title: Production of medium-chain length polyhydroxyalkanoate from food waste
Project_Description: The project aims to validate and enhance food waste conversion into biodegradable bioplastic materials using novel genomic solutions through a collaboration with EcoPoly Solutions, SUEZ, and GHD. This will facilitate a low carbon circular economy and create new jobs and opportunities for Ontario.
Keyword: Food waste, valorization, circular economy, bioplastics, genomic solutions, biodegradable plastics, polyhydroxyalkanoates, low carbon, process optimization

Project_Title: Efficient Routing in Communication Networks
Project_Description: The proposed research targets various aspects related to the efficient routing of messages in different types of networks. With the rapid growth of the communication industry, through the internet and the emergence of wireless communication, these problems are of particular relevance. The main goal of this research is to experimentally study existing schemes as well as develop new schemes to route messages on networks where the physical location of nodes plays an important role such as Mobile Ad hoc Networks and Cellular Networks.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project_Title: Neuroimmune Sensitization Effects of Cytokines'A National Ultrahigh-Resolution Electron Microscopy Facility for Nanoscale Materials Research
Project_Description: To assess the role of the immune system messenger proteins, cytokines in normal and pathological brain processes. Our previous data indicate that certain cytokines exert relatively long-term effects upon neurotransmitter activity and behaviours that appear to mimic those evident in clinical depression. More recently , evidence has been presented that cytokines also play a role in chronic degeneration of neurons in Parkinson's and other brain disease states. We suggest that a wide range of environmental toxins and even psychological stressors stimulate brain cytokines activity which, in turn, promotes the development of behavioural and neurological disturbances.

Project_Title: A Multi-Component Model of Stereotype Activations
Project_Description: This research examines the cognitive representation of social categories. Specifically, this research investigates the different types of associations (such as stereotypes and negative evaluations) that become automatically activated when people are presented with social categories and how these various activations impact responses to target groups and processes that are relevant to the self and not directed at the target group.

Project_Title: The Deployment of Attention of Meaningful Information
Project_Description: Dr. Eastwood investigates how people pay attention to emotionally expressive faces. His finding that negative faces attract and hold attention more than positive faces challenge existing models of visual attention.

Project_Title: Gender and Precarious Work:  Labour Market Insecurity in Comparative Context
Project_Description: This research program analyzes the relationship between gender, nationality, and precarious work in comparative context.  In industrialized countries, women are more likely than men to engage precarious work and (im)migrants are often over-represented.  However, manifestations of precariousness vary from country to country.  This research is concerned with mapping precarious work in several different contexts in North America and Europe as well as in Australia.
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development

Project_Title: Appetite Control in the Regulation of Body Weight: An Investigation of the Role of Blood-Borne Peptides in the Regulation of Feeding in Humans
Project_Description: Obesity continues to increase in our society despite continued efforts from health professionals and agencies to warn against its toll on human health.  The countless diets and other strategies that people try have been only partially successful.  Researchers have found that after weight loss, many people quickly revert to their initial weight.  One explanation is that weight loss increases appetite.  Dr. Eric Doucet at the University of Ottawa will lead his research team in an investigation of how nutrition and exercise affect the hormones (blood-borne peptides) that play a key role in appetite control.  Dr. Doucetâ€™s research could lead to new ways to take off weight and keep it of

Project_Title: Quantifying the Influence of Implant Stem Geometry and Material on Load Transfer and Fixation
Project_Description: Joint replacements have improved the quality of life for many people, but the longevity of these devices is plagued by a phenomenon called â€œimplant loosening.â€  When this occurs, expensive and complicated surgery is required to restore function to a joint replacement.  Dr. Cynthia E. Dunning and her research team at the University of Western Ontario will examine the role that design features play in keeping implants in place, and â€œload transferâ€ or the way weight is transferred between the implant and the patientâ€™s bones. Dr. Dunningâ€™s research will increase the lifespan of joint replacements and patient comfort by identifying how loosening can be reduced

Project_Title: Genetic Analysis of Mechanisms Involved in the Establishment and Maintenance of Neuronal Polarity in C. elegans
Project_Description: Neurons are the main unit elements of the nervous system. An understanding of the human brain requires knowledge of the properties and function of neurons. Dr. Antonio Colavita and a team of researchers at the University of Ottawa are using the simple nervous system of c. elegans, a microscopic nematode (worm), to discover how neuronal cells acquire distinct characteristics such as a polarized cell shape and branched morphology. The work is part of an overall effort to advance the understanding of nervous system function in both health and disease.

Project_Title: Design, Dynamics and Control of Miniature Satellites
Project_Description: Miniature satellites weighing less than one kilogram offer exciting possibilities for scientific research and discoveries in a number of fields. At Ryerson University, Dr. Krishna Kumar and a team of researchers will study the dynamics and control aspects of miniature satellites to further their design and development. The work will include the development of micro-electromechanical systems and nanotechnologies for systems engineering, flight control, and mission analysis. The program could lead to systems design and Canadian missions using these low cost research tools.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project_Title: Material Processing with Intense Ultrashort Light Pulses
Project_Description: Light plays a pivotal role in life sciences and communications technologies. Photonics describes how light is manipulated, controlled and monitored with a wide range of devices. Dr. Ravi Bhardwaj Vedula and his team at the University of Ottawa will explore the unique properties of ultrafast lasers. The intense light pulses of the femtolaser offer the potential for surgery with minimal damage to surrounding tissues, precision biomedical imaging, cell manipulation, and the production of new photonic devices.

Project_Title: Ecological and biological effects of multiple environmental drivers in lakes and rivers
Project_Description: Freshwater is vital to our survival and well being, providing food, air purification, and recreation among many other benefits. Itâ€™s an integral part of the biosphere, and its degradation from climate change and land use has serious consequences for the economy and society in general. A research team at Trent University led by Dr. Marguerite A. Xenopoulos will assess the ecological and biological repercussions of global change stressors in Ontarioâ€™s lakes and rivers on species ranging from bacteria to fish. The results will have numerous uses in agriculture, water quality, energy, and biodiversity conservat
Keyword: rural, climate change

Project_Title: New Inorganic Molecules and Materials
Project_Description: The field of inorganic materials chemistry is at the forefront of scientific research and has significant industrial applications. Dr. Paul Ragogna and his team will use an Early Researcher Award to develop new polymers â€“ materials that are formed by combining different elements. The aim of the research is to identify chemical processes that are more environmentally compatible. This will have significant impact in the area of polymer science

Project_Title: Musculoskeletal Rehabilitation: Reducing Physical Disability by Enhancing Joint and Muscle Function
Project_Description: Joint and muscle disorders are the leading cause of pain and physical disability. Knee osteoarthritis alone costs Canada more than $4 billion annually in lost productivity and use of the health care system. Dr. Trevor Birmingham at the University of Western Ontario in London will use an Early Research Award to develop better rehabilitation treatments to reduce physical disability.  He and his team at the Universityâ€™s School of Physical Therapy will use a combination of laboratory-based measures that apply state-of-the-art instruments to test joint and muscle function, and clinically evaluating patientsâ€™ long-term rehabilitation. This will help decrease the burden of musculoskeletal disability on individuals, as well as reduce the toll these disorders take on our econ

Project_Title: Naturally disordered proteins and diseases
Project_Description: Statistics tell us that approximately one in every four Canadians will die of cancer. Scientists have determined that â€œdisorderedâ€ proteins in macromolecules (very large molecules) play a role in cancer, as well as in diseases such as Alzheimerâ€™s, Parkinsonâ€™s and Huntingtonâ€™s. These unstructured proteins differ from regular, three-dimensional proteins. Dr. Wing-Yiu Choy and his research team at the University of Western Ontario will use an Early Researcher Award to perform detailed studies to better understand the structure of these disease-related proteins and how they function.  Dr. Choyâ€™s research could lead to breakthroughs in new drugs and therapies for cancer and oth

Project_Title: Novel Targets for the Prevention & Cure of Diabetes
Project_Description: Diabetes Mellitus is a life-altering disease with an enormus economic and social burden estimated at $9B/yr in Canada alone.  When patients present with diabetes, it is often years after the disease onset.  Complications such a blindness, amputation, heart disease, stroke, and kidney failure are an ever-present threat for all patients with diabetes.  In both type 1 & 2 diabetes there is destruction of the insulin producing B cells which occur years before clinical presentation.  The objective of the proposed project is to better define the molecular events that trigger the destruction of the B cells which will lead to therapeutic targets for B cell preservation.

Project_Title: Epigenetic Approaches to Identifying Autism Susceptibility Genes
Project_Description:
John Vincent currently holds a scientist position at CAMH. His work is
on the genetics of psychiatric disorders, with the main focus looking at
the genetics of autism, and related disorders such as Rett syndrome.

Project_Title: Targetting ICAM-1/LFA-1 Interaction in Reducing Sepsis-Induced Lung Injury
Project_Description:
Lipopolysccharides (LPS) or endotoxins are major microbial pathogens leading to deadly sepsis and lung injury. Dr. Zhang's team demonstrated that LPS-stimulated lung epithelial cells actively transfer inflammatory signals to naÃ¯ve white blood cells even after LPS removal, resulting in uncontrolled inflammation. Selected as cover page by the Journal of Immunology, his work provides a viable explanation for the failure of anti-LPS antibodies in human sepsis and human studies which anti-LPS antibodies were successful when given prior to LPS injection in animals, but not in patients who were already endotoxemic.
His team will examine the mechanisms whereby intercellular cell adhesion molecule-1 mediates this excessive inflammation. He will also test several novel therapeutic approaches to block the LPS-induced inflammatory responses in sepsis and acute lung injury.

Project_Title: Functional Genomic Analysis of Vibrio vulnificus: Identifying New Virulence Factors & Novel Vaccine Candidates
Project_Description:
Dean A. Rowe-Magnus, Assistant Professor in the Department of Laboratory
medicine and Pathobiology. My research focuses on integrons and the
evolution of bacterial pathogens by horizontal gene transfer

Project_Title: Self-Assembled Monolayers on Ultrasmooth Surfaces
Project_Description: Microelectronic devices are rapidly shrinking into the nano-scale realm and require increasingly thin barrier layers to protect their components. If these barriers are not thin enough to isolate components from oxidation and diffusion, particularly copper interconnects used in integrated circuits, the devices wonâ€™t work as effectively. With an Early Researcher Award, Dr. Tricia Carmichael of the University of Windsor will study self-assembled monolayers (SAMs), extremely thin organic films that form spontaneously on surfaces and could serve as barrier layers for future nano-electronic devices. Because SAMs are more effective on smooth surfaces, Dr. Carmichael will explore an industrial technique called â€œchemical-mechanical polishingâ€ for polishing surfaces to nearly atomic ultrasmoot
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project_Title: Cell Housekeeping Enzymes: Our Guardian Angels Against Dementia
Project_Description: A malfunction in the proteasome system in the brain is one of the leading causes of neurodegenerative disorders such as Alzheimerâ€™s and Huntingtonâ€™s disease. In these disorders, a deficient cellular â€œhousekeeping teamâ€ is responsible for the accumulation of plaques that lead to the death of neurons. Dr. Joaquin Ortega leads a team of researchers at McMaster University that is studying the mechanisms that activate the proteasome system. The team is also studying a bacterial protein that is a factor for pathogens in these diseases. Since their research has direct links to several diseases (including BSE or â€œmad cowâ€ disease), it will be useful in the development of new pharmaceutica

Project_Title: Neonatal Development of Auditory Neural Circuits
Project_Description: The neural networks our bodies use to process sensory information are not hard-wired, but are created through neuronal activity and specific developmental mechanisms. When these networks malfunction, they can produce developmental auditory disorders and language and learning difficulties (such as dyslexia) that can have a great impact on the quality of life. A group of researchers at McMaster University led by Dr. Deda Gillespie is investigating how the immature auditory system organizes neural circuits. Their work will produce new insights into the development of auditory perception, with applications for a range of disorders from dyslexia to epilepsy.

Project_Title: Best Practices for Computer Simulations in History
Project_Description: Leading scholars have called for more use of computers in teaching history and other social sciences.
