Dr. Kevin Kee at Brock University in St. Catharines is leading a study of â€œserious gamesâ€ and simulations, once reserved for the military, as educational tools. These interactive software applications take their ideas, skills and techniques from commercial computer games designed for entertainment. Dr. Kee and his research team will work with an Ontario educational software company to create a prototype 3D simulation that is set in historic London. This project aims to determine the â€œbest practicesâ€ for designing digital media that will allow students to look at history more analy
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project_Title: Understanding Chromosome End Biology and Pathology
Project_Description: In human cells, the ends of chromosomes act as a protective cap, a cap that is eroded over time with each cell division as the cell ages. At Mount Sinai - SLRI  Dr. Daniel Durocher leads a project that will use genomic tools to understand how these chromosome ends are capped in normal, aging and cancerous cells. The teamâ€™s goal is to discover genes that act to either strengthen or weaken the chromosome end cap. Discovery of these genes will help in the design of novel therapies to fight cance

Project_Title: Taming the Strong Interactions: Perturbative and Non-Perturbative Methods
Project_Description: Most of our current understanding of nature is based on theories in which a particle, such as a photon, mediates forces among other particles, such as the electromagnetic force between electrons. Although physicists find these theories simple to express, it is usually very difficult to extract useful information from them. Dr. Freddy Cachazo and a team of researchers at the Perimeter Institute for Theoretical Physics are developing new techniques to use theories governing the behaviour of elementary particles. The projectâ€™s goal is to bridge the gap between theories and how they will be used in the next levels of micro-technolog
OIA_AREA: Chemical and biological experimentation for the future

Project_Title: Cosmology and Fundamental Physics
Project_Description: Along with giving us a profound understanding of the universe, theoretical physics has led to virtually all of the technological advances we enjoy, from lasers and cell phones to GPS systems and MRI scans. Dr. Thomas Thiemann leads a team at the Perimeter Institute for Theoretical Physics that will take advantage of new satellite missions that will deliver highly precise cosmological data over the next five to 10 years. The project will determine possible imprints that the physics at very small scales of space and time may have left in cosmological quantities.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project_Title: Electronic and Magnetic properties of novel complex materials
Project_Description: Dr. Young-June Kim of the University of Toronto will use an Early Researcher Award to study electronic and magnetic properties of complex materials (such as high temperature superconductors), using state of the art instruments. This research will shed light on how electrons interact among themselves, which in turn could lead to microscopic understanding of advanced materials for future development of technology.

Project_Title: Presynaptic active zone development in C. elegans
Project_Description: Synapses in the brain are junctions where cells of the nervous system communicate with each other. Current research has found important connections between synapse formation and mental health. To gain insight into cognitive development and the onset of mental illness, Dr. Mei Zhen of Mount Sinai Hospital will use an Early Researcher Award to investigate the development of the synapse in the central nervous system. Using the roundworm (C. Elegans) as a model, Dr. Zhen aims to identify mechanisms that regulate the development and differentiation of synapses. The goal is a breakthrough in understanding brain development, the synapse and, ultimately, the onset and treatment of mental illness.

Project_Title: Evolutionary and behavioural ecology of mammals:  Indivdual & Genetic Approaches
Project_Description: The researcher studies wild populations of animals to understand how and why variation in individual Darwinian fitness is affected by individual differences in behaviour, size, and life history and the environment.

Project_Title: Development of Solid State NMR Methods for Structure Elucidation
Project_Description: Developing sophisticated probing techniques called solid-state NRM methods to learn about the structural detail of membrane proteins. Membrane proteins are drug targets and amyloidogenic proteins are related to diseases such as Alzheimer's.

Project_Title: Beyond Diversity and Stability:  The Role of Biological Structure
Project_Description: Dramatic changes in biodiversity are placing ecosystems under stress. This research will enhance our understanding of how biodiversity governs the stability and function of these systems and help us better manage biological resources.

Project_Title: Anti-Microbial Compounds from Stone Fruits and their effect on plant and human health
Project_Description: Stone fruits -- such as peaches -- are a source of antimicrobial proteins and antioxidants, which help these trees stay healthy. This research will look at European plums and isolate the genes responsible for the antimicrobial traits.

Project_Title: Associations of Health Care, Social Welfare and Education Policies with Personal, Familial and Population Health Outcomes
Project_Description: Dr. Gorey is exploring why lower income Canadians living in large cities tend to survive life-threatening diseases better than their American neighbours. The findings will help in improving forecasting for future healthcare needs.

Project_Title: Dynamics of Delay Differential Systems with Applications to Neural Networks
Project_Description: Dr. Chen's main research interest is on the dynamics of differential equations arising from neural networks and population biology, where the future state of the equation is influenced by both the current state and history.
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development

Project_Title: Towards rational administration of rapamycin compounds: development of a prognostic test based on the Rheb signal transducer
Project_Description: One of the most promising classes of anti-cancer treatments is rapamycin and its related compounds, which are currently used in clinical trials. They are showing significant promise in therapy for many human tumours, including solid tumours of the breast, prostate, uterine, lung and pancreas. However, the diagnostic tests necessary to screen patients and predict their responses to rapamycin compounds do not exist.  Dr. Vuk Stambolic will lead his team at the Ontario Cancer Institute in developing a test to predict how sensitive individual tumours are to these compounds. The results could lead to improved treatment for many cancer patients within the next five years.

Project_Title: Examining the role of sensory information in shaping and guiding movements.
Project_Description: One of the brainâ€™s main tasks is using sensory information to control movement. Neurological disorders caused by stroke, tumours, injury and degenerative disease result in sensorimotor malfunction. Sensory and motor functions are usually studied separately, but Dr. Denise Henriques and her colleagues at York University are taking a new approach. Their research will analyze how sensorimotor systems operate as integrated wholes, and may provide a new approach to neurological assessment, therapy and rehabilitation. The work also has applications for improving virtual reality devices, control panels, and other user interface

Project_Title: Plant Population and evoutionary genomics
Project_Description: There is a long-standing debate on whether demographics or genetics play a greater role in causing some plant species to become extinct.  Dr. Stephen I. Wright at York University will use an Early Researcher Award to look at the interaction between demography and genetics.  Dr. Wright and his research team will investigate how plant populations evolve and adapt at the molecular level. This genome research could lead to improvement in important Canadian crops like canola, swede and turnip.  The results are also expected to produce important tools for the management of endangered species and provide other valuable information for use in agriculture, health and environmental protection.
Keyword: rural, climate change, bio-economy

Project_Title: Characterization of SNARE function in the regulation of cell migration
Project_Description: In cancer, tumours that are confined to their primary site of growth (non-mestastatic) can generally be managed with early detection and surgical removal. By contrast, metastatic or malignant cancers, in which tumour cells migrate away from the primary tumour and spread throughout the body, are much more difficult to treat. Dr. Marc Coppolino and his research team at the University of Guelph are investigating the function of proteins within cells that control cell movement and may be a key factor in the progression of cancer. The results of Dr. Coppolinoâ€™s research will help to identify cellular molecules that could eventually be targeted to stop the spread of some cancer

Project_Title: Investigating the genomic basis for plant growth under water stress
Project_Description:
When plants sense low water conditions, growth quickly slows or ceases. This adaptation works well in nature, but limits the yield in corn and other agricultural crops. 
With the overall goal of improving crop yields and productivity, Dr. Lewis Lukens and his team of researchers at the University of Guelph are studying genetically pure maize (corn) plants that are resistant to water scarcity. Using a new technology, they will identify genes; clusters of genes and DNA sequences that could lead to greatly enhanced crop yields in Ontario. Developing maize plants with a greater stress tolerance could expand Ontarioâ€™s corn growing region to the north and wes
Keyword: Bio-economy, rural, climate change, water, wastewater

Project_Title: Development of virtual prototyping tools to reduce repetitive strain injuries
Project_Description: Heavy equipment operators in industries such as forestry, mining and construction control their vehicles with hydraulic joysticks.  But few studies have examined the effects that joystick movements have on the human body.  Work requiring small, precise movements of the arms over long periods is thought to predispose workers to muscle tenderness and shoulder strain. Dr. Michele Oliver and her research team at the University of Guelph will develop computer tools to quickly assess the long-term safety of joysticks and other hand tools and determine how much injury they cause. Dr. Oliverâ€™s research will provide information and tools to reduce repetitive strain and overuse injuries in heavy machinery operator
Keyword: rural

Project_Title: Mathematical Aspects of Quantum Error Correction
Project_Description: Experimental prototypes of the quantum mechanical computer have already been built, and it is only a matter of time before they will process billions of calculations simultaneously. These amazing possibilities face challenges including â€œerrorsâ€ that disrupt quantum systems as they evolve in time. Dr. David W. Kribs and a team at the University of Guelph will use a mathematical approach to find new techniques for error correction. Since their work is interdisciplinary, it will offer opportunities to apply tools from physics and computer science to the probl
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project_Title: Discovery of Functional RNA Transcripts in the Human Genome
Project_Description: Ribonucleic acids (RNAs) are very important molecules, many of which are thought to play a role in cancer and other genetic disorders.  Dr. Zhaolei Zhang and his research team at the University of Toronto will use an Early Researcher Award to identify a list of RNAs specific to humans that have previously been overlooked.  Many human disorders are known to be associated with certain regions in the human genome, but no protein-coding genes have been found in those regions.  Dr. Zhangâ€™s hypothesis is that these regions actually produce RNAs instead of proteins. Identifying these RNAs will help researchers to understand the origins of these disorders and open the door to new treatmen

Project_Title: Rediscovering the left-examining deficits of temporal and spatial processes in patients with neglect
Project_Description: Injury to the right half of the brain from a stroke often leads to a disorder known as â€œneglectâ€, where the patient fails to acknowledge their left side. They behave as if one half of their world has ceased to exist, not eating food on the left side of a plate and ignoring events in the left side of space. Current treatment for this debilitating condition includes the use of prisms, to shift the patientâ€™s perception to the neglected space. Dr. James Danckert and his research team at the University of Waterloo will use behavioural and brain imaging techniques to explore time and space perceptions after the use of prisms. This work offers great potential to develop more efficient forms of rehabilit

Project_Title: Enhanced Sequential Decoding in MIMO Links
Project_Description: Reliable communication over wireless channels has major importance in todayâ€™s world. Mutliple-input multiple-output (MIMO) technology, a mathematical model for communication systems, is the primary focus of research in this proposal. Dr. Mohamed Damen will use an Early Researcher Award to enhance the quality and quantity data and voice communications over wireless channels using MIMO technolog
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project_Title: A self-healing Framework to Enable Adaptive Software Systems
Project_Description: Anyone who has used a computer is all too familiar with the term â€œcrashâ€. Most software operates in an environment that is not always well defined or predictable. By incorporating self-healing capabilities into software systems, Dr. Ladan Tahvildari and a team of researchers at the University of Waterloo aim to make them adaptive to unexpected changes. The project will investigate, develop and design a self-healing framework that will detect improper operations of applications, transactions and business processes, and correct the problem without disrupting users. The project includes the production of prototypes for external evaluation and
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project_Title: Microelectromechanical Systems and Nanotechnology-based devices for Biomedical Applications
Project_Description: The development of new diagnostic and therapeutic methods has fuelled investigation of new clinical techniques and invention of novel biomedical instruments. This intense global interest stems from the pursuit to find new cures for terminal diseases and to invent new instruments for improving the quality-of-life through early and effective detections. This proposal focuses on microelectromechanical systems (MEMS), the technology of the extremely small. The technology merges at the nanoscale level with nanotechnology. Dr. Tze-Wei (John) Yeow will use an Early Researcher Award and apply MEMS and nanotechnology to fundamentally improve biomedical devices for clinical diagnosis and treatment.

Project_Title: Quantum Communication
Project_Description: Prof. Gregor Weihs of the University of Waterloo will use an Early Researcher Award to study what many agree is the future of information technology. Quantum computers will be able to solve problems that are intractable on conventional computers while providing absolute data security. This project will focus on a central element of quantum communication technology: sources of single photons and photon pairs. The work being done by Prof. Weihs could be the building blocks of future quantum communication networks.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project_Title: The Implementation of a Culturally-Appropriate Web-Based Tool to Assess Food Intake (Including Wild Game) and Physical Activity Behaviour in First Nation Schoolchildren (James Bay Region of Northern Ontario), as Related to Obesity and Diabetes
Project_Description: The rising prevalence of obesity and Type 2 diabetes is directly linked to poor diet and lack of physical activity. The problem is especially serious among First Nations youth living in isolated communities who often donâ€™t have access to relevant information on appropriate food choices and physical activity. Dr. Leonard Tsuji and a team at the University of Waterloo will implement a culturally appropriate web-based survey of diet and physical activit

Project_Title: Safe Drinking Water Technology Development and Optimization for Pathogen Removal
Project_Description: Public drinking water supplies are often treated with multiple specialized processes, to ensure that numerous disease-causing pathogens are eliminated. These multiple treatments are costly, especially in developing countries where water is a precious commodity. At the University of Waterloo, a research team led by Dr. Monica Emelko will develop and optimize conventional and emerging technologies to produce safe drinking water. The work will contribute directly to pubic health by developing cheaper, effective methods of water treatment and will encourage new environmental technologies.
Keyword: water, wastewater

Project_Title: The Cosmic Cradle: A study of Small, Distant Galaxies
Project_Description: Scientists continue to explore the origins and the size of our universe, but some small, far-away galaxies have been too faint for observation, even with the most up-to-date theories and the worldâ€™s largest telescopes.  Dr. Michael Balogh and his team at the University of Waterloo will use an Early Researcher Award to observe what he calls â€œthe Cosmic Cradleâ€ and study small, distant galaxies.  Using new techniques and the latest telescopes, Dr. Baloghâ€™s research will measure the rate of star formation in the faintest galaxies ever detected. The goal is to ensure accurate measurements of stellar mass and their envir

Project_Title: Expedient and Modular Entries into Bioactive Natural Products and Analogues
Project_Description: In our world of aging baby boomers and rapidly spreading contagious diseases such as SARS, the demand for new drugs quickly continues to grow.  Dr. Eric Fillion at the University of Waterloo is using an Early Research Award to develop new technologies, including â€œdominoâ€ processes, to speed up drug discovery.  Dr. Fillion and his team will use an Early Researcher Award to reduce the number of steps required to allow rapid access to medically important compounds and biologically active natural products which will help to develop new or improved medicines.  Pharmaceutical and biopharmaceutical companies can use these new technologies in drug production to make drugs chea

Project_Title: Information discovery in biologial sequences
Project_Description: Genetic research offers tremendous hope for people suffering from a wide variety of diseases and ailments. While genomic sequencing projects are creating a huge wealth of raw data, the technology needed to understand that data has not kept pace. Dr. Daniel Brown and a team of researchers at the University of Waterloo are closing this gap by developing new ideas and software to understand DNA and protein sequences. This project focuses on finding genes, interpreting the structure of membrane proteins, and identifying evolutionary sequences. The new tools developed from the research will be used to better understand genetic diseases and develop individualized medical interventions.

Project_Title: Genetic Variation and Risk of Infection in Children with Primary Acute Myeloid Leukemia
Project_Description: Children with cancer face yet another serious risk: infection. Ten percent of children with acute myeloid leukemia (AML) will die from infection. The ability to predict those patients who are at high risk of infection would help health care workers to prevent it. Since genetic factors affect susceptibility to infection, Dr. Lillian Sung and her colleagues at The Hospital for Sick Children will conduct a national study to measure genetic variation. The data will be used to predict the likelihood of serious infections in young cancer patients and improve their rate of survival.

Project_Title: An investigation of abnormal vision and eye movements in infants born with crossed eyes
Project_Description: A crossed eye in infancy is one of the most prevalent health problems among children. Since we know very little about the parts of the brain that are affected in this condition, it is not yet curable. Dr. Agnes Wong leads a team at the Hospital for Sick Children seeking the answers to two questions: 1) Which parts of the brain are responsible for the slow-following eye movements typically found in crossed eyes? 2) How do the visual and eye movement systems interact to facilitate stereovision? The results will have important implications for the treatment or cure of a condition that affects one of every 100 children.

Project_Title: The role of TGF-beta in Alzhemier's disease and aging
Project_Description: Alzheimerâ€™s disease (AD) is a progressive, degenerative disease associated with aging that produces symptoms such as memory loss and dementia. In Ontario thousands of people suffer from AD, resulting in lost productivity for both patients and caregivers.  Dr. Paul William Frankland at Torontoâ€™s Hospital for Sick Children will use an Early Researcher Award to study the role that the TGF-Î² signalling pathway plays in Alzheimerâ€™s disease. (TGFs are regulatory molecules that stimulate or inhibit cell growth.)  Dr. Frankland and his research team will use mouse models to examine whether TGF-Î²1-based treatments will help improve mental function. This research could lead to new treatments for memory loss due to AD or norma

Project_Title: Combined magnetic resonance imaging and positron emission tomography imaging systems
Project_Description: In diagnosing diseases such as cancer, coronary heart disease and memory disorders, doctors must be able to see both soft tissue images and images of how a patientâ€™s biological system is functioning.  Currently, this is done with two separate systems: Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) and Positron Emission Tomography (PET.)  Dr. Blaine Chronik and his research team at the University of Western Ontario are developing a new technology to combine these two systems into one.  Initially, this dual mode scanner will be used for imaging on small animals.  Dr. Chronikâ€™s project is expected to lead to an advanced biomedical imaging system for use in human health c

Project_Title: Assisted Reproduction: Molecular and Developmental Effects of In Vitro Embryo Culture
Project_Description: Evidence suggests that children conceived with Assisted Reproductive Technologies (ARTs) may develop genetic disorders. This may be related to using ARTs to manipulate important genes at a crucial stage in their growth. Dr. Mellissa Mann and her team at the University of Western Ontario will investigate in vitro embryo cultures in mouse models to determine the effects of ARTs on genomic imprinting and development.  Dr. Mannâ€™s research will help to identify optimal times for in vitro fertilization to assure normal development of the fetus and chil

Project_Title: Molecular Biology of streptococcal superantigen toxins
Project_Description: Every year approximately 500 Canadians are stricken by invasive diseases caused by group A streptococci. These include necrotizing fasciitis (â€œflesh-eating diseaseâ€) and toxic shock syndrome. The high fatality rates and long recovery periods indicate that new therapies are required.  But a better understanding of streptococcal virulence is necessary to develop alterative treatments. Dr. John K. McCormick of the University of Western Ontario will study how a group of potent bacterial toxins (superantigens) produced from pathogenic streptococci and staphylococci interact with human white blood cells. This research will lead to new treatments for advanced stages of toxic shock syndrome, and anti-cancer therapies that will use immune cells to target specific tumo

Project_Title: Cures for scarring diseases
Project_Description: Various diseases cause scarring, which is a natural result of tissue repair.  However, in some patients scarring is uncontrolled and can cause fibrotic disease, which can lead to organ failure and death. Approximately 35 per cent of health care costs in Canada are due to diseases involving fibrosis, including diabetes, cardiovascular disease and liver cirrhosis.  Dr. Andrew Leask and his research team at the University of Western Ontario will study the causes of scleroderma, a chronic scarring disease affecting the skin and internal organs.  Dr. Leaskâ€™s research aims to identify specific proteins that can be targeted by therapeutic drugs to treat scarring in fibrotic diseases, but cause minimal side effect

Project_Title: Laboratory for Asymmetric Catalysis and Nanomaterials Research
Project_Description: Just as a personâ€™s hands are mirror images of one another, many molecules are also â€œhandedâ€ or chiral. Chiral molecules are important because they are the building blocks of much of nature, for example, DNA, proteins, and sugars. Many chemical interactions, such as those between drugs and their specific targets in the body, depend upon recognizing the correct â€œhandâ€ of a chiral molecule. The other mirror-imaged â€œhandâ€ of a chiral molecule is not recognized and is rejected in a chemical interaction.  Dr. Nathan Jones and his team will use an Early Researcher Award to develop methods to selectively produce the proper â€œhandsâ€ of chiral molecules that are of pharmac

Project_Title: The Physiological Ecology of Migratory Birds and Bats
Project_Description: Migration can be risky and physically demanding for birds and bats. Migratory birds fly with an intensity that is twice the maximum aerobic capacity of a running animal.  Dr. Christopher Guglielmo at the University of Western Ontario will use an Early Researcher Award to investigate how birds and bats store and use body fat during demanding, long-distance flights. This could help in the understanding of human diseases such as obesity and diabetes.  The research will also examine the â€œstop-oversâ€ these animals make to refuel while migrat

Project_Title: Central and Peripheral Control of Appetite & Hydromineral Balance in Teleost Fish
Project_Description: My research focuses on understanding how central and peripheral endocrine factors control appetite and hydromineral balance in fish when environmental conditions vary either through natural means or by human disturbance.
OIA_AREA: Research and study of the functioning of the human body
Keyword: water, wastewater

Project_Title: Design Study & Preparation of New Hybrid Organic/Inorganic Materials
Project_Description: Dr. Pilkingtonâ€™s research focuses on the synthesis and study of molecular building blocks as precursors for the assembly of molecule-based electronic, optical, and/or magnetic materials. Examples of materials targeted by her approach include molecular metals, semiconductors, superconductors, and magnet
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project_Title: Predicting Disease Risk Based on DNA Mutation Load in Single Cells
Project_Description: Researchers will develop novel methods to measure the amount and type of mutations occurring with aging and aging-associated diseases such as cancer and neurodegeneration.  These methods will help identify the origins of mutations and ultimately, the therapies effective in preventing damage to DNA thereby delaying or preventing aging-associated disease.

Project_Title: Novel Cellular Therapy for Induction of Tolerance by Tolerogenic Dendrtic Cells
Project_Description: This research aims to develop a safer way toÂ prevent the rejection of transplanted organs by a process called"immune modulation".Â  We will investigate various genetic and cellular therapies to prevent transplant rejection without needing global immune suppressive drugs

Project_Title: Cultural Complexity and Knowledge Management:  Time in the Transatlantic Baroque
Project_Description: The research will demonstrate that the transatlantic baroque was an adaptive complex system and that it developed through the creation of new forms of knowledge management that, at the time, were unique in modern history.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project_Title: Top-down & Bottom-up Influences on Eye-Head Gaze Shifts
Project_Description: The purpose of the proposed research is to elucidate how the central nervous system flexibly transforms the neural commands for coordinated eye-head gaze shifts within different behavioural contexts.  This will contribute indispensible information to how the CNS controls all types of complex movements, including those of the limbs.

Project_Title: Structure-Function Analysis of the Retinoblastoma Tumor Suppressor Protein in Cell Cycle Control & Oncogenesis
Project_Description: This work seeks to identify the pathways regulated by the Retinoblastoma Tumor Suppressor Gene and prioritize their importance with respect to cancer.  This work is expected to provide new diagnostic tools to guide treatment options as well as to identify novel targets for therapeutic intervention.

Project_Title: Investigation of mCLCA3 in Mouse Models of Cystic Fibrosis
Project_Description: The objective of this research is to unravel the role of mClCa3 in cystic fibrosis through development and characterization of CF mice that overexpress or are deficient in its function.

Project_Title: Large-scale Computational Simulations and Data Assimilation of Earthquake Fault Systems
Project_Description: This research will employ large-scale fault modeling, intensive image processing and source inversions for that data, and the associated data assimilation into these models in order to improve our understanding of earthquake processes and their underlying physics.

Project_Title: Dynamics and Patterns in the Structured Populations:  Modelling, Analysing & Predicting
Project_Description: This research aims at deriving new models for some biological problems such as structured population growth,  spred of infectious diseases,  dynamics of biological and artificial neural networks  etc.  Analysis of these models may help us better understand the mechanisms of the above problems, and thereby,  better predict  and better control.

Project_Title: Cross-talk Between AMPA & NMDA Receptors in the Hippocampus
Project_Description: This research will focus on studies of the interaction between AMPA and NMDA receptors, which will help to develop new strategies in the treatment of neurological disorders such as epilepsy and cognitive impairment.

Project_Title: Development of Nano-Structured Composite Membranes for Olefin/Paraffin Separation
Project_Description: This research is aimed at developing innovative nano-structured composite membranes for olefin separation, which is one of the most important separations in the polyolefin industry.

Project_Title: Performance Evaluation for Hybrid Optical Switches & Hybrid Optical Networks
Project_Description: Our research is to explore potentials and capabilities of the advanced supports from Optical Burst Switched (OBS) infrustructure for the upper layer applications such as bulk data transfer and voice services.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project_Title: The Evolution of the Red Algae (Rhodophyta)
Project_Description: Red algae are an ancient lineage of economic and biological importance yet are poorly understood.  My research will use innovative approaches to identify red algal species that will impact conservation, biodiversity and aquaculture.
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development

Project_Title: Hybrid Polypropylene-Clay Nanocomposites
Project_Description: Novel hybrid polymer nanocomposites will be developed to create commodity goods with exceptional properties that bridge the functionality of plastics and ceramics. These novel nanocomposites should benefit important sectors of the Ontario economy, like the automotive, packaging, coatings and energy for instance. The method developed has high productivity and can be implemented in commercial manufacturing in Canada or worldwide.

Project_Title: Rehabilitation of Structures with Prestressed Carbon Fibre Reinforced Polymer Reinforcement
Project_Description: To increase the service life of Ontarioâ€™s Infrastructure, the research will comprise an interactive development approach on the use of carbon fibre reinforced polymer tendons in rehabilitation or new constructio

Project_Title: Support for XML & XQUERY in Reltional Databases
Project_Description: The research pursues a novel approach to implementation techniques of the XQuery language, a W3C standard for querying XML documents.  The proposed approach is layered on top of standard database systems in an attempt to leverage considerable investments in existing technology by major database companies such as IBM, Oracle, and Microsoft.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project_Title: Laser Welding of Advanced High Strength Steels for Automotvie Applications
Project_Description: This study on laser welding of advanced steels aims to improve understanding of how welding conditions affect joint quality and will have a real impact on Ontarioâ€™s automotive manufacturing industr

Project_Title: NMR Investigation of the Interactions between Amyloid Inhibitors & Prions
Project_Description: Our goal is to elucidate the mechanism of action of amyloid inhibitors.Â  Amyloids are linked to several neurological disorders and the PREA will help us advance significantly towards this aim

Project_Title: The Origin & Evolution of HIV-1 & SIVcpz; when, where & how?
Project_Description: When, where and why the worst human pandemic began remains unsolved.  Through the use of archival gene sequences from the earliest known HIV-1 cases we propose to shed light on the timing, tempo and mode of HIV evoluation since its stransfer to humans.

Project_Title: Metabolic Adaptations to Chronic Hypoxia
Project_Description: Chronic hypoxia is characterised as inadequate oxygen supply to tissues either by disease or environmental conditions.Â  This research will investigate how hypoxia changes the metabolic properties of skeletal and cardiac muscle

Project_Title: Role of Microbial Infections in the Pathogenesis of COPD
Project_Description: The proposed research investigates novel experimental paradigms and therapeutic approaches in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

Project_Title: Resource-Constrained Testing of Systems-on-a-Chip
Project_Description: The research supported by this PREA award aims to enable a faster transition to smaller and faster electronic systems by improving the reliability and implementation cost of digital integrated circuits.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project_Title: Representation of Vegetation-Climate Feedbacks in Earth System Models
Project_Description:
Dr. Sharon Cowling is an Assistant Professor in Ecological Climatology
at U of T. Her research interests focus on better understanding the
importance of vegetation processes for modelling past, present and
future changes in climate.

Project_Title: The Shilimate pathway in P. falciparum
Project_Description: Dr Dinesh Christendat is a biochemist in the Botany Department at the University of Toronto.  He is studying the shikimate pathway in plants and microbes for the development of novel herbicides, anti-malarial and anti-bacterial drugs.

Project_Title: Improved Human-Computer Interactions Using Multi-Sensor Speech Processing
Project_Description:
Parham Aarabi, Associate Professor of Electrical and Computer
Engineering at the University of Toronto Examples of his recent research
include reliable internet image search algorithms and reconfigurable
speech recognition hardware.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project_Title: Genetics & Ecology of Social Evolution
Project_Description:
Aneil Agrawal is an Assistant Professor and Canada Research Chair in the
Department of Zoology at the University of Toronto.  He uses both
empirical and theoretical approaches in his research on the evolution of
social systems and modes of reproduction.
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development

Project_Title: Discovering Genes Responsible for Human Disease Using Genome-Wide Mutagenesis
Project_Description:
Dr. McKerlie is a veterinary pathologist and phenogenomic scientistis
working on three project areas that are all linked by a common goal to
discover and understand the function of genes that cause disease in
children and adults.

Project_Title: Investigating the Causes of Lou Gehrig's Disease as a means to Developing Effective Treatments & a Potential Cure
Project_Description: Dr Janice Robertson, Centre for Research in Neurodegenerative Diseases. Her research utilizes a multidisciplinary approach to investigate the causes of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) including protein-biochemical analyses, molecular-cell biology techniques, transgenic mouse technology and analysis of human ALS pathological material.

Project_Title: Biochemical Mechanisms of Mismatch Repair during Somatic Hypermutation
Project_Description: Dr. Alberto Martin, a University of Toronto graduate, returned to Toronto after a postdoctoral fellowship in New York to work on mechanisms of antibody formation and their involvement in cancer.

Project_Title: Enhancing Retroviral Gene Therapy
Project_Description: Dr. Tailor is a Scientist at The Hospital for Sick Children. His research includes understanding how retroviruses enter cells and cause disease, and modifying retroviruses to cure human diseases

Project_Title: An Approach to Developing Treatments for Parkinson's Disease
Project_Description:
Dr. Tandonâ€™s laboratory investigates the interactions of disease-causing
proteins in Parkinsonâ€™s disease, with other cellular factors in order to
understand the biological cascades that lead to neurodegeneration.
Identification of aberrant interactions will provide a rational basis
for the development of therapeutics that aim to prevent the assembly of
pathological complexes before neurons become irreversibly dama

Project_Title: Mechanisms of Ischemic Brain Damage
Project_Description:
Dr. Tymianski is a world-renowned researcher focused on finding a cure
for stroke. He is a leading neurosurgeon, treating patients with complex
brain tumors and brain vascular malformations.

Project_Title: Uncoupling the D1-D2 receptor interaction: In search for the novel therapeutic target for antipsychotics
Project_Description: Schizophrenia is a severe, chronic and debilitating mental disorder that occurs in one out of every 100 people. Symptoms include delusions, hallucinations, disorganized thinking and cognitive dysfunction. Current anti-psychotic drugs block D2 dopamine receptors in the brain to alleviate some symptoms, but also negatively affect the D1 dopamine receptors, which are coupled to the D2 receptors. Dr. Fang Liu at the Centre for Addiction and Mental Health is leading a team which aims to create a peptide to uncouple the D1 and D2 receptors. This will enhance the positive pharmacological effects of the anti-psychotics, without their side effects.
Lead_Research_Institution: Centre for Addiction and Mental Health

Project_Title: Low Oxidation State Chemistry: Unique Routes to New Phosphorus-Containing Polymers
Project_Description: Polymers - materials formed by combining different elements - are one of the most abundant and useful materials in the world, primarily because their versatile properties lend them to many industrial and domestic applications. Dr. Charles Lloyd Bergstrom Macdonald and his research team at the University of Windsor will focus on synthesizing and developing new families of phosphorus-containing polymers (plastics.) These new polymers will have substantially different properties from conventional, carbon-based plastics that are currently used for everything from packaging food to making foam mattresses. Some of the new materials Dr. Macdonald and his team are developing may be flame-retardant and others may eventually help the environment by identifying and removing metal pollutants.

Project_Title: Design and Synthesis of Molecular Magnets and Switches: Materials for the Future
Project_Description: Dr. Kathryn Preuss of the University of Guelph will use an Early Researcher Award to develop molecular magnets and switches to be used one day as key components in quantum computers. The new designs may be exploited in the future development of â€œspintronics,â€ an emerging field of nanoscale electronics that takes advantage of the propensity of molecules to spin. Dr. Preuss and her team are also working on new, molecule-based materials such as light-weight, high-tech coatings with a memory that allows the molecules inside to interact or â€œtalkâ€ to each other. This changes the material so its magnetic, conductive and optical properties can be manipulated to fit specific technological appli
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project_Title: Proteins supermolecular assemblies at interfaces
Project_Description: Consumer interest in soy-based foods continues to grow. But, while nutritional studies show the health benefits of soy protein, food product developers still face problems with soy instability (particularly in emulsification), changes in texture and flavour, or unpredictable processing behaviour when incorporating soy protein into processed foods. With an Early Researcher Award, Dr. Milena Corredig and her team at the University of Guelph will use soybean protein as the model to study how macromolecules (very large molecules found in proteins) absorbed at the interface of oil and water affect the stability of emulsions. Their work will help to expand the use of healthy soy protein in emulsified foods.
Keyword: bio-economy, climate change

Project_Title: Neurobiology of Social Cognition, Social Learning and Social Memory in Rodents
Project_Description: In recent years, the increasing incidence of the diagnosis of autism has put the spotlight on behavioural science.  With an Early Researcher Award, Dr. Elena Choleris and her research team at the University of Guelph will use rodent models (mice, rats, gerbils) to study how the brain processes social information and regulates social behaviour. The goal is to understand the neurobiological basis of human psychiatric disorders that affect social behaviour, including autism, social phobia, schizophrenia and depression. This understanding will help develop drug treatments to support behavioural therapies for these disorders.

Project_Title: Nuclear Magnetics Resonance Study of Materials Exhibiting Heavy Metal-Heavy Metal Interactions
Project_Description: Creating new materials for the future relies on a deep understanding of the properties of their component parts. Heavy metals (gold, silver, platinum, thallium) offer unique and practical applications in a wide range of industries from pharmaceutical production to advanced manufacturing. At the University of Ottawa, Dr. David L. Bryce leads a team of researchers that is applying spectroscopic and quantum chemical methodologies to better understand the properties of heavy metal-based materials. Possible applications include nanoscale optical sensors and functional materials with â€œtuneableâ€ propert

Project_Title: Targeting XIAP for the treatment of acute myeloid leukemia
Project_Description: Acute leukemia is an aggressive malignancy that strikes individuals at all ages.  In adults, most subtypes of acute leukemia have a 2-year survival of <35%.  Therefore, new therapies to improve outcome and overcome chemoiesistance are required.  Dr. Aaron Schimmer and his research team at the University Health Networkâ€™s Ontario Cancer Institute will use an Early Researcher Award to investigate new therapies to improve this survival rate. They will study the over-expression of the X-linked Inhibitor of Apoptosis Protein (XIAP), which is associated with chemoresistance in patients with acute myeloid protein (AML).  Dr. Schimmerâ€™s research will investigate agents that inhibit XIAP which could be used in treatment of the dise

Project_Title: Structural Proteomics of Bacterial Virulence
Project_Description: Diseases are a threat to plants and destroy many crops. Dr. Darrell Desveaux and his research team at the University of Toronto will use an Early Research Award to explore the molecular details of the plant immune system, particularly how plants resist bacterial infection. Designing efficient disease control mechanisms requires a thorough understanding of pathogen virulence mechanisms and how the host responds to attempted infection. Many bacterial pathogens use type III secretion systems to infect and cause disease in hundreds of plant species.  Dr. Desveauxâ€™s work will lead to an understanding of these secretion systems and ways to control plant disease and reduce the use of pesticides that can harm the environmen
Keyword: bio-economy, rural, climate change

Project_Title: The molecular evolutionary basis of night vision
Project_Description: How did humans develop the ability to see at night? Research led by Dr. Belinda Chang at the University of Toronto will recreate the evolutionary transition from cones to receptors (rods) with greatly increased photosensitivity. The project will use bioinformatic methods to better understand the molecular basis of the differences between day and night vision. The insight gained into the mechanisms of vision will help address a wide range of defects and degenerative eye diseases. The research will also serve as a model system for the study of G-protein coupled receptors, which are involved in a wide range of disorders from cancer to substance abuse.

Project_Title: Microtubule proteins in Macrophages and Osteoclasts
Project_Description: Infectious diseases are the leading cause of death in the world. Some scientists believe drug-resistant tuberculosis is a growing threat in Canada. Salmonella and other microbial pathogens are also a major health problem. Ten per cent of Canadian patients infected with salmonella develop arthritis as a complication. Professor Rene Harrison and her team at the University of Toronto will study the two most destructive cell types in animals: macrophages, which are crucial front-line cells in the bodyâ€™s defense against infection and osteoclasts, which cause bone degeneration in diseases such as osteoporosis, rheumatoid arthritis and some cancers. Dr. Harrisonâ€™s research will help to develop treatments for infectious diseases and bone disord

Project_Title: Establishing New Methods For Reliable and Secure Business Process Execution in Distributed Environments
Project_Description: Todayâ€™s large organizations need to securely manage and coordinate the many business processes they conduct through computer systems. These tasks commonly use a system with different types of computers that are widely distributed, sometimes around the world. For example, a manager of an international retail chain may wish to monitor key performance indicators across retail stores and initiate the transfer of inventory from one country to another according to changing demand. Professor Hans-Arno Jacobsen and his research team at the University of Toronto will develop middleware that allows for better scalability to improve business process coordination, business activity monitoring, workload management and job schedulin

Project_Title: Understanding the causes of type 2 diabetes in high risk groups and populations
Project_Description: The global epidemic of adult-onset (Type 2) diabetes has extra relevance in Canada, where aboriginal Canadians and those of Hispanic and African origin are at especially high risk. Dr. Anthony Hanley and his team at the University of Toronto will investigate the causes and associated complications of diabetes in these populations, focusing on the early stages in the natural history of the disease. The study will identify the factors related to diabetes in these populations, providing valuable information that will be used in treatment and prevention programs.

Project_Title: Exploring the Origins of Stars, Brown Dwarfs and Planets
Project_Description: What are the origins of stars, brown dwarfs (objects with masses between stars and planets) and planets? Numerous stars and discoveries in this area in the past decade have produced significant advances in astronomy. The University of Torontoâ€™s Dr. Ray Jayawardhana and his team will use the most advanced optical, infrared and millimeter instruments on the worldâ€™s largest telescopes to continue their research in this area. This project is centered on star formation, with a particular focus on the origin and evolution of sub-stellar objects. Dr. Jayawardhana is involved in the development of three of the most ambitious research facilities of the next decade, including the Thirty Metre Telesc
OIA_AREA: Development and creation of investigation spots

Project_Title: Nano-Silicon Photovoltaics-Solar Electricity
Project_Description: Scientists are searching for solutions to todayâ€™s pressing challenges of ensuring sufficient energy suppies, environmental protection, economic growth, and the need for clean, sustainable energy. Solar energy is the largest potential source of energy for the planet, dwarfing all other sources combined. But the challenge in taking solar electricity (silicon photovoltaics) mainstream is cost. Professor Nazir Kherani and his team at the University of Toronto aim to develop technologies that will cut the cost of solar energy in half. Experts believe that by 2020, solar power could deliver electricity to more than one billion people, and by 2040 it could supply more than one fifth of global electricity need

Project_Title: Large Scale Information Sharing in a Network World
Project_Description: Prof. Nikolaos Koudas of the University of Toronto will use an Early Researcher Award to drastically change the way people search for and locate information. The key research objectives involve the development of new search technology and novel algorithms that aid in performing searches over diverse types of data sources. This new technology can significantly enhance the current keyword-based interface of current search engines.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project_Title: Towards a New International Copyright Norm
Project_Description: Assessment of the legal and economic criticism of copyright and related intellectual norms;proposal of a new norm consonant with Canada's international obligations and the needs of authors, scientists, educators and other users of copyright material, taking account of the growth of P2P file-sharing and the social norms at play.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project_Title: Scalable Interactive Simulation-Based Technology for Distributed Collaborative Virtual Environments
Project_Description: Explore the theoretical and practical aspects of distributed interactive simulation.  The key objectives is to develop interactive simulation based technology for distributed collaborative virtual environments, study the scalability and high performance of our systems as well as the interoperation and composition of large-scale distributed simulation systems and show how distributed interactive simulation technology can be efficiently applied to real-time applications.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project_Title: Experiments on the Origin & Fate of Biodiversity
Project_Description: Why are there so many species? This research seeks to answer this question by following evolution in real time using microbial populations.
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development

Project_Title: Thrombophilia: Novel Disease Associations & Therapeutic Interventions
Project_Description: Research aims to answer important questions about thrombophilia. Such as; are people with thrombophilia at risk of other complications (pregnancy complications or hemodialysis catheter clots)? What therapies (if any) should be given to people with thrombophilia in order to prevent these complications?

Project_Title: The Development of Solar/Optical Tools for use in Solar Energy and Energy Efficiency Applications
Project_Description: The proposed research is in the development and application of new materials to solar energy systems. This will play a major role in reducing our individual energy demands.

Project_Title: Use of DNA Replication Proteins as Biomarkers for Early Cancer Detection
Project_Description: I plan to identify proteins that can be used as biomarkers for early cancer detection, and characterize their potential as drug targets for anti-cancer therapies.

Project_Title: The Use of Information Technology to Measure and Improve Health Care Safety
Project_Description: According to recent estimates, more than 24, 000 Canadians die annually from medical errors. Dr. Alan Forsterâ€™s research team will develop new methods of measuring healthcare safety. These methods will help us to understand the causes of safety problems and guide priority setting. Information-technology solutions will be used to develop interventions designed to improve car

Project_Title: Treatment and Survivorship in Young Adults with Cancer
Project_Description: Although young adults (20-44) represent about 10% of all cancer patients in Canada, there is a lack of research aimed at understanding survivorship in this group. Dr. Nancy Baxter and a team at St. Michaelâ€™s Hospital will use existing cancer registry and administrative data to identify young adults with cancer. Comparing these patients with a group without cancer, they will determine the effects of treatments such as surgery, chemotherapy and irradiation on the risk of developing further cancers and fertility. They will also examine patient compliance rates with surveillance and screenin

Project_Title: Human Motor Control: Implications for Stroke Recovery
Project_Description: With stroke affecting more than 50,000 Canadians and costing more than $2.7 billion in health care expenditures each year, there is an urgent need for innovative approaches to reduce disability and prevent subsequent stroke. At the University of Waterloo, Dr. Richard Staines and his team of researchers will study how central nervous system networks adapt following a brain injury. This data will be used to assist in the development of new treatments and training devices that will improve the sensorimotor control of patients. Sensorimotor control is an essential component of aspects of daily living such as washing, dressing, and meal preparation.

Project_Title: Mobile Genetic Elements as Facilitators of Genome Evolution
Project_Description: The human genome is predominantly composed of â€œjunk DNAâ€, DNA that does not appear to have any apparent function. Some junk DNA consists of discrete units called mobile genetic elements that function to promote their own distribution within the human genome. In doing so, however, mobile genetic elements can profoundly influence genome integrity and human health by altering vital genetic sequences. Dr. David Edgell will use an Early Researcher Award to examine the molecular mechanisms that mobile genetic elements use to promote their spread, and the consequences of their insertion into genes. This research has implications for understanding the structure and function of the human gen

Project_Title: Meteoroid Observation and Analysis: Investigating our Solar System's Early Ingredients
Project_Description:
Observing the early â€œingredientsâ€ that formed our solar system
Meteoroids are the last remaining crumbs of the original ingredients that became our solar system.  They contain a wealth of information about the birth of our solar system, the origin of life and the possibility that life exists elsewhere.  Dr. Paul Wiegert and his research team at the University of Western Ontario will use an Early Researcher Award to staff an automated video meteor observing system being built near London, Ontario.  Over the long term, the station will provide a database of information on meteoroids near the Earth, and allow a better assessment of any threat they may pose to satellites and spacecr

Project_Title: Development and Application of Novel Nanomaterials for Fuel Cells
Project_Description: World demand for energy is expected to double by 2050.  Fuel cells are an efficient form of clean energy that is expected to play a dominant role in the future.  But the cost remains high.  Dr. Xueliang (Andy) Sun at the University of Western Ontario will use an Early Researcher Award to apply nanotechnology to address the challenges posed by fuel cells.  He and his research team will use three-dimensional nanowire-based fuel cell electrodes that are ideal materials for providing higher catalytic performance and longer operational life for fuel cells.  The goal of this project is to produce cheaper fuel cells that could be used in the automobile industry.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project_Title: Adaptation to Low Oxygen in Cardiovascular Disease
Project_Description: Cardiovascular diseases are the second leading cause of death in Ontario. Cardiac arrest and stroke are the result of clots that block the flow of blood (ischemia) to portions of the heart and brain. During ischemia, cells sense a decrease in oxygen (hypoxia) through a process called protein hydroxylation. Dr. William Winmore leads a team of four researchers at Carleton University who will examine the role of hydroxylation in ischemic cardiovascular diseases and stroke.  Understanding this cellular response to hypoxia will provide insight into how cells recover from ischemic stress. Over the longer term, this will lead to new therapies for patient recovery from cardiac arrest and stroke.

Project_Title: Surgical Training Systems with High-Fidelity Haptic Feedback
Project_Description: With its reliance on animals, cadavers, human volunteers and patients, conventional surgical training has obvious disadvantages. Animals have different anatomies than humans, cadavers donâ€™t provide physiological responses, and it is risky for students to practice on patients. Dr. Peter X. Liu and his team at Carleton University plan to change that with the development of a new Virtual Reality and Haptics-based Surgery Simulator (VHSS). Dr. Liuâ€™s team will focus on developing the haptic (touch and feel) interface for the simulator, which will be built by an industrial partner. The simulator will train medical staff in cricothyroidotomy, a subtype of a tracheotomy which is a common (and life-saving) surgical procedure. Students will palpate the virtual patient, use virtual instruments to make an incision and insert a virtual tracheotomy t

Project_Title: Studying and Applying Quantum Effects in Superconducting Devices
Project_Description: Superconducting quantum interference devices (SQUIDs) are currently the most sensitive sensors of magnetic fields. For example, a SQUID can detect a change of energy as much as 100 billion times weaker than the electromagnetic energy that moves a compass needle. Dr. Jan Kycia is leading a research team at the University of Waterloo that is dedicated to making these devices even better, by studying the intrinsic noise that is currently a significant obstacle for their use in quantum computing. The research will also produce new measurement techniques that could be used in everything from medical scans to mineral exploration.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project_Title: Multiagent Negotiation Mechanisms for Resource-bounded Environments
Project_Description: In the past, designers of computing systems told users how things were to be done. Those who didnâ€™t follow the rules were greeted with an â€œerrorâ€ message. The Internet has brought high-powered computer systems to the home, serving millions of different users with unique and diverse needs. Using artificial intelligence, game theory and mechanism design, Dr. Kate Larson and a team of researchers at the University of Waterloo will design protocols that are capable of serving users in a unique way. The research will be of assistance in a wide range of information technology applications, and will be especially useful for e-commerce applica

Project_Title: Efficient Quantum Algorithms and Protocols
Project_Description: Experimental prototypes of the quantum mechanical computer have already been built, and it is only a matter of time before they will process billions of calculations simultaneously. While this tremendous increase in computing power will obviously be of benefit, these same quantum computers could be used to crack the most sophisticated data encryption schemes. Dr. Ashwin Nayak and a team of researchers at the University of Waterloo will devise new protocols for cryptography that use the power of quantum computing to solve a variety of problems in statistical physics and to ensure the strongest possible security.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project_Title: Molecular Devices for Nanomedicine and Biology
Project_Description: Nanotechnology (manipulating materials on an atomic scale) is revolutionizing a wide variety of fields, including manufacturing, electronics and devices. In nanomedicine, a variety of nanodevices that are triggered by light, chemicals or electrochemical stimuli have been developed, but the two worlds of artificial machines and biological systems remain separate. Dr. Anne Petitjean leads a team at Queenâ€™s University that will examine possible interactions between these artificial devices and nature. Their research focuses on bio-targeting nanodevices that aim to change the shape of DNA. The work will help develop new anti-cancer drugs and deepen understanding of existing drug

Project_Title: Quantum Measurement in Nanostructures
Project_Description: Nano-electrical-mechanical systems (NEMS) are tiny moving devices (a few atoms across) that offer the potential to measure the mass of a single molecule. NEMS devices promise increased speed and sensitivity as sensors for the medical, automotive and semiconductor sectors. Dr. Robert Knobel leads a team at Queenâ€™s University that will use NEMS at low temperatures to study the quantum limits of measurement. This research could answer fundamental physics questions and lead to sensors and measurement techniques far beyond the limits of todayâ€™s technol

Project_Title: Understanding the Molecular Mechanism of Tumor Suppressor Gene LATS1 in Cancer
Project_Description: Cancer affects one in three Ontarians. Mounting evidence strongly suggests that the loss of tumor suppressor genes may be responsible for the development of cancers. Dr. Xiaolong Yang and his research team at Queenâ€™s University will explore the roles of a novel tumor suppressor gene (LATS1) in cell activity during the formation and invasion of tumors. Their work will increase understanding of the roles of tumor suppressor genes and provide valuable information for new diagnosis and treatment protocol

Project_Title: Development of Engineered Cartilage Suitable for Joint Repair
Project_Description: About one in 10 Ontarians suffers from cartilage degeneration, and with the aging baby boomer population, the numbers will continue to rise over the next few years. Dr. Stephen D. Waldman leads a team at Queenâ€™s University that will develop functional tissue that can be used to repair cartilage defects, and avoid the use of synthetic joint replacement devices such as artificial knees and hips. The researchers will grow cartilage tissue and create implantable materials for cartilage repair. The potential market for tissue-engineered cartilage is estimated at over $1 billion worldwid

Project_Title: Mechanistic Studies of Radical Chemistry Relevant in Biology
Project_Description: A chemical mechanism called radical oxidation is a common factor in almost every human degenerative disorder, from heart disease to cancer to Alzheimerâ€™s. Dr. Derek A. Pratt leads a team of researchers at Queenâ€™s University that will study the oxidation of biological molecules (generally involving free radicals) to develop a means of controlling or preventing these reactions, for both medical and industrial purposes. This research has broad implications for medicine and also in the energy, materials and agriculture sectors of the Ontario econ
Keyword: rural

Project_Title: Impacts of the Round Goby, a New Invasive Species in Lake Ontario's Ecosystem
Project_Description: The bottom-feeding round goby invaded Lake Ontario in 1998, after being introduced to other Great Lakes by trans-oceanic ships. Little is known about the impact of this rapidly multiplying fish that feeds on mussels that can accumulate large amounts of toxins. Dr. Sigal Balshine leads a research project that examines the effects of this invasive species on native fish and the spread of PCBs and other toxins in Lake Ontario. The work will provide key insights into the process of species invasion and its impact on conservation measures.

Project_Title: Wireless Optical Communication Systems
Project_Description: Wireless networks that use optical radiation offer users a high-speed, secure link, which unlike other media, is free of spectral or wavelength licensing issues. Dr. Steve Hranilovic and a team at McMaster University are developing theory, algorithms and prototypes to allow high-rate data transmission on indoor wireless and outdoor free space optical channels. Techniques developed will greatly improve both the rate of data transfer (up to a gigabit per second) and network ranges. The technology will allow extensive distribution of broadband services in both urban and remote communities, without the expense of constructing extensive fibre networks.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Keyword: rural

Project_Title: Understanding the Interaction of Sexually Transmitted Viruses in the Female Genital Tract
Project_Description: Sexually transmitted infections (STIs) are a leading cause of death worldwide and a burden on health care systems. Clinical evidence shows that women are more susceptible than men to sexually transmitted viruses such as herpes, human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) and chlamydia.  But very little is known about why this is the case.  Dr. Charu Kaushic of McMaster University will use an Early Researcher Award to investigate how the female genital tract interacts with STI viruses and the immune system. The research done by Dr. Kauschic and her team will have an important impact on womenâ€™s reproductive health by helping to develop new vaccines, the most cost-effective way to control ST

Project_Title: Investigations in the Theory of Numbers
Project_Description: Number theory is a major branch of modern mathematics that originated in ancient times with attempts to solve basic problems such as determining prime numbers. Today, number theory plays a crucial role in technology, such as the public-key encryption systems used to secure information exchanged over the Internet. Dr. Romyar Sharifi leads a team of researchers that is exploring intricate connections among a wide variety of mathematical objects. Their work in pure mathematics is vital to future scientific and technological advances in Ontario.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project_Title: The Importance of Social Community in Determining Political & Social Values
Project_Description: Using advanced statistical models, this project examines the role of social contextâ€”e.g., community characteristicsâ€”on social attitudes. It promises to affect how we address social issues related to various inequalit
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development

Project_Title: Neural Basis of Visual Behaviour
Project_Description: "This research project will examine how our brain endows us with self-control. The expected results will advance our understanding of neurological and psychiatric disorders, including schizophrenia, and provide the basis for developing better therapies."

Project_Title: Mathematical  Control Theory for Difficult to Control Mechanical Systems
Project_Description: Dr Lewis's research concerns the control theory for mechanical systems, such as might arise in robotic or aerospace applications. His particular interests are in those systems for which no known techniques are applicable. By studying such systems, Dr Lewis expands the boundaries of what is technologically possible.

Project_Title: Evaluation of the Sustainability Implications of Bioenergy Alternatives for Canada
Project_Description:
Heather MacLean, Assistant Professor in the Department of Civil
Engineering at University of Toronto.  She received her Ph.D. from
Carnegie Mellon University in 1998. Her research evaluates the
environmental and economic implications of alternative energy systems,
focusing on alternative-fueled vehicles.
Keyword: Bio-economy, climate change

Project_Title: Writing Systems: their classification, structure and use
Project_Description:
Gerald Penn is an Associate Professor of Computer Science at the
University of Toronto. Professor Penn will use his PREA to study the
automated acquisition and classification of writing systems, the
associations between languages and scripts, to improve the quality of
multi-lingual search engines.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project_Title: The Role of Slit/Robo Signalling Pathways in Kidney Inflammation
Project_Description: If you understand all of the world's languages, you still could not read many of the texts on the world wide web, because they are written in languages, like Hindi or Arabic, in non-Roman scripts with non-standard electronic encodings of their characters. This modern nuisance reflects a dilemma as ancient as writing itself: the relationship between written words and their pronunciations has an internal logic to it, but their logic is different in every individual case - even among languages that use the same script. This project proposes to study the automated acquisition and classification of writing systems, the associations between languages and scripts.

Project_Title: Neurobehavioural Research Pgm. In HIV/AIDS
Project_Description:
Dr. Rourke's research focuses on understanding how HIV and AIDS can 
affect cognitive (brain) functioning, the extent to which impairments in 
cognitive abilities can lead to changes in everyday functioning and 
health-related quality of life, and the potential benefits of cognitive 
rehabilitation interventions to ameliorate these changes.

Project_Title: Potential Treatments for the Cognitive Decline Produced by Alzheimer's Disease
Project_Description:
Dr. Josselyn received her PhD from the University of Toronto.  Following
post-doctoral training at Yale and UCLA she joined the Hospital for Sick
Children and the Department of Physiology at U of T.  Her research is
dedicated to understanding the neural basis of cognitive function and
dysfunction. Specifically, her lab is examining potential treatments for
memory impairments such as those caused by Alzheimerâ€™s diseas

Project_Title: Investigation of Helicobacter Pylori in Host Cells
Project_Description:
Dr. Nicola Jones is a clinician scientist at Sick Kids. Her research
focuses on delineating mechanisms by which Helicobacter pylori, a bacterium which causes ulcers and gastric cancer, evades host responses to promote chronic infection and disease.

Project_Title: Shape and Motion Capture of Complex Physical Systems
Project_Description: Aaron Hertzmann is an Assistant Professor of Computer Science at University of Toronto. He received a PhD from NYU in 2001.  His researches computer animation, computer vision, and machine learning.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project_Title: Spatial Coordination of Immune Responses within the Lymph Node Organs
Project_Description: Canadians have one of the highest rates of multiple sclerosis in the world, and there are no satisfactory treatments for this chronic and debilitating disease. Dr. Jennifer Gommerman and a team at the University of Toronto will test a new hypothesis for treating auto-immune diseases, using experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis,  a rodent model of multiple sclerosis. The team has developed technology to observe immune responses in real time, and will use it to determine which aspects of the lymph node environment must be manipulated to treat autoimmune diseases.

Project_Title: Origin of Planets
Project_Description: The discovery of extrasolar planets, or planets outside Earthâ€™s solar system, has motivated scientists to understand their origins. Dr. Roman Rafikov at the University of Torontoâ€™s Canadian Institute for Theoretical Astrophysics (CITA) will use high performance computers to investigate the formation of terrestrial planets (planets that resemble the Earth) such as Mercury, Venus and Mars, as well as â€œgas giantsâ€ such as Jupiter.  Dr. Rafikovâ€™s research will produce software that can be used by other groups studying planetary studies. The results are expected to significantly improve our understanding of how planets form and will have immediate industrial application by contributing to the development of information and communication tec

Project_Title: Reducing rates of violence within Canadian Families
Project_Description: Family violence is a serious problem in Canada. Each year, 45 of every 100,000 children are involved with child protective services, and an estimated 7-8 % of women and men have experienced some type of violence in their intimate relationships during the past five years. At the University of Toronto, Dr. Katreena Scott and a team of researchers aim to reduce rates of violence within Canadian families through prevention. A variety of research and intervention methods will be developed for children, families, educators and professionals. Research areas include intervention with abusive fathers, assessment of child maltreatment among professionals, and intervention with intimate partner violence.
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development

Project_Title: Exploring the relationship between pigmentation and vitamin D levels in individuals of diverse ancestry living in the Greater Toronto Area
Project_Description: Synthesized through the skin by the action of ultraviolet rays, vitamin D plays a critical role in bone and cell growth and immune function. A lack of vitamin D has been linked to diabetes, cancer, multiple sclerosis, and hypertension. These diseases have a greater incidence at higher latitudes in countries like Canada, which also has a high prevalence of vitamin D deficiency. Dr. Esteban J. Parra and his colleagues at the University of Toronto will evaluate the relationship between skin pigmentation and vitamin D levels in the diverse population of the Greater Toronto Area, and recommend levels of supplementation required.

Project_Title: Rational Mechanobiological-based design of tissue engineered heart valves
Project_Description: Cardiac valve disorders are among the most frequent causes of heart disease. Treatment usually involves surgical replacement of the diseased valve with either a mechanical or bioprosthetic valve. The limitations of these valves have sparked interest in creating living replacement valves that mimic healthy valves. Dr. Craig A. Simmons and a team at the University of Toronto will establish the definition of a â€œhealthy valve cellâ€ and test various biomaterials for their ability to direct adult stem cells to become valve cells. The work will establish design criteria for the next generation of functional tissue engineered val

Project_Title: Early Events in Fibrosis
Project_Description: Fibrosis is the formation of scar tissue, a central process leading to the damage and failure of organs like the lungs, liver, heart and kidneys. Early events in fibrosis include a process called â€œepithelial mesenchymal transitionâ€ (EMT). Dr. Peter Margetts and a team at McMaster University will use models of fibrosis to decipher EMT and define its key processes. Their work could lead to new therapies to prevent progressive organ fibrosis and failure in numerous life-threatening diseases, including renal failure, lung fibrosis, and cirrhosis of the li

Project_Title: Automating Software Composition and Customization: Towards a Next-Generation Web
Project_Description: Advances in information and communication technology mean that organizations can automate their workflow within and outside their companies.  But advances in software have not kept pace, costing businesses billions of dollars a year.  To be competitive, businesses need to automate the ability to â€œinteroperateâ€, or exchange information, with their business partners and customers.  Dr. Sheila McIlraith and her research team at the University of Toronto will develop ways to design and customize software programs so that one organizationâ€™s computer can understand another companyâ€™s software applications and what they do.  The results of Dr. McIlraithâ€™s research could also revolutionize the way we use the web, for example when booking a
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project_Title: A Simple Model for Gene Discovery in the Context of Immune Responses: The Role of Toll-like Receptors and the Origins of Jawed Vertebrate Adaptive Immunity
Project_Description: More knowledge about the human immune system would help in the development of new drug therapies and treatments for illnesses such as leukemia and autoimmune diseases.  Dr. Jonathan P. Rast at Sunnybrook Health Sciences Centre will use an Early Researcher Award to monitor immune responses in sea urchin larvae. The sea urchin larva is an ideal model for this type of work because it is an uncomplicated and very sensitive organism.  Dr. Rast and his research team will investigate the counterparts of genes in the human immune system. The results of this work are expected to provide important new information for the next generation of drugs to fight infectious diseases.

Project_Title: Identification of Novel Genes that Promote Pancreatic Beta Cell Survival
Project_Description: The incidence of Type I (juvenile) and Type II (adult onset) diabetes is increasing in Canada.  Both forms can have complications such as kidney failure, cardiovascular disease or blindness.  Currently, the main limitation of transplanting pancreatic islet cells as a treatment for diabetes is the premature death of the transplanted islet cells.
