Dr. Muiseâ€™s research on these proteins in the gastrointestinal tract will determine their role in the development of this debilitating disease and could lead to new diagnostic tests and therapies for patients with inflammatory bowel diseas

Project_Title: Using Non-Standard Statistical Techniques to Map Genes for Rolandic Epilepsy
Project_Description: Rolandic epilepsy, a complex brain disorder of unknown genetic cause, is the most common form of human epilepsy, affecting as many as a quarter of school-age children who have epilepsy. It usually causes brief partial seizures that involve the face and mouth, at night or during the early morning. These children are at increased risk of reading, speech, and attention disorders. Dr. Strugâ€™s non-standard statistical methodology to identify genes related to Rolandic Epilepsy traits has had excellent initial success. Her team is extending the development of this statistical work to identify genes for Rolandic epilepsy-associated seizures, speech sound disorder, reading disability and migraine. This work could lay the groundwork for prevention or treatment of these disorder

Project_Title: Structural Analysis of a Molecular Proton Pump
Project_Description: Vacuolar ATPases (V-ATPases) â€“ molecules that control the acidity inside and outside cells â€“ are involved in many disease processes, including osteoporosis, renal tubule acidosis, and cancer. Dr. Rubinsteinâ€™s teamâ€™s research into the structure, mechanisms and functions of V-ATPase will help us move closer toward designing drugs that can inhibit the activity of these molecules. The drugs developed as a result of this research will affect the lives of the many Ontario citizens who are living with these d

Project_Title: Restoring Function to the Auditory Cortex in Children who are Deaf
Project_Description:
The auditory parts of the brain are virtually silent in children who are deaf. These areas are vulnerable to take-over by active brain regions. A cochlear implant surgically implanted into only one inner ear may ward off abnormal effects of deafness. Dr. 
Gordonâ€™s proposed studies will use measures of brain activity in children to find effects of childhood deafness, track changes promoted by unilateral cochlear implant use, and determine whether bilateral implants improve brain development more effectively than unilateral implants. These results will help Ontario determine whether one, or two, cochlear implants should be the standard of care for children in Ontario who are deaf in both ear

Project_Title: Novel Ultrasound Methods for the Treatment of Cancer Therapy
Project_Description: Radiation is a common method for treating many kinds of cancer. Dr. Czarnotaâ€™s team recently discovered that radiation can be far more effective when combined with ultrasound. It found that the use of ultrasound is able to perturb the blood vessels in tumours, making them 10 times more sensitive to treatment. Now the team is using cell death detection methods developed in Dr. Czarnotaâ€™s laboratory to monitor the effects of this type of treatment. These research findings could replace standard radiation treatments around the world with an innovative, more potent cancer treatm

Project_Title: Autism Online: The Social and Cultural Implications of the Internet for Individuals on the Spectrum
Project_Description: Ontario has an estimated 70,000 individuals with Autism Spectrum Disorder, a developmental disability that affects social interaction and communication skills. The Internet can reduce or eliminate distractions associated with face-to-face interaction and its use for communication has enabled new forms of agency and communication among people with autism. Dr. Davidsonâ€™s research team will examine how individuals with autism use the Internet to develop new spaces for shared experience. It will generate data about the social implications of the recent growth in online communication among autistic individuals, and assess whether this is leading to the emergence of new autistic cultures. These findings will have important implications for autistic individuals, researchers, policy makers, and other groups who are developing strategies and services with, and for, autistic peopl

Project_Title: Investigating the Impact of Climate Change on Slope Stability
Project_Description: Ontarioâ€™s soil slops are vital components of our environment. We build our towns and cities on natural soil slopes. We also rely on artificial soil slopes to hold our transportation networks, manage our water resources, and protect our environment from industrial waste products. Climate change will likely affect these slopes by increasing the total amount of precipitation and producing frequent and severe extreme rainfall events. OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development

Project_Title: Rational Design of Lubricants through Chemical Simulation
Project_Description: We can extend the usable lifetimes of devices and reduce energy losses due to friction by improving the lubricants for their specific applications. Dr. Mosey and his team are developing methods to chemically simulate realistic models of lubricated contacts, and use these techniques to predict the performance of lubricant systems. Their findings will help us better understand the wear, friction and lubrication of specific applications. It will also guide the rational design of improved lubricants for emerging and existing technologies, which holds significant economic and environmental benefits for Ontario.

Project_Title: Improving Governance and Competitiveness in Ontarioâ€™s Mineral Resource Sect
Project_Description: Ontarioâ€™s mineral resource sector is a vital contributor to our economy. In 2007, mineral production in this province was worth $10.7 billion, and our mining sector employed 24,700 people, most in northern Ontario. A mineral resource sector that values good governance, takes the interests of all stakeholders into consideration and is also innovative, transparent and environmentally responsible, will enjoy a competitive advantage in attracting investment. Dr. Grantâ€™s proposed research project will assess Ontarioâ€™s mineral resource sector and provide comprehensive strategies to improve governance and increase competitiv
Keyword: rural

Project_Title: Towards Integrative Data Analysis for Reliable Predictive Modeling in Biomedical Computing
Project_Description: Todayâ€™s biology research is producing a large amount of information in the form of throughput genetic data, public databases, medical images and much more. But despite his abundance of data, we still have limited knowledge of the complex biological events that underly disease. Dr. Mousavi has taken an innovative integrative approach to describing complex biological phenomena. He is using data from multiple modalities to build computational models that formulate disease, within the framework of prostate cancer and multiple sclerosis. This research could lead to earlier diagnosis of these and other disorders, and discovery of personalized therapie

Project_Title: Contemporary Adaptation in Wild Animals
Project_Description: Evolution is the fundamental process responsible for biological diversity. While differences between species have arisen over millions of years, they result from many small evolutionary changes over single generations. Dr. McAdam is focusing on contemporary evolution in the wild. He is using three different model systems to identify the connections and test the importance of three fundamental factors â€“ food abundance, competition and predation â€“ on contemporary evolution in the wild. His findings will improve our understanding of how evolution happens in nature. They will also help us better predict how organisms will respond to future environmental changes, such as climate change and exotic species invas
Keyword: climate change

Project_Title: Climate change and Disturbance Effects on Boreal Ecosystem Health
Project_Description: Canadian peatlands have stored atmospheric carbon as peat for thousands of years. Today, they hold an estimated 154 gigatonnes of carbon, 95% of which is in boreal and subarctic areas. Climate change currently is threatening these peatlands, forcing them to release carbon back to the atmosphere, which in turn exacerbates climate change. Water tables that have been lowered due to climate change, for instance, are exposing deeper peat to accelerated decomposition and burning during wildfires, making their carbon stocks even more vulnerable to loss through conversion into carbon dioxide. Dr. Turetskyâ€™s research will provide the first insight into climate-mediated disturbances, such as drought and wildfire, on Ontario peatlands. This information will play an important role in helping us sustainably manage one of the globeâ€™s largest terrestrial carbon sto
Keyword: climate change

Project_Title: The Molecular Mechanisms Controlling Sensory Neuron Development, a Foundation for Cell-based Therapy for Neuropathies.
Project_Description: Muscle sensory disorders are frequently associated with cancer, diabetes, HIV infection and congenital ataxias. Cell based therapies to selectively replace the missing neurons without increasing unwanted pain neurons could alleviate these disorders. The development of such therapies, however, requires knowledge of the molecular pathways controlling neuron development and function. Dr. Chen's research team proposes to use the easily accessible simple stretch knee-jerk reflex, to elucidate the molecular pathways that control sensory neuron development and function. It will use electrophysiological recording to assess the functional integrity of this reflex circuit. Researchers will be able to apply their findings to treat other neuropathies that affect sensory neurons, including hearing and vision loss

Project_Title: New Radioactive Probes to Image the Living Human Brain
Project_Description: The Centre for Addiction and Mental Health has created radioactive molecules used around the world to assess people who have psychiatric illnesses. Dr. Vasdev and his team will assess individuals using a medical technique known as Positron Emission Tomography (PET). A person undergoing a PET scan is injected with the radioactive molecules. A special camera then measures the distribution of these molecules, and creates an image of the biochemical processes in the living person. Dr. Vasdev is training students in radiochemistry, a field critically short of qualified personnel. They will join the growing ranks of Ontarioâ€™s highly trained workforc
Lead_Research_Institution: Centre for Addiction and Mental Health

Project_Title: Central Nervous System and Cholesterol Metabolism
Project_Description:
People with cardiovascular disease, diabetes or obesity often benefit from lowering their blood cholesterol levels. Dr. Lam and his team plan to determine whether the 
Central Nervous System (CNS) plays a role in lowering cholesterol production in the liver, which would, in turn, lower blood cholesterol levels. Their research into the physiological and molecular components of CNS sensing may result in new treatments that target molecules in the brain to help lower the blood cholesterol levels in people who have cardiovascular disease, diabetes or obesity

Project_Title: An Integrated Approach for Tumor Marker Discovery for Kidney Cancer
Project_Description: Tests for early detection of kidney cancer are needed. Dr. Yousef is using highly advanced techniques and computer bioinformatic programs to compare the thousands of genes produced in kidney cancer to normal kidney genes. This research could identify new tumour markers that will help detect this disease and predict its aggressiveness and also help more accurately plan treatment and follow up for recurrence of kidney cancer. It will also help us better understand how other types of cancer develop and create new treatments.

Project_Title: Regulation of Centrosome Maturation in Mammalian Cells
Project_Description: All of our cells contain structures called centrosomes. Among other functions, centrosomes play an important role in making sure our chromosomes separate accurately during cell division. Defects in centrosome function are linked to cancer progression and disorders such is polycystic kidney disease and Down Syndrome. Dr. Pelletier will probe the sequenced human genome to identify novel regulators of centrosome function. He will use cutting-edge microscopy techniques to study the most promising candidates in living cells. This work will help us more fully understand their roles in the myriad of functions associated with centrosomes and how, if mutated, these genes affect disease.

Project_Title: Tackling the Childhood Obesity Epidemic- Starting with Mom
Project_Description: Almost 60% of adults ages 18 and over, or 14.1 million Canadians, are overweight or obese. Obesity affects all ages, ethnic and socioeconomic groups, and is harder to treat the longer it is not addressed. Prevention is therefore essential. Current evidence shows that preventing obesity in pregnant women may prevent these women and their children from becoming obese later in life. Dr. Adamo will provide structured physical activity and nutrition programs to overweight or obese women during their pregnancies to determine whether these activities can them avoid excessive weight gain during pregnancy and thus attenuate pregnancy related complications and weight issues in their offspring.
Lead_Research_Institution: Children's Hospital of Eastern Ontario Research Institute Inc.

Project_Title: The Quantum Internet
Project_Description: The application of quantum mechanics to computing and communication technologies is an exciting new field of basic research. It could completely revolutionize these technologies â€“ if it gets past the problem of how to distribute quantum information, which is generally more delicate than classical information, over a network of spatially separated nodes. Dr. Duncan Oâ€™Dell and his team will conduct theoretical research that could help researchers surmount this stumbling block. They will address the problem of transferring photons reliably, and on demand, over a network of optical cavities connected by optical fib

Project_Title: Molecular Genetic Study of the Development of Reproductive System
Project_Description: Dr. Guptaâ€™s laboratory is conducting research on the reproductive system of worms (nematodes) including Caenorhabditis elegans and Caenorhabditis briggsae. This work will help us understand how genes function and interact with each other throughout the amazing series of events that take place from the time an egg is fertilized until it develops into an adult human. The alteration of any interactions in the gene networks that control these events could cause diseases, including cancer. Dr. Guptaâ€™s findings will reveal the basis of such diseases, leading to improved diagnosis and treatme

Project_Title: Toxic or Not? â€“ Protein Interactions in a Bacterial Syst
Project_Description: Amyloids are aggregations of proteins associated with diseases such as Alzheimer's. It was traditionally assumed that amyloids formed when proteins interacted in inappropriate ways, and that these interactions were toxic and caused disease. Now research is suggesting that not all amyloids are toxic, as recently identified â€œfunctional amyloidsâ€ play important roles in diverse biological systems, including skin pigmentation and bacterial development.  Dr. Elliot and her teamâ€™s efforts to understand how amyloid formation occurs in the bacterium Streptomyces coelicolor could help us determine what differentiates a toxic amyloid from a functional one, and, thereby, bring us one step closer to a cure for Alzheimerâ€™s

Project_Title: Understanding the Risk of Microbiological Contamination of Groundwater Posed by the Presence of Fractures.
Project_Description: Groundwater is typically considered a safe source of drinking water. Dr. Dicksonâ€™s research combines field and laboratory scale experiments with computer modeling to identify those situations that might cause water sources to become vulnerable to pathogens.  The results will provide government regulators with better science to guide water protection legislation. This will ultimately protect the public health of Ontarians who rely on groundwater for their drinking water suppl
Keyword: water, groundwater

Project_Title: An investigation of Mechanisms Leading to Drug Induced Weight Gain in Patients with Mood Disorder
Project_Description: Dr. Taylorâ€™s research team is working on developing a better understanding of why the prevalence of obesity among people diagnosed with a mood disorder exceeds that of the general population. Researchers know that people who are taking medication to treat mood disorders, a relatively common mental illness, gain weight as a side effect of the drugs. But what are the exact factors that contribute to weight gain and subsequent physical illness? Dr. Taylor proposes to find out. She is examining patterns of nutrition, physical activity and metabolism in individuals being treated for a mood disorder. This work will help individuals who are taking medication to treat mood disorders avoid obesit

Project_Title: The Evolution of Sex Determination in Frogs.
Project_Description: Dr. Evansâ€™ research on sex determination and sex chromosome evolution in frogs will constitute a step forward in our understanding of genome evolution, genetic variation, chromosomal recombination and genetic mechanisms of reproduction. This research could help learn more about the evolution of the chromosomes that define gender determination in humans and human disorders that relate to sex determination and gene duplication, as well as the impact of environmental pollutants on reproduction. It will also expose members of Dr. Evansâ€™s research team to cutting edge technology, high-throughput data collection and analysis. They will gain made-in-Ontario expertise necessary for the jobs of the future â€“ in bioinformatics, computational biology, and molecular bi

Project_Title: New Phases of Matter and String Theory
Project_Description: Over the last century, scientists have come to realize that gauge theories such as quantum chromodynamics (which encodes the force binding the constituents in atomic nuclei) describe all of the fundamental forces in nature and states of matter. One of the goals of theoretical physicists is to characterize the possible states of matter that could have been formed in the big bang, as well as the new states of matter that can be created in the lab and particle accelerators. Dr. Gomis and his team are developing new theoretical tools to study observables in gauge theories with the aim of identifying novel phases of matter. This work is contributing important theoretical tools, including some from string theory, aimed at predicting previously unknown states of matter, whichcan ultimately be investigated experimentally.

Project_Title: Investigating the Effect of Amidation on the Activity of Antimicrobial Peptides
Project_Description: Antibiotic resistance â€“ the ability of bacteria to develop strains that can resist certain antibiotics â€“ is a serious health care problem related to the widespread use of antibiotics in Ontario and around the world. Dr. Ianoul is researching antimicrobial peptides â€“ substances that could become an alternative to synthetic antibiotics. Project_Title: High Energy Barrier Single-Molecule Magnets for Molecular Electronics
Project_Description: Molecular magnetism, an up-and-coming field in nanotechnology, is the study of magnetically interesting phenomena displayed by molecular materials. More work on how we can isolate and fundamentally understand these materials could open the door to faster and low-powered electronics and higher density data storage. Dr. Murugesuâ€™s research into novel molecule-based magnetic materials will provide new insights into their unique properties. This work will contribute to the important economic area of emerging material

Project_Title: MicroRNA-mediated Translational Control of Biological Timing in Mammals
Project_Description: Our internal biological clocks drive our daily, circadian rhythms in behaviour and physiology, and help us adapt these rhythms in response to environmental change. The internal biological clocks of people who suffer from certain genetic disorders, cancer, bipolar disorder and night-shift work, is often disrupted. Dr. Chengâ€™s research focuses on the role of microRNAs in clock regulation, and aims to decipher the underlying cellular and molecular mechanisms involved. This work could one day help these individuals readjust their internal biological clocks more effectivel

Project_Description: Remembering the past and thinking about the future are two of the most remarkable feats of the human mind. But psychologists know little about its developmental origins and trajectory. Dr. Atance is addressing this gap in knowledge through a series of novel methods she has developed to assess young childrenâ€™s capacity to think about the immediate and more distant future. Her team will also test whether factors such as perspective-taking and inhibitory control help children develop an awareness of the fut

Project_Title: Toward Simple, Efficient Approaches to Nitrogen-Containing Bioactive Molecules
Project_Description: Over 90% of the compounds manufactured and tested by pharmaceutical companies have at least one nitrogen atom in their structure â€“ and the conversion of alkenes, alkynes and arenes into these nitrogen-containing molecules currently requires several steps. Dr. Beauchemin is researching more cost-effective, efficient processes, which would give us shorter and more efficient access to these compounds. This work will provide Ontario with an important new technology, as well as a workforce trained to work in the pharmaceutical or fine chemicals sector

Project_Title: Improving Depression Outcomes Through Better Sleep
Project_Description: At any given time, almost three million Canadians are suffering from serious depression which is often also associated with insomnia. Dr. Carneyâ€™s research is aimed at finding out whether treating both insomnia and depression improves treatment outcomes for those with depression. This work will help her establish the first Cognitive Behavioural Sleep Medicine training program in Ontari
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development

Project_Title: Cognition Throughout the Lifespan: Examining the Aging and Expert Brain
Project_Description: As we get older, our physical and mental systems mature and it becomes important to accommodate these changes so that we continue to understand and appreciate the world. However, with maturity often comes expertise. The positive effects of expertise often offset the negative effects of aging. Dr. Dysonâ€™s research seeks to investigate the extent to which expertise inhibits or facilitates the natural reconfiguration of cognitive processes as a result of aging, using both behavioural and event-related brain recording
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development

Project_Title: Performance Enhancement of Artificial Muscle Actuated Catheter for Biomedical Applications
Project_Description: Dr. Yang and his research team will utilize advanced laser micro-machining, fibre optical sensing and close-loop control schemes to manufacture and control a new generation of active catheters with improved performance. Such micro-catheters can be inserted into the human body and controlled by physicians to diagnose and treat a wide variety of diseases such as strokes and heart attacks in a minimally invasive manner. This could decrease procedural time, reduce complications, and lower treatment cost.

Project_Title: An Immuno-Epidemiological Model for Influenza Vaccine Predictability
Project_Description: Every year many Ontarians contract influenza.  While many recover easily, some become severely ill. As influenza viruses change, usually by mutation, their alterations also increase peopleâ€™s lifetime susceptibility. The flu vaccine, freely distributed in Ontario, targets the dominant annual flu strain, reducing the number and severity of cases. Despite recent advances, prediction of the dominant strain is imperfect. Viral mutation is driven by viral/immune system/vaccine interactions within the body. Dr. Heffernan and her team propose to develop new mathematical models capturing this in-host viral evolution, and create epidemiological models to improve sensitivity to changes in key viral characteristics. Resulting improvements include better prediction of dominant strain and vaccine creatio

Project_Title: Suffer the Little Children:  Understanding the Development of Infant Pain Reactivity and the Impact of Parental Management
Project_Description: Infants do not have the ability to self-report or self-manage their pain and are dependent on their caregivers.  To date, however, infant pain research has largely ignored parent-infant interaction â€“ an important framework in which to understand infant distress. Dr. Pillai Riddellâ€™s innovative research follows parents and infants over the infantsâ€™ first immunization appointments and studies parentsâ€™ patterns of soothing the infant. It will contribute to the reduction of infant suffering by providing longitudinal evidence on how to optimally manage infa

Project_Title: Regulation of metabolic Partitioning and Whole-body Energy Homeostasis by AMPK Activation in Adipose Tissue and Skeletal Muscle
Project_Description: Dr. Ceddiaâ€™s research goal is to reverse or prevent obesity; a major metabolic disorder with rapidly increasing incidence in the Canadian population. Molecular biology, cell biology, and in vivo physiology/metabolism techniques are utilized to study the regulation of energy expenditure and storage under conditions of diet-induced obesity, food restriction, and exercise. Dr. Ceddiaâ€™s research may provide the foundation for the development of alternative therapeutic approaches to treat obesity that are safer and more efficient than the methods that are currently availa

Project_Title: Outflows from Disks of Matter Orbiting Super-massive Black Holes
Project_Description: Matter spiralling into a super-massive black hole heats up and gives off the light called a quasar. We understand only vaguely how observable quasar properties are determined by basic parameters like orientation, mass accretion rate, black hole mass and spin. Researchers believe that winds launched from disks around black holes can affect the evolution of massive galaxies. Dr. Hall and his team will compare in detail the properties of thousands of quasars to wind model predictions.  Research results will guide theoretical modeling and improve our understanding of quasars and their role in galaxy evolution.

Project_Title: Hormonal Regulation of Feeding and Weight Gain in Fish and Rodents
Project_Description: Hormones regulate food intake, blood sugar levels, and body weight of animals. The overall objective and long-term goal of Dr. Unniappanâ€™s research is to identify novel metabolic hormones and elucidate their biological actions. His studies are expected to provide new insights into the possible mechanisms by which novel hormones regulate energy balance in fish and rodents. The results of Dr. Unniappanâ€™s research have the potential to be used to develop new therapies for metabolic diseases including obesity and diabetes, and also to induce growth and increased body weight in cultured f
OIA_AREA: Chemical and biological experimentation for the future

Project_Title: Birdsong as an Indicator of Genetic Diversity and Local Adaptation
Project_Description: Why has the number of songbirds on inhabited continents declined alarmingly over recent decades? Dr. MacDougall-Shackleton and her team are helping us find out. They are studying the role of mate selection and infectious disease on genetic diversity in wild songbird populations within a variety of Ontario geographical areas. Birds that sing local-sounding songs tend to be more similar genetically to the local population, and also more resistant to infection by local parasites than their counterparts whose songs sound less local. Dr. MacDougall-Shackleton will study whether variation in song affects mate selection and reflects genetic differences among populations. Her understanding of the factors that promote genetic variation will add to the worldâ€™s knowledge of evolutionary and conservation biolog
Keyword: climate change

Project_Title: Meteorite Impact Craters on the Earth and Moon: Exploration Strategies and Techniques
Project_Description: Impact cratering is a fundamental geological process that affects all solid planetary bodies and has played an important role throughout Earthâ€™s history, shaping the geological landscape and affecting the evolution of life. Meteorite impacts are destructive, catastrophic events. However, they can also produce positive effects, such as the generation of economically-viable mineral and hydrocarbon deposits, the formation of sedimentary basins that can preserve evidence of climate change, and providing â€œwindowsâ€ into the deep subsurface. Dr. Osinskiâ€™s research will explore the beneficial effects of impact events and develop strategies and techniques in partnership with Canadian industry, for their expl

Project_Title: Use of Auditory Feedback During Speech Production
Project_Description: We use the sound of our own voices to help us speak accurately. Dr. Purcell is determining how the brain makes ongoing use of speech sounds by introducing real-time auditory errors and measuring how our speech changes to compensate. He is also studying the role of the auditory nervous system in processing this auditory feedback. These findings may lead to improved treatments for people with speech and hearing problems as well as better designs for cochlear implants.

Project_Title: Insect Low Temperature Performance in an Era of Climate Change
Project_Description: Low temperature may be one of the key factors limiting insect populations in temperate regions. A change in winter conditions, as predicted by climate change models, may therefore have a substantial effect on populations of both pest and beneficial insects, with consequences for agriculture, forestry and conservation. Dr. Sinclairâ€™s research will take an integrative approach to understanding insect responses to changing winter conditions, investigating the mechanisms responsible for insect success and failure, and putting these into a broader ecological contex
Keyword: rural, climate change

Project_Title: Image Based 3D Modeling from Multiple Cameras
Project_Description: Automatic extraction of the three-dimensional shape of objects is a critical step in a wide variety of applications such as quality control in manufacturing, bio-medical engineering (computer-assisted diagnosis, surgery planning), and special effects in the entertainment industry. Currently, most commercial 3D shape acquisition systems use expensive specialized equipment. An alternative is to extract 3D shapes from image data acquired with cameras. Traditionally, such image-based methods have been unreliable. Dr. Veksler and her research team plan to combine several factors offering an excellent opportunity to improve image-based 3D modeling: the availability of inexpensive cameras, the new generation of fast personal computers, and recent progress in computational algorithms.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Keyword: Artificial Intelligence

Project_Title: A Nanoinjection AFM Probe for Controlled and Site-targeted Nanomedicine on Single Cells
Project_Description: Nanotechnology has been leading a revolution in life science and health care, as demonstrated by newly developed tools or techniques in nanoscales. Control and manipulation at the cellular and subcellular level has always been a challenge. Dr. Yangâ€™s team will develop a nanoscale probe that enables the probing, imaging and detecting of living cells, and the delivery or extraction of molecules into, or from, deep-lying cells. This technique will open a new avenue of nanodiagnosis, nanosurgery and nano-therapeutics at the single cell level. It will have tremendous applications in DNA transfection, drug discovery, gene therapies, and stem cell research and therapie

Project_Title: Mechanisms of Cell Death in the Brain
Project_Description: Cell death contributes to the loss of brain function in stroke and neurodegenerative diseases such as Parkinsonâ€™s, Alzheimerâ€™s and Huntingtonâ€™s disease. Dr. Creganâ€™s research program is focused on identifying the molecules that trigger cell death in the brain and determining how they are activated and function. These cell death regulating factors will be attractive targets for the development of therapies to promote cell survival and maintain brain function in individuals affected by these neurodegenerative con

Project_Title: Computer-Aided Design for Managing the Complexity of Multi-Domain Microsystems
Project_Description: The design of microsystems requires knowledge of multiple engineering principals such as electronics, mechanics, and optics. Currently, computer aided design tools have difficulty addressing the multidisciplinary nature and computational complexity of modern microsystems and are one of the major bottlenecks in designs. Dr. Dounavisâ€™s proposed research will develop advanced modeling and simulation algorithms to reduce the computational complexity of microsystems and create an integrated computer-aided design environment for mixed-signal multi-domain microsystem
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project_Title: Enabling the Nano-Age World
Project_Description: The invention of the transistor came from exploring interface-related phenomena. This innovation generated the multi-trillion dollar integrated circuit industry and enhanced the digital age. Similarly, nanotechnology is poised to advance fundamental research to investigate nanoparticle design. Applications range from electronics to biomedical aspects such as gene delivery and biomedical imaging. Dr. Goncharovaâ€™s research team will explore novel bulk properties of oxide materials to address related interface issues at the atomic scale. At the same time, Dr. Goncharovaâ€™s group will develop model surfaces with controlled biological activity for specific biomedical functions. This fundamental research will help unlock the potential Ontario has to enable the nano-age wo

Project_Title: Understanding and Boosting Anticancer T Cell Responses: An Important Step Towards Developing Effective Tumor vaccines
Project_Description: Although radiation and chemotherapy are widely used in treating cancer, they do not selectively target malignant cells, and have adverse and often intolerable side-effects. Novel treatments that can eliminate cancer cells while sparing normal cells are urgently needed. T cells are an important component of the bodyâ€™s own defence mechanisms to fight cancer. Dr. Haeryfarâ€™s research will reveal why only a limited number of T cell clones can respond to cancer efficiently, and will test the beneficial effects of certain immune-enhancing lipid molecules in boosting all tumour-reactive T ce

Project_Title: Emerging Childhood Vulnerability to Depression: Biological, Emotional, and Cognitive Pathways
Project_Description: Depression is a widespread, chronic disorder with great costs to society. Identifying vulnerability markers is critical, since early identification can lead to cost-effective prevention strategies. Dr. Hayden will use longitudinal methods to examine early childhood depression vulnerability. Specifically, she will examine whether genes, hormones, emotional traits, and cognitive styles predispose children to depression. Dr. Hayden and her team will also examine whether contextual factors, including parenting and life events, exacerbate childhood vulnerability. This research will assist in preventing depression and increase Ontarioâ€™s international stature in this area of researc

Project_Title: Preventing Suicide Among Older Adults: Enhancing Resiliency, Reducing Risk, and Translating Knowledge to Practice
Project_Description: Older adults have high rates of suicide. Dr. Heiselâ€™s research will involve designing assessment tools to enhance detection of risk and protective factors, testing a model of psychological resiliency to suicide risk, testing a psychotherapy adapted for older adults, and developing and evaluating knowledge translation tools to move research into clinical practice. Members of the research team will actively contribute to these projects, developing content and methodological expertise to become Ontarioâ€™s next generation of prevention research

Project_Title: The Neurobiology of Nicotine Addiction
Project_Description: Addiction to nicotine remains a persistent threat to the health and welfare of Ontario. Dr. Lavioletteâ€™s research examines the precise regions of the brain that control how nicotine is perceived as a rewarding stimulus, leading to dependence and nicotine craving. Dr. Laviolette and his research team will use recordings of neuronal activity within the brain to examine how nicotine interacts with brain reward centres, and more importantly how continued exposure to nicotine may induce alterations in these brain pathways leading to chronic nicotine addiction and dependenc

Project_Title: Advances in the Design of Cancer Targeted Molecular Imaging Probes.
Project_Description: Early tumour detection and treatment can increase a personâ€™s chances of surviving cancer. Molecular imaging using isotope-based modalities allows for a non-invasive diagnosis of cancer in its early stages, and could help determine the biochemical properties of a tumour before and during treatment. Dr. Luytâ€™s focus is on the development of an entirely new class of metal-organic radiopharmaceuticals that the medical profession can one day use as molecular imaging agents to target receptors on tumour cell surfaces at a very early stage of the dise

Project_Title: Internal representations of space for perception and action
Project_Description: Our brains combine streams of incoming signals from our vision, touch, hearing and other senses to form internal representations of the space around us that can be used for action. Dr. Blohm at Queenâ€™s University is working on a theoretical and experimental framework that describes how networks of neurons do this â€“ in healthy people, and in people who have suffered a stroke. His findings could to lead better diagnosis, rehabilitation and treatment of neurological impairme

Project_Title: Characterization of turbulent mixing dynamics in large lakes
Project_Description: The Great Lakes contain 20 per cent of the worldâ€™s fresh surface water, yet are under threat from pollution, excessive nutrient loads, invasive species, declining levels and climate change. Dr. Leon Boegman of Queenâ€™s University will use field measurements and laboratory experiments to study currents and turbulent mixing in the Great Lakes and help manage this vital resource bet
Keyword: water

Project_Title: Computational Analysis and Optimization for Greenhouse Gas Reduction in Manufacturing and Innovative Biomechanical Design
Project_Description: Dr. Kimâ€™s goal is to develop computational analysis and optimization tools for manufacturing process design and biomechanical design. These tools will be used to reduce carbon dioxide in the automotive manufacturing process, and optimize the design of artificial knee implant
Keyword: climate change, automobile manufacturing, car, greenhouse gas, carbondioxide

Project_Title: Optimizing the Impact of Persuasive Messages Encouraging Canadians to Participate in Physical Activity
Project_Description: Dr. Amy Latimer at Queenâ€™s University is evaluating messages and communication strategies that encourage people to stick to physical activity guidelines. Her findings will help us better understand how physical activity messages can persuade people to adopt an active and healthy lifestyle. This will improve quality of life for Ontarians and reduce health care cost

Project_Title: Mapping Organizational Assets to Enhance Disaster Resilience: A Salutogenic Approach to Business Continuity Planning
Project_Description: The tsunami and nuclear catastrophe in Japan and the Slave Lake fire in Alberta are salient reminders of the need to build resilient organizations and communities to resist, absorb and recover from the impacts of disasters, such as flooding, fire, chemical spills, severe weather, cyber-terrorism and pandemic. While acknowledging the importance of traditional risk management strategies, this research program introduces an upstream salutogenic approach, using health promotion principles to promote business continuity planning. Community engagement strategies will be applied to explore how organizational asset-mapping can be used to promote collaboration and build organizational resilience, to protect critical infrastructure during disasters.

Project_Title: Discovery of functional aptamers targeting cell receptors (Apta2R)
Project_Description: Why are cancer cells different from normal cells? How can we recognize and remove diseased cells leaving normal cells intact? How can we harness the power of cancer-infecting viruses (oncolytic viruses) to target and destroy cancer cells? In this proposal, I will develop a technology for generating synthetic probes targeted at a desired population of cells. These probes called aptamers will be used to visualize abnormal cells, track their position and eliminate them from an organism. This highly novel approach will bring new insights into fundamental processes involved in cancer development and oncolytic virus action. In addition, we will make new drug candidates for novel cancer therapies based on next-generation oncolytic viruses.

Project_Title: Beyond screening: Towards understanding the effects of mild bilateral and unilateral hearing loss on children in the early school years.
Project_Description: Universal newborn hearing screening (UNHS), implemented in Ontario in 2002, aims to reduce or prevent the negative effects of childhood hearing loss.  More than 40% of early childhood hearing loss presents as mild bilateral or unilateral hearing loss and is considered "minimal".  However, there is strong evidence that many children with minimal loss experience difficulties at school. Prior to UNHS, these children were late-identified (age five years) and little is known about the consequences of minimal loss or preferred interventions when identified in infancy.  This study will examine outcomes at early school-age through standardized measures and parent perspectives. The findings can guide intervention decisions in the early years.

Project_Title: Adaptation in invasive species management.
Project_Description: Invasive species management costs governments billions of dollars annually. Global climate change is predicted to promote the northward migration of harmful invasive species that are currently found only in the United States. Biological control methods, which take advantage of natural enemies to manage invasive species, are appealing because they do not rely on chemical application. However, the introduction of a new species to an ecosystem is not without risks. The proposed research will contribute knowledge about the role ecological and evolutionary patterns and processes play in the ultimate success or failure of a biological control program. The knowledge gained will be used to inform policy regarding the management of invasive species.

Project_Title: Elucidating how attention is controlled by networks of brain cells - Identifying the cellular mechanisms that decide what we attend.
Project_Description:
To focus attention on one stimulus, event, or thought, and ignore the many alternative stimuli available in our environment is achieved in our brains by activating a network of brain cells that is very poorly understood. 

The attention network is composed of those cells that represent that stimulus, which is most relevant for the organism. The same network hosts mechanisms to prevent attention to be distracted by irrelevant, intruding stimuli or thoughts.  
 
Our research aims to unravel the cell mechanisms that identify the relevance of stimuli before we attend to them, and that prevent distraction from irrelevant stimuli â€“ measuring multiple cell activities in the nonhuman primate prefrontal cortex and basal ganglia.

Project_Title: Sensing Botanical Sensoria: An Anthropological Study of Plants in Technoscientific Culture
Project_Description:
This anthropological research project examines how plants are acquiring new status and visibility in contemporary culture, and not just as the green symbols of 
environmentalism. Plant scientists, for example, are unearthing new insights and discovering that plants are active agents that can catalyze ecological relations. At the same time, artists are actively experimenting with plants and using plant-based artworks as a public platform to stage ethical debates. This grant will fund members of my laboratory as I train them to develop and sustain intensive inquiry into emerging "botanical cultures," including the experimental practices and cultural meanings that are shaping the value of nonhuman life in Western technoscience.

Project_Title: Molecular and cellular mechanisms underlying chronic kidney disease
Project_Description: At St Michaelâ€™s Hospital, Dr. Katalin Szaszi is researching the molecular mechanisms behind the origins of kidney disease. She is examining the effects of inflammation-promoting cell stress, as well as a substance produced in the kidneys during injury. Her findings could bring us closer to a cure or better treatment for kidney diseas

Project_Title: Geochemical controls on electron transfer processes, carbon sequestration, and methane production in aquatic systems
Project_Description: In the absence of oxygen, decomposing biomass in bodies of water emits methane â€“ a potent greenhouse gas â€“ into the atmosphere. At the University of Guelph, Dr. Christian Blodau is examining the chemical and physical mechanisms that control the decomposition of biomass in wetlands, lakes, and rivers. His goal is to determine the role of soils and sediments in stabilizing our climate, and the effects of climate change on the nutrients in Ontarioâ€™s freshwater reso
Keyword: climate change, rural, water, methane, carbon sequestation, CCS

Project_Title: Geometry and representation theory
Project_Description: Symmetry is an important mathematical concept: all objects in nature have symmetries. University of Toronto mathematician Dr. Joel Kamnitzer is applying geometric techniques to the study of the groups of symmetries that underlie the structure of elementary particles, in order to uncover new structures important for number theory and mathematical physics. Similar research has resulted in applications that include cryptography for wireless communications.

Project_Title: Towards Greener Skies: Reducing Harmful Emissions from Aircraft through Active Flow Control
Project_Description: At the University of Toronto, Dr. Philippe Lavoie is researching more effective ways to control the flow of air over civil aircraft. He is manipulating the dynamics of airflow around airplanes to produce improved flow characteristics that can reduce drag, structural vibration, noise and harmful emissions. His findings hold great potential for reducing the environmental impact and cost of operating airplanes.
Keyword: climate change, Aerodynamics, aircraft, emissions

Project_Title: Computer-assisted cancer diagnosis and treatment planning
Project_Description: At the University of Toronto, Dr. Quaid D. Morris is developing computer algorithms capable of processing molecular RNA signatures of cancer and normal tissues. The goal is to identify patterns that predict cancer types and their response to drug and/or radiation treatments. This research could, ultimately, improve our ability to match cancer treatments to individual tumours, leading to more effective treatment.

Project_Title: Rational mechanobiological-based design of tissue engineered bone
Project_Description: Dr. Lidan You at the University of Toronto hopes one day to grow living replacement bone tissue that could treat osteoporosis-related fractures, which affect more women in Canada than breast and ovarian cancer combined. She will first establish what a â€œhealthy bone cellâ€ is, and then test different biomaterials for their ability to direct adult stem cells to become bone ce

Project_Title: The Role of End-State Comfort in Planning and Executing Actions in Independent and Social Settings
Project_Description: The University of Torontoâ€™s Dr. Timothy Nevin Welsh is investigating the complex cognitive and neural processes that allow us to move with ease. This research will influence the design of environments and technologies that will benefit those with cognitive and motor disabilities, as well as the general publi

Project_Title: Dynamic microsimulation modelling of urban commercial vehicle operations using electronic on board recorder data.
Project_Description: The University of Torontoâ€™s Dr. Matthew John Roorda is using Global Positioning System data to develop a model of commercial vehicle operations in order to create a decision-support software program. This could provide policy makers with better tools to analyze and predict the impact of public sector decisions on the transportation network, leading to more responsive and effective solution
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project_Title: Charge and energy transfer dynamics in molecular junctions: From fundamentals to functionality
Project_Description: Dr. Dvira Segal at the University of Toronto is developing theoretical approaches and computational techniques to help us better understand chemical processes at the molecular level. Her findings on the basic mechanisms of charge transfer and energy transmission in single molecules could assist in replacing standard electronic semiconductor technology with highly efficient, low cost molecular technology.
OIA_AREA: Development and creation of investigation spots
Keyword: Climate change, energy efficiency, semiconductor

Project_Title: The development of self-regulatory personality in adolescence
Project_Description: The University of Torontoâ€™s Dr. Jennifer L. Tackett is seeking insights into maladaptive personality behaviour, one of the most treatment-resistant forms of mental disorder. Maladaptive personality disorders begin to develop in childhood and adolescence, and by adulthood become deeply ingrained patterns of behaviour. Dr. Tackettâ€™s research aims to better understand both risk factors and resiliencies in youth to inform prevention and treatm

Project_Title: Digital Media and Humanities Synergy: A Model of Heroes and Communities in Pir Sabzaliâ€™s Journey to the Roof of the Wor
Project_Description: The University of Torontoâ€™s Dr. Shafique Nizarali Virani is harnessing digital media and communications technology to share his humanities research with audiences across Ontario and around the worl
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project_Title: A systems-level study of sensory information processing in C. elegans
Project_Description: Dr. William S. Ryu at the University of Toronto isstudying how biochemical and neuronal networks in organisms process and measure sensory information and then adapt to them, in order to  increase their ability to survive.

Project_Title: Identifying the role of skin and vestibular input in postural control
Project_Description: Dr. Leah Rachel Bent at the University of Guelph is investigating which receptors in the skin on the soles of our feet are most important in controlling our posture, as well as how feedback from our soles and our inner ears helps us keep our balance. Her findings could lead to the development of specialized shoe insole devices that would help improve the mobility of people who suffer balance-related problems due to age or other conditions.

Project_Title: Biomimetics of high performance protein fibres
Project_Description: At the University of Guelph, Dr. Douglas Steven Fudge is developing technologies that mimic biological systems in order to build biomaterials that are as good as or better than petroleum-based synthetics. His goal is to make these environmentally-friendly biomaterials from sustainable raw materials without using toxic solvents or generating toxic by-products.
Keyword: bioeconomy, bio-economy

Project_Title: Development of Combined Mass Spectrometry and Laser Spectroscopy Techniques for Bioanalysis
Project_Description: Dr. Rebecca A. Jockusch at the University of Toronto is developing combined mass spectrometric and laser spectroscopic techniques. In addition to providing students with crucial interdisciplinary training within the field of biotechnology, these techniques hold promise for future biological and medical research.

Project_Title: A Novel Approach to Energy Recovery from Slag
Project_Description: Metal manufacturing produces a high-temperature liquid waste, known as slag, which must be cooled in the air or in water, releasing a vast amount of heat in the process. Dr. Mansoor Barati at the University of Toronto is investigating a new approach for harnessing the energy of the waste heat. Energy recovery from slag presents a tremendous potential for both energy savings and carbon dioxide emission reduction.
Keyword: climate change, energy recovery, mining

Project_Title: Understanding how cellular systems are encoded in the genome
Project_Description: Dr. Gary Bader at the University of Toronto is mapping the interactions of the components of the cell using computers. This will help us understand how genes function in cellular processes and what happens when specific genes fail in conditions like cancer, heart disease and autism. This could lead to more timely diagnoses and better treatments.

Project_Title: Program of Drug Safety and Effectiveness Research
Project_Description: Dr. Suzanne M. Cadarette at the University of Toronto is researching how we study the safety and effectiveness of drugs. She is focusing on the safety and effectiveness of osteoporosis drugs, and the impact of non-osteoporosis medications on fracture risk. Her research is a first step towards building a new research and training program that could help Ontario become a world leader in drug safety and effectiveness research.

Project_Title: Role of Nuclear Receptors in Metabolic Disease
Project_Description: While glucocorticoid drugs are widely prescribed to treat inflammation, their long-term use can cause severe complications including the onset of Type II diabetes, osteoporosis and muscle wasting. At the University of Toronto, Dr. Carolyn L. Cummins is working to develop safer anti-inflammatory drugs, leading to improved quality of life for patients taking glucocorticoid drugs and increased health care savings for Ontario.

Project_Title: Developing Novel Uba1 Molecular Therapeutics: Suppressing the Side-Effects of Aggressive Chemotherapy
Project_Description: The University of Torontoâ€™s Dr. Gunning is developing new types of chemotherapy to fight leukemia and lymphomas. He is developing molecules that will inhibit Uba1, an enzyme that helps break down unneeded proteins inside cells. Dr. Gunning proposes that when these molecules are used on cancer cells, they will cause protein â€œtrashâ€ to build up inside the cells, overwhelming and ultimately killing

Project_Title: Algebraic structures in generalized geometry
Project_Description: The University of Torontoâ€™s Dr. Marco Gualtieri is developing generalized geometry â€“ a novel type of high-dimensional space that plays an important role in theoretical physics. This field encompasses a variety of new geometric structures that we are only beginning to understand. Solving such problems would raise the international profile of Ontario mathematicians, positioning the province as a global leader in pure mathemat
OIA_AREA: Development and creation of investigation spots

Project_Title: Inventing Better Tools for Building Molecular Architecture
Project_Description: Dr. Vy Maria Dong at the University of Toronto is devising green strategies for making organic molecules. Her goals are to invent cleaner and more environmentally friendly technologies for pharmaceutical research and manufacturing, and train chemists to become expert at building complicated molecules. This will ultimately enhance Ontarioâ€™s ability to lead in the discovery of new medicines and material

Project_Title: A biomechanical model of fatigue-induced subacromial impingement
Project_Description: Shoulder injuries are increasingly common and associated with long and costly recoveries. At the University of Waterloo, Dr. Clark R. Dickerson is researching the causes of these injuries. He hopes to develop more effective workplace ergonomics, rehabilitation strategies, preventative exercise programs and public education â€“ and ultimately help reduce the occurrence and severity of shoulder injuries in Ontari

Project_Title: Treatment of type 1 diabetes by enhancing islet graft function using a novel gene delivery technique called Ultrasound Targeted Microbubble Destruction to improve islet transplantation success.
Project_Description: According to the Canadian Diabetes Association, there are more than two million diabetic patients in Canada, costing the health care system an estimated $13.2 billion annually. Dr. Jamie William Joseph at the University of Waterloo is investigating the mechanics of insulin secretion in order to develop new and better ways to treat diabetes.

Project_Title: Privacy-enhanced Communication for Internet Users
Project_Description: Dr. Ian Goldberg at the University of Waterloo is working to improve the privacy of online communications, including Web, instant messaging, and email. His research could give people the ability to control the spread of information about their online activities.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project_Title: Mid-Infrared Tunable lasers and VSCELs for bio-chemical sensing
Project_Description: Dr. Simarjeet Saini at the University of Waterloo is developing lasers that can be tuned to the specific portion of the mid-infrared wavelength region sensitive to many environmental pollutants. Such lasers could help detect and measure pollutants such as trace gases in the atmosphere, especially those released by iron and steel processes, semiconductor foundries, auto emissions and livestock.

Project_Title: Exploring Quantum Entanglement as a Resource for Condensed Matter Research
Project_Description: Entanglement describes the ties that bind microscopic particles together across time and space. The goal of Dr. Roger Gordon Melkoâ€™s research is to develop entanglement measures in large-scale computer simulations, opening up new avenues to study novel and important physical phenomena in condensed matter, ultracold atoms, and other quantum materials. This leading-edge research will complement the activities of the world-renowned Perimeter Institute for Particle Physics and Institute for Quantum Computin
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project_Title: Static Verification of Object-Oriented Programs
Project_Description: Dr. OndÅ™ej LhotÃ¡k at the University of Waterloo aims to improve software development tools by integrating precise program analysis algorithms into practical tools. These algorithms will be applicable to mainstream programming languages, usable in real programming tools and capable of detecting programming errors before a program execute
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project_Title: Ultra-deep sequencing for characterizing complex microbial communities
Project_Description: Dr. Josh David Neufeld at the University of Waterloo has developed a microbial gene sequencing technique that can quantify microbial diversity more effectively than other existing approaches. He will use this novel method to identify the factors that govern microbial community composition and diversity in a variety of terrestrial, aquatic and human environments.
OIA_AREA: Chemical and biological experimentation for the future

Project_Title: Pharmacogenetics in Psychiatry: Specific genetic hypotheses for predicting response and side effects
Project_Description: Dr. Daniel Josef Mueller at the Centre for Addiction and Mental Health is studying the genes that help the liver break down antipsychotic and antidepressant drugs. The results could help us find the best combination of drugs and dosages for psychiatric disorders such as schizophrenia and depression. This would lead to better treatment and reduced health care costs in Ontario.
Lead_Research_Institution: Centre for Addiction and Mental Health

Project_Title: Location Based Cognitive Wireless Technologies for Ubiquitous Mobile Health Care
Project_Description: Advanced wireless technologies are seen to have great potential in cost-effective mobile healthcare, by providing real-time remote diagnosis, patient mobility and efficient emergency response. Dr. Wangâ€™s team is primarily focused on overcoming technological challenges associated with mobile healthcare, including cognitive wireless communications, patient monitoring and location tracking.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project_Title: Supermassive Black Holes and Their Host Galaxies: Evolution in Tandem
Project_Description: As galaxies build their stars, huge black holes at their centres grow as quasars. Quasar winds caused by the ejection of gas ultimately stop star formation. At The University of Western Ontario, Dr. Sarah Connoran Gallagher is using multiwavelength data from ground and space observatories to reveal the mechanics of these quasar winds and their impact on their host galaxies.

Project_Title: Hydrothermal Systems on Earth and Elsewhere: Ore Deposits and Oases for Life
Project_Description: Dr. Neil R. Banerjee at The University of Western Ontario is investigating the early origins of life on Earth. His research on water-rock reactions in the seeps and crevices of nutrient-rich lavas has deepened our understanding of the evolution of oceanic crust through billions of years of Earth history and may hold the key to understanding the development of life on Earth and possibly other planets.

Project_Title: Improving Research Efficiency while Preserving Data Integrity
Project_Description: Dr. Dianne Bryant of The University of Western Ontario aims to maximize the efficiency of research in a clinical health care setting. She is developing and evaluating a new research design and evaluating the cost-effectiveness and feasibility of using web-based software to follow up with older adults after joint replacement surgery and determining whether conducting follow-up visits online can improve the wait time for new patients to see the surgeon for the first time.

Project_Title: Organic nanostructured solar cells assembled on large-area transparent and conducting layers of graphene
Project_Description: Dr. Giovanni Fanchini of The University of Western Ontario will investigate how graphene â€“ a single layer of carbon atoms â€“ can be used to create low-cost, printable solar cells that will generate power from sunlight. He is currently focusing on how graphene can integrate with other solar-grade materials and is training highly qualified personnel in graphene nano-optoelectroni
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development
Keyword: climate chage, PV, photovoltaic, solar

Project_Title: GPR54 signaling in human placentation
Project_Description: Dr. Andy Videsh Babwah of The University of Western Ontario is researching how a protein molecule called the GPR54 receptor contributes to a healthy pregnancy. His findings will allow scientists to develop drugs that will help pregnant women experiencing adverse health conditions.

Project_Title: Computational Investigations of a New Class of Advanced Materials
Project_Description: The University of Western Ontarioâ€™s Dr. Viktor N. Staroverov is developing theoretical models and computational techniques to explore electrides, a new class of materials with unusual optical and magnetic properties. His findings could lead to significant advances in imaging technologies used in communication equipment, manufacturing and health car
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project_Title: Advanced Doppler Ultrasound and Particle Imaging for Vascular Disease Studies.
Project_Description: Stroke â€“ frequently caused by a build-up of plaque in the carotid artery â€“ is the third-largest cause of death in industrialized countries. Dr. Tamie L. Poepping, of the University of Western Ontario, is developing techniques that could improve our ability to assess stroke risk, prevent strokes, and determine who can most benefit from costly interventional surger

Project_Title: Understanding breast cancer metastasis
Project_Description: Dr. Alison Lawrie Allan of The University of Western Ontario is building our understanding of the biology of breast cancer metastases â€“ the tendency of breast cancer cells to spread from an initial breast tumor and grow in distant organs. Her research could lead to new, more effective treatments to prevent or target metastatic disease in general and breast cancer metastasis in particula

Project_Title: Social Technologies: Opportunities and Constraints for Value Creation at the Intersection of Socially-responsible Markets and Social Movements
Project_Description: Dr. Oana Branzei of The University of Western Ontario explores how disruptive social innovations can leverage social movements to stimulate more socially-minded business markets, and thereby create sustainable value in Ontario. She will systematically survey how social interactions lead to the emergence and evolution of green technologies in five cities: Toronto, Ottawa, Kitchener-Waterloo, Sarnia and London.
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development
Keyword: climate change, social innovation, green technology

Project_Title: Multiband and Multiprotocol Radios for Cognitive and Green Wireless Infrastructure
Project_Description: At the University of Waterloo, Dr. Slim Boumaiza is working on software-defined radio technology for effective use of radiofrequency spectrum and reduced carbon footprint for wireless networks. Creating software programmable, cost effective and ultra power-efficient radios could help create wireless communication networks that would eventually expand into a universal communication infrastructure.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Keyword: climate change, energy efficiency

Project_Title: Pregnancy complications, perinatal outcomes and use of health care resources in adult survivors of childhood cancer.
Project_Description: Dr. Paul Nathan at the Hospital for Sick Children is creating a comprehensive database of children and adolescents treated for cancer in Ontario over a 20-year period. This registry is expected to become an important resource for examining acute outcomes in children with cancer, and for understanding the long-term physical and psychological challenges faced by the growing population of childhood cancer survivors.

Project_Title: Structural studies of tetherin, a host cell protein that inhibits viral replication
Project_Description: The protein tetherin protects our bodies by preventing cells infected by certain viruses from releasing new virus particles into the rest of the body. Some viruses, however, can fight back. The HIV-1 virus, for instance, has a protein that can overcome tetherinâ€™s protective effect. At the Hospital for Sick Children, Dr. Simon Sharpeâ€™s research on the interaction between tetherin and the HIV-1 virus could lead to new antiviral therap

Project_Title: Proteomics of Staphylococcus aureus response to antibiotics that target cell wall biosynthesis
Project_Description: Extensive use of antibiotics has diminished their effectiveness against Staphylococcus aureus, or S. aureus â€“ a bacteria that ranks as the leading cause of hospital- and community-acquired infections. Dr. Dasantila Golemi-Kotra at York University is investigating the genes that protect the S. aureus cell wall from antibiotics. Her goal is to identify the factors involved in antibiotic resistance, ultimately leading to new ways to fight bacteri

Project_Title: Regulation of Ion Homeostasis in Disease Vector Insects
Project_Description: The larvae of mosquitoes and midges live in the same bodies of water that people rely on for survival. These insects survive by taking in ions through specialized tissues. Dr. Andrew Donini at York University is investigating the ion transport mechanisms, which could lead to ways to control infestations and prevent disease.
Keyword: water

Project_Title: Honey bee genes, behaviour and adaptation.
Project_Description: Dr. Amro Zayed at York University is studying the genetic basis ofhoney bee behavior. He is investigating how genes (nature) and the environment (nurture) regulate social behaviour, the effect of changes in worker behaviour on colony fitness, and the evolution of the genes that control honey bee behaviour. His findings have significant implications, given the honey beeâ€™s role in agriculture and its use as a model for understanding the genetic basis of behaviou
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development

Project_Title: Intelligent Decentralized Signal Processing for Cooperative Green Communications
Project_Description: Dr. Shahram Shahbazpanahi at the University of Ontario Institute of Technology is developing new, more power-efficient architectures for our wireless infrastructure. His focus is on enabling minimal electrical power usage at network nodes and radio spectrum sharing among different user devices, without compromising quality of service.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Lead_Research_Institution: University of Ontario Institute of Technology

Project_Title: Cellular Responses to the Micro-Environment
Project_Description: Dr. Andrew Edward Pelling at the University of Ottawa is creating new micro-environments in which to culture cells. His goal is to create a material that allows regenerative medicine and tissue engineering researchers to grow large numbers of specific cell types on a large scale.

Project_Title: Tapping the genomes of uncultivatable bacteria for antibiotic and anticancer drug discovery.
Project_Description: Many of our best medications are natural drugs that come from cultured bacteria. Dr. Christopher Noyce Boddy at the University of Ottawa plans to access the vast reservoir of natural products produced by the bacteria. His findings will help researchers find new natural product drug candidates.

Project_Title: The Governance of Major Sporting Events: Stakeholder Coordination and Knowledge Transfer
Project_Description: Dr. Milena Madeleine Parent at the University of Ottawa is investigating how stakeholders who support major sporting events, such as governments, the community, sponsors, media, and sport organizations, use and share lessons learned from past experiences. Future organizing committees will benefit from these findings by understanding how to maximize the use of public funds when organizing events.
OIA_AREA: Development and creation of investigation spots

Project_Title: Random Matrices and their applications to Quantum Information Theory
Project_Description: Dr. Benoit V.P. Collins at the University of Ottawa is studying the communication protocols of quantum computers â€“ computers that can process large amounts of data. He is using techniques inspired by an advanced mathematical theory known as Random Matrix Theory. His findings could ultimately lead to the development of large quantum computers, which would be able to process even larger amounts of dat
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project_Title: A New Generation of High Strength, Low Cost Steels
Project_Description: Ontarioâ€™s manufacturing and automotive sectors currently use bainitic steels â€“ strong types of steel that can be stretched or molded without breaking. Dr. Hatem S. Zurob at McMaster University is focusing on a new generation of bainitic steels that would have the same attractive malleability of traditional bainitic steels but a much higher strength level. One of the main challenges to overcome is to ensure that the new steels are easy to weld. Dr. Zurob is working to develop new heat treatments to overcome this challenge and put better made-in-Ontario bainitic steels on the mar

Project_Title: Innovative devices to reduce building damage and improve building occupant safety during an earthquake
Project_Description: Dr. Michael Tait at McMaster University is using reduced-scale model testing and advanced numerical modelling to evaluate innovative devices to protect buildings and their occupants during earthquakes. This research could result in low-cost, reliable, and environmentally friendly devices that will prevent building damage and save lives.
OIA_AREA: Development and creation of investigation spots

Project_Title: Microfabrication and microfluidic technologies for drug-discovery
Project_Description: Developing cures for diseases requires the screening of millions of potential drug candidates â€“ an expensive and laborious process. Dr. Ponnambalam Ravi Selvaganapathy is developing low-cost, automated techniques that hold the potential to speed up this screening process by performing these experiments simultaneously. These techniques could lead to faster discovery of potential drug molecules at a lower cost for a wider range of diseases.

Project_Title: Mechanisms by which Cholesterol Levels are Elevated in Obesity: Roles of Two Fat Tissue Derived Proteins Resistin and Adiponectin
Project_Description: Dr. Shirya Rashid at McMaster University is investigating whether altered levels of two proteins â€“ resistin and adiponectin â€“ secreted by the fat tissue of obese people increase their liversâ€™ production of very-low-density lipoprotein or â€œbad cholesterolâ€. If so, new drugs can be developed to reduce levels in obese people, potentially saving millions

Project_Title: Earlier detection of heart attacks in the emergency room
Project_Description: It can take a health care team up to nine hours and sometimes longer to identify a heart attack. Dr. Peter Kavsak at McMaster University is investigating how to do it within the first 90 minutes in the emergency room. The time savings would get heart attack victims the care they need faster, potentially saving lives.

Project_Title: Biodegradable Nanoengineered Hydrogels for Prolonged and Targeted Drug Delivery
Project_Description: Embedding drugs in hydrogels â€“ water-swollen polymer networks â€“ has unique potential to deliver specific doses of medications to specific areas of our bodies. Current hydrogels, however, cannot effectively deliver drugs for prolonged periods of time, or can only deliver relatively water-soluble drugs. Dr. Todd Ryan Hoare at McMaster University is using nanoengineering to create new types of hydrogels that address these challenges. These new hydrogels could eventually become the foundation of effective and adaptable medications that would enhance clinical outcomes and quality of life for Ontari

Project_Title: Mental Health and Academic Achievement among Immigrant Youth
Project_Description: McMaster Universityâ€™s Dr. Katholiki Georgiades is conducting a study of 165 immigrant and non-immigrant Hamilton youth in Grade 4 to Grade 8. She will compare the mental health and academic achievement of the two groups, and identify both the risk and protective factors for mental health and academic success. These findings will inform the development of policies and programs for immigrant yout

Project_Title: Sustainable Concrete Masonry Building Systems
Project_Description: The Canadian construction industry currently uses millions of tons of cement and natural aggregate every year. Dr. Wael El-Dakhakhni of McMaster University is researching the utilization of industrial byproducts and construction waste to reduce the ecological footprint of concrete block building construction.
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development
Keyword: climate change, waste to energy, concrete

Project_Title: Strongly interacting electrons in low dimensional systems
Project_Description: When many quantum mechanical particles strongly interact with each other, new collective phenomena, which cannot be understood in terms of individual particles, can emerge. Traditional theories based on the assumption of weak correlations between particles have drastically failed in describing the emergent phenomena in many recently discovered materials where interactions between electrons are strong. Dr. Lee is developing an alternative theory to help researchers understand the physical properties of these strongly correlated materials.

Project_Title: A New Look at the Fundamental Limits of Multisource Multicast Communication
Project_Description: In wireless communication, the simultaneous delivery of many different types of data in real time â€“ also known as multicasting â€“ is integral to many current and emerging networked services, including audio and video conferencing, multi-party games, and collaborative multimedia distance learning. McMaster Universityâ€™s Dr. Jun Chen is developing information theories that can lead to better, more efficient multicast technol
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project_Title: How do cells coordinate with growth and division?
Project_Description: Our bodies require a key regulator named Wee1 to coordinate the growth and division of our cells. Dr. Adam Daniel Rudner at the University of Ottawa is studying how Wee1 monitors cell growth and regulates cell division. His findings will help us learn more about why cell growth and division is mis-regulated in many human cancers.
OIA_AREA: Development and creation of investigation spots

Project_Title: Using light to study synapse function
Project_Description: Our brainâ€™s ability to change the strength of our synapses â€“ the tiny spaces across which our nerves send impulses to other cells â€“ underlies our ability to learn and remember. Dr. Jean-Claude BÃ©Ã¯que at the University of Ottawa is investigating the basic functioning of these synapses. His findings will help us understand how our brain controls the strength of our synapses, both when we are healthy and when we a

Project_Title: Defining factors involved in the immune resistance to retroviruses
Project_Description: Our bodies use APOBEC3 proteins to inhibit the infection of retroviruses of human and animal origin. Dr. Marc-AndrÃ© Langlois at the University of Ottawa is investigating how these proteins work and are regulated, as well as how some retroviruses (like HIV) manage to resist control. His findings will help us understand how our immune systems prevent infection and may lead to treatments that will strengthen our immune systems
