Project_Title: Biochemical studies of proteins related to leukemic disorders
Project_Description: Epigenetic markers have been associated with various cancers. Dr. Jean-Francois Couture at the University of Ottawa is studying epigenetic markers with the goal of establishing a molecular basis for controlling leukemia and a structural framework that will help medical researchers develop new molecules to treat this disease.

Project_Title: The role of blood flow in shaping the function and structure of human arteries
Project_Description: Dr. Pyke at Queenâ€™s University is studying how different patterns of blood flow affect the structure and function of our arteries. This work will improve our understanding of human vascular physiology and contribute to the development of strategies to prevent, diagnose and treat cardiovascular disease in Ontari

Project_Title: Structural and Functional Studies of Novel Motor Protein Complexes in Disease-Causing Fungi
Project_Description: Living cells rely on kinesins to distribute their chromosomes evenly and to the right locations when they divide. Dr. John Allingham at Queenâ€™s University is investigating forms of kinesin that are exclusively found in certain fungi to see how they function differently from those found in humans and other animals. The findings could lead to drugs that treat fungal infections by specifically impeding the fungal kinesinâ€™s movem

Project_Title: Neural control of immune system activation
Project_Description: Our bodies need inflammation to protect us against injury and infection. However, inflammation can also cause many human diseases, ranging from Crohnâ€™s disease to multiple sclerosis. Dr. Lomax at Queenâ€™s University is researching the ability of the nervous system to keep inflammation under control. His findings could lead to treatments for several human disea

Project_Title: Investigating the social environmental and behavioural pathways linking socioeconomic status to cardiovascular disease risk across the life course
Project_Description: Could the places where we live or the people we know affect our chances of developing cardiovascular disease? Dr. Douglas Spencer Moore of Queenâ€™s University is examining such questions as whether people are more physically active if they live in a place with more parks, and whether people eat healthier foods if their friends do. His findings could help inform programs and policies that contribute to the health of all Canadian

Project_Title: Investigating biogeochemical molecular scale processes of mine wastes and ecological remediation technology
Project_Description: The University of Windsorâ€™s Dr. Christopher G. Weisener is studying metals in mine waste environments that have undergone treatment using sustainable ecological remediation technologies. He will see whether these wastes remain stable and do not release toxic metal into the environment. This work will contribute to Ontarioâ€™s expertise on mine waste restoration and to the commercialization of sustainable remediation technology. It will also train much-needed professionals on sustainable technologies in Onta

Project_Title: Nanostructured Materials for Advanced Optical Applications via Synthetic Control and Self-Assembly of Nanoscale Building Blocks
Project_Description: Dr. Vladimir Kitaev at Wilfrid Laurier University is synthesizing nanostructured materials made of uniform nanoscale building blocks. The main structural units of these materials are plasmonic metal nanoparticles including gold and silver, which provide them with unique optical properties. Potential applications range from optical devices to biosensors for medical diagnostics.

Project_Title: Mindfulness and Acceptance-based Treatments for Social Anxiety: Mechanisms of Action
Project_Description: People who experience social anxiety are concerned that others are judging them. This ailment can escalate into a social anxiety disorder. Wilfrid Laurier Universityâ€™s Dr. Nancy Kocovski is researching the effectiveness of mindfulness and acceptance-based group therapy for social anxiet

Project_Title: Improving the design and analysis of clinical trials
Project_Description: Randomized clinical trials provide the highest quality evidence about effective medical treatment. Dr. Timothy Owen Ramsay of the Ottawa Hospital Research Institute is looking for ways to get even better information out of these trials, which would help researchers better evaluate different treatments.

Project_Title: Design of nanoscale aptamer films for the triggered delivery of fertilizers
Project_Description: At Carleton University, Dr. Maria Cynthia DeRosa is conducting research that could help farmers synchronize the release of fertilizers with the readiness of their crops. She is developing nanoscale coatings that would enable signals from a crop to trigger the release of fertilizers. This could mean farmers could use less fertilizer, cut costs and reduce their farmsâ€™ environmental impac
Keyword: Climate change, rural, fertilizer, targeted release, nanaotechnology

Project_Title: Language: Systems and Interfaces
Project_Description: Dr. Asudeh and his team at Carleton are investigating the division of language systems into discrete modules, and the interfaces between such modules. The resulting advances in linguistic theory could improve the ability of computers to understand natural language and could reduce barriers to global communication.
OIA_AREA: Development and creation of investigation spots

Project_Title: Development of High Performance Parallel Robotic Machine for Reconfigurable Manufacturing Systems
Project_Description: Dr. Dan Zhang at the University of Ontario Institute of Technology is developing new, improved robotic machines for manufacturing systems that could reduce production costs for Ontarioâ€™s manufacturing companies and improve their global competitiveness. These new machines are expected to be more accurate, reliable, and flexible, and have better load capacity than current machine
OIA_AREA: Development and creation of investigation spots
Lead_Research_Institution: University of Ontario Institute of Technology

Project_Title: Hypothesis testing over formalized knowledge in the life science
Project_Description: Advancing knowledge in the life sciences involves experimentally testing hypotheses and interpreting the results based on prior scientific work. Researchers face the difficult challenge of collecting, evaluating and integrating diverse and exponentially growing information to establish a valid, well supported hypothesis. Our research aims to further develop a novel approach to construct and evaluate biological hypotheses using established scientific knowledge. We will further develop a platform to acquire, share, compare and refine knowledge so as to foster scientific data-sharing communities and develop the capacity to inform scientific researchers with data that supports or disputes scientific hypotheses

Project_Title: Green Wireless Communications Technologies for Reducing Greenhouse Gas Emissions
Project_Description: Wireless communications technologies have transformed the way we live, work, learn and play. To fight against global climate change, wireless communications technologies can play a very significant role. A direct contribution is to reduce the energy consumption and greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions from wireless communications products and services. In addition, a bigger role wireless communications could play is in helping to improve energy efficiency in other industries, such as electric power. The goal of this project is to contribute to the development of green wireless communications technologies to make their widespread deployment practical and commercially viable.

Project_Title: Use of e-Health Technologies to Promote Pediatric Disease Self-management
Project_Description: Childhood chronic and life threatening illnesses impacts all aspects of young peopleâ€™s lives. Self-management (i.e., coping skills) therapies are effective in promoting better disease management (reduced pain) and improving child health outcomes (quality of life). However, most youths do not have access to these treatments due to barriers (expense and inaccessibility to clinical treatments). My research explores how information and communication technologies (ICTs) can be used for the provision of self-management and transitional care programs. ICTs offer the potential for greater access to medical care; reduced waiting times; enhanced acquisition of information, self-management skills and social support; and reduced health care cost

Project_Title: Determining the underlying cause of polycystic kidney disease (PKD)
Project_Description:
Polycystic kidney disease (PKD) is the most common heritable life-threatening syndrome. It afflicts 1 in 500 people, and 50% of these individuals will ultimately lose all kidney function. Treatment is extremely costly, and there are no therapeutic drugs or preventive strategies. PKD therefore represents a critical target for medical research.

My lab uses zebrafish to study the cause of PKD. Zebrafish biology is remarkably similar to humans, and we have engineered mutant strains that develop PKD. Moreover, we have developed powerful techniques that allow us to define, in a living embryo, how these mutations disrupt kidney formation at both a cellular and molecular level. Our research will identify the cause of, and new treatments for, PKD.

Project_Title: Enhanced bone marrow stem cell characteristics following exercise: Implications for bone marrow transplantation
Project_Description: It is known that bone marrow (BM) stem cell transplantation (BMT) is associated with a high rate of failure (60-70%), even when the host and donor are well matched.  Failed BMT is primarily due to low input cell number, cell death due to stress, or failed engraftment.  My lab has recently shown that exercise induces adaptations in BM that protect it from stress.  We believe that exercise-training a BM donor may be a potent strategy for improving BMT success. Results from our experiments may revolutionize therapeutics for BMT candidates and represent a major breakthrough in BM stem cell biology.

Project_Title: Perceiving Percussive Sounds: Studying our perception of impact events
Project_Description: Our brains effortlessly integrate the sight of a film actorâ€™s moving lips with the sound of his voice, even when this voice comes from speakers positioned off to the side of the screen. We generally take this process of audio-visual integration for granted, however it poses serious problems for those suffering from sensory integration dysfunction, such as children with autism. Our research will explore the underlying cues giving rise to a novel audio-visual illusion employed for centuries by on-stage musicians.  Research on this illusion will both inform clinical treatments for those suffering from deficits in audio-visual integration, and help musicians understand how their movements affect the way listeners â€œhearâ€ their

Project_Title: The impacts of human pharmaceuticals in fish
Project_Description: Human pharmaceuticals are released into the aquatic environment from wastewater effluent (WWE) discharge.  Aging demographics and increasing urbanization will increase pharmaceutical discharge into our water.  Using zebrafish as a model fish species, we are testing the impacts of pharmaceuticals on fish reproduction, development and physiology.  All of the drugs we have tested decrease reproduction suggesting that WWE is a source of endocrine disrupting compounds to the aquatic environment.  With this funding, we will assess multi-generational impacts of pharmaceuticals in zebrafish and in fish adjacent to WWE discharge, and determine the mechanisms through which pharmaceuticals reduce reproduction in fish.
OIA_AREA: Development and creation of investigation spots

Project_Title: Understanding Early Factors in the Development of Diabetes and Cardiovascular Disease in Women
Project_Description: Young women represent the segment of our population that has experienced the greatest increase in the prevalence of type 2 diabetes in recent years. Diabetes is a risk factor for heart disease, the leading cause of death of Canadian women. Interestingly, the way that her bodyâ€™s metabolism responds to pregnancy can predict a womanâ€™s risk of developing type 2 diabetes and heart disease later in life. Thus, my goal is to study the body changes that occur in the years following pregnancy, in order to identify early factors that contribute to the development of diabetes and heart disease in wo

Project_Title: Understanding genes, epigenetic changes, and their interaction with environment in children with Wilms tumors
Project_Description: Much remains unknown regarding why and how Wilms tumors occur in young children.  As it occurs very early in life, it has major impact on public health particularly on the potential gain of years and quality of life. We propose to conduct a large study in N. America based on parent-child trios in collaboration with the International Study of Embryonal Tumor identify why this tumor occurs.  We will look at how genetic makeup and their interaction with environment factors affect childrenâ€™s risk of developing Wilms Tumors.  The results of this research project will help us to understand why and how these tumors occur in young children, and contribute to the prevention and treatment of this diseas

Project_Title: Decision Support for Software Development Activities Using Historical Project Data
Project_Description: The proposed research will help software companies create complex products that are delivered on time and within budget. Software repositories, such as source control systems and bug tracking databases, contain a wealth of historical information about the progress of a project. By mining historical project information, practitioners will be able to base software development decisions and release planning activities on concrete knowledge and solid information, rather than using ad-hoc techniques and gut feelings in their decision process. These well-researched decisions will help companies not only improve the quality of their software products, but also control development costs
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project_Title: Neurocognition and Functional Disability in Chronic Mental Disorders
Project_Description: Even after symptoms improve, individuals with chronic mental disorders such as schizophrenia and mood disorders have persistent difficulty functioning in the community. These impairments are found in academic, vocational, and interpersonal domains at a tremendous cost to society.  Recent evidence suggests that behavioural treatments are effective at improving functional outcomes. I have initiated a program of research that targets neurocognition and other factors associated with long-term disability for individuals with chronic mental illness. The resources requested in this application will supplement these clinical intervention studies with highly-qualified personnel, including post-doctoral researchers and laboratory staff.

Project_Title: Enhancing perception of music in deaf and hard of hearing populations
Project_Description: So great is the desire of deaf and hard of hearing people to experience music that they will often listen at volumes that put their already fragile hearing at risk. My research aims to give them access to the emotional richness of music through the senses of sight and touch instead. Using the Emoti-Chair, a device I helped develop to translate notes of different pitch to vibrations in different parts of the back, we will explore more fully how people across the spectrum of hearing loss can enjoy music when sound is diminished or absent. A further key goal is to help improve rehabilitation efforts for children who use cochlear implants, which allow music to be heard only imperfectly, and to spark innovation in related areas of digital media.

Project_Title: A new generation of bone-like "green" composite materials for orthopaedic applications
Project_Description: There is an urgent need to extend the life of medical implants. They now last only 10 to 15 years, after which patients face a repeat of the original surgery, with attendant pain, risks and recovery period and significant health care costs. My research aims to design and make strongercomposites for medical implants that function like real human bones and have the same material properties. By replacing metal with a natural-fibre based material, these implants will also offer major environmental benefits. The project will significantly expand clinical knowledge, training and education. Practically, it will improve the lives of patients, reduce health care costs, promote â€œgreenâ€ technology and advance Ontarioâ€™s medical ind
Keyword: bio-economy

Project_Title: Mechanisms of Protection and Informed target discovery for gene and stem cell therapy in Acute Lung Injury
Project_Description: As the number of patients with acute lung injury grows so does the challenge of preventing or reversing the need for life support. Currently there are no specific medications to treat, limit or/and repair lung damage. Promising options involve either gene or stem cell therapy. However optimum lung delivery and therapeutic effectiveness is needed. I have developed a strategy to identify novel factors which may improve the delivery and reparative potential of stem and/or gene therapy. Thus, my research could lead to effective non-invasive methods of providing novel treatments for lung injury that can be translated to the clinic.

Project_Title:
Mechanical Ventilation Utilization and Survivorship

Mechanical Ventilation Utilization and Survivorship
Project_Description: We plan to conduct 2 studies to evaluate how clinicians use breathing macines and the impact of their use on important clinical outcomes. In an observational study involving approximately 150 adult intensive care units (ICUs) around the world, we plan to evaluate variation in how clinicians discontinue breathing machines in critically ill adults and describe the influence of different practices on outcomes such as death and length of stay. In a second study, we will use large databases to match patients hospitalized patients treated with breathing machines with hospitalized patients not treated with breathing machines to quantify the impact of being treated with a ventilator on outcomes including death and readmission to hospital and ICU

Project_Title: Improving assessment and outcome after aneurysmal subarachnoid hemorrhage
Project_Description: Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) is a type of stroke that affects approximately 10 per 100,000 Canadians per year and accounts for 27% of all stroke-related years of potential life lost before age 65. Approximately 40% of previously employed survivors of SAH are unable to return to work, usually as a result of impaired thinking abilities. Little is understood about the underlying cause of impaired thinking and return-to-work difficulties after SAH. The long-term objective of this research program is to define the changes in the brain that are associated with impairments in thinking and day-to-day functioning after SAH.

Project_Title: Stopping Bleeding in the Brain: Developing an Innovative Image-Guided Emergency Treatment Protocol for Patients with Intracerebral Hemorrhage
Project_Description: Every 10 minutes in Canada, someone dies or is disabled by a stroke. The worst kind is a brain hemmorhage from a ruptured blood vessel (40% die within days), for which these is no proven treatment. Our research aims to combat stroke, reduce disability and save lives. We are on the verge of discovering a way to treat these strokes and ready to test it in hospital emergency rooms, SPOTLIGHT is the first Canadian study of an image-guided treatment protocol, building upon our earlier discovery of the "spot sign" -- an imaging marker that enables rapid targeted treatment to the right patients. This leading-edge research will create new knowledge, collaboration and training opportunities and will allow Ontario researchers to lead internationally.

Project_Title: Qualitative and Arts-based Health Research: Keys to Improving Person-Centred Care
Project_Description: The aim of this research is to improve dementia care and brain injury rehabilitation by using drama to convey an approach to person-centred care that emphasizes the importance of non-verbal communication, individualizing care, and psychosocial interventions. Qualitiative inquiry (focus groups, interviews, observations) will facilitate understanding of barriers and facilitators regarding person-centred care as well as the benefits of using drama to translate our research on person-centred care into clinical practice.  Findings will provide Mnistry decision-makers with vital information about the conditions required to improve care for Ontarians.

Project_Title: Failure to Slow Down When You Should: Self-Regulation and Judgment in Surgical Practice
Project_Description: Research into medical error prevention and patient safety has focused on system issues with much less attention on human factors that contribute to error. Recently, the phenomenon of â€˜slowing when you shouldâ€™ was described as a critical component of physician judgment and studied in the setting of a surgical practice. Using this as a foundation,  the proposed program of research will further explore the psychosocial causes of surgeons failing to slow down in the social and cultural context of surgery and the implications this might have on surgeon well-being and patient safety. This will help contribute to reduced surgeon error and improved surgeon well-be

Project_Title: Clustering Manifest Variables of Mixed Type with Applications in Bioinformatics & Sensory Science
Project_Description: Contemporary science research is confronted with ever-growing masses of data. Given that scientists rely on statistics to interpret results, the availability of suitable methods is essential. Unfortunately, some research questions cannot be answered due to the lack of appropriate statistical techniques. The proposed research will develop new techniques to address this problem. Specifically, the techniques developed will aid in determining the genes responsible for certain cancer types by allowing genetic data to be jointly analyzed with patient history. They will also support the evaluation of food products via taste testing. Benefits to Ontario will include job creation, increased competitive advantage, and improved healthcare.

Project_Title: Evaluating soil health, microbial biodiversity and nutrient cycling in agroecosystems for biofuels
Project_Description: The Canadian government has released a biofuel strategy as a way to minimize our dependence on fossil fuels.  A major environmental concern is long-term sustainability of soil health, because of the large volumes of crop residues removed from fields.  Soil microbial communities are intrinsically linked to the quality and quantity of crop residue that is returned to soils, and in turn determine greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions and soil productivity.  We will quantify the effects of biofuel agroecosystems on soil health. This research focuses on microbial biodiversity and microbial communities associated with GHG emissions and carbon sequestration and will help to identify the type of soil and region that would be best for biomass biofuel.
Keyword: bio-economy

Project_Title: Regulation of Adipose Tissue Metabolism and Gene Expression: Implications for the treatment of type 2 diabetes
Project_Description: The incidence of type 2 diabetes is increasing at a staggering rate and presents a signficant burden on the Canadian health care system. While traditionally viewed as a storage depot it is now widely accepted that adipose tissue, i.e. fat, is an active metabolic organ and is a target of several commonly prescribed anti-diabetic medications. While effective in improving glucose homeostasis these drugs are associated with a host of undesirable and harmful side effects. Within this framework my research program is centred upon identifying alternative approaches, i.e. diet and exercise, to improve adipose tissue function and metabolism. Modern cellular and molecular biology techniques are utilized in these studies

Project_Title: Grasslands, species loss, and global environmental change
Project_Description: Dr. MacDougall's research will examine how global environmental change is affecting the diversity and function of terrestrial ecosystems, with specific emphasis on grasslands. Grasslands cover ~25% of Canadaâ€™s landmass, they are major repositories for endemic species, they provide a range of highly valued ecosystem services including carbon sequestration and biofuel production, but are imperilled by the combined effects of invasion, climate change, eutrophication, and trophic collapse. He uses mostly field-based experimental work to clarify the consequences of global change on grasslands, with relevance for conservation, ecosystem-level management, and understanding the fundamental mechanisms that shape biological communitie
OIA_AREA: Development and creation of investigation spots

Project_Title: Developing therapeutic approaches to improve joint implant longevity
Project_Description: Joint replacement surgery improves patient mobility and quality of life. However, since the average patient requiring this type of surgery today is more active as well as younger, the likelihood of patients outliving their implant is very high. Therefore, the need to improve implant longevity is growing. The primary cause of implant failure is aseptic loosening, to which implant wear particles largely contribute by inducing a biological reaction that leads to bone destruction around the prosthesis (periprosthetic osteolysis). This research aims to better understand the biological mechanisms leading to periprosthetic osteolysis, and develop innovative therapeutic approaches to control the biological response and increase implant longevity.

Project_Title: Algebraic and geometric structures of homogeneous spaces
Project_Description: The proposed research focuses on the study of geometry of spaces endowed with an action of an algebraic group. Such spaces play a major role in the modern theory of algebraic groups and have applications in mathematical physics, representation theory, topology, cryptography and algebraic geometry. The goal of the project is to develop novel efficient algorithms that enable the calculations of their various invariants and characteristics.
OIA_AREA: Development and creation of investigation spots

Project_Title: Men who have Sex with Men: An In-Depth Examination of Ontarioâ€™s HIV Prevention Effor
Project_Description: Over the last several years, rates of HIV transmission have increased across Ontario among men who have sex with men (MSM). This is compounded by the fact that upwards of one-third of all HIV+MSM are unaware that they are HIV+, and consequently continue engaging in the sexual and injection drug practices that rendered them HIV+ in the first place. In reaction to this situation, interviews will occur with four groups of HIV+MSM who engaged in high-risk behaviour before being diagnosed with HIV, but who infrequently underwent HIV testing during this time. Data from these four groups will be used to understand Ontario-based HIV prevention, and ot make recommendations for improving these services.

Project_Title: Why Do Newly Born Cells in the Adult Brain Die?
Project_Description: Within the last decade, scientists discovered that the adult brain makes new neurons in many species, including humans. This was a huge breakthrough since these cells provide hope for treatments that could use the new cells to replace dying cells.  However, we are currently unable to therapeutically use the newly born cells since most of these new cells die during their development in the adult brain.  This proposal will identify what controls the death of newly born neurons, and therefore will help us in harnessing the potential of newly formed neurons in the treatments of many degenerative and debilitating diseases.

Project_Title: Visual Navigation of Mobile Robots in Extreme Environments
Project_Description: Mobile robots have come to play essential roles in scouting some of the worldâ€™s harshest and challenging environments; examples include search & rescue in the collapsed World Trade Center on 9/11, monitoring of the Chernobyl Sarcophagus, reconnaissance of the Deepwater Horizon oil spill, and exploration of the surface of Mars.  the global positioning system (GPS) is often not available in these extreme situations and thus camera feedback is typically used to navigate robots manually over short distances.  This project will create an innovative visual navigation framework for autonomous exploration of GPS-denied environments, thereby pushing the frontiers of robotics to where humans dare not g
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project_Title: Can plant derived omega-3 fatty acids support brain health?
Project_Description: Omega-3 fats from fish are important for normal brain function and health.  In fact, nutritionists are recommending we increase our intake of fish.  However, there is currently considerable strain on global fish stocks and fear that dietary advice to increase fish consumption could potentiate the decline in fish stocks.  In this study we will compare the ability of omega-3 fats from plants with fish omega-3s in regards to their ability to maintain brain function in rats.  If plant omega-3s can make up a part of the requirement of omega-3 from fish, we could decrease our fish consumption without compromising brain health.

Project_Title: Creation, Tuning, and Study of Nanocrystals to Address Scientific and Technical Challenges
Project_Description: Mechanical Exfoliation is a technique first developed in 2004 for the manufacture of a single atomic sheet of graphite (Graphene). We propose exploiting this technique to produce a wide variety of materials on the nanoscale. This new paradigm will enable us to fabricate nanocrystals, interfaces and multi-functional devices that are impossible by other means. In addition, we will use optical techniques to non-invasively probe these new nanocrystals and the structures they provide. These studies will enable unique insights into the novel properties of materials at the forefront of condensed matter physics. Particular focus will be paid to devices and compounds aplicable to increased energy efficiency.
OIA_AREA: Chemical and biological experimentation for the future

Project_Title: Enabling the Health Care System to Support Family Caregivers
Project_Description: Unpaid family caregivers are essential to the sustainability of Ontarioâ€™s health care system. Family caregivers play a key role in supporting patientsâ€™ recovery, rehabilitation, and on-going care. Unfortunately, there is no standard clinical practice to prepare or support family caregivers. As a result, many experience stress and poor health outcomes and this can ultimately threaten the sustainability of the home care situation. Dr. Cameronâ€™s research program will address this problem by developing, evaluating, and putting into practice programs to support family caregivers.  Our ultimate goal is to have a health care system that prepares and supports family careg

Project_Title: Evolution of Fungal Drug Resistance in the Human Host
Project_Description: Invasive fungal infections are a leading cause of mortality among immunocompromised individuals, such as those with HIV or undergoing treatment for cancer.  Treatment is hampered by the emergence of resistance to the limited number of antifungal drugs.  This research exploits cutting-edge sequencing technologies to identify mutations on a genome-wide scale that accompany the evolution of fungal drug resistance in human hosts.  We will assess the functional importance of mutations for drug resistance and identify molecules that render resistant pathogens responsive to treatment.  This work will benefit Ontario by identifing novel drug resistance mechanisms and therapeutic strategies for life-threatening infectious disease.

Project_Title: Substance Abuse in Emerging Adulthood: A Focus on Risk and Resilience
Project_Description: Emerging adulthood is the stage of development from the late teens to the early twenties; no longer adolescents, but not yet adults, this is a period of risk for increased substance use and substance-related problems. This research will examine factors unique to this developmental stage that contribute to (risk) and buffer against (resilience) increased substance use. I will focus this research on emerging adults in general and those facing increased vulnerability to substance abuse: youth making the transition out of child welfare. This research will provide important information regarding the development of substance abuse in emerging adulthood and will shed light on the policy and practice needs of Ontarioâ€™s emerging adult

Project_Title: Adaptation of conifers to climatic change - Screening tools for assessing adaptation of conifers to future climate
Project_Description: With an area of 71 million ha Ontario's forests represent two percent of the world's total, support almost 200,000 jobs in the forestry sector and a value of CAD 15.3 billion in 2007. Climate change is projected to increase average temperatures in Ontario between 3Â°C and 6Â°C by 2070. This will make local trees less well adapted to climate and set Ontario's forests at risk. We will examine genetic and physiologic mechanisms in conifers for adapting and acclimating to climate change and develop innovative tools for gene-assisted selection of trees and forest management that can be adapted to future climate changes. The project will thus sustain economic activity in Ontario's forestry sector and provide benefits to the environmen

Project_Title: Network Management for Next Generation Internet
Project_Description: The Internet has exponentially grown both in size and the amount of data it carries during the past 25 years, and has reached a point where some of itâ€™s intrinsic limitations are becoming clear. Software-defined networks are proposed recently to overcome these fundamental limitations, and as a clean slate design for future generation networks. This project will design and develop tools and methods to make software-defined networks practical by physically distributing network management and control. The logical management remains centralized which leads to simplicity and flexibility of making changes to the infrastructure. We will verify our system in a controlled testbed environment, as well as in real network
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project_Title: Sleep problems for women: effects on maternal and infant health during pregnancy and after birth
Project_Description: Sleep problems in pregnancy and after birth are common, but we know little about how sleep problems develop, or what factors make sleep problems more likely.  Since problems with sleep can lead to poor health, poor sleep in pregnancy and after birth may lead to problems with the health of women and their babies.  Our study will determine how common sleep problems are and what factors make sleep problems more likely to occur.  We will also find out if having sleep problems makes it more likely that other physical and mental health problems occur for women or their babies.  The information we gain will help us develop ways to find, prevent and treat sleep problems and improve the health of Ontario's mothers and babies.

Project_Title: Boron Catalysts for the Streamlined Synthesis of Carbohydrate Derivatives
Project_Description:
Carbohydrates are the most abundant naturally occurring chemical feedstocks. Their derivatives are important targets for chemical synthesis, with applications as drugs, vaccines, and tools for the study of human diseases. Unfortunately, it is not generally feasible to efficiently prepare high-value targets from readily available sugars: lengthy sequences of â€˜protectionâ€™ and â€˜deprotectionâ€™ (generating large amounts of waste) are required to prepare a specific target. 
This proposal describes research aimed at developing boron catalysts able to promote targeted chemical reactions of carbohydrates at a single position. This new mode of chemical reactivity will significantly streamline the synthesis of biologically relevant sugar der

Project_Title: Characterization of the water circulation in the coastal wetlands and bays of Ontario
Project_Description: Coastal wetlands, lagoons and harbours are confined bodies of water that have critical environmental and economic importance. They are primary breeding grounds for fish and birds, yet they are also a key entry point for pollutants into the Great Lakes. My research team uses cutting-edge field measurement techniques and innovative computer models to determine how circulation in confined bodies of water is driven by short-term changes in water levels and temperature. Detailed understanding of water circulation and flushing in wetlands and harbours is required to prevent the loss of commercial and recreational fishing industries valued at $535 million per year.

Project_Title: Structural and dynamic studies of the of the nucleotide binding domains from an ATP-binding cassette transporter
Project_Description:
Potassium channels in cells are essential for healthy function of the heart and pancreas. Potassium channels are formed from two proteins: Kir6 proteins form the channel pore and SUR proteins regulate opening and closing of the pore. Regulating channel function is critical, as mutations in the SUR proteins cause disease.
Using a technique similar to medical MRI, we will obtain 3D pictures of SUR regions that are sites of disease-causing mutations. Knowledge of the changes in the molecular structure of the SURs caused by mutations and drugs developed from this research will benefit many Ontarians with cardiovascular diseases and diabetes.

Project_Title: Investigating the neurobiology of psychiatric vulnerability
Project_Description: Psychiatric illnesses, such as mood and anxiety disorders, afflict more than 1 in 10 people in Ontario and result in devastating personal and economic losses. Yet, the neurobiological predictors that lead people to be vulnerable to developing a psychiatric illness are poorly understood. My laboratory uses rodent models, electrophysiological tools and multiphoton imaging to investigate the cellular mechanisms associated with the vulnerable state and the progression to symptoms of anxiety and depression. This approach is critical to develop and test novel strategies to prevent the onset and the progression of psychiatric illness in vulnerable populations.

Project_Title: Leaking blood vessels - new insights into how influenza causes death
Project_Description: In the elderly and the young, influenza can cause a life-threatening illness than can be fatal.   Deterioration in patients with the flu has been attributed to a second infection with bacteria.  However why patients get really sick despite antibiotics is not clear.  We believe that the influenza virus causes blood vessels in the body to leak.  This effect is greatly magnified when a bacterial infection occurs.  We will prove this hypothesis using sophisticated cell biology approaches and we will identify the key molecules that are involved.  Determining how influenza causes blood vessels to leak may lead to new therapies for severe infections with influenza.

Project_Title: Regulation of gene transcription by aryl hydrocarbon receptor and estrogen receptor
Project_Description: Breast cancer is the second leading cause of cancer death in Canadian women. The aryl hydrocarbon receptor (AHR) and estrogen receptor (ER) are two proteins that are implicated in this disease. AHR mediates the toxic effects of environmental contaminants called dioxins, whereas ER is the key regulator of estrogen action. These two proteins and their associated networks interact with each other and this interplay is regulated by activation of AHR. However, the molecular mechanisms remain elusive. This research will study reciprocal interactions between AHR and ER which will provide better estimates of the health risks associated with exposure to activators of these proteins

Project_Title: Using evolutionary conservation to identify short linear motifs in disordered domains
Project_Description: Proteins carry out most biological processes, during which their activity is carefully controlled in time (e.g., active after eating?) and place (e.g., active in the eye?) Many diseases are the result of proteins being active at the wrong time or place, and in some cases drugs have been developed to restore protein activity to normal. Unfortunately, for most proteins in the genome we have little specific information about how their activity is controlled; the experiments necessary to determine this are difficult and time-consuming. This proposal aims to develop new computational methods to predict how protein activity is controlled, by searching for short sequences that are preserved over evolution.

Project_Title: Surface-atmosphere exchange of aerosol in forests
Project_Description: Aerosol, tiny particles suspended in the atmosphere, have major impacts on climate and air quality, and can deliver nutrients (e.g. nitrogen) when they deposit to Earth's surface. The growth of North American forests is thought to be limited by the availability of nitrogen, thus attempts to offset greenhouse emissions by increasing forest sequestration of carbon may be thwarted by insufficient nutrients. Dr Murphy's team will quantify the rate of deposition of aerosol to a commercial forest and investigate the drivers of this process. These measurements will inform the development of effective strategies for forestry resource management, climate change mitigation, and improvements in air quality.

Project_Title: Identification of Pharmacological Chaperones for the Dopamine Transporter
Project_Description: Schizophrenia is a severely debilitating mental disease. The current treatment for schizophrenia consists of primarily in the use of a class of pharmacological agents antipsychotics. These drugs act by blocking the action of a specific neurotransmitter (dopamine) in the brain. However, these drugs have some limitation in their therapeutic action and also display numerous side effects. In this study we propose to develop new pharmacological agents that would reduce dopamine action in the brain by reducing its levels rather than blocking its actions. These drugs would act by increasing the levels of the dospamine transpoerter, a molecule regulating dopamine levels.

Project_Title: Nanomaterials for Solar Energy
Project_Description: We are at the onset of a revolution that aims to use the chemistry that was forged by the pharmaceutical industry to rapidly and inexpensively produce electronic materials.  The fundamental challenge is developing chemical compounds with desirable electronic structure, size and properties. Matter with nanoscale dimensions are critical for electrochemical processes, such as he ones that convert sunlight into electricity. This team will develop the science of synthesizing nanomaterials that efficiently convert sunlight into electricity.  Our nanomaterials are designed to be processed into solar cells in the form of self-assembling paints, which could lead to world changing innovations in energy generation and electronics in general

Project_Title: Defining Ontarioâ€™s Future Forests: Science, Stakeholders, and Assisted Colonization of Forest Tre
Project_Description: Ontarioâ€™s tree species may expand northward in response to climate change, potentially bringing economic benefits, but ecologists have warned that they may not be able to spread rapidly enough to track the rate of climate change. Controversially, they propose that humans assist treesâ€™ colonization of more northern areas. This project will consult with scientists as well as a broad range of bodies concerned with Ontarioâ€™s forests to understand their views of, concerns about, and recommendations for assisted colonization. The objective will be to provide information for future policy development concerning how we will define the future shape of our fo

Project_Title: Astrophysical Windows into Fundamental Physics
Project_Description: Some 74 % of the cosmic energy budget appears to be comprised of a mysterious dark energy accelerating the universeâ€™s expansion that is some sixty orders of magnitude lighter than theoretical expectations. Likewise, gravity on galactic scales is dominated by dark matter, which has evaded detection for more than half a century. This research program will utilize data from current and upcoming space probes to develop a better understanding of the nature and dynamics of dark matter and dark energy. Moreover, this research will develop new theoretical, observational, and computational tools that will be key to identifying these dark components of our univers

Project_Title: Sensitive detection using superconducting quantum circuits
Project_Description:
Research in recent years has shown that it is possible to isolate and fully control individual quantum systems of various types. While this research is driven mainly by the prospects of quantum information processing, we will pursue the use of single quantum systems as ultra-sensitive detectors.

We propose to use individual quantum systems built with superconducting nanostructures to detect electromagnetic fields. Harnessing quantum behaviour will lead to improved sensitivity over today's best detectors. The ability to detect weak electromagnetic fields has potential applications in a variety of fields, including communication, position detection, medical diagnosis, material characterization, and fundamental research
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project_Title: Integrated Counter-Terrorism Institutions in Comparative Perspective
Project_Description: The purpose of this study is to understand integrated counter-terrorism bureaucracies in democracies. The project studies a group of integrated counter-terrorism units in Canada, the United States, and the United Kingdom which share a common goal (improved co-ordination across levels of government) and a basic structure (institutionalized, function-specific centres housing experts from the fields of intelligence, policing, security, and emergency planning). This project maps and explains the structure and origins of integrated units, studies the socialization of bureaucrats within them, and evaluates their effectivenessâ€”including their ethical and political implication
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development

Project_Title: Adaptations in bone quality in response to neurologic injury and reduced mechanical loading
Project_Description: Neurologic injury (e.g. stroke, spinal cord injury [SCI]) results in bone loss and increased fracture risk. Characterizing factors modulating bone quality after neurologic injury is critical for developing fracture prevention strategies. No guidelines exist for managing osteoporosis after neurologic injury. The research will evaluate how bone quality deteriorates in chronic SCI, to estimate fracture incidence, and to identify potential predictors of fracture. The research will inform fracture prevention in conditions of neurologic injury, will provide the basis for a cross-Canada multi-centre study of osteoporosis in SCI, and will ultimately inform the development of evidence-based guidelines for fracture prevention in SCI.

Project_Title: DNA-Functionalized Hydrogels for Visual Detection and Removal of Contaminants in Water
Project_Description: To protect our natural water resources, one of the challenges is to develop new sensors that can perform on-site detection of contaminants without expensive instruments. It is also desirable to remove these contaminants at the same time. To achieve this goal, we will isolate new DNA sequences to bind pollutant molecules via a combinatorial selection method. The selected DNA will be made into sensors and immobilized in hydrogels for simultaneous target detection and removal. We will test our new hydrogels with water samples from Lake Ontario and this project will generate useful sensors and materials for protection of the natural water resources in Ontario and Canada.
Keyword: water

Project_Title: Satellite based quantum communication
Project_Description: The proposed research develops quantum transceivers suitable for satellites, enabling quantum communication and science at global distances. At present, quantum protocols operate on a radius of up to 200 km, and major distance improvements will require significant technological advances such as to employ satellites as one of the communication node. Since photons travel empty space without obstruction and absorption, this will enable quantum transfers over thousands of kilometres. It is anticipated that this research will significantly boost the applicability of quantum communications to real satellite missions, lead to future global quantum networks for secure communication, and bring tests of quantum science into space.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project_Title: Interference Management in Asynchronous Wireless Networks
Project_Description: Interference is well known to be a fundamental limitation to the performance of wireless networks. There has been much recent interest in using advanced techniques that mitigate interference by carefully aligning transmitted signals, which requires very precise knowledge of the environment and delicate calibration. In the research proposed here, we will look at methods to mitigate interference in wireless networks in the absence of such perfect fine synchronization information. Specifically, we will i) look at methods and performance limits that provide rough synchronization for distributed phased antenna arrays using feedback, and ii) provide fundamental limits for networks in the absence of any synchronization
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project_Title: Multifunctional Nanowires: Understanding and Manipulating Optical and Magnetic Properties through Defect Engineering
Project_Description: The realization of the full potential of nanotechnology rests largely upon rational design and controlled synthesis of low-dimensional materials with multiple targeted functional properties. My research group is interested in synthesis, fundamental physical and chemical properties, and applications of nanomaterials that combine tunable optical, electrical and magnetic properties. The proposed research will explore expanding and controlling the functionalities of individual semiconductor nanowires through incorporation of functional metal atom impurities. The main goal from the scientific standpoint is to address the structure-function relationship as a fundamental question in physical-inorganic and materials chemistry.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project_Title: Representations of the hand in higher-order somatic loci and their neural interactions with primary  motor cortex
Project_Description: Sensory areas within the brain interact with the primary motor cortex (M1) to influence the control of hand movement.  However, it remains unclear how the hand is represented in these brain areas and the circumstances in which these areas interact with M1 to influence hand control.  This information is essential to developing therapeutic interventions that aim to improve hand control in patients populations such as stroke and focal dystonia. The proposed research program will investigate the representation of the hand in two sensory areas, and probe their interaction with M1.  The ultimate goal is to identify novel neural paths that can be used to influence and improve the control of hand movement in patients with impaired hand function.

Project_Title: Assessing the vulnerability and environmental impact of pumping wells near wetlands and streams
Project_Description: Understanding the interactions between wells, streams, and wetlands is invaluable for water management in Canada, where there are millions of public and private water supply wells. Water managers need efficient strategies for (1) estimating the origin of a given drinking wellâ€™s source water (to protect public health) and (2) determining the impact of pumping on surface water bodies (to protect ecosystem health). This research investigates methods for understanding coupled groundwater-surface water systems through application of novel mathematical models. These relatively simple models can be deployed in a regulatory context to simulate environments where aquifer data is limite
Keyword: water

Project_Title: Algorithms for quantum computers
Project_Description: While today's computers are well-described by classical physics, we can envision building a fundamentally quantum mechanical computer. Quantum computers could quickly perform certain tasks that appear classically intractable, with potentially dramatic implications for information technology. However, only a few examples of quantum speedup are known, and the nature of the advantage provided by quantum mechanics is unclear. My research aims to better understand the power of quantum information by developing new quantum algorithms that achieve dramatic speedup over classical computation. This serves both to illuminate the differences between classical and quantum information and to explore potential uses of quantum computers.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project_Title: Manipulating single electron spins for quantum information processing
Project_Description: The grand experimental challenge of quantum information processing is to build a device that can efficiently store and manipulate vast amounts of coherent quantum information - a quantum analogue of the CMOS technology underlying modern classical computers. The spin property of an individual electron perfectly encodes a quantum bit, and by confining a string of single electrons in nanoscale semiconducting wires we are developing techniques to manipulate and read out their spin states. In the present two-qubit devices, we aim to achieve robust one and two-qubit logic at the nanosecond timescale, paving the way towards a viable solid-state quantum processor.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project_Title: Comparative Inner Colonizations: Ontario, Germany and the World, 1870-1945
Project_Description: When most of us think of colonization, we imagine people moving to a distant place, and even in historical texts this understanding of the word dominates discussion. Throughout the period 1870-1945, however, a significant form of global colonialism was 'inner colonization', colonialism within a country, from the often urbanized centre to the usually still agrarian borderlands. Ontario (and Canada more generally) was deemed around the world to be a model of â€˜inner colonialismâ€™, and it is the purpose of this project to compare and contrast global, contemporaneous moments of this form of settler colonialism in order to uncover the legacy of such migration and land-use for our world to
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development

Project_Title: An Interdisciplinary Investigation of Decomposition Chemistry
Project_Description: Decomposition chemistry is a new field of research in forensic science which investigates the chemical processes of soft tissue degradation. The decomposition process is inherently impacted by environmental variables which are presently not well understood. The proposed research will investigate the chemical degradation pathways of lipids within soft tissue under different environmental parameters with the aim of identifying important organic markers which are indicative of the degradation period. These biomarkers will be used to develop novel, accurate methodologies for locating clandestine remains and estimating time since death which will significantly assist law enforcement and legal agencies involved in homicide investigations.
OIA_AREA: Chemical and biological experimentation for the future
Lead_Research_Institution: University of Ontario Institute of Technology

Project_Title: Fostering Global and Culturally Sensitive Adolescents: Social Action through Digital Literacy
Project_Description: The proposed study will explore the impact on adolescentsâ€™ learning when given opportunities to create digital texts for a wider audience and engage with social justice issues on a global scale. The research positions adolescents as agents of change as they produce digital texts based on issues identified through the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child, such as the impact of war, child labour, poverty and environmental concerns. They will share their work in a variety of venues, both within and beyond the classroom context, including on a class blog, on the project website, at community art galleries, and on community organizationsâ€™ websites, such as War Child Can
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Lead_Research_Institution: University of Ontario Institute of Technology

Project_Title: Improving outcomes for children with specific delays in language or working memory
Project_Description: Some children fail to develop the fundamental skills necessary to succeed in todayâ€™s society. In an effort to understand the nature of these difficulties, my research has focused on two key systems: language and memory. It is widely recognized that developmental delays in language or memory carry large costs for individual children, families, and society. My work has been the first to differentiate children with primary language or memory deficits, a finding that has important implications for intervention. Drawing on effective brain training strategies, my research program will carefully evaluate the relationships between a child's primary deficit in language or memory, the intervention targets, and treatment outcome

Project_Title: Organic molecules as an environmental diagnostic tool
Project_Description: Polycyclic Aromatic Hydrocarbons (PAHs) are the largest, abundant, organic molecules in space playing a crucial role in various chemical and physical processes and also in the prebiotic evolution of life. This project aims to unravel the PAH life cycle and study their dependence on the local environment. When properly calibrated, these omnipresent molecules then serve as an environmental diagnostic tool (like a weather station) to probe the conditions in a vast amount of astronomical environments. Therefore, studying PAHs is of tremendous importance for our understanding of galaxy evolution, our universe and our cosmic roots.
OIA_AREA: Chemical and biological experimentation for the future

Project_Title: Adaptive potential of salmonid fishes in response to climate change
Project_Description: An unresolved question in evolutionary biology is how quickly adaptation can happen. With impending climate change, the speed of adaptation will influence whether populations persist or not. The proposed research will study rates of adaptation in response to climate change in salmonid fishes. Research will focus on introduced Chinook salmon that have rapidly colonized Lake Huron. Field and lab experiments will to test the hypothesis that juvenile and adult traits evolve in response to the different patterns of environmental seasonality present in this system. These findings will contribute new knowledge concerning rapid evolution and will be used to predict how climate change will impact Great Lakes biodiversity and fisheries.
OIA_AREA: Development and creation of investigation spots

Project_Title: Effects of habitat fragmentation on genetic diversity of natural populations:  investigations using swallowtail butterflies of southern Ontario
Project_Description: Destruction and fragmentation of natural habitats threaten biodiversity across the globe, leaving small, isolated habitat patches in which remnant populations of plants and animals hover precariously close to extinction.  A key factor contributing to the vulnerability of these remnant populations is low genetic diversity. My research uses insects, particularly swallowtail butterflies, to understand how genetic diversity is lost following habitat fragmentation and the resulting impact on the ability of individuals and populations to survive.  My work will contribute to management and preservation of the unique butterfly communities of southern Ontario.  I will train students in key aspects of conservation biology.

Project_Title: Surface treatments to enhance metal implant integration with bone
Project_Description: Hip and knee replacement with metal implants is the most commonly used surgical treatment for patients with arthritis. However, the lifespan of these devices is often limited due to eventual separation of the bone from the implant surface as a result of bone resorption caused by wear particles released from the implant.The surface micro- and nano-topography of a metal implant is an important determinant of bone cell response essential for integration of the implant into the bone. We propose that optimization of the implant surface topography could be used to enhance the response of osteoblasts (bone-forming), while inhibiting osteoclasts (bone resorbing cells) which we will test using cells and well-established animal models.

Project_Title: Molecular regulation of breast cancer metastasis
Project_Description: Breast cancer is one of the most common causes of cancer-related deaths worldwide. The high mortality rate from breast cancer is largely due to the spread (metastasis) of the breast cancer cells. Therefore suppression of dissemination is an important issue in the treatment of the disease. Effective anti-metastatic drugs are lacking. To address this problem, the goal of Dr. Bhattacharyaâ€™s research program is to gain a greater understanding of how breast cancer cells spread and to identify molecules that can be targeted in the treatment of this disease. These studies may lead to the development of novel therapeutics to control metastasi

Project_Title: Investigating the Reactivity of Engineered Nanomaterials Under Industrial and Atmospheric Conditions through Surface Science, Computational Chemistry, and Mathematical Modeling
Project_Description: Nanomaterials have promising applications in a number of areas related to energy and the environment.  Harnessing solar energy, heterogeneous catalysis in oil refining and remediation of contaminated soil and water are just few examples of where nanomaterials would play a transforming role.  They also enter the air we breathe and the water we drink through industrial emissions.  Our goal is to investigate the chemistry of man-made nanomaterials under conditions relevant to the energy sector and atmospheric climate.  Specifically, we will quantify the effectiveness of nanomaterials in arsenic removal from crude fuels and waste water, and their chemical transformation once they enter the atmosphere due to combustion of fuel.

Project_Title: Synthesis and Characterization of New Self-Assembled Organic Molecular Materials from Aromatic Building Blocks
Project_Description: The electronic properties of organic materials depend on both structure of the constituent molecules as well as the organization of the molecules. Thus, the design of new organic materials for applications in electronic devices such as transistors, flat-panel displays, and photovoltaic solar cells requires control over the molecular structural features and an understanding of how the molecules assemble themselves in ordered media. The proposed research will use modern techniques in synthetic organic chemistry to prepare new molecules designed to exhibit the desired molecular properties and to self-assemble in predictable ways.  The resulting materials can find applications in displays, solar cells, and other devices
OIA_AREA: Development and creation of investigation spots

Project_Title: Understanding the Molecular Basis of Protein Misfolding Diseases
Project_Description: The accumulation of misfolded protein 'amyloid plaques' in the brain is a hallmark of many common neurodegenerative diseases, including Alzheimer's and Parkinson's. The emerging consensus is that it is not the fully formed plaques themselves, but rather an unidentified precursor to plaque formation that is the cause of neurodegeneration. Our research is motivated by two basic questions: 'Why do the plaques form?' and 'How do the plaques form?'. To answer these questions, we conduct molecular level studies which reveal the chemical interactions and structural features of proteins that cause them misfold and clump together. Our aim is to shed light on neurotoxic plaque precursors and to identify new ways of treating neurodegenerative disease.

Project_Title: A Virtual Ward to Reduce Readmissions after Hospital Discharge
Project_Description: I am leading the implementation and evaluation of a new model of care called the â€œVirtual Wardâ€ for high-risk patients after discharge from hospital. Patients being cared for in the Virtual Ward live at home but benefit from an interdisciplinary team, a shared set of notes, a single point of contact, round-the-clock physician availability and increased co-ordination of care. If the Virtual Ward is effective, we expect that it will reduce emergency department visits and readmissions to hospital. The Virtual Ward exemplifies the kind of integrated, collaborative approach that has the potential to improve health even in the context of budgetary constrai

Project_Title: Enhancing Recovery Following Nerve Injury
Project_Description:
Nerve injuries are common, and patients rarely enjoy full functional recovery. 

In my clinic I have treated hundreds of patients with nerve injury. Despite application of the most current techniques, a significant proportion of severely injured patients lack complete recovery and are left with disabling pain, paralysis, and loss of sensation. 

In my lab we have shown that nerve grafts from healthy nerves can be used in novel ways to 'protect' injured nerves while they heal, enhancing regeneration following surgical repair. We plan to optimize this protective effect and determine whether outcomes can be further improved using growth factors and electrical stimulation. This holds the potential for accelerating recovery for many Ontarians.

Project_Title: Prevention of tumor recurrence by targeting telomere dependent self-renewal capacity of neural tumor initiating cells
Project_Description: Relapse is the main cause of death from childhood neural-tumors. We have discovered that telomerase is active only in cancer stem cells (CSC) and enables these cancers to recur. Strikingly, normal stem cells do not require telomerase for their survival. Inhibition of telomerase causes dramatic tumor arrest in pre-clinical models. We intend to explore the causes of telomerase inactivation in normal stem cells during development and how CSC reactivates this enzyme. Finally, we will use this to develop combination therapies with novel drug screens to target CSC. Prevention of relapse by CSC exhaustion can transform the lives of children with neural-tumors.

Project_Title: Regulation of Cardiovascular Disease by MicroRNA
Project_Description: Heart disease (also known as atherosclerosis) is a leading cause of death in Ontario. Chronic inflammation results in the narrowing of the inside of blood vessels, leading to heart attack and stroke. We have found that microRNAs (small regulatory RNAs that control the levels of cellular proteins) can control inflammation. MicroRNA-146 (miR-146) levels increase in response to inflammation, and this microRNA then acts to decrease the severity of inflammation. We will determine how this microRNA is regulated in blood vessels, identify the proteins regulated by miR-146, and develop methods to deliver it in mouse models of atherosclerosis to determine if it might be used to treat/prevent heart disease.

Project_Title: Transforming Dementia Care in Ontario: Application of Genetic Testing to Treatment of Parkinsonâ€™s-Related Dementia
Project_Description: Parkinsonâ€™s-related dementias are common neurodegenerations that cause memory loss, behavioural and motor disabilities that impair quality of life. Cognitive enhancers help people afflicted with these conditions. However, some people do not benefit from this treatment, while others experience serious side effects. Side effects and poor response lead to hospitalization and early institutionalization. Pharmacogenomics, the study of how DNA variation can influence drug effects, will be applied to treated patients in order to develop a predictive test that can be administered in the clinic to aid physiciansâ€™ choice of medication. This can reduce health care costs and improve treatment to Ontari

Project_Title: X-ray based investigations of fuel cells for predictive model development
Project_Description: Fuel cells can be paired with renewable energy resources (wind and solar), to produce emission-free power and heating for remote Northern Ontario communities, who are currently relying on expensive, polluting diesel generation. However, water tends to accumulate within the fuel cell, inhibiting reactions needed for power production. Water accumulation can also lead to material degradation during the freeze/thaw cycles associated with operation in extreme cold weather conditions. We will use x-ray methods to study the microscale features of the fuel cell and develop a powerful modelling tool for designing the next generation of materials for the polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cell (PEMFC).

Project_Title: Developing cancer drug candidates using a unique combination of modern technologies
Project_Description: Recent years have seen great advances in our understanding of cancer. However, this has not led to a boost in cancer drug development. In this project, we will address this problem by systematically searching for and validating novel drug targets. For this, we will use a unique combination of techniques including computational biology, combinatorial biochemistry and cancer biology. Briefly, our approach presents a complete pipeline that encompasses the computational identification of optimal targets using machine learning and structural biology, development of specific inhibitors through combinatorial chemistry and finally the validation of biological efficacy of those inhibitors in cancer cell lines.

Project_Title: Communication and Compression techniques for Real Time Interactive Multimedia Streaming
Project_Description: While human communication is inherently a two-way (or more generally a multi-way) process, surprisingly most communication protocols use feedback information in a very limited way. Most communication systems have been engineered for transmission of static data such as files and images, where the use of such feedback information is not critical. However for real-time streaming communication, which is necessary for emerging applications such as cloud computing and multi-party video conferencing, use of such feedback information can be very useful. The proposed research will develop both fundamental limits as well as practical architectures that proactively use receiver feedback and provide significant improvements over existing sytems. â
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project_Title: Development of novel biosensors and therapeutics for Alzheimer's disease: from in vitro to in vivo
Project_Description: Canada is facing a dementia epidemic and immediate action is needed. As the leading form of dementia, Alzheimerâ€™s disease (AD) impacts Canada from two fronts: diminishing quality of life and over-burdening the health care system. Alzheimerâ€™s Disease International is calling on all governments to make dementia a health priority and to increase research funding. To address the urgent need for effective AD treatment, the proposed research aims to develop new generation of biosensors that aids AD therapeutics discovery. It will offer better prospects for AD individuals, benefit Canadian economy by alleviating AD associated costs, and position Canada, especially Ontario, as leader in biosensor research with training of Canadian research tale

Project_Title: Evolutionary Consequences of Asexual Reproduction in Plants: An Interdisciplinary Approach
Project_Description: This project seeks to understand the advantages of sexual versus asexual reproduction in plants. Asexual plant reproduction is predicted to cause decreased defences against insect and fungal parasites. This prediction will be tested using molecular techniques, new genomic technologies, chemistry and ecological experiments to examine how repeated losses of sexual reproduction in plants affects molecular evolution of defence genes, the production of toxic chemicals, and how these changes influence natural enemies of plants. This research will help agricultural biologists understand the impacts of creating inbred and asexual crops, which may have long-term negative consequences for the sustainability of Ontario's agricultural industry.

Project_Title: Reconfigurable Antennas for Emerging Micro-Satellite Systems
Project_Description: The satellite industry is undergoing a major shift towards using micro-satellites to conduct specialized, fast-turnaround missions in a cost-effective way.  At the same time, more complex missions impose challenging requirements on the communication systems in these satellites, particularly on the antenna.  Next-generation systems need adaptive antenna technologies to meet the constraints of this unique platform.  The proposed research will develop reconfigurable antennas to greatly enhance the communications and sensing capabilities of micro-satellites and ground stations by developing designs with low mass, low volume, large scanning ranges, and above all, low cost for advancing micro-satellite technology where Canada is a world leader.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project_Title: The ecology and evolution of mutualisms in invaded landscapes
Project_Description: Deliberately or accidentally, species are being moved around the globe at increasing rates. In recent years, ecologists have uncovered many dramatic examples of how invasive species affect native species through new competitive or predatory interactions, but little is known about the consequences of biological invasions for mutualisms (i.e., beneficial interactions between species). My proposed research will investigate whether: 1) invasive species disrupt existing mutualisms between native species, and 2) whether new mutualisms between invasive species facilitate further spread. In Ontario and abroad, we will study whether invasive ants threaten two important plant-animal mutualisms, specifically seed dispersal and pollination by insects.

Project_Title: Solving Inequalities: Building Capacity for Schools and Communities to use Mathematics towards Social Justice
Project_Description: Many students, especially those from marginalized groups, are not provided access to engaging and rigorous mathematics instruction that helps them apply mathematics to important community problems. For this project I plan to work with schools and community organizations to improve mathematics achievement and graduation rates, and help youth to use mathematics as a lens to understand real world problems. Youth will be engaged directly in identifying issues of concern to their communities, and using mathematics to investigate these issues and to work for positive change in their communities. Research will focus on how best to support youth in mathematics learning and engagement, both inside and outside of schools.
OIA_AREA: Development and creation of investigation spots

Project_Title: High Performance Many-Core Architectures and Interconnection Networks
Project_Description: Processor vendors incorporate multiple processors on a single chip to improve performance, rather than a single core with increased speed and complexity. To leverage the computational power of multiple cores, communication and coordination between cores is essential. This research proposes techniques to streamline and improve the efficiency of the communication between cores. Improved communication will enable novel, large computer systems that researchers across Ontario can leverage to solve societyâ€™s most pressing problems in disciplines ranging from medicine to economics. This research will also enable Ontario to maintain its competitive advantage in the quickly evolving landscape of computer system
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project_Title: Adaptive and robust radiation therapy for breast cancer
Project_Description: Breast cancer is the most frequently diagnosed type of cancer in women worldwide; 25,000 new cases are diagnosed in Canada each year.  Radiation is commonly used to treat breast cancer by killing tumour cells.  However, radiation also damages nearby heart tissue and other critical organs.  In this project, we will develop a new mathematical model to design radiation treatments that target the breast, while ensuring minimal heart dose.  Our research will improve the efficiency and effectiveness of current radiation therapy treatments, will be tested in collaboration with partners at Ontario hospitals, and will prepare trainees for careers in engineering and medicine.

Project_Title: Discovering how nutrients are processed to allow cells to live and grow
Project_Description: Organisms take up nutrients and break them down to release the energy necessary for cellular maintenance or chemically transform nutrients to manufacture the building blocks for growth. Mass spectrometry can identify the chemicals within cells and accurately measure the quantities of each molecule. This project will identify previously unknown metabolic pathways within cells by using mass spectrometry to measure the changes in intracellular metabolites that result from the deletion of enzymes.  In addition, this project will investigate the role of our newly discovered pathway of ribose biogenesis in the production of the biofuel ethanol by yeast acting on plant sources.

Project_Title: Understanding Electoral Behaviour and Public Attitudes from Large Self-Selected Samples
Project_Description: To understand citizens' attitudes and behaviours, social science researchers have long relied on surveys conducted on randomly drawn samples. Such samples are increasingly hard to obtain. As a consequence, researchers are beginning to search out new data sources. The principal objective of this project is to understand how citizens' attitudes and behaviors can be studied using large datasets composed of self-selected respondents.
