Specifically, I propose to study how data collected through online voter engagement applications (VEAs) can be statistically modelled in a fashion which a) takes advantage of the massive statistical power provided by large samples b) can be considered representative of the population.
OIA_AREA: Development and creation of investigation spots

Project_Title:
Increasing Moral Development, Decreasing Aggression: 
A Developmental Intervention Study for Adolescents
Project_Description: Antisocial behaviour problems in adolescents pose major social and health burdens on individuals, their families, and Canadian society. Thus, effectively preventing aggression is of critical importance. Research indicates that moral development serves as crucial protective factor against aggression. The proposed research will implement and evaluate an innovative intervention study using a curriculum that promotes morality. This knowledge is likely to contribute to new evidence on what works in the promotion of mental health and the reduction of aggression in early adolescents. It will also create a system that can be used in schools and afterschool programs across Ontario.

Project_Title: Regulation of gene expression through genome folding
Project_Description: Every cell in our bodies contains the same DNA yet cells are functionally different, expressing distinct genes. Many diseases occur as the result of dramatic changes in gene expression. Despite the importance of proper gene regulation, the key DNA sequences that regulate most genes have not been identified. Using new techniques that identify folds in the genome, bringing regulatory sequences close to distant genes, this project will identify DNA elements that regulate specific genes. A better understanding of gene regulation in disease states will lead to new biomarkers and treatments for diseases that arise due to aberrant gene expression.

Project_Title: Modelling Travel Behaviour Adaptation Processes in the Face of Increasing Fuel Cost
Project_Description: Cost of transportation is increasing with increasing fuel price and traffic congestion. Fuel price almost doubled in last five years, but, demand for transportation has not reduced proportionally. Transportation planner and policy makers use travel demand models, which consider travel costs as a sensitive factor in defining demand for transportation. However, the current models use only observed travel cost and demand data for model estimation and fail to predict people's adaptation to increasing travel costs. This project will develop a new data collection method for collecting data on peoples' reaction to unforseen changes in transportation cost and new models for forcasting travel demand adaptation choices in the face of rising costs.

Project_Title: Durability of Reactive MgO Concrete for New Sustainable Infrastructure
Project_Description: Forty-six percent of the nation's cement manufacturing is occurs Ontario. There is pressure to reduce the carbon footprint of cementing materials and the production process of concrete products because every tonne of cement produced yields 0.85 tonnes of CO2 (carbon dioxide) emissions.  Drawing on this challenge as an opportunity, this research program examines the material properties, economic feasibility and long term durability of reactive MgO as cement replacement subjected to a carbonation curing regime.  The timing of this research is critical since there is a need to develop robust construction materials while reducing CO2 emissions and lowering energy consumption associated with the materials and manufacture of concrete products.

Project_Title: Mediating â€œCultureâ€ and Cultures of Mediation in the Early Modern Mediterra
Project_Description: This research explores the role of diplomatic interpreters as cultural intermediaries between the Ottoman Empire and Europe in the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries. Using new digital technologies for visualizing, analyzing, and presenting research data, the project will illuminate how concepts like â€œEuropeâ€ and â€œWestern Civilizationâ€ emerged in the context of political rivalry and commercial collaboration between the Ottoman Empire and its neighbours, particularly Venice. It will also shed light on the lives and writings of diplomatic interpreters who have rarely been studied, but who vitally helped to shape enduring ideas about the Ottomans in
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development

Project_Title: The Role of Subtle Nonverbal Cues on the Incidence and Impact of Homophobia
Project_Description: People can tell whether someone is gay or straight from as little as a yearbook photo. More interesting, they do not even know that they can do it. Rather, when we see people we unconsciously categorize their sexual orientations as soon as we their faces; and even when the faces are viewed for only 1/25th of a second. In the proposed work, my team and I will be studying the consequences of this; specifically, the impact that perceptions of sexual orientation have upon gaysâ€™ and lesbiansâ€™ opportunities and life outcomes. In addition, we will examine the influence of perceiversâ€™ individual levels of homophobia on amplifying those effects. Better understanding of these processes will help to improve social equality in Ontario and b
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development

Project_Title: Learning Hierarchical Models: Theory and Applications.
Project_Description: Building intelligent systems that are capable of extracting meaningful representations from high-dimensional data lies at the core of solving many Artificial Intelligence tasks, including visual object recognition, information retrieval, speech perception, and language understanding. The proposed  research aims to discover such representations by learning rich probabilistic models which contain hierarchical structure and which support inferences at multiple levels. These models hold great promise for making a significant impact on many research areas, including computational biology, neuroscience, medical diagnosis, computer vision, data mining, and robotics.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Keyword: Artificial Intelligence

Project_Title: Bringing Research Findings into Action to Improve Walking Recovery After Stroke
Project_Description: A multi-step research program is proposed to develop and evaluate the impact of an online education tool (i-walk) on the use of guideline recommended walk tests in stroke rehabilitation. Steps include: 1) a qualitative study to identify contextual factors influencing physical therapistsâ€™ (PTs) administration of tests of walking ability across the continuum of care post-stroke; 2) development by researchers, expert PTs and people with stroke of an evidence-informed guide and knowledge tools (eg, videotaped patient encounters) guiding use of walk test results; 3) pilot testing of i-walk by nine PTs to obtain feedback for improvement; 4) a pilot randomized trial to evaluate two strategies for integrating i-walk content into clinical practic

Project_Title: Measuring Organizational Structures and Approaches to Student Support: The Relationship with Student Success
Project_Description: In the 2010 Speech from the Throne, the provincial government committed to a plan of increasing Ontarioâ€™s postsecondary enrolment from 62 to 70 percent. Yet, access to does not equate to persistence through postsecondary education. Supporting students through completion of their postsecondary education is essential for realizing studentsâ€™ and the provinceâ€™s investment.  Although a host of programs and services exist to support  students in attaining their educational goals, little research has examined the relationship between organizational structures, student support approaches and student success. This research will inform policy and practice needs for postsecondary persistence, thus fully realizing the Throne Speechâ€™s obj
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development

Project_Title: Are active preschoolers healthy preschoolers?
Project_Description: Ontario is facing a childhood obesity epidemic and unprecedented levels of physical inactivity. There has never been a greater need to understand how physical activity during the early years is related to health. The goal of the Health Outcomes and Physical activity in Preschoolers (HOPP) study is to measure physical activity in 3-5 year old boys and girls and determine how activity relates to key health outcomes, including obesity, how well blood vessels work (heart health), and fitness levels. The HOPP study will provide the necessary evidence to inform effective public policies and physical activity promotion during the early years.

Project_Title: Evolution of voice pitch and perceptions of the speech of political candidates
Project_Description: In our social lives, our initial impressions of people guide our future interactions. We form the basis of trust, leaders, our friendships, romantic relationships, and much more based on our first encounters with individuals. As my recent research demonstrates, voice pitch alters peopleâ€™s voting preferences, particularly during wartime elections. Here I propose to continue this line of research, investigating how our social environment can change social perceptions of voice pitch, attractivneess and dominance, and hence incfluence our voting behaviour. Target areas include: foreign policy and immigration, the use of military force, and economic recovery. Any results will be of critical importance to the public, politicians, and the medi
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development

Project_Title: Periods of Automorphic Representations
Project_Description: Number theory, one of the oldest yet deepest subjects in mathematics, studies the internal relations bewteen integers. On the other hand, representation theory is the branch of mathematics that studies symmetry, an important concept in both mathematics and the study of nature. In chemistry for example the symmetry properties of a molecule gives important information about how the molecule functions. The research program initiated by Robert Langlands in the 60's aims to reveal the hidden symmetry of integers by using representation theory, which has since led to various advances in both subjects. The aim of this project is to investiagte questions related to a geometrical quantity, known as period, in the context of number theory and representation theory, whose solutions would lead to better understanding of both subjects.
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development

Project_Title: Lost memories â€“ Can we turn back time in Alzheimerâ€™s dise
Project_Description: About 200,000 people in Ontario suffer from some type of mental deterioration. Aggregation of amyloid peptides in the brain plays a key role in Alzheimerâ€™s disease. In preliminary studies we determined that Alzheimerâ€™s peptides are incorporated in brain-like membranes and that their interaction and aggregation depends on the molecular composition of those membranes. Starting from â€œhealthyâ€ artificial brain membranes we will mimic Alzheimerâ€™s disease under controlled lab conditions by varying cholesterol and peptide concentration and percentage of unsaturated lipids of the tissue. The outcome of this project will be used to determine more precise risk factors, such as high cholesterol level, to aid in early diagnosis and treatment of

Project_Title: Contribution of groundwater to the water quality in dynamic lake environments
Project_Description: The health of the Great Lakes is integral to the well-being and economic prosperity of Ontarians. Despite this, the water quality in the lakes continues to degrade. To develop effective pollution mitigation strategies for improving the water quality it is essential that the contributing pollution sources are properly understood. This research will combine field investigations with advanced predictive computer models to generate much-needed understanding of the importance of groundwater as a source of pollutants to the lake. The research outcomes will be applied to improve water quality predictions and guide management plans, thus ensuring the long term protection of the Great Lakes.

Project_Title: Gait  and Cognition. A New Approach to Understand Cognitive Decline and Risk of Falls in Older Ontarians.
Project_Description:
Ontario's population is aging. Falls and dementia affect a third of older Ontarians each year, and combined are a main cause of disability and generate a significant burden on our health system. Slow walking is common with aging and is a strong predictor of future falls and disability.  Many older people also develop mild cognitive impairment (MCI), however, only some of these older people will develop dementia. Interestingly, MCI and slower walking often coexist in elderly people. 
This study will assess our ability to predict who will develop dementia based on how a person walks. Better detection will help to optimize resources and strategies to reduce the risk of falls and improve the quality of life of seniors in Ontario.

Project_Title: Brain mechanisms of musical rhythm processing
Project_Description: When we speak or dance, we rely on precise communication between auditory and motor brain areas. These interactions may be altered in speech disorders like dyslexia , but are strengthened during rhythm perception and by musical training. These auditory-motor links may even allow musical rhythm to improve movement in disorders like Parkinsonâ€™s disease.  The proposed project uses brain imaging to investigate how auditory-motor interactions relate to musical training, rhythmic ability,  and phonological skills, and whether they underpin our desire to move to music.  The research will also quantify what specific aspects of music activate motor systems the most, and how this may be harnessed for therapeutic applications in movement disorder

Project_Title: More than sports and games: Physical culture at Indian residential schools and Aboriginal conceptions of health
Project_Description: The residential school system is generally known for the abuses and deficiencies that have contributed to an array of negative health effects that impact Aboriginal lives in Canada. Yet, in the growing literature base that accounts for the maltreatment and neglect, there remains almost no analysis about the history of physical culture at these institutions â€“ an oversight that limits our understanding of the relationship between residential schooling and Aboriginal health. This project will address that gap by documenting and analyzing the history of sports and games at two residential schools in northern Ontario, and by investigating how student involvement in those activities informed their understandings of healt

Project_Title: Improving food and nutrition security in southern Africa
Project_Description: This projects brings students to southern Africa to work alongside farmers, African students and researchers to improve child nutrition and household food security. Students will do community-based social science research within an innovative project which scales up a farmer-led approach using sustainable agriculture methods to address food security and nutrition in rural southern Africa, and will critically examine current climate change adaptation strategies and policies in southern Africa. Students will gain knowledge of interdisciplinary, human geography research, agriculture, food security, climate change, participatory approaches and cross-cultural exchanges and learn to communicate complex research findings to policy makers.

Project_Title: The Role of Antibiotic Tolerance in Urinary Tract Infections
Project_Description: Antibiotics are widely used in the treatment of urinary tract infections (UTIs). While most UTIs are cleared successfully with antibiotics, their use can also lead to recurrent infections in a number of patients.  Our laboratory has been studying the phenomenon of antibiotic tolerance, a state whereby bacteria slow their growth and change their behaviour  in order to avoid antibiotic killing.  Using Staphylococcus saprophyticus, a common cause of recurrent UTI, we are currently investigating the mechanisms by which antibiotic tolerance is achieved to find ways to combat its development. We hope this will provide doctors with new strategies to avoid this problem.

Project_Title: Enhancing wound healing and regeneration with adipose-derived stem cells
Project_Description: Soft tissue damage due to trauma, burns, birth defects, or cancer causes scarring and deformity, and can limit mobility. Tissue engineering holds promise for the development of new regenerative therapies that overcome the limitations of existing surgical approaches, which primarily rely on soft tissue transfer from other sites on the patientâ€™s body, or synthetic implants that are prone to failure. The long-term objective of this study is to engineer novel soft tissue substitutes, incorporating natural bioscaffolds that are seeded with the patientâ€™s own stem cells isolated from fat. These constructs will be engineered to fully integrate into the body, promoting regeneration and preventing scarring, to restore lost shape and funct

Project_Title: Sustainable Drinking Water Main Asset Rehabilitation and Renewal Planning in Ontario
Project_Description: Ontario municipalities are dealing with deteriorating water main assets and facing an estimated $31B water infrastructure deficit. The research will examine the factors that drive water main breaks and leakage with field and laboratory measurements and statistical modelling. The field and laboratory data will be used to construct a pipe break and leakage forecasting model which will be integrated with a water main asset management model. This framework will help Ontario municipalities prioritize and schedule the rehabilitation of their water mains assets in a fiscally sustainable manner.

Project_Title: Blocking the growth of blood vessels as a new treatment for endometriosis
Project_Description: Endometriosis occurs in 7â€“10% of women, and is characterized by the growth of endometrial tissue (normal uterine lining) outside of the uterus. Therapeutic approaches to treat endometriosis have been ineffective; surgery remains the only solution, although the recurrence rate is 50%.  Establishment of blood supply is crucial for the growth of endometriosis, and therefore treatment to block vessel growth offers a great promise. We have observed a protein (SDF-1) that supports blood vessel growth and lesions in endometriosis patients. We propose to block SDF-1 in combination with a blood vessel inhibiting drug to prevent the establishment of endometriosi

Project_Title: Building Green Communications through Cooperation: Fundamental Limits and Practical Techniques
Project_Description: Cooperative communication is the key enabling technology for future wireless networks that addresses critical challenges in transmission reliability, speed, and range extension. To align with global development of clean technology, there is an urgent need to develop energy-efficient green cooperative communications. We aim to establish the fundamental limit of cooperative communication under energy awareness, and through joint design of signal processing and resource control to develop practical techniques for optimum energy efficiency and conservation. The expected research outcomes will provide environmentally sustainable wireless solutions that will impact the wireless sector and benefit other sectors of economic importance to Ontario.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Lead_Research_Institution: University of Ontario Institute of Technology

Project_Title: I can see it in your eyes - Understanding the links between emotions, eye gaze and social skills.
Project_Description: Being able to understand what people think or feel based on their facial expressions and where they look is necessary for proper social interactions. Itierâ€™s research program examines the brain processes involved in decoding information from the face using cutting-edge techniques such as neural recordings. Her proposed research will determine how eyes are involved in the recognition of facial expressions, how gaze and emotion cues are integrated at the neural level and how they relate to social skills. Itierâ€™s work will uncover neural markers of social competencies to better understand how these abilities go awry in mental health disord

Project_Title: Increasing the applicability of mixed-integer programming
Project_Description: There is a huge volume of information available today to enterprises of all kinds, made possible by developments in Information Technology. Mixed-Integer Programming (MIP) is one of the main techniques that is used for exploiting this information in a quantitative approach to decision making. Dr. Fukasawaâ€™s research proposes novel methods that have the potential to significantly improve the performance of MIP techniques. These improvements will bring enormous benefits to numerous application fields, ranging from Logistics and Finance to Healthcare and Forestry. His research advances the state-of-the-art on MIP techniques and also proposes a novel application of them in surgeries to correct cranial deformities on childre
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project_Title: Cross-cultural Integration in the Greek Poetic Tradition
Project_Description: The research will investigate cross-cultural integration in the Greek poetry of Late Antiquity and establish Ontario as a leading centre within the international community for the study of this important and expanding field. The period of Late Antiquity (3rd to 7th centuries CE) in the Mediterranean Basin was a time of intense cultural integration: numerous cultures and religions collided amidst political and social change as the Roman empire declined and the Byzantine empire emerged. The project will consider how cultural integration is effected and reflected in Greek literature of other periods, especially the Hellenistic period (c. 323 â€“ 30 BCE), the time of expansion and â€˜globalizationâ€™ after the conquests of Alexander the
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development

Project_Title: Advanced Nanomaterials for Next Generation Fuel Cells
Project_Description: Fuel cells are an efficient form of clean energy that is expected to provide the best long-term solution to achieve global climate change targets and reduce our dependence on fossil fuels. Performance, stability and cost issues still remain a challenge facing the commercialization of fuel cells in wide spread applications. Dr. Chenâ€™s research will develop novel nanostructured materials to address challenges preventing widespread implementation of fuel cell technologies. The proposed research project is to develop novel advanced nanowire and nanotube based electrodes with higher catalytic performance and longer operational life for next generation fuel cell

Project_Title: Functionalized Biomimetic Micro- and Nano-structured Adhesive Materials
Project_Description:
As future technological innovations steer towards miniaturizing machines and maximizing performance density, our challenges as engineers and scientists are to increase
 our ability to build micro- and nano-machines and understand phenomena at a scale we normally do not deal with. To meet these challenges, Dr. Zhaoâ€™s team will develop new, biomimetic adhesion technologies to enable joining materials to manufacture products at ever-smaller scales, based on scientific insights derived from the superior adhesive foot pad designs of gecko lizards. This research will help secure Ontarioâ€™s future as a global leader in advanced manufacturing and the emerging bionanotechnology indus

Project_Title: Computer-aided prostate cancer diagnosis using multi-parametric MRI imaging
Project_Description: Prostate cancer is the most common cancer diagnosed in Canadian men, and the third leading cause of cancer death.  A promising new imaging method for diagnosing prostate cancer is multi-parametric magnetic resonance imaging (MP-MRI).  Currently, MP-MRI requires highly-qualified subspecialty radiologists to interpret, has high inter-observer variability, and current interpretation methods miss 15-20% of clinically significant cancers.  The goal of the proposed research is to develop advanced computer-aided systems for prostate cancer diagnosis using MP-MRI, which is seen as a critical missing piece in the management of this deadly disease limiting advancement of novel therapeutics.

Project_Title: Rational Design of Novel Surface Active Compounds for Improving Non-viral DNA Transfection Efficiencies
Project_Description: Gene therapy represents a significant opportunity for the treatment of both acquired and genetic diseases.  Successful gene therapy requires an effective delivery systems capable of delivering DNA to specific areas within the body.  Unfortunately there are very real safety concerns with many systems (based on viruses) currenly used in clinical trials; in some cases these have resulted in the death of the patient.  Our research is focused on developing safer alternative delivery systems that are non-virus based and are targeted for the gene therapy treatment of ovarian cancer.  Ovarian cancer is an excellent target for the development of a new treatment due to the low success rate of current treatments.

Project_Title: Classifying and Evaluating Speech Acts
Project_Description:
I will investigate two questions about speech and communication. First, which features of a speakerâ€™s context affect our estimation of the force of her words? Second, what evidential standards must a speaker satisfy when making assertions and related speech acts? I will pay special attention to ways that context can affect the force of a speakerâ€™s words despite the speakerâ€™s communicative intentions, and to the role played by knowledge in licensing speech. This research will sharpen our understanding of how communication works â€“ and suggest how it ought to 
work â€“ across different contexts, which will benefit our culture and improve the transfer of
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development

Project_Title: Next generation cardiac stem cell therapies for heart failure
Project_Description: Heart failure is a growing epidemic. While medical advances help people live longer, the number of patients with heart failure is increasing at a staggering rate. Currently over 500,000 Canadians are living with heart failure but many will not survive for long. Heart failure is also the most serious killer in cardiovascular diseases.  Dr Davisâ€™ research explores new ways to repair these broken hearts using natural heart stem cells.  This work will dissect out the mechanisms underlying cardiac stem cells benefits and will provide a means of fundamentally enhancing these cells to provide a new life-saving therapy for our pateints living (and dying) with heart failur

Project_Title: The ecology and evolution of avian visual signals and how they respond to environmental stress
Project_Description: I use animal visual signals as a model system for conducting research in ecology, evolution, and environmental biology. My proposed research will investigate how complex feather nanostructures influence the evolution of iridescent colouration in birds, and its role in reproduction and speciation. My research team will also assess the influence of developmental and environmental stress on nanostructural architecture and iridescent feather colouration, as well as their possible use as bioindicators of environmental stress. Our research will test these novel hypotheses using integrative approaches and leading-edge technologies, thereby providing students with unique technical expertise that will prepare them for careers in the sciences.

Project_Title: Pre- and post-spawning selection for genetic quality in Chinook salmon: improving supportive breeding programs for the Great Lakes
Project_Description:
Each year millions of juvenile Chinook salmon are raised using supportive breeding programs and are stocked into the Great Lakes in Ontario to support a multi-million dollar 
fisheries and tourism sector. The juveniles are produced in hatcheries with random mating of parents, whereas in nature mating is anything but random. As such, the benefits of sexual selection (increased offspring quality due to female choice and male-male competition) are not possible in these hatcheries.  Supportive breeding programs would benefit from a better understanding of the pre- and post-spawning sexual selection that occurs in the wild.  This research proposal will train highly qualified personnel in both academic and applied research in fisheries management.

Project_Title: A Translational Approach to Targeting Natural Killer Cells in the Perioperative Period With Innovative Cancer Therapies
Project_Description: While surgical resection is an essential treatment for patients with localized solid cancers, many develop a metastatic recurrence and ultimately die of the disease. The immediate postoperative period provides an ideal environment for the formation of metastases. Despite this, it remains a therapeutic window that is largely ignored. Dr. Auerâ€™s translational research uses laboratory models and high-content clinical trials to explore why surgery helps cancer cells to spread and how to reverse these effect using novel cancer treatments that can be safely given to patients around the time of surger

Project_Title: Quantum Field Theory at Finite Coupling
Project_Description: Our understanding of the force that binds together the constituents of atomic nuclei (quarks and gluons) is based on a quantum theory called quantum chromodynamics. Yet, basic questions such as, what is the mass of the proton still lack a clear theoretical answer. The reason is that at everyday energies quarks are confined together and the system is strongly coupled (SC). Our current theoretical tools and computations skills are manifestly insufficient to study SC systems. This research program will build on new Integrability and Holography techniques to develop next-generation tools, suitable for computing exact dynamical quantities in SC particle theories hence probing fundamental aspects of the forces and constituents of nature.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies

Project_Title: Shifting from paper to electronic documents:  The cognitive implications
Project_Description: Digital technologies are changing how we communicate in our social life, business and in science.  Some herald this as the beginning of a new era for humanity on par with the change from oral to written communication.  Others decry this as an evolutionary misstep with negative implications for how we acquire and remember information.  The present research will examine digital technologies and virtualizing documents change how we extract information from these sources and their meaning to us.
OIA_AREA: Development and creation of investigation spots

Project_Title: Novel plasmonic nanophotonics technology for solar-powered sensing
Project_Description: The proposed research develops the next-generation solar-powered sensing technology that can be applied to identify life-threatening pathogens or bio-terror agents, in near real-time, using revolutionary temperature-insensitive detection. The integrated sensor will be compact in size, equipped with on-chip solar photovoltaic cells to enable self-sustainability for field use and clinical settings. Through established collaboration with local hospitals, the novel sensing technology will impact the current healthcare system by providing rapid diagnostics with reduced cost and improved public health responses to disease outbreaks. In addition, the self-sustained technology can be utilized in remote or third world humanitarian operations.

Project_Title: How and When Can Victims of Workplace Unfairness Write Their Way to Effective Healing? Exploring the Role of Apologies, Expressed Forgiveness, and Sensemaking
Project_Description: Unfairness in the workplace is a pervasive and costly problem impacting employees/organizations. Few studies have examined how to help people who believe they have been unfairly treated in the workplace cope with their experiences. This study explores the effectiveness of expressive writing interventions (i.e., guided journal writing) for experiences of workplace unfairness. My previous research demonstrated that expressive writing can increase employeesâ€™ psychological health and decrease retaliation. The proposed research extends this work by investigating whether incorporating additional strategies into the intervention (apologies and expressed forgiveness) can further increase the effectiveness of the expressive writing interventio
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development

Project_Title: Comparative analysis of northern boreal forest dynamics in a changing climate
Project_Description: Boreal forests form the worldâ€™s second largest forest type and are critical in climate regulation and greenhouse gas storage. Climate change impacts are expected to be particularly large in these regions necessitating an improved capacity to predict and plan for these impacts. The proposed research will contribute to this via large forest plots in which tree growth and death and forest cover changes are monitored in response to environmental change. Responses to permafrost loss and water stress will be examined as potential drivers of change. Using these data and existing long-term data available for these sites we will develop tools for making predictions of the responses of different boreal forests to climate chang

Project_Title: Infrastructure deterioration: detection and assessment
Project_Description: Civil infrastructure in Ontario is deteriorating but limited maintenance budgets make it difficult to ensure that it is fit for purpose. Extending the service life of these assets has both economic and environmental benefits through reduced capital costs and CO2 footprints. This project will develop fibre optic and digital image correlation sensor technologies to deliver a better understanding of the impact of deterioration on infrastructure and better tools for their assessment. The project will also train 6 HQP giving them a skill set that is in high demand in Ontario and internationally.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Keyword: structural health monitoring, fibre optic sensors, digital image correlation, assessment, deteriorated infrstructure, reinforced concrete, steel, corrosion

Project_Title: Online social support program for people with diabetes and foot ulcers
Project_Description: Foot ulcers and related complications are common and difficult to treat in people with diabetes, placing a huge burden on the health care system. Dr. Woo will develop a peer led foot club using social media and online platforms to promote self-management of diabetes and treatment adherence for foot complications. The innovative use of social media has the potential to 1) enhance social support and quality of life among people with diabetes; 2) reduce home care expenditure associated with the care and recurrence of diabetic foot ulcers; and 3) make contact with hard to reach or isolated population in Ontario because of their geographical location, cultural dispositions, and socioeconomic status.
Keyword: Self-management of chronic diseases, social media, adherence, diabetic foot ulcers

Project_Title: Wood pellet-based biorefinery
Project_Description: The high price and availability of oil as well as environmental concerns associated with oil use have created a strong incentive for the consideration of wood pellets as an alternative fuel. However, wood pellets have high water absorbency and a moderate heating value. In this proposed research, a new process for producing wood pellets with superior properties (i.e. a low water absorbency and high heating value) to commercial ones will be developed. In this process, hemicelluloses will be extracted from wood chips. The treated wood chips will be converted to wood pellets, while the hemicelluloses will be chemically converted to flocculants. The developed process will benefit Ontario as the wood pellets can be produced by Ontario-based companies, such as Resolute Forest Products, and used by Ontario-based customers such as Ontario Power Generation in Atikokan as fuel; and hemicellulose-based flocculants can be readily used in the mining industry that is currently expanding in northern Ontario. The proposed research will also create more job opportunities in Ontario and make Ontario  a leader in the area of the proposed technology.
Keyword: Wood pellet, biorefinery, flocculants, mining, hemicelluloses, water hydrolysis, hydrophobicity, chemical reaction, lignin, heating value

Project_Title: Repairing Donor Lungs Outside the Body to Improve Lung Transplant Outcomes
Project_Description: A shortage of healthy donor lungs combined with post-surgery complications has contributed to relatively low success rates of lung transplantation compared to other organs. I have recently co-developed a new lung preservation strategy called normothermic Ex vivo Lung Perfusion (EVLP). During EVLP, donor lungs are kept functioning (i.e. alive) at normal body temperature outside of the body which has so far proven to help maintain excellent lung function, in contrast to traditional cold static preservation. My research will use EVLP as platform to treat the most common donor lungs injuries, significantly increasing Ontarioâ€™s donor organ pool for this life-saving procedur
Keyword: lung transplantation, ex vivo lung perfusion, acute lung injury, organ donors, organ repair, respiration, translational research

Project_Title: Targeting resistance to anti-EGFR therapies in colorectal cancer through inhibition of Nrf2 activity.
Project_Description: The purpose of this proposal is identify biological strategies to increase the sensitivity of colorectal cancers (CRCs) to cetuximab, an anti-EGFR (epidermal growth factor receptor) inhibitor and the only targeted therapy currently approved in CRC. We have identified a way to increase response to cetuximab in CRC by inhibiting Nrf2, the master regulator of the antioxidant response. Our plan is to genetically knock down Nrf2 in 50 genetically diverse CRCs to determine if we can increase response to cetuximab. We will also test small molecule inhibitors of Nrf2 (e.g. trigonelline), which have potential for use in the clinic. Our ultimate goal is to identify new targeted therapies which will lead to improved outcomes for CRC patients.
Keyword: colorectal cancer, cancer stem cells, cetuximad, EGFR, Nrf2, xenograft model, chemoresistance

Project_Title: Using mathematical models to optimize Ontario's emergency antiviral stockpile in time for the next flu pandemic
Project_Description: Ontario is hit heavily by flu each year. Vaccines against a new flu strain take 6 months to develop: too long to rely solely on vaccines. The Canadian/Ontarian emergency flu antiviral stockpiles consist of ~90% Tamiflu, but emerging resistance to this drug in H1N1 and bird (H5N1/H7N9) flu strains suggests the stockpiles need to be diversified. In this project, we will develop mathematical/computer models for the effect of various antiviral drugs on controlling flu infections within a cell culture and its spatial spread within the human respiratory tract. Using these models, we will identify: a) optimal cocktails of antivirals to maximize benefit to patients, minimize cost and resistance emergence; and b) the ideal stockpile composition.
Keyword: influenza, antivirals, amantadine, oseltamivir, pandemic preparedness, antiviral stockpiling, mathematical modelling

Project_Title: Functional and molecular characterization of lysosomes and tubular lysosomes in immune function
Project_Description: Organelles are the â€œorgansâ€ of the cell. When they fail, diseases develop. Thus, we study how organelles function and acquire their identity. Lysosomes and lysosome-related organelles like the MHC-II compartment (MIIC) are responsible for pathogen degradation and antigen presentation. The activation of macrophages and dendritic cells, which are immune cells, causes lysosomes and the MIIC to become tubular, but the importance of this process is not known. We propose to identify the biological roles of lysosome tubulation and its molecular regulators. In addition, we will investigate whether immune activation up-regulates lysosome biogenesis, which may help immune cells clear ongoing infections. Overall, this research may lead to translational research that might be useful for developing treatments for infectious, inflammatory, and autoimmune diseases that afflict Ontari
Keyword: lysosomes, MHC-II compartment, lysosome-related organelles, membrane trafficking, organelle identity, macrophages, dendritic cells, immunity, phagocytosis

Project_Title: Development and Evaluation of Two New Interventions for Generalized Anxiety Disorder
Project_Description: Approximately 12% of Canadians suffer from an anxiety disorder. Generalized anxiety disorder (GAD) is characterized by excessive and uncontrollable worry and anxiety, serious medical consequences, and suicidality. GAD is also difficult to treat and is understudied. The proposed research, funded in part by CIHR and Ryerson, will test the therapeutic value of two new cognitive training interventions designed to directly target problematic â€œmental habitsâ€ in GAD. The research program is in line with Ontarioâ€™s commitment to the development of advanced health technologies and will increase expertise in GAD and its treatment. The longer-range plan is to test and disseminate these new interventions within the provinceâ€™s healthcare
Keyword: generalized anxiety disorder, worry, cognitive processe, interpretation bias, abstract processing, cognitive training, neural correlates, intervention, proof-of-concept, efficacy

Project_Title: Behavioural and neuroimaging studies of decision making across the lifespan
Project_Description: As we age, our brains undergo biological changes associated with cognitive decline. Cognitive functions such as memory and decision making play a crucial role in the welfare of older individuals. Supported by funding from NSERC, Dr. Spaniol uses laboratory experiments and brain imaging to discover how mental functions that are relatively stable across the lifespan â€“ namely, motivation and emotion â€“ can help boost cognition and brain function in younger and older adults. Dr. Spaniolâ€™s broader goals are to find novel ways to help maintain or improve cognitive function across the lifespan, and to train the next generation of cognitive aging resear
Keyword: aging, motivation, cognition, decision making, neuroimaging

Project_Title: SmarterKids Music Based Training for Children with Specific Language Impairment
Project_Description: Specific Language Impairment (SLI) is a disability characterized by difficulties producing and understanding spoken language. In Ontario alone, SLI affects over 51,000 children, however, to date no treatment has proven effective. We propose to investigate a new rehabilitation program, SmarterKids, within an SLI population â€“ a program that has remarkably improved language and executive function skills of typically developing children. Finding an effective treatment for SLI would have a great economic and social impact for Ontario, reducing rehabilitation costs and improving academic performance, behaviour, and self-esteem in affected individual
Keyword: specific language impairment, neuroeducation, musical training, music-language transfer, SmarterKids, electronencephalograhy (EEG), executive functions, auditory processing, intervention, children

Project_Title: Higher Glutamate Levels in the Associative Striatum of Patient with Treatment Resistant Schizophrenia
Project_Description: Schizophrenia is a chronic mental illness that affects up to 1% of the population. Unfortunately, about 30% of patients do not respond to current antipsychotic treatments targeting dopamine neurotransmission. Glutamate is another neurotransmitter thought to be abnormal in patients with schizophrenia. This study is the first to measure glutamate in the brains of patients with schizophrenia who have responded poorly to antipsychotic treatments, using a non-invasive technique called magnetic resonance spectroscopy. If increased glutamate is linked with treatment non-response, new treatments for schizophrenia which normalize glutamate may be developed, which would reduce the economic and personal burden of mental illness in Ontario and beyond.
Lead_Research_Institution: Centre for Addiction and Mental Health
Keyword: schizophrenia, glutamate, treatment resistance, antipsychotics, striatum, magnetic resonance spectroscopy

Project_Title: Repetitive Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation for the Treatment of Working Memory Deficits in Schizophrenia and Effects on Brain Structure
Project_Description: Schizophrenia poses enormous health and economic challenges for Ontario. Memory deficits are amongst the hardest problems to treat, and cause poor functioning in people with schizophrenia. Therefore, finding new treatments to improve quality of life is essential. Our pilot data suggests that using rTMS to stimulate frontal brain regions leads to gains in working memory (WM). We will examine the efficacy of rTMS and use advanced neuroimaging to determine if rTMS results in brain structure changes important for WM performance. If successful, this would provide a new treatment option and hope for those who would otherwise suffer from this illness, improve health outcomes, and provide economic benefits for Ontarians.
Lead_Research_Institution: Centre for Addiction and Mental Health
Keyword: brain stimulation, rTMS, schizophrenia, neuroimaging, MRI, DTI, memory, mental health

Project_Title: Enhancing the inclusion of people with disabilities in the workforce
Project_Description: Although cultivating an appropriate labour supply is critical for economic growth Canada currently faces a labour shortage. One promising response is to include under-utilized groups, such as people with disabilities. Of the 2.4 million working-age Canadians with a disability, most are unemployed but want to work, and their disabilities do not prevent them from doing so. This research program will address this issue by exploring employment readiness skills and synthesize inclusionary best practices and disability awareness interventions for employers. Our goal is to improve the inclusion of people with disabilities in the workforce.
Keyword: disability, employment, business-friendly climate, skilled workforce, diversity, leveraging skills, human resources, social inclusion, qualitative research, knowledge transfer

Project_Title: Continuum limit of quantum gravity models
Project_Description: Quantum gravity aims to unify quantum theory and gravity, the two fundamental theories of physics. The proposed research investigates how a continuous space time, which we experience on macroscopic scales, emerges from microscopic quantum gravity models. We will use and adapt coarse graining techniques recently developed in condensed matter physics, which pursues similar questions, such as determining the macroscopic properties of a material from its atomic constituents. This will advance understanding of quantum gravity in important ways, and enable physical predictions from these models. Conducting this research at Waterlooâ€™s Perimeter Institute will enhance Ontarioâ€™s status as a global hub for cutting-edge theoretical phys
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Keyword: quantum field theory, quantum gravity, loop quantum gravity, spin foams, tenor netowrk renormalization methods

Project_Title: Quantum transport and collective states in Dirac materials
Project_Description:
Discovering new materials, understanding their properties and discerning their potential applications is vital to science. An important breakthrough is the recent discovery of graphene, a monolayer of carbon in which electrons behave as quasi-relativistic, Dirac-like particles. There is intense interest in finding other materials with Dirac-like excitations (Dirac materials). 

The goal of this research program is to develop a theoretical understanding of fundamental quantum effects, transport properties, and collective many-body phenomena in Dirac materials. We will combine methods from condensed matter physics, field theory, and advanced numerical methods. 

Deeper understanding of Dirac materials will enable a new generation of Dirac materials-based devices, which will drive technological innovation in Ontario for decades to come.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Keyword: condensed matter physics, mesoscopic physics, quantum transport, graphene, topological insulators, dirac materials, spintronics, Quantum Hall effect, functionalized materials, strongly correlated systems

Project_Title: Untangling the Fundamental Forces of Nature
Project_Description: We propose a two-pronged study of Nature's fundamental forces: The first element pioneers accelerator-based searches for new forces at nuclear length-scales, a young field in which I am an international leader. We will also explore such forces' possible connections to dark matter, complementing the dark-matter search program at SNOLAB.  The second aspect tests whether symmetry arguments uniquely determine the structure of long-range forces, electromagnetism and gravity, by exploring the consistency and physical consequences of theories where these forces are mediated by so-called "continuous-spin" particles. Both facets position Ontario as a world-leader in emerging fields of fundamental research.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Keyword: particle physics, dark forces, dark matter, fixed-target experiments, space-time symmetries, massless particles, new field theories

Project_Title: Investigations in strongly-coupled quantum field theory
Project_Description: The proposed research will develop new computational tools and ideas to understand strongly-coupled quantum field theories. The proposal innovatively combines ideas developed in theoretical high energy physics and theoretical condensed matter physics. Progress in this area will impact our ability to tailor exotic quantum systems for practical applications, understand the fundamental laws of the universe and lead to deep mathematical advances.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Keyword: quantum field theory, defects and interfaces, mathematics, topological field theory, conformal field theory, string theory, topological phases of matter

Project_Title: The neural basis for somatosensation and pain
Project_Description: Recall a bad sunburn â€“ the searing pain as your shirt collar touches your neck. One in 15 Ontarians will endure similar pain, or worse, because of nerve injury or diseases like diabetes. But unlike the sun burn that goes away, so-called neuropathic pain can persist for months or years, undiminished by even the most powerful pain medications. Such pain occurs because sensory information is mis-coded and, consequently, innocuous stimulation is misperceived as painful. Using a unique interdisciplinary approach, I seek to understand sensory coding and how it goes awry, and to use that knowledge to identify better drug targets and treatment paradigms that will contribute to the Province's technological innovation and to the health of its peopl
Keyword: pain, somatosensation, nerve injury, neuropathy, sensory coding, neurobiology, electrophysiology, computational neuroscience, computer model, optogenetics

Project_Title: Mechanism of Metabolic Organelle Maintenance and its Role in Human Disease
Project_Description:
Neurodegenerative disorders (NDs), including Parkinsonâ€™s and Alzheimerâ€™s diseases, are the fastest growing diseases in Canada and are predicted to be the second highest cause of death by 2040. Treatment is extremely costly and no drugs or preventive strategies are available. Therefore, NDs represent a critical target for medical research.
The Kim Lab uses cutting-edge imaging technologies coupled with other advanced methods to study the cellular processes involved in NDs. Using these novel techniques, their work promises to identify pathways involved in NDs in order to identify novel targets for the development of new drugs for treatm
Keyword: peroxisome, mitochondria, autophagy, organelle biogenesis, Live-Cell imaging, neurogenerative disorder

Project_Title: A Brain-Penetrant Drug Delivery Platform to Treat Neurological Diseases
Project_Description: Treating brain disorders is complicated by the fact that the brain is shielded from the rest of the circulation by the blood-brain-barrier. Dr. Melnyk and his team are proposing the development of a safe and non-invasive approach to ferry drugs across the blood-brain-barrier, by attaching them to an established carrier molecule that naturally and safely enters the brain.  Through their re-engineering of this system, they will deliver curative doses of proteins to specific destinations in the brain to restore a missing functionality. This approach has broad applicability and the potential to unlock therapeutic intervention for many heretofore-untreatable neurological diseases.
Keyword: drug discovery, protein engineering, cell biology

Project_Title: An Empire Dances Back: Nationalism, Postcoloniality and the Canadian Diaspora Through Philippine Folk Dance Traditions
Project_Description: Dance is both a window into and shaper of culture. Philippine folk dance is no exception. My research studies the Filipino immigrant experience to Canada by way of this expressive cultural form. It aims to answer the critical role that Philippine folk dance plays in the formation of Filipino identity in the Canadian diaspora. Ethnographic research among Philippine folk dance companies, multimedia projects, and folk dance workshops will be produced. My research can help guide dance curriculum development, art funding policies, and multicultural projects that aim for cultural exchange and complex representations of world dance traditions within the province and beyond.
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development
Keyword: dance ethnography, folk dance, Philippines, Filipinos, immigration, diaspora, multiculturalism, cultural studies, cultural representation, cultural authenticity

Project_Title: La and La-related protein function in cellular metabolism and human disease
Project_Description: The normal function of human proteins is to support the healthy growth of cells. However, certain proteins can also play important roles in human disease through abnormal participation in other processes. One such family of proteins includes the La and La-related proteins. Many La-associated diseases are of primary importance to Ontarians, including cancer and Hepatitis C infection. However, knowledge of the mechanisms by which La proteins abnormally contribute to cancer and viral infection is severely lacking. My work targets this knowledge gap. By enhancing our understanding of how these contribute to disease states, we aim to identify new therapeutic targets for disease intervention.
Keyword: RNA biology, protein translation, RNA processing, metabolism, stress response, RNA processing, genetics, microbiology

Project_Title: Wait-room Interactive eHealth for Mental Health
Project_Description: Timely detection and access to care for prevalent mental health (MH) illnesses remains a challenge despite availability of effective treatments. Social stigma associated with MH illnesses leads to a delay in communicating oneâ€™s concerns to a clinician, who report time-constraints in medical consults to identify early cues of compromised MH. In collaboration with multiple primary care sites, the proposed research will determine whether the use of a wait-room interactive computer-assisted screening (iCAS) tool that generates tailored reports for patients and clinicians at the point of care, would maximize the clinician detection of and patient coping with prevalent MH illnesses. This model of care could then be implemented provincially, saving costs by reducing morbidity. This is an important concern as 1 in 5 Ontarians experience a MH problem or illness in any given yea
Keyword: eHealth, health risk-assessment, primary care, vulnerable communities, mental health, prevention, health promotion, quantitative, qualitative

Project_Title: Understanding the needs of nurses to improve care for hospitalized older adults
Project_Description: In response to evidence indicating that up to 49% of older adults leave hospital with declines in their functioning, Ontario health authorities committed to developing Senior Friendly Hospitals. Some hospitals have endorsed a function-focused model of care, yet little is known about nursesâ€™ capacity to provide this care. Through a large provincial survey, this project examines nursesâ€™ educational, role, interprofessional, geriatric resource, and leadership needs to provide function-focused care. Informed by the survey results, the project then explores nursesâ€™ recommendations for practical strategies to improve their ability to provide function-focused care and help older adults experience better outcomes during hospitaliz
Keyword: function-focused care, patient-centered care, functional decline, acute care, aged, nurse, organization, hospital, geriatric, care processes, models of care

Project_Title: microRNA Manipulation of Cardiometabolic Risk Factors
Project_Description: Our research studies how molecules called â€œmicroRNAsâ€, which are found encoded in our DNA, can change the expression of genes and modify cardiovascular disease development- a disease which affects approximately one in every three people in Ontario.  microRNAs are found in a variety of cell types, but we are interested in how they function in inflammatory cells to increase inflammation.  Inflammation is a key driver of disease in the artery wall, in the liver, and in adipose tissue, and microRNAs can be released from cells to act as danger signals to promote inflammation.  We are going to study how macrophages (inflammatory cells) in the artery wall release microRNAs into the extracellular space to communicate to other cells to promote inflammation and disease.  This will be done using cultured macrophages in vitro, as well as using atherosclerosis-prone mice to see how these miRNAs affect disease development.  If we can understand how microRNAs control inflammation, we can potentially develop new therapeu to treat diseases like atherosclerosis, diabetes and heart disease.
Keyword: microRNA, cardiovascular disease, atherosclerosis, macrophages, inflammation, genes, cholesterol

Project_Title: Linking Mood and Heart in Adolescent Bipolar Disorder
Project_Description: The symptoms of bipolar disorder alone are distressing and impairing, but the 2-5% of Ontarioâ€™s youth with bipolar disorder are also at risk for premature heart disease. This study examines early signs of heart disease using a cutting edge measure of blood vessel functioning and two types of blood markers. This research will tell us how these blood markers may inform the treatment of bipolar disorder and the prevention of heart disease among these youth. By demonstrating that bipolar disorder is disorder is a medical disease affecting both mind and body, this research will improve patient outcomes while reducing the stigma encountered by these yout
Keyword: bipolar disorder, adolescent, inflammation, brain-derived neurotrophic factor, biomarker, endothelial function, cardiovascular risk, genotype, classification

Project_Title: Stopping heart failure by reducing free radicals in diabetes: Can we improve our bodies natural defenses against heart failure by increasing thioredoxin activityÂ
Project_Description: Heart Failure (HF) is a major cause of poor health and death, and is incredibly costly to treat. Approximately 2% of Canadianâ€™s have diabetes, and these patients are 25 times more likely to develop HF than those without diabetes. Studies show that ~ 50% of people develop HF because the heart muscle is stiff and cannot relax. No therapies are available to treat this. This project will focus upon diabetes and HF, specifically looking at oxygen free radicals, and how they are produced/removed from the heart. We will also assess if enhanced removal of these free radicals can stop
Keyword: congestive heart failure, diastolic dysfunction, reactive oxygen species, thioredoxin, thioredoxin interacting protein

Project_Title: Organization and distribution of cellular fats and the consequences of abnormalities
Project_Description: The cellular distribution and organization of fats (or lipids) are regulated by a variety of transfer proteins, including but not limited to scramblases and flippases. Not surprisingly, mutations in these proteins are proposed to influence a myriad of disorders including male infertility, bile acid accumulation in the liver, diabetes, obesity and neurological degeneration. This proposal will explore both the cell biological roles of lipids and the proteins that regulate their distribution. Understanding the function of lipids within the cell and these proteins will help us understand the disorders described and aid in the development of potential treatments.
Keyword: lipids, cholesterol, cell biology, caveolae, mass-spectrometry, super-resolution microscopy, biophysics, TIRF microscopy

Project_Title: Improving Health Care Transitions and System Performance
Project_Description: Use the space below (no more than 750 characters or approximately 100 words) to summarize the proposed research using non-technical language. State the issue(s) that the research will address, how the research will address it and how the research could benefit Ontario. This information will be used by the multidisciplinary review panel in understanding the application. Ensure the description can be understood by individuals with expertise outside of the research field
Keyword: care transitions, medically complex patients, performance data

Project_Title: DO IT! Trial: Vitamin D Outcomes and Interventions in Toddlers
Project_Description: Vitamin D levels are alarmingly low among Ontarioâ€™s children. Colds and asthma attacks have been linked with low vitamin D levels. Being the most common and costly infectious disease in childhood, preventing the common cold through a simple vitamin D supplement could offer enormous economic savings through reduced healthcare costs and increased parental work productivity in addition to reducing childhood suffering.  I am leading the largest vitamin D clinical trial in children and one of the largest clinical trials ever conducted on young Canadian children to determine whether high dose daily vitamin D supplementation in early childhood can prevent colds and asthma attacks during the Canadian winte
Keyword: vitamin D, supplementation, randomized control trial, children, viral upper repiratory tract infections

Project_Title: Improving the Evaluation of Physical Fitness for Major Surgery
Project_Description: Poor physical fitness is a risk factor for death and complications after surgery. The current approach to evaluate fitness for surgery (physician judgment) is not accurate, leading to poor allocation of testing, interventions and monitoring, as well as increased costs and harm. This multicentre cohort study compares the prognostic accuracy of the usual method to assess preoperative fitness against an exercise test (CPET), questionnaire about physical activities (DASI), and blood test (NT pro-BNP). It will develop a risk stratification algorithm to more accurately assess preoperative fitness, which will be integrated as decision support within preoperative assessment clinic software.
Keyword: surgery, preoperative risk assessment, function capacity, perioperative medicine, anesthesiology

Project_Title: Do You See What I See? The Relationship Benefits of Accurately Perceiving a Partnerâ€™s Emotions in Daily Li
Project_Description: Satisfying romantic relationships are critical to the fabric of our society. Empathic accuracyâ€”the ability to perceive a partnerâ€™s thoughts and feelingsâ€”is a vital component of satisfying and fulfilling romantic relationships. Due to methodological limitations, existing research on empathic accuracy has been limited to laboratory settings, preventing us from gathering critical information about how taking a partnerâ€™s perspective impacts relationships in the course of everyday life. This research will develop a new digital media tool to study empathic accuracy in daily life and conduct two studies to test novel research questions about how empathic accuracy for a partnerâ€™s daily events translates into tangible relationship
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Keyword: social psychology, positive psychology, close relationships, romantic relationships, emotions, daily experience methods, empathic accuracy

Project_Title: Challenges in geometric Partial differential equations: General relativity and inverse problems.
Project_Description: I propose to study three central problems in geometric PDE. The first concerns the stability and instability of singularity formation in Einstein's equations of general relativity. Specifically I wish to study the stability of the singularity occurring inside the black hole region of the (maximally extended) Scharzschild space-time. The second project would seek to prove the null version of Penrose's inequality; this is an important conjecture relating the mass in a space-time with the total area of a black hole inside it. Finally, I propose a geometric inverse problem (motivated by questions in medical imaging), where one would try to reconstruct the interior geometry of a 3-dimensional body by making boundary measurements of natural geometric surfaces that cut into the body.
OIA_AREA: Development and creation of investigation spots
Keyword: general relativity, geometric analysis, partial differential equations, inverse problems, penrose inequality, hyperbolic equations, singularity formation

Project_Title: Catalytic Production of Drop-in Liquid Fuels from Biomass
Project_Description: The vast quantities of lignocellulosic biomass in Ontario are valuable feedstocks for bio-fuel production. This work develops catalytic technologies for conversion of biomass into drop-in liquid fuels using a new class of hierarchical catalysts with meso- and micro-pores that host metal and acid active sites at local environments with enzyme-liked specificity. The catalyst will kinetically couple the tandem hydrogenation and alkylation reactions at optimum rates for upgrading of bio-oil derived oxygenates into fuels. New conversion strategies with increase reaction specificity and extended catalyst life are expected from the multidisciplinary approach taken here and cross fertilization among the academic, research, and industrial partners
Keyword: biomass, catalytic process, deoxygenation, bio-oil, heterogeneous, kinetics, hyrdoxygenation, bio-fuel, lignocellulosic biomass, thermochemical conversion

Project_Title: Advancing Rehabilitation in the Context of HIV: Interventions to Reduce Episodic Disability Among People Living with HIV in Ontario
Project_Description: Aims of this research program are to 1) explore the episodic nature of disability experienced by people living with HIV (PHAs), 2) develop and implement a community based exercise intervention to reduce disability, and 3) establish the measurement properties of the newly developed HIV Disability Questionnaire (HDQ).   We will conduct a qualitative study to establish a community-based exercise program specific to PHAs. We will implement the program with PHAs (aim #2). We will administer the HDQ pre and post exercise to assess the ability of the HDQ to detect change in disability (responsiveness) and the clinical importance of HDQ scores (interpretability) (aim #3). Finally, we will use data from the Ontario HIV Treatment Network Cohort Study to explore the episodic nature of disability among Ontarians with HIV over time (aim #1).
Keyword: HIV/AIDS, disability, episodic disability, community-based exercise, questionnaire, validity, interpretability, responsiveness

Project_Title: Perinuclear molecular networks in genome stability and disease states
Project_Description: Factors assaulting genomes often lead to toxic DNA breaks. To continue normal growth, cells must properly repair breaks either by fusing broken ends or using similar DNA elsewhere in the genome as template. Breaks located near the ends of chromosomes are preferentially repaired via the latter mechanism. This proposal will test if and how this repair choice is guided by specific DNA-protein interactions determining the location/movement of break sites within the nucleus. Proteins implicated in this DNA localization/repair process are mutated in age-related diseases including cancer.  We thus test how to restore proper repair choice to promote the health and longevity of Ontarians.
Keyword: nuclear envelope, telomeres, ribsomal DNA, nuclear pore complexes (NPC), homologous recombination (HR), non-homologous end joining (NHEJ), cohibin complex, sirtuins, lamins, emerin

Project_Title: Investigating the relationship between mutations and disease
Project_Description: Genetic diseases, such as cancer, result from function-altering mutations in genes. Genome sequencing has the potential to detect mutations even before disease symptoms are evident. However, because only a small fraction of mutations lead to disease, it is important to be able to distinguish those mutations that can cause disease from those that are functionally innocuous. The research I propose here will enable us to identify disease-causing mutations in genes involved in cell communication pathways, known to play key roles in multiple diseases, in particular cancer. With more than 60,000 annual new cancer patients diagnosed, and close to 25,000 annual cancerrelated deaths in Ontario, novel approaches for early diagnosis are key.
Keyword: cell signaling, disease-causing mutations, functional genomics

Project_Title: How secretory mRNAs are exported from the nucleus and translated into proteins.
Project_Description: In eukaryotes, mRNA is synthesized and processed in the nucleus and then exported to the cytoplasm where it is translated into proteins. The Palazzo lab has discovered that mRNAs encoding secretory proteins, which originate from about 1/3rd of all human genes, contain an RNA element that helps to potentiate their nuclear export and enhance their translation into proteins. They have also figured out the mechanism that these mRNAs use to reach their final destination, the surface of the endoplasmic reticulum, where secretory proteins are made. This proposal outlines the major ongoing projects in the Palazzo lab to follow up on their breakthrough discoveries.
Keyword: cell biology, gene expression, mRNA regulation, secretion

Project_Title: Pursuit of structural mechanisms to understand virus-host conflicts
Project_Description: In the past decade, viral pathogens have posed a major threat to the Canadian and Ontarian public health infrastructure. My group seeks to understand the molecular mechanisms at play in the tug-of-war between virus and host, specifically how viruses enter cells and how, once they enter, innate immune molecules antagonize their functions. Immunological recognition and restriction of viral pathogens is fundamental for fighting infectious disease. Our laboratory adopts an innovative and interdisciplinary approach that merges cutting-edge structural, biochemical, biophysical, immunological, and virological techniques to discover new targets and to provide models for the structure-based design and development of novel therapeutics.
Keyword: virology, structural biology, viral-host interactions, innate immune restriction, viral glycoproteins, viral fusion

Project_Title: Black Hole Collisions: Detection and Observations through Gravitational Waves
Project_Description: Two colliding black holes represent the most energetic explosions in the Universe.  Entirely invisible to traditional telescopes, these explosions create Gravitational Waves, ripples in space-time which propagate through the universe. Utilizing our world-leading computer-calculations of black holes we will develop sophisticated new search strategies to detect gravitational waves from coalescing black holes. We aim to discover colliding black holes for the first time and to determine their sizes and their location in space. This being the only research group in Canada of its kind, we will expand Ontario's world-class astronomical research into the gravitational-wave window which promises entirely new views of the Universe.
Keyword: black holes, gravitational waves, compact objects, binary stars

Project_Title: Advances in Concurrent Program Analysis
Project_Description: Program analysis, automated reasoning about the dynamic behaviour of computer programs, is a fundamental problem in computer science. Beyond its use in finding software faults and synthesizing programs, program analysis has widespread applicability throughout the sciences since many physical, chemical, and biological systems can be modelled as programs. A central difficulty in program analysis is that programs can exhibit nondeterministic behaviour. While nondeterminism makes programs difficult to analyze, it adds expressive power which is useful for modelling systems. The proposed research will push the boundaries of the theory and practice of program analysis in the presence of nondeterminism.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Keyword: program analysis, program verification, test generation, software reliability, logic concurrency, abstract interpretation, constraint solving, invariant generation, automata theory, petri nets

Project_Title: The role of species in maintaining ecosystem function in urban landscapes
Project_Description: The natural world is no longer untouched and pristine. Given that Ontarians increasingly rely on fewer functioning ecosystems in human-dominated landscapes, we need a better understanding of how ecosystem services and functions can be maximized. Species that inhabit these ecosystems provide important services, but they do not all do so equally. Previous research has shown that species ecological differences predict species contributions to function. This research will develop methods to quantify speciesâ€™ differences and apply these to understand how species contribute to function in 12 urban green areas in the Toronto region, allowing us to predict the speciesâ€™ aspects that best maintain funct
Keyword: biodiversity, conservation of nature, ecosystem function, ecosystem services, endangered species, evolutionary history, exotic species, species coexistance, species invasions, urban green areas

Project_Title: P-adic reciprocity in number theory
Project_Description: Number theory is a fascinating and important branch of mathematics. It developed millennia ago with the study of whole numbers (1, 2, 3, ...). Though it is a part of pure mathematics, number theory has important applications to secure data transmission over the internet. Reciprocity is the study of deep interconnections between number theory, geometry, and the theory of symmetries, leading to progress on old, unsolved problems. The aim of this project is to shed light on an exciting new kind of reciprocity, known as p-adic reciprocity.
Keyword: mathematics, number theory, reciprocity, langlands programme, Serre's conjecture, p-adic

Project_Title: Reliable and energy-efficient next-generation data centers
Project_Description: Data centers have developed into resource hogs with annual operating budgets of many million dollars. Our goal is to create more cost-efficient, greener data centers by addressing two key challenges: (1) System reliability: 30-40% of the operating budget is made up by the cost of system failures and efforts to protect against them; (2) Energy usage: Typically more than a third of the operating budget goes into electricity consumption. Our approach is to address these problems by first collecting detailed field data from production machines, followed by a rigorous statistical analysis and experiments to derive solutions. A large number of industry sectors critically rely on data centers and hence will benefit from reduced cost of ownership.
Keyword: data centers, large-scale systems, reliability, energy efficiency, empirical study, DRAM memory, storage systems

Project_Title: Improving Responsiveness of Interactive Systems Beyond the Limits of Human Perception
Project_Description:
We have an expectation of responsiveness when making input to a computer. In 2011, the computer industry was turned upside down: worldwide sales of tablets and smartphones outpaced PCâ€™s for the first time. This created a crisis in responsiveness: mobile processors are low-power, and slower, and touch input makes latency more apparent as objects lag behind usersâ€™ fingers.

We will build two distinct user interface technologies: (1) one which enables zero-latency computer architectures we have developed, and (2) UI for present-day systems, custom-tailored to hide latency, and reduce its impact on performance. This will be accomplished by deeply understanding human perception and performance with latency, and applying our findings to build new technolog
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Keyword: computer science, HCI, interactive computing, interactive graphics, user interface, input sensing

Project_Title: Understanding How Small RNAs Regulate Gene Expression in the Nucleus
Project_Description: Patterns of gene expression distinguish different cell types (ex. hair and muscle cells express different genes). Misregulated gene expression can lead to cancer and disease, thus there are many cellular safety mechanisms that regulate the process. One key mechanism for controlling gene expression involves inhibitory small RNA molecules that can act in different cellular compartments and at several steps in the process. We focus on understanding how small RNAs regulate gene expression in the cellâ€™s nucleus, where the process of gene expression begins, using a powerful combination of genetics, high throughput DNA sequencing, microscopy and biochemistry in our studies. Small RNA actions in the nucleus are currently poorly understood, yet could provide valuable new avenues for cancer therapeutics and key insights into how cancer emerge
Keyword: small RNA, argonaute, RNA interference (RNAi), regulation of gene expression, transcription, chromatin, C. elegans

Project_Title: Low-Power High-Throughput Computing Through Hardware Customization
Project_Description: The research will improve the performance and energy efficiency of computing by customizing computer hardware to application needs.
