The custom hardware for an application will be generated automatically from the applicationâ€™s software, using an approach called high-level synthesis.  The hardware circuit will be implemented on a field-programmable gate array (FPGA), which is a specialized computer chip that can be configured by the end-user. The research has the potential to change the way hardware design is done today, making it accessible to software engineers, thereby reducing engineering effort and cost. The tools developed will be open source, and Ontario companies involved in computer hardware design stand to benefi
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Keyword: software, hardware, circuits, low-power, energy, performance, computer-aided design, FPGAs

Project_Title: Adhesion Studies In Vesicle/Bilayer Systems
Project_Description: Membranes called bilayers can roll up to form hollow, nanometer-sized particles called vesicles, which are used in therapeutics, fabric softeners and body creams - all multi-million dollar industries in Ontario. These products have large carbon footprints in their lifecycles due to their high water contents. Unfortunately, the high water fractions are necessary to avoid the adhesion or sticking of vesicles that renders these products unstable. This project will lead to scientific processes that circumvent adhesion and produce stable, concentrated products, thereby significantly reducing their carbon footprint. A second objective of this proposal is to study adhesion in the hysiologicallyoccurring bilayer, myelin, for understanding multiple sclerosis (MS), a disease that afflicts thousands of Ontarians.
Keyword: vesicle, bilayer, adhesion, carbon footprint, volume fraction, deformability, myelin, multiple sclerosis, creaming instability, force measurement

Project_Title: Understanding Memory Disorders: Why Does Brain Damage Impair Memory?
Project_Description: Memory disorders such as Alzheimerâ€™s disease touch the lives of hundreds of thousands of Ontarians and cost Ontario taxpayers billions of dollars. Their destructive consequences are far reaching â€“ it burdens those afflicted, their families and caretakers, and the broader health care system. Despite years of research, we know very little about the neural mechanisms underlying the profound memory loss that so often follows brain damage. Knowledge gained through the present research will elucidate the link between brain damage and the complex cognitive problems seen in memory disorders. This work opens new possibilities for improved diagnostic techniques and rehabilitative strategies in memory disord
Keyword: cognitive neuroscience, neuropsychology, neuroimaging, fMIR, amnesia, Alzheimer's disease, memory, perception, perihinal cortex, medial temporal lobe

Project_Title: Organization of Cortical Memory Network in Health and Disease
Project_Description:
My research aims to uncover physiological mechanisms of memory and their dysfunction in Alzheimerâ€™s disease (AD). 

These mechanisms are examined by measuring the activity of multiple cells at millisecond resolution in several cortical regions of rats performing associative learning paradigms while precisely manipulating connections between cortical regions or gene expression associated with AD pathogenesis.

The novel mechanistic insights at neuronal network level will be translated into early interventions to diagnose, halt or even reverse the progression of AD ï€­ one of the biggest health challenges in Ontario. This would also have far-reaching consequence internationally, thereby critically raising Ontarioâ€™s academic pr
Keyword: consolidation, neurophysiology, behavioural neuroscience, psychopharmacology, Alzheimer's disease, prefrontal cortex, hippocampus, entohinal cortex, classical conditioning, rodents

Project_Title: Large-Scale Computational/Experimental Distributed Simulation Framework for Civil Infrastructures
Project_Description: Simulating the failure process of a structure subjected to extreme loads, such as earthquakes, fire, or strong winds, is still a very challenging task. In the proposed research, a framework for the large-scale computational/experimental distributed simulation of civil infrastructure will be developed. The framework will consist of a main simulation module running in a supercomputer, state-of-art numerical substructure modules, and experimental substructure modules. The framework will allow for a fast continuous distributed simulation through the Internet. The research project will make Ontario a hub of high-end structural simulation and provide unique training opportunities to HQPs.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Keyword: seismic simulation, hybrid (experiement-analysis) simulation, distributed testing

Project_Title: The Development of Antimicrobials Through The Structural Investigation of Membrane Proteins
Project_Description: Research in the Moraes lab examines protein and ion translocation across bacterial membranes.  In particular, the Moraes lab dissects the components of these pathways examining their interactions in molecular detail.   Biochemical tools such as X-ray crystallography provide us with atomic resolution 3D-models of the proteins, while surface plasmon resonance, isothermal calorimetry or bio-layer interferometry are used to determine kinetic parameters and validate models that describe their mechanism of action. These membrane proteins have various receptor and transport functions that are essential for pathogenic bacteria to survive within the host, thus this research provides the basis for developing novel antimicrobial therapeutics including vaccines and novel antibiotics.
Keyword: biochemistry, microbiology, structural biology, membrane proteins, vaccine, bacterial pathogenesis, biomolecular interactions

Project_Title: From child to scientist: Using symbolic media to promote science education in young children
Project_Description: According to the Ontario Ministry of Education an important learning area for children in the Full-Day Early Learning Program is the area of â€œgeneral knowledgeâ€, that is of factual knowledge about the world around them. For this project I will work with teachers and graduate students to design a feasible, classroom intervention that guides Grade K children towards a rudimentary, mechanistic understanding of science concepts by using the pedagogical tool of picture storybooks. One benefit of introducing young children to science concepts and methods before elementary school years is to increase foundational knowledge in children from different socio-economic backgro
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Keyword: science learning, education, inquiry-based learning, children, picture books, explorative play, Full Day Kindergarten, randomized control trial intervention

Project_Title: Geometric and structural graph theory
Project_Description: Networks have become a pervasive element of modern life. For example, most people today know what a â€œsocial networkâ€ is, and what â€œsix degrees of separationâ€ refers to, not to mention the â€œinternetâ€. A graph is a ubiquitous mathematical structure that models networks. As such, many practical applications, including information visualization, VLSI design, micro-fabrication, require them to be visualized in 2D or 3D. This project will study fundamental questions in this area with help from the tools of the modern graph theory, namely, the celebrated Graph Minors Theory.  Due to its many links with other areas of computer science, the proposed research has the potential to have a significant impact well beyond its
Keyword: graphs, geometric graphs, graph minors, treewidth, graph visualization, graph drawing, computational geometry, algorithms, data structures

Project_Title: Ice island drift and deterioration modelling
Project_Description: Ice islands are extensive (up to several km long) icebergs that break-off of ice shelves in the High Arctic. Over the last decade, 1000 km2 of ice islands have calved from their parent ice masses under the influence of rapid Arctic climate change. These ice masses are drifting south and breaking into progressively smaller pieces. We will examine the drift and deterioration of ice islands by developing and testing a model of these processes for operational ice hazard forecasting. Relevant capacity developed at Carleton University can be applied to assess and mitigate risks to marine transportation and the offshore petroleum industry. This will enhance a growing node of expertise in marine ice hazards that exists in Eastern Ontario
Keyword: climate change, ice hazards, Arctic, ice island, deterioration, drift, modelling, remote sensing, offshore industry, marine transportation

Project_Title: Mapping the Journey - Inuit perspectives on the role and value of participatory mappingâ€‚
Project_Description: Participatory mapping is commonly used to help document and represent Aboriginal knowledge, but little critical evaluation of the use of mapping has been conducted in an Inuit cultural and geographic context.  This research will investigate the role and value of participatory mapping from Inuit perspectives, based on consultations across Nunavut. These insights will inform new applications such as journey mapping and caribou habitat mapping in Gjoa Haven, NU.  Project outcomes translate into benefits for Ontario by supporting enhanced Ontario university collaboration, involving and training Inuit youth based in Ottawa, and sharing lessons with Far North Ontario land use planning activities to potentially benefit Ontario First Nations.
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development
Keyword: participatory mapping, Inuit, community-based research, multimedia, remote sensing, caribou, Gjoa Haven, Nunavut, youth training, Ontario First Nations

Project_Title: Diversity and phylogenetic community structure of Ontario forest insects: problems and solutions
Project_Description: Incorrectly identifying species has a cascade of serious consequences for science and society. It compromises our capacity to identify diversity, to manage present-day distributions, or to predict those distributions in a changing climate. However, surveys that overlook cryptic diversity amongst the most diverse animals in those forests (the arthropods) diminishes our ability to accurately understand the ecological community dynamics and structures that underpin forest health. HQP from this project will help us understand how forest composition affects the diversity and phylogenetic structure of forest insects. This will help mitigate losses from pest outbreaks and provide great economic benefit to Ontarioâ€™s forest secto
Keyword: biodiversity, species, evolution, ecology, taxonomy, arthropod, insect, DNA barcode, taxonomic development

Project_Title: Development of Preclinical Microfluidic Models for Understanding Clinical Wound Bacterial Biofilms
Project_Description: Ontario spends approximately $1.5 billion towards wound care management annually through several programs. Due to lack of clinically relevant in-vitro and ex-vivo models, our understanding of the biofilm infections on wounds is limited. For designing effective therapeutic strategies to impede bacterial biofilm colonization and for preventing the development of polymicrobial infections, novel wound model systems are essential. The goal of this project is to develop microfluidic 3D culture models such as skin for understanding chronic wound biofilms. The results will help to understand the host inflammatory response to wound infection, and to investigate the antibiotic efficacies against multi-drug pathogens such as Staphylococcus aureus and Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
Keyword: biofilms, microfluids, bionanotechnology, microenvironment, bioimaging, microfabrication, collagen, wound models, staphylococcus aureus, Atomic Force Microscopy

Project_Title: Parent-child feeding interactions: Identifying best practices for a healthy weight.
Project_Description: The overarching goal of this research is to improve the health of Ontarioâ€™s children by developing â€˜best practicesâ€™ for parental feeding practices. Due to inferential limitations of current research, our understanding of how parental feeding practices influence childrenâ€™s dietary intake and obesity risk is limited. This gap in knowledge hinders our ability to develop effective obesity prevention interventions. The proposed research will address this fundamental gap by using novel observation techniques to determine how parental feeding practices are related to childrenâ€™s dietary intake and obesity risk. This information will optimize childhood obesity prevention interventions as well as paediatric clinical care i
Keyword: parental feeding, obesity prevention, chronic disease prevention, dietary intake, observational techniques, preschool aged children

Project_Title: Metal(loid) toxicity and mobility in the environment: development of novel biosensors.
Project_Description: Ontario is a leader in Canadaâ€™s metal production and metal use in industry, agriculture and healthcare is expected to further increase. By-products from metal mining and processing activities may be harmful to ecosystems. Dr. Poulain proposes to develop new, microbe-based diagnostic tools to track the toxicity and mobility or metal(loid)s in effluents and wastewaters. These new tools are aimed at ultimately improving: environmental risk assessment of metal mining; monitoring of effluents originating from metallurgical industrial activities; pollution prevention strategies; and potential remediation efforts. Biosensors are versatile, flexible and economical to use and operat
Keyword: metals, bacteria, mining, smelting, toxicity, metal mixtures, bioreporter, monitoring, policy, contaminants

Project_Title: Multifunctional Supramolecular Conjugated Materials for Molecular Electronics
Project_Description: Since the digital revolution, information storage and global communications have transformed how we live. Essential to the continuation of technological advancements is the need for smaller, lighter, inexpensive and more efficient electronic, optical and magnetic materials. The proposed research addresses these challenges through the design and synthesis of new magneto-optoelectronic materials for molecular electronics. The development of self-organizing multifunctional advanced materials will not only benefit existing Ontario high-tech companies, but also bolster Ontarioâ€™s clean energy, information technology, materials and nanotechnology sectors. Furthermore, HQP will obtain an exceptionally rich and diverse set of research skills ready to enter Ontarioâ€™s work fo
Keyword: conjugated macromolecules, neutral radicals, heterocyclic materials, organic electronics, magnetic materials, coordination complexes, organic semiconductors, metal-organic-frameworks, molecular conductors, synthesis

Project_Title: Origin and fate of genetic diversity in economically relevant microbes
Project_Description: Microbes are central to the health and wealth of humans worldwide, either as agents of diseases or beneficial symbionts. Not all members of one microbial species affect human activities in similar ways, however, and the main goal of the proposed research is to identify the mechanisms involved in the origin of this intra-specific variation; with applications in medicine and agricultural practices. Such mechanisms will be sought in two microbial lineages that are important for economic activities in Ontario by exploring the genetic make-up of their populations using state-of the-art molecular biology tools, cutting-edge bioinformatics techniques, and targeted experimental approaches.
Keyword: fungal symbionts, opportunistic pathogens, virulence, population genomics, next generation sequencing, bioinformatics, selection, recombination

Project_Title: Examining the responses of individuals and populations to environmental stressors
Project_Description: The health of populations and ecosystems is built upon the capacity of individuals to succeed (survive and breed) under continuously changing environmental circumstances. This research program will determine whether individual variation and flexibility in the response to, and management of, multiple environmental stressors leads to some mothers and offspring being better able to cope than others within rapidly changing ecosystems such as the Great Lakes and the Canadian Arctic. The research uses carefully chosen bird and fish systems linked to specific targeted questions centred around maternal and environmental stress to determine whether individual differences and flexibility in stress management has the capacity to buffer organisms from ongoing human-induced environmental change.
Keyword: maternal stress, environmental stressor, fitness, stress physiology, reproductive decisions, climate change, maternal effect, Great Lakes region, Lake Ontario, Arctic ecosystem

Project_Title: Learning from the experiences of adolescents with mental illness, their families and service providers to co-design more coordinated services and better transitions in Ontario: Design rules, barriers and facilitators
Project_Description: Services for adolescents with mental illness in Ontario are fragmented, with youth at risk of falling through the cracks as they transition to adult services. Poor coordination between primary care, hospital, community, school-based and other services hampers the ability to meet peoplesâ€™ multiple needs in a consistent manner. Using experience-based design, adolescentsâ€™ experiences will be gathered in real time using smart phone technology as they journey through multiple services. â€˜Touch pointsâ€™ that shape experiences will be identified and then co-designed through a series of meetings involving adolescents, family members and providers. Design rules, policy barriers and facilitators to their implementation will be id
Keyword: mental health services, coordination, transitions, experience-based design, policy frameworks, personal technology, mental health trialogues, design rules, policy barriers and facilitators

Project_Title: Informatic searches for bioactive natural products
Project_Description: Nature is a constant inspiration for drug discovery, evident by the numbers of diseases treated by naturally derived small molecules and the billons of dollars these natural products contribute to the economy per annum. Whilst it is clear that known natural products are of significant economic and therapeutic importance, an urgent need exists for safer, more effective and targeted medicines for Ontarians and this ERA award will focus directly on this need. It will deliver new drug leads and create patented drug discovery technologies to spur Ontarioâ€™s bioeconom
Keyword: natural products, microbe, drug discovery, medicinal compounds, microbiome, biosynthesis

Project_Title: Developmental of a Diabetes Economic Model
Project_Description: The objective of this program of research is to develop a state-of-the-art diabetes disease model to help health-policy makers determine the most efficient way to spend resources on diabetes.  Analysis of information from clinical and economic sources will be used to create a computerized model that simulates diabetes progression and predict whether a person will experience a complication (e.g. stroke) and whether changes in risk factors (e.g. high blood pressure) can alter the occurrence of future complications.  A current and flexible disease model will be useful for policy makers responsible for making decisions regarding the provision of diabetes care.
Keyword: economic evaluation, cost-effectiveness, diabetes mellitus, disease modelling

Project_Title: Natureâ€™s solutions to oxygen deprivati
Project_Description: Almost all animals require a steady supply of oxygen. Oxygen limitation â€“ which can arise clinically or in many extreme environments in nature â€“ can be catastrophic to normal cellular function because it impairs aerobic metabolism. And yet, some unique species of mammals, birds, and fish thrive in environments where oxygen is scarce. The proposed research will elucidate how the respiratory systems of these animals are unique compared to most others, and how cellular and mitochondrial function is maintained during low oxygen. It will provide important insight into natureâ€™s solutions to an important clinical and environmental problem, while training 4 graduate and many BSc stu
Keyword: comparative physiology, respiratory physiology, hypoxia, high altitude, oxygen transport pathway, mammals, fish

Project_Title: Sustainable synthetic fuels: combining biomass, natural gas, and nuclear energy to produce diesel and gasoline with reduced CO2 emissions.
Project_Description: This proposal addresses the issue of sustainable energy conversion. We will study a novel process which converts biomass, natural gas, and nuclear energy into diesel and gasoline with improved efficiencies and considerably reduced CO2 emissions across the entire life cycle. The process will be investigated in detail using computer simulations, economic analyses, and life cycle analyses which will quantify its benefits, risks, costs, technical feasibility, environmental sustainability, and economic impact on the province. Due to its status as a leader in nuclear energy, Ontario is ideally suited for the process which would create hundreds of jobs and position Ontario as the worldâ€™s lead exporter of products derived from nuclear energ
Keyword: biomass, natural gas, nuclear energy, gasoline, diesel, sustainability, CO2 capture

Project_Title: Improving regenerative therapy through understanding how the Msi2 protein promotes blood stem cells
Project_Description: Life-saving blood stem cell transplants are currently severely hindered by the shortage of hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs) in donor samples. I have recently identified the RNA binding protein Msi2 as an important enhancer of mouse HSC self-renewal, a process which multiplies these cells. Here I propose to use state-of-the-art technologies to determine the HSC-specific RNA targets of Msi2 and to identify which of these mediate its positive effects on HSCs. This research aims to identify Msi2-regulated pathways that, when manipulated, could amplify human HSC, a possibility which would profoundly improve regenerative HSC therapies and provide associated economic benefits for Ontario.
Keyword: hematopoietic stem cells, self-renewal, RNA binding protein, mRNA, regenerative therapy, transplantation

Project_Title: Developing novel blood tests to predict complications of diabetes
Project_Description: Over 9 million Canadians currently have diabetes or prediabetes.  In people with diabetes, heart disease is the leading cause of death and accounts for over half of all mortality.  Diabetes is also the leading cause of kidney disease in Canada.  Despite all of this, there is currently no tool to help physicians determine which individuals with diabetes are at high risk of developing heart or kidney complications.  Our project seeks to develop such tools by combining blood analysis with genetic analysis to help provide early and maximal preventive therapy to individuals with diabetes at high risk of complications.
Keyword: diabetes, biomarkers, genetics, kidney disease, cardiovascular disease, risk prediction, pharmacogenetics, personalized medicine

Project_Title: Learning to Read and Reading to Learn
Project_Description: According to Statistics Canada (2005) over 15 million Canadians are unable to read at a level necessary to be successful at work and in day-to-day life. The most common cause of oneâ€™s failure to develop adequate reading comprehension is a difficulty in recognizing printed words. Little is known about how cognitive characteristics of readers affect this component of reading. We propose an experimental investigation of individual variability in word recognition, as found in an understudied non-clinical population of low-literacy young adults in Ontario. Our research explores causes of reading difficulty at the levels of cognition, emotion and sensation, and will inform current methods of adult literacy teaching and learnin
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development
Keyword: reading, literacy, psycholinguists, cognition, emotional and sensation, eye-movements, statistical modeling, work recognition, text comprehension, learning

Project_Title: Understanding the interplay between inflammation and impaired anti-bacterial immunity in the elderly
Project_Description: It is unclear why susceptibility to bacterial pneumonia begins to increase in middle age (i.e 55 yrs); however, these infections become increasingly common and costly to treat with age. In addition, acquiring bacterial pneumonia in mid- or late life often exacerbates or accelerates sub-clinical or existing chronic inflammatory conditions, decreasing the quality of life and increasing the cost of care.  This proposal investigates the mechanisms of susceptibility to the major causative agent of pneumonia in the elderly, Streptococcus pneumoniae, and the interplay between age-associated inflammation, chronic inflammatory diseases and the anti-bacterial response, targeting age-associated inflammation as a novel therapeutic target.
Keyword: aging, elderly, immunoscience, chronic inflammation, infection, leukocytes, pneumonia, chronic disease, macrophage

Project_Title: Exercise and cardiovascular health after stroke
Project_Description: At nearly $1B, the annual costs associated with stroke are high in Ontario. People living with stroke often also have cardiovascular health issues, yet face challenges in their walking ability to maintain active lifestyles to counteract these risk factors. My research examines how exercise and regular physical activity can improve walking and fitness after stroke, improve overall health, and lower the risk for future strokes. This research has the potential to improve stroke care and lower health care costs in Ontario. It is aligned with the aims of the Ministry of Health and Long-Term Care Ontario Stroke Strategy, and the Heart and Stroke Foundation to reduce the incidence and burden of stroke.
Keyword: stroke, rehabilitation, physical fitness, exercise, walking, risk factors, secondary prevention, cardiovascular disease

Project_Title: Predictors of treatment response in individuals with depression
Project_Description: Depression is a major public health concern that affects 10-15% of Canadians. To date, there are no tests that allow us to predict those who will respond to different treatment modalities. In our study, 200 individuals with depression will undergo a brain-imaging exam during a treatment trial. We will combine clinical and brain-imaging results using advanced mathematical techniques to reveal patientsâ€™ unique characteristics that will guide treatment choice. This study has the potential to develop a more accurate treatment selection, which would decrease the length of individualâ€™s emotional suffering. This could have major impact decreasing the economic costs associated with work loss in our Provi
Keyword: biomarkers, predictors, treatment, brain imaging, MRI, major depression

Project_Title: Development of New Nanocomposites for Advanced Medical Devices
Project_Description: Advanced nanocomposites with multifunctional properties are specialized emerging materials, in which engineered nanoparticles are incorporated into biopolymer matrices. They are playing a critical role in many fields, e.g. lightweight products, e-paper, and poin-of-care medical devices. Dr. Zhang's research involves development of a near infrared (NIR) laser-assisted technique to produce biocompatible nanocomposites for advanced biomedical devices. Trainees will use world-class facilities for manipulating the interface of inorganic-organic molecules. The proposed research nicely integrates the fields of biomaterials engineering and nanotechnology, and will make a significant impact on the micro/nanofabrication and biotechnology in Ontario.
Keyword: nanocomposites, nanoparticles, biopolymer, NIR laser deposition, NIR-sensitive nanomaterials, biosensor

Project_Title: Exploring the connections between land, cultural continuity and health using a Community Based Research Approach with First Nations in Southwestern Ontario
Project_Description: This research proposal employs an interdisciplinary, Community Based Research (CBR) approach that will link Ontario First Nation communities and organizations with Highly Qualified Personnel from the Indigenous Health Lab (Western University) to design and carry out mixed-methods research on inter-related issues of health, environmental change and cultural continuity.   This innovative research approach builds on a critical new paradigm that is currently framing the way Aboriginal health research is done in Canada. These participatory methods are anchored in CBR that capitalizes on research as a tool for enabling Ontarioâ€™s First Nation communities to build local capacity, and identify tangible strategies for overcoming the most pressing health challenge
Keyword: community based research, firt nations, health, culture, land, integrated knowlesge, translation, mixed methods

Project_Title: The genetic basis of mating behaviours underlying species isolation.
Project_Description: The formation of new species gives rise to the wide array of biodiversity we see today, yet very little is known about the underlying process of speciation, hindering the ability to make informed policy decisions on conservation policy in Ontario. My lab's research focuses on the genetics of species isolation, in particular the basis of behaviours that prevent two species from mating. These behaviours are thought to be the first barrier that arises in the process of speciation, and thus understanding their genetic basis will provide an understanding of the basis of species formation, allowing a stronger definition of what constitutes a species and how to maintain Ontario's current level of biodiversity.
Keyword: speciation, reproductive isolation, behaviour genetics, genetic variation, quantitative genetics, drosophila

Project_Title: Functional consequences of biodiversity
Project_Description: The loss of biodiversity is the greatest threat facing ecosystems in the world today. My research provides the scientific basis for the mitigation of this threat by uncovering the drivers of biodiversity loss, and the consequences of loss on ecosystem function and resultant services. My lab will experimentally study biodiversity in the context of global change, specifically the role of forest soil biodiversity in the regulation of carbon storage and forest productivity. This research will be the first to incorporate soil biodiversity into the understanding of forest function, leading to the protection and management of healthy Canadian forests and ensuring their viability in a changing environment.
Keyword: biodiversity, boreal forest, carbon storage, climate change, decomposition, ecosystem function, nitrogen fixation, nutrient cycling, trait-based

Project_Title: Novel approaches to target empathy deficits in frontotemporal dementia and related disorders
Project_Description: Sensitivity to the emotions of others is a critical cognitive function that enables positive social behaviour. In some neuropsychiatric diseases including dementia, patients lack the capacity for empathy. This symptom is one of the most devastating for caregivers, and currently is untreatable. The training of HQP in dementia research is critical as within one generation the prevalence in Canada will climb to over 1 million. The overall goal of my research program is to identify and delineate the cognitive mechanisms which breakdown and lead to inappropriate behaviours. The proposed research will train HQP to examine the basis of empathy deficits and potential therapeutic interventions for patients with dementia and related disorders.
Keyword: frontotemporal dementia, social cognition, emotion, empathy, oxytocin, neuroimaging, biomarkers

Project_Title: Multi-scale experimental and computer modeling of wind effects on the built-environment
Project_Description: Simulation of wind and its interaction with the built-environment is a complex process that requires unique high resolution laboratory and computer modeling.  This proposal will develop new urban wind environment models for useful for sustainable building design/retrofit that will utilize Blue Gene Q  (Canadaâ€™s #1 super computer). The performance of the new numerical model will be assessed in comparison with WindEEE (the newly constructed, one-of-a-kind large-scale wind testing facility capable of simulating various wind systems and their interaction with buildings and neighbourhoods). Ultimately, this project will provide a brand new tool that will enable Ontarioâ€™s infrastructure to minimize the impact of extreme weather and to maximize effectiveness of energy efficient design and environmental protection initiati
Keyword: urban wind environment, sustainable buildings, resilient buildings, vegetated roofs, computational fluid dynamics, wind load, pedestrian level wind, natural ventilation

Project_Title: Housing the workforce: The effect of economic restructuring on young workersâ€™ housing dema
Project_Description: The objective of this research is to analyze how economic restructuring influences young workersâ€™ housing and location decisions in Ontario and other North American cities. Restructuring resulted in service sector growth but also more frequent job changes and reduced income security. Implications for young adultsâ€™ housing situations are not yet fully understood. Developing a survey, the research evaluates implications for affordability, homeownership, locational preferences and demands for urban amenities and infrastructures. The research informs innovative housing policy and infrastructure investments in Ontario. It helps train highly qualified personnel in housing market analysis, and aims to position Ontario as a leader in this fi
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development
Keyword: housing, affordability, young adults, tenure, labour markets, economic restructuring, flexible labour, new economy, residential location

Project_Title: The Stratford Festival Online: Games and Virtual Learning Environments for Education and Audience Engagement
Project_Description: This project builds on a pilot collaboration among the University of Waterloo, the Stratford Festival, and the Kitchener-Waterloo digital media industry to build a centre for collaborative innovation in the digital media, creative arts, and education sectors of Ontarioâ€™s knowledge economy. To develop long term theatre audiences, establish a gamification research centre, and model tri-sector collaboration, it will produce three digital educational games, an online theatrical learning environment, a metadata protocol for encoding promptbooks, digital editions of archived promptbooks for three plays, an interactive interface for audience engagement and theatre research, and a white paper on policies and processes for tri-sector collaborati
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Keyword: educational games, virtual learning environments, theatre education, theatrical production history, digital editions, data encoding, performance visualization, theatre archives, archive digitalization, audience engagement

Project_Title: Retirement in Transition:  A Life Course Perspective on Diverse Family Adaptations to Cumulative Disadvantage in Later Life
Project_Description: Retirement planning is critical for financial security and wellbeing as people age and the aging of the population adds urgency to this topic. The increasing diversity of family forms in Ontario (e.g., cohabiters, same-sex couples, single parents) represents another major demographic shift, but little is known about their retirement planning. Dr. Mock and his research team will examine the retirement planning of diverse family forms with nationally representative data and longitudinal survey research to uncover potential challenges and adaptive strategies. This project will be informed by a university/business partnership to yield insights of economic and social benefit to Ontario
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development
Keyword: retirment planning, family, marriage, sexual orientation, gender, wellbeing, life course

Project_Title: Towards a Self-Correcting Quantum Computer Based on Superconducting Nano-Circuits
Project_Description: In 1982 R. Feynman conjectured that quantum computers can solve certain problems much more efficiently than any classical computer. Quantum computers will be key for communication security, materialsâ€™ analysis, and drug synthesis. However, quantum computers suffer from errors that degrade the information being processed. Hence, Dr. Mariantoni proposes to build a self-correcting quantum memory, a key element for the correction of errors in a quantum computer. The implementation will be based on superconducting devices realized on silicon chips. The proposed research will promote Ontarioâ€™s strive for excellence in novel aspects of information technology, while furthering the province leadership in the international academic establishm
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Keyword: quantum computing, superconducting quantum circuits, Josephson junctions, microwave devices, nano fabrication, surface code, fault tolerance, quantum memory, topological order, anyons

Project_Title: Resource Control for Dynamic Binary Instrumentation
Project_Description: This project will develop new methods and tools to understand programs at run time. The tools will help developers understand why programs function, and why they malfunction. We will investigate methods for extracting information from programs at run time, specifying constraints on when to extract information, and develop an free tool for Ontarioâ€™s embedded software industry. Resulting techniques will replace current expensive trial-and-error practices and boost developer productivity. Currently, Ontario has over 300 companies serving its embedded systems industry in a global market valued at over $100 billion; this research will reduce development costs and improve competitiveness of this vital sect
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Keyword: software development, instrumentation, monitoring, embedded systems, real-time systems

Project_Title: Speak freely: improving vocal quality of patients with total laryngectomies
Project_Description: Each year, nearly 1000 Ontarians are diagnosed with laryngeal cancer, requiring their voice box to be removed. Surgical construction can restore a facsimile of voiced speech in some patients via an internal prosthesis. There is, however, no good predictor for the success of the surgery at restoring voice, due in part to the poor understanding of the fluid-structure-acoustic coupling in the reconstructed vocal tract. This proposal aims, for the first time, to construct predictive models of this speech modality in order to establish guidelines for pre- and post-surgical treatment to recover the best possible voice by exploring tissue compliance and implant type, placement, and orientation, and the resulting produced sound
Keyword: human phonation, tracheoesophageal speech, laryngectomy, fluid mechanics, fluid-structure interaction, computational modeling, optical diagnostics

Project_Title: Nanoparticle-based eye drop delivery platform for the targeted treatment of glaucoma
Project_Description: Glaucoma is a leading cause of blindness in Ontario, and is currently treated using eye drops through a complicated medication schedule (2-3 times daily) that is difficult to follow, particularly by the elderly population. The ERA research aims to develop mucoadhesive nanoparticles that can adhere to the eye and perform tunable releases of glaucoma medications for multiple days after one application. We will determine the optimal nanoparticle properties required for rapid adhesion to the eye, followed by optimizing the drug release kinetics. This research will lead to the development of novel therapeutics for glaucoma and will help maintain Ontarioâ€™s competitive advantage in the global pharmaceutical and healthcare industrie
Keyword: nanotechnology, targeted therapy, ocular diseases, controlled release, polymers, nanomaterials, nanomedicine

Project_Title: Advanced Carbon Nanomaterials for Next Generation Supercapacitors
Project_Description: We will develop a new method to measure 3D CTF caused by migration in 3D physiological ECM, providing a more accurate tool for earlier diagnosis of cancer, cardiovascular disease, and other devastating illnesses, helping Ontario reduce healthcare costs and improve the quality of life.
Keyword: graphene, carbon nanotubes, carbon nanomaterials, energy storage, energy conversion, supercapacitor

Project_Title: The history and politics of Indigenous heritage sites in Canada
Project_Description: This research program concentrates on the interface between discourses of heritage preservation and resource/urban development in Canada. It examines how various Indigenous communities understand and draw on multiple and shifting concepts of â€œheritage,â€ and how â€œheritageâ€ has been deployed in a number of historical, political, and economic contexts. The program will produce virtual and material exhibits (incorporating 3-D printing and digital technologies) and scholarly publications that highlight case studies from Ontario. Given contemporary debates about the relationship between Aboriginal rights, resource development, and local and national culture, this project will make culturally appropriate research accessible to community-based researchers, academics, heritage professionals, policy makers, and the
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development
Keyword: indigenous history, resource development, digital technologies, heritage, history of archeology, material culture, oral traditions, legal traditions, museum studies

Project_Title: Nutrition and Metabolism in Breast Cancer
Project_Description: Despite the success of breast cancer chemotherapy treatments, patients gain fat and lose muscle during treatment and in survivorship, which increase risk of cancer recurrence, diabetes and cardiovascular disease. Dr. Mourtzakis will characterize nutrition, metabolic, physical activity and body composition parameters of newly diagnosed breast cancer patients during chemotherapy treatment, and assess the effectiveness of a combined nutrition and exercise intervention on body composition and metabolism. Her findings will lead to cost-effective nutrition and exercise therapies that aim to improve the health of Ontario breast cancer survivors and ultimately reduce the risk of cancer recurrence or other diseases.
Keyword: body composition, glucose metabolism, muscle anatomy, muscle metabolism, nutrition, exercise, protein metabolism, cancer

Project_Title: Building Blocks for a Quantum Communication Network
Project_Description: Quantum information science has advanced rapidly, with quantum cryptography systems already commercially available. These systems are quantum channels that allow quantum information to be distributed over long distances. The proposed research is focused on combining these channels with quantum nodes which offer basic memory, processing and routing capability. The combination of these channels and nodes will create a fully quantum network, enabling applications simply impossible today. The application and development of this technology will have a significant and potentially disruptive impact on information and communications technology, an important industry in Ontario, generating over $85 billion in annual revenue.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Keyword: circuit QED, microwave quantum optics, superconducting quibits, mesoscopic physics

Project_Title: Nutrient Legacies in Anthropogenic Landscapes: A coupled modeling-monitoring framework for improving drinking water quality and aquatic ecosystem health
Project_Description: Nutrients (nitrogen and phosphorus) are placing drinking water quality at risk and threatening the ecosystem health of surface waters in southern Ontario. The objective of my research is to clarify ways in which nutrients may accumulate across anthropogenic landscapes, and the time periods over which these nutrient legacies may be released into aquatic ecosystems. The research will include creating nutrient budgets for the Grand River Watershed (GRW) to estimate legacy, obtaining soil cores to quantify accumulation, and modeling of legacy accumulation. Maps of legacy accumulation and time lags will be created for the GRW that can be used by the province to identify sites where management practices will yield the greatest water quality benefits.
Keyword: biogeochemistry, ecohydrology, watershed modelling, nutrient, source water protection, human impact, time lag, agriculture, water quality, groundwater vulnerability

Project_Title: Human Motion Analysis for Rehabilitation and Human-Robot Interaction
Project_Description: Human motion is difficult to analyze due to its high complexity and spatial and temporal variability, caused by multiple factors including fatigue, changes in movement strategy, and injury, rehabilitation and aging. This proposal aims to develop analysis and modeling tools to enable accurate human motion measurement, modeling and prediction, based on on-line, continuous observation of motion, taking short and long term temporal variability into account. These tools will enable quantitative diagnosis and analysis of patient progress during rehabilitation, and improve safety and task effectiveness during human-robot interaction, enabling collaborative robots to improve productivity and safety in Ontarioâ€™s advanced manufacturing setting
Keyword: human motion analysis, on-line incremental learning, automated rehabilitation systems, human-robot interaction

Project_Title: Dissecting the neural mechanisms underlying the â€œnear-miss effectâ€ in problem gamb
Project_Description: Near-misses, such as occur when the third cherry on a slot machine stops just short of the win line, are powerful drivers of behavior. In problem gamblers -- about 2% of Ontarians -- specific reward-related brain areas show abnormal responses to near-misses. I propose to identify (1) the neural mechanisms responsible for the near-miss effect, and (2) individual differences or â€œmarkersâ€ that predict vulnerability to near misses. This work will facilitate targeted prevention and coping strategies for problem gambling, and contribute a new dimension to models of normal and dysfunctional decision-making necessary to sustain long-term innova
Keyword: neuroscience, reinforcement learning, decision-making, gambling, addiction, dopamine, rodent models, electrophysiology, optogenetics, decoding

Project_Title: Improving relevance of randomized trials for equity-oriented decisions
Project_Description: This program will improve the appropriate inclusion and analysis of vulnerable populations in clinical trials. This program will:1) Assess the extent to which randomized controlled trials report and analyze information about health equity; 2) Assess available guidelines for randomized controlled trials and the analysis of health equity; 3) Consult with global experts on appropriate methods; and 4) Reach formal consensus on items for reporting health equity in randomized controlled trials. We will use innovative knowledge translation methods to promote uptake.  This research will benefit Ontario by improving the relevance of funded research to the most vulnerable and disadvantaged populations, thus contributing to promoting health equity.
Keyword: health equity, clinical epidemiology, randomized controlled trials, reporting guidelines, systematic reviews, vulnerable populations

Project_Title: High-frequency trading in financial markets
Project_Description: The proposed program focuses on the recent structural shift in global financial markets whereby high-speed computers have crowded out human traders. High-speed computerized trading is common in Canadian markets, including the Toronto Stock Exchange. Given the ultra-high frequencies at which computers switch positions (their speeds are often incomprehensible by human senses), regulators such as the Ontario Securities Commission are questioning the effects of high-frequency trading on functionality and fairness of financial markets. The proposed program will use the latest data and methods to answer the question pondered by regulators: Should high-frequency trading be restricted? The results will be essential for evidence-based policymaking
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Keyword: securities markets, market structure and regulation, high-frequency trading

Project_Title: Analyzing Indigenous-Local Intergovernmental Partnerships in Canada: Why does cooperation occur and what impact does it have on Indigenous-settler relations?
Project_Description: This project examines the emerging partnerships between Indigenous and local/regional governments in Canada.  It seeks to uncover the factors that generate cooperation between these governments and to assess the effects of these partnerships on Indigenous-settler relations at the local level and writ large. To do so, the research team will gather and analyze all publicly available Indigenous-municipal intergovernmental agreements. Specific instances of cooperation will also be studied using qualitative methodology. The research findings will be useful for government and non-government stakeholders interested in fostering better relationships between Indigenous and local/regional governments in Canada and abroad.
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development
Keyword: indigenous-municipal intergovernmental relations, indigenous-settler relations, federalism and multilevel governance

Project_Title: Integrating Nanosensors on Microfluidic Devices for Biomedical Applications
Project_Description: Microfluidic and nanofluidic devices offer remarkable advantages over their macroscopic counterparts by exploiting phenomena that start to dominate at these reduced length scales. This research will focus on the development of a microdevice that integrates nanopore sensors with microfluidic sample processing capabilities. We will drive this research by developing a scheme capable of multiplexed detection of disease biomarkers for diagnostics purposes. On-chip functionalities will be integrated providing for high-throughput and point-of-care capabilities. These analytical microdevices will provide new capabilities otherwise not possible using conventional approaches.  Such technologies are bound to benefit the health of Ontarians, while providing opportunities for industrial partnerships in Ontario.
Keyword: microfluids, biosensors, nanopore, disease diagnostics, microfabrication, MEMS, separation technologies, lab-on-a-chip, coulter principle

Project_Title: Improving diagnostic strategies for venous thromboembolism
Project_Description: Venous thromboembolism affects 1-2 /1.000 persons every year. The diagnosis of venous VTE remains a challenge for the physicians. While the risks associated with an untreated VTE (fatal in up to 30% of patients) and with VTE treatment (anticoagulant therapy) make a sure diagnosis necessary, clinical signs and diagnostic tests lack accuracy when used separately. The current proposal aims at improving diagnostic strategies for VTE, integrating new diagnostic tools, and addressing challenges specific to some groups of patients (pregnant women, etc). This will lead to improved care for people from Ontario, and reinforce Ontarioâ€™s world leadership in clinical research on Thrombosi
Keyword: clinical research, diagnosis, venous thromoembolism, clinical decision rules, signs and symptoms, diagnostic tools, diagnostic strategies

Project_Title: Molecular magnetic refrigerants for ultra-low temperature cooling: A â€˜greenâ€™ and energy efficient alternative to heli
Project_Description: Molecular materials have been proposed as candidates for magnetic refrigeration, an energy-efficient and environmentally friendly cooling technology which can provide invaluable solutions in light of the high cost of helium-3 in Ontario. Magnetic refrigeration is based on the magneto-caloric effect (MCE), the change of magnetic entropy upon application of a magnetic field. When the magnetic field is removed, the order of the system decreases and the magnetic entropy increases. To compensate for these changes, energy must be lost and the material cools down. The proposed research will focus on the synthesis of new, ferromagnetic molecular materials with record MCE values.
Keyword: polynuclear high-spin molecules; isotropic metals; azides; organic radicals; magneto-caloric effect; environmentally friendly technologies; low-temperature cooling devices; helium-3; reduced CO2 release; magnetic entropy

Project_Title: Unraveling the alteration history of Mars by rover and terrestrial analogue field and lab studies on volcanic terrains
Project_Description: The proposed work will determine if detections of minor and trace components by bulk chemical and mineralogical instruments onboard the Mars Science Lab Curiosity rover can be used to fingerprint specific alteration processes and conditions by investigating unaltered and altered Hawaiian volcanics.
OIA_AREA: Chemical and biological experimentation for the future
Keyword: Mars geology, basalt geochemistry, volcanology, palagonite alteration

Project_Title: Innovative design and control of comfortable, robust, resilient, and energy efficient condominiums
Project_Description: Ontario has experienced a surge of high-rise condominiums construction. These buildings are prone to occupant discomfort and high heating and cooling loads - a major driver for Ontarioâ€™s costly investment in energy infrastructure. The proposed research addresses this in three major phases: 1) a comprehensive field study to investigate occupant comfort and energy-related behaviour; 2) a simulation-based design methodology and design guidelines, and 3) development of -and demonstration project for- advanced window blind and window opening controls. The research will strengthen Ontario's building stock (economically and environmentally), provide students with hands-on training opportunities, and reduce the need for new energy infrastructur
Keyword: condominium design and construction, building envelope, comfort, model-predictive control, occupant behaviour

Project_Title: Modelling the interactions of radiation with matter to advance radiotherapy for cancer treatment
Project_Description: Simulations of the interactions of radiation with matter are widely used for cancer radiotherapy research and treatment planning.  Although sophisticated code systems have been developed, their application can be limited due to long calculation times or conceptual and fundamental limits.  The proposed research will address these shortcomings through the development of computational approaches to model the interactions of radiation with matter.  These computational tools will be applied to advance knowledge of radiation physics, evaluate and improve radiotherapy for cancer, and develop new treatments; software may be commercialized.  Ontarians may benefit through improved, new, and more efficient cancer treatments.
OIA_AREA: Chemical and biological experimentation for the future
Keyword: Radiation physics, radiation transport, Monte Carlo simulation, dosimetry, radiotherapy, cancer treatment, radiobiology, medical physics, microdosimetry, brachytherapy

Project_Title: Theta-Gamma Coupling and Working Memory in Patients with Late-Life Depression
Project_Description: Late-life depression (LLD) is the second most promising modifiable risk factors for dementia. Cognitive deficits associated with LLD increases the risk of developing dementia. This study uses novel cognitive and neurophysiologic approaches to uncover a biomarker that can lead to the identification of those patients with LLD who will develop dementia. Towards this aim, this study leverages a funded trial that intends to prevent cognitive decline among patients with LLD. The knowledge gained from this research could have a major impact in identifying a new basis for further developments of treatments to prevent cognitive decline in patients with LLD.
Lead_Research_Institution: Centre for Addiction and Mental Health
Keyword: Aging, Alzheimer disease, Cognitive Remediation, Dementia, Depression, Electroencephalography, Mild Cognitive Impairment, Prevention, transcranial Direct Current Stimulation, Working Memory

Project_Title: Oxidative Stress in Complex Mental Illness
Project_Description: Mental illness affects approximately 10-20% of Canadians. The current diagnostic criteria are based on self-reported or behavioral observations and lack substantial biological validation. Identifying biological treatment targets will optimize treatment choice and ultimately prevent the progression of illnesses. One such potential treatment target is oxidative stress, specifically lipid oxidation, which is increased in the brain and peripheral blood cells of patients with complex mental illness. The overall goal of this study is to examine the role of oxidative damage to lipids in white matter integrity of  youth and adults patients with bipolar disorder, schizophrenia and major depression disorder.
Lead_Research_Institution: Centre for Addiction and Mental Health
Keyword: Complex mental illness, bipolar disorder, depression, schizophrenia, oxidative stress, mitochondria, lipids, youth

Project_Title: Burden and Variation in Care of Children with Inflammatory Bowel Disease in Canada: A Population-Based Study
Project_Description: The inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD) are chronic, life-long disorders resulting from inflammation of the gastrointestinal tract. Rates of childhood-onset IBD, including Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis, are rising rapidly in Ontario. This study will use Ontario health databases to describe rates of IBD, as well as the burden these diseases place on the families and the health system. We will describe the variation in care and outcomes faced by children with IBD. This will be part of a larger project, where data from multiple provinces will be combined  to describe the burden of IBD nationwide.
Lead_Research_Institution: Children's Hospital of Eastern Ontario Research Institute Inc.
Keyword: Inflammatory Bowel Disease, Pediatric, Health Services Research, Variation, Epidemiology

Project_Title: Interactive computer play for rehabilitation of children with cerebral palsy: translating motor skills practiced in the virtual world to the real world
Project_Description: One of every 500 Canadians born has Cerebral Palsy, a lifelong condition affecting movement and function that can be improved through physical and occupational therapy. Ongoing therapies are time and resource intensive for our healthcare system and families. Movement-based video games may provide an accessible, efficient, and motivating service delivery model to improve adherence to home-based programs.  This study will develop and evaluate technologies that promote the transference of skills practiced in the virtual world to real world function through innovations in touch/force feedback, introduction of â€œmixed realitiesâ€, and integration of goal-setting and coaching in a customizable, story-based video g
Keyword: virtual reality therapy; interactive computer play; cerebral palsy; motor learning; neuroplasticity; motion capture; telerehabilitation; physical and occupational therapy; computer vision; motivation

Project_Title: Surface Engineering of Sustainable Composites Based on Nanocellulose
Project_Description: Nanometer-sized particles of cellulose, called cellulose nanocrystals (CNCs), have gained attention in the media and research community due to their industrial-scale production, renewable nature, unique properties, and potential to enhance composites, coatings, adhesives, and gels. No commercial products exist currently for CNCs. This proposal aims to design high-performance materials by addressing challenges in nanocellulose product development, including how to improve CNC compatibility and how to thoroughly measure CNCâ€™s interfacial and mechanical properties. Implementation of this research plan will ensure commercial success of CNCs by developing new products and new markets, allowing Ontario to remain at the forefront of nanocellulose discoverie
Keyword: cellulose nanocrystals, bio-nanocomposites, interfacial properties, mechanical properties, adhesion, atomic force microscopy, surface modification, polymer characterization

Project_Title: Developing geochemical proxies for climate changes and biosignatures using stable isotopes
Project_Description: Carbonates are among the most abundant minerals on Earthâ€™s surface.  These minerals of marine or continental origin are used to reconstruct Earth's climate history because the conditions in which they were formed are imprinted in their chemical structure.  My research team will investigate the geochemical properties of carbonate minerals to develop an innovative technique that identifies the environmental conditions and the signatures of biological activities that were present when they formed.  This research will enable us to confidently model future climate variability, allowing Ontario to efficiently prepare relevant government initiatives while providing cutting-edge research opportunities for highly qualified personne
Keyword: Geochemistry, Stable isotope geochemistry, Low-temperature geochemistry, Paleoclimatology, Climate change, Climate proxy, Thermometry, Biosignature, Mineral synthesis, and Carbonate minerals

Project_Title: Simple and Inexpensive Fabrication of Micro and Nanostructured Surfaces for Sensors, Flexible Electronics, and Tissue Engineering Applications
Project_Description: Micro/nanostructured surfaces show unique properties that make them attractive for applications in biosensor, flexible electronics, and tissue engineering. Fabrication approaches currently used to structure surfaces involve one or more expensive or time consuming steps. The research proposed aims at developing simple, rapid and inexpensive ways to fabricate structured surfaces with features tuneable in the micro- to nanoscale and demonstrate their use in biosensing, flexible electronics and cell culture applications. Developing such approaches will enable the creation of inexpensive sensors, diagnostic and biomedical devices that will contribute to advanced health technologies, and therefore enhance the quality of life of Ontarians.
Keyword: Micro and nanofabrication, surface topography, stress-driven wrinkling, thin film, transferrable topography, high surface area electrode, biosensor, flexible electronics, tissue engineering, fluorescence microscopy

Project_Title: How do the bacteria in our gut link obesity, diabetes and fighting infections?
Project_Description: The prevalence of obesity in Ontario is alarming. Obesity causes inflammation and is a major risk factor for type 2 diabetes. We know very little about the potential triggers of inflammation during obesity. There are trillions of bacteria in our gut. Changes in these bacteria can promote and even prevent inflammation inside the body. We discovered that pre-diabetes is linked to a specific group of immune sensors that cause inflammation in response to bacteria and certain drugs (i.e. Lipitor).  We will continue to research how to prevent bugs and drugs from causing pre-diabetes by understanding where immunology and metabolism connect.
Keyword: Insulin, glucose, endocrinology, exercise, obesity, inflammation, physiology, immunometabolism

Project_Title: How dark is Dark Matter? Looking for ways to interact with 80% of the matter in the Universe.
Project_Description: Astrophysical and cosmological observations reveal that 80% of the matter in our Universe is a new form of matter that interacts very weakly with. One of the most compelling possibilities is that it is some new fundamental particle. My proposal's objective is to find new ways to search for the interactions of dark matter with normal matter in several large experimental frontiers: underground labs (e.g. SNOLAB), particle colliders (e.g the LHC), and modern astrophysical observatories (e.g. IceCube). The research will train highly qualified personnel and strengthen the provinceâ€™s profile in the global academic communit
Keyword: Dark Matter, Weak Interactions, Beyond the Standard Model, Astroparticle physics, Direct Detection, Indirect Detection, Large Hadron Collider, SNOLAB

Project_Title: New Frontiers of Fundamental Forces and Matter
Project_Description:
The Universe is largely composed of dark matter of unknown form, which may interact with ordinary matter through
new fundamental forces. My research will pioneer powerful new approaches to study dark matter, search for
undiscovered forces, discover True Muonium, and exp lore theoretical implications and experimental tests of forces
mediated by continuous-spin particles. This work will leverage my international leadership developing new
experiments to search for forces at nuclear length scales, add significantly to Ontario's influential program in particle
physics, and develop cutting-edge experimental techniques to advance dark matter science with strong potential for
technological applications.
Keyword: particle physics phenomenology, dark matter, continuous spin particles, theoretical physics, experimental high-energy physics, collider physics, beyond the Standard Model physics, fixed-target experiments, space-time symmetries, new field theories

Project_Title: Next generation data analysis for cosmic microwave background and large-scale structure
Project_Description:
The goal of cosmology is to answer some of the oldest, most self-motivating questions in science: what is the universe
composed of, how did it begin, and how will it end? Modem cosmology is a data-driven science; we make progress
toward answering these questions largely by doing new experiments. My research spans a range of subfields
including theoretical physics, computational techniques, and data analysis of new and exciting datasets. This research
will benefit Ontario by enhancing its scientific profile in this high-impact field, by training the next generation of
scientists, and by increasing Ontario involvement in cutting-edge international experiments.
Keyword: cosmology, cosmic microwave background, large scale structure, data analysis

Project_Title: Development of Miniaturized Batteries: Application to Portable Diagnostic Systems and Renewable Energies
Project_Description: In the current research, we propose the development of a novel type of rechargeable micro battery with a wide range of applications. A single micro battery can be used for portable medical diagnostic systems benefiting Ontarioâ€™s health care system.  Large numbers of micro batteries can be bundled into stacks with high energy contents despite their small volumes. These stacks could solve the battery bottleneck for electric cars or they can serve in combination with regenerative energy sources as power supply in remote areas of Ontario. We will use a combined experimental and computational approach to develop these batterie
OIA_AREA: Development and creation of investigation spots
Keyword: Microfluidics, Rechargeable Batteries, Regenerative Energy Storage, Lab-on-a-Chip, Electrochemical Engineering

Project_Title: Cognitive and Visual Processing of  Familiar Environments Across the Lifespan
Project_Description: The proposed research will explore how visual and cognitive processing of our environment changes with the increased personal familiarity and how familiarity may act as a mitigating factor in the cognitive decline as we age. Through a series of innovative experiments that use state-of-the-art eye movement and neuroimaging technology, the proposed work is an essential first step towards a thorough understanding of the mechanisms and importance of familiarity in cognitive function over our lifespan. This has important implications for the optimal care for Ontarioâ€™s ballooning senior population, since seniors often exhibit rapid cognitive decline when separated from familiar environment
OIA_AREA: Development and creation of investigation spots
Keyword: visual cognition, visual memory, scene perception, object recognition, visual search, selective attention, eye movements, neuroimaging

Project_Title: THE ROLE OF THE PRENATAL ENVIRONMENT IN ADOLESCENT BRAIN DEVELOPMENT: A STUDY IN ADOLESCENT TWINS
Project_Description: Studies have shown that early adverse environmental exposures increase risk for psychopathology later in life. The proposed research will investigate the brain and molecular mechanisms accounting for this relationship, using data collected in a longitudinal twin cohort. Such research may inform early (preventive) intervention programs that foster brain development and, consequently, prevent psychopathology. This would not only benefit the health of many Ontarians, but also reduce the economic and societal burden associated with psychopathology. Moreover, the research offers highly interdisciplinary training in the mental health field, which will prepare trainees very well for a highly competitive job market.
Keyword: psychopathology; mental health; brain-imaging; depression; serotonin; gene-environment interaction; stress; brain development; epigenetics

Project_Title: Gender Mainstreaming in the Military: Economic and Social Implications for Ontario
Project_Description: The Canadian Armed Forces play a big role in Ontario. The province hosts many of the country's military bases and therefore, understanding the interactions between the women and men who serve on these bases is of paramount importance. Of particular interest are military-to-civilian professional transitions in the province. While Canada could be perceived as a leader in this regard, little research exists to date on this topic. The proposed project focuses on military-to-civilian transitions of service women and men to design professional programs in Ontario that assist veterans' reintegration into civilian life after a career in the Armed Forces.
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development
Keyword: Canadian Armed Forces; Gender; War in Afghanistan; Veterans; Professional Training;

Project_Title: A Neutrinoless Double Beta Decay Search with SNO+
Project_Description: This research seeks to determine whether or not neutrinos are their own anti-particles by searching for a rare nuclear decay process called neutrinoless double beta decay. To do this, tellurium metal will be dissolved into the SNO+ neutrino experiment, which is located at SNOLAB near Sudbury, giving SNO+ world-leading sensitivity to neutrinoless double beta decay. Detecting neutrinoless double beta decay â€“ which would be a major breakthrough in international science  â€“ would prove that neutrinos are their own anti-particles, helping us to better understand not only neutrinos themselves, but also the way that neutrinos have influenced the evolution of the Unive
OIA_AREA: Chemical and biological experimentation for the future
Keyword: particle astrophysics, particle physics, nuclear physics, neutrinoless double beta decay, materials purification, ultra-low background techniques, SNO+, SNOLAB

Project_Title: Activation of Mesenchymal Stem Cells with Danger Signals: Enhancing Bacterial Clearance and Tissue Repair  during sepsis-induced ARDS
Project_Description: When people become critically ill, such as during severe infection, their lungs often fail â€“ termed Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS). ARDS is common, often fatal, and has no treatment. Mesenchymal Stem Cells (MSCs) offer significant hope for ARDS patients, repairing injured lung and reducing damaging inflammation. This project aims to enhance the efficacy of these cells to reliably treat patients with ARDS. If our efforts are successful, we aim to ultimately develop a new MSC therapy to save the lives of ARDS patients and improve the quality of life of survivors in Ontari
Keyword: Sepsis, Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome, Mesenchymal Stem Cells, Macrophages, Phagocytosis

Project_Title: Responding to the needs of policy-makers through systematic reviews and network meta-analysis
Project_Description: Policy-makers make decisions at the systems level and require information on all potential interventions in a timely manner. Conducting a systematic review and network meta-analysis (NMA) is the only feasible approach to formally compare the safety and effectiveness of all interventions. I aim to improve the methods of NMA by identifying methods for: integrating complex evidence (e.g., patient preferences) from multiple sources (e.g., qualitative, observational studies); conducting NMA of complex interventions; conducting NMA in a timelier manner without compromising validity of results. This will optimize decision-making capabilities through increased availability of timely evidence-based findings, leading to enhanced healthcare in Ontario.
Keyword: systematic reviews, network meta-analysis, knowledge synthesis, research methods, decision-making, complex interventions, drug safety and effectiveness

Project_Title: microRNA as mediators of aggression and therapy resistance in prostate cancer
Project_Description: Found through their alteration in prostate cancer, our group has linked specific small fragments of genetic material to increased radiation resistance.  By investigating the mechanism of these microRNAs in promoting resistance to  therapy, we aim to develop microRNAs as predictive biomarkers to identify resistant forms of prostate cancer through a urine test and to further explore microRNAs as identifiers of aggressive forms of prostate cancer.  This will allow a simple screen to detect early on hard-to-treat prostate cancers in patients so that more efficient decisions with a personalized course can be made upon diagnosis, effectively improving outcomes.
Keyword: prostate cancer, radiation treatment, therapy resistance, microRNA, biomarkers

Project_Title: The Ontario Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) Population Health Network
Project_Description: Dr. Gershon is a scientist at Sunnybrook Research Institute and the Institute for Clinical Evaluative Sciences and a practicing respirologist. She is an internationally-recognized health services researcher who, although early in her career, has already published 53 peer reviewed journal articles including articles in the Lancet and Annals of Internal Medicine.  As a principal investigator, she has held more than two million dollars in peer-reviewed funding from the Canadian Institutes of Health Research and other funding agencies.  Her academic honours include being a CIHR New Investigator, an Ontario Career Scientist and a Physician Services Incorporated Fellow in Translational Research.
Keyword: chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), respiratory disease, quality of care, chronic disease, evidence based practice

Project_Title: Understanding the roles of stem cell biology in cancer development
Project_Description: We are the only lab in Canada to use the freshwater flatworm (planarian) as a model for stem cell biology, cancer, and regeneration.  Planarians are a powerful model because they have a large population of adult stem cells that can be manipulated and visualized in live animals.  This allows us to study how the normal stem cells might go awry during cancer development, as well as the ability to understand how the stem cells allow the worm to regenerate any tissue that is lost during injury.  This work will allow for innovation in the fields of cancer biology and regeneration.
Keyword: stem cells, cancer, tumor suppressors, lineage development, planarians, differentiation, regeneration

Project_Title: Mechanisms and biomarkers of growth faltering in early childhood
Project_Description: A babyâ€™s size and growth are key determinants of future health. Yet, surprisingly little is known about why some babies grow slowly or â€˜falterâ€™. Dr. Rothâ€™s research will generate new knowledge about infant growth in the first months of life. Early preterm infants in Ontario and babies in Bangladesh have distinct early-life experiences, yet both populations are at high-risk of early growth faltering. Using cutting-edge techniques to integrate a range of biochemical and clinical data from both groups, Dr. Rothâ€™s proposed studies aim to advance our understanding of the detection and prevention of infant growth deficits in Ontario a
Keyword: Child, Growth, Nutrition, Malnutrition, Biomarkers, Anthropometry, Epidemiology , Translational medicine, Global health, Proteomics

Project_Title: Co-clinical trials in autism
Project_Description: Autism has proven frustratingly difficult to treat. New treatments seem to always fail, though often with intriguing retrospective analyses that a subset of participants did very well on the drug. A likely reason is the complex mix of causes that underlie this disorder. Autism is highly heritable, yet no single gene accounts for more than 1-2% of patients. To create more effective therapies we thus have to separate patients into groups that will respond similarly to new treatments. We have to move to personalized medicine; to do so we have to first identify the factors that predict treatment response.
Keyword: autism, neurodevelopmental disorders, magnetic resonance imaging, neuroscience, mouse models, neuroanatomy

Project_Title: Using imaging to determine how chemotherapy affects brain development
Project_Description: Modern chemotherapy cures 90% of children with acute lymphocytic leukemia (ALL), the most common childhood cancer. However, in half of these patients, chemotherapy has neurological side effects that affect performance in school and reduce quality of life. We will use magnetic resonance imaging in mice to study how brain development is altered by chemotherapy and determine which chemotherapy agents are most detrimental, individually or in combination. This represents a critical first step to allow individualization of ALL chemotherapy, with the aim of ensuring ALL survivors enjoy the same quality of life as their cancer-free peers.
Keyword: magnetic resonance imaging; brain development; pediatric cancer treatment; chemotherapy; cognitive impairment

Project_Title: High-Throughput Discovery of Synergistic Drug Combinations in High-Grade Serous Ovarian Cancer
Project_Description: Due to development of resistance, treatment failure rates remain high for single-drug therapies. It has been recently demonstrated that simultaneous therapy with two drugs is much more effective than single and sequential therapies. We propose here to implement a novel bioinformatic pipeline that leverages large pharmacogenomic datasets to enable high-throughput identification of efficient drug combinations in high-grade serous ovarian cancer (HGSC), the most lethal gynecologic malignancy.
