We plan to identify sensitizers to 10 drugs used in HGSC, to increase therapeutic efficacy and potentially decrease toxicity, therefore reducing the burden of HGSC on Ontario health care.
Keyword: Cancer, Pharmacogenomics, Bioinformatics, Computational Biology, Machine Learning, Big Data, Drug repurposing, Targeted Therapy, Biomarkers, Translational Research

Project_Title: Development of Systemic Sclerosis Subset Classification Criteria
Project_Description: In systemic sclerosis (SSc), the immune system attacks the skin, heart and lungs leading to death. There is no cure. Currently, only patients with established disease have access to trials; and patients with early disease are denied access to potentially life-saving treatment. I will use innovative methods to develop classification criteria to identify subsets of SSc patients. This will enable selection of the right patients, to access the right treatment, at the right time. This proposal provides leading-edge training to produce highly qualified personnel; enhances Ontarioâ€™s profile in the global academic community and implements knowledge transfer through advanced health technologie
Keyword: Classification Criteria, Systemic Sclerosis, Validation, Systemic Review, Content Analysis, Multicriteria decision analysis, similarity network fusion

Project_Title: Novel treatments to improve reactive balance control for falls prevention
Project_Description: Reactive balance control is the ability to regain stability following an unexpected loss of balance, and is essential for preventing falls in daily life. However, reactive balance control is impaired among seniors and those with brain injury (e.g. stroke). While some rehabilitation strategies seem promising, our understanding of how people acquire and make lasting adaptations to reactive balance control is currently lacking. This work will develop and evaluate novel treatment strategies for improving reactive balance control among seniors and individuals with stroke. Implementation of these novel treatments is expected to prevent falls and reduce associated health care costs.
Keyword: Aging; Neurology; Rehabilitation; Balance; Mobility; Falls; Motor Control; Motor Learning; Biomechanics

Project_Title: Improving Diabetes Outcomes for First Nations Populations in Northern Ontario Using Community Health Workers: Adapting Leading Models of Care through Global Knowledge Translation
Project_Description: First Nations (FN) populations suffer from a disproportionate disease burden and poor health outcomes associated with diabetes. Although some of the barriers that lead to these health disparities are unique to FN communities in Ontario, many are similar to those faced by vulnerable populations elsewhere in the world. The proposed research aims to apply international best practices for integrating community health workers (CHWs) with diabetes care in Ontarioâ€™s remote FN communities. Global evidence demonstrates that CHW programs improve health outcomes, deliver services efficiently and support local empowerment. We will design, implement and evaluate key elements of  models of CHW program
Keyword: Aboriginal Health, Primary Care, Diabetes Mellitus, Community Health Workers, Knowledge Translation, Global Health

Project_Title: Nutrigenomics and Metabolic Syndrome: Unravelling the interactions between omega-3 fats, genes, and inflammation.
Project_Description: Metabolic syndrome (MetS) is one of the most serious public health concerns affecting Ontarians. Individuals with MetS have a higher risk of diabetes and cardiovascular disease, thus placing an enormous burden on the healthcare system. High consumption of dietary fats increases body weight, which is a major risk factor for MetS. However, different fats affect a personâ€™s metabolism in a variety of ways. Dr. Mutch will use state-of-the-art technologies to generate novel information regarding the use of omega-3 fats for the prevention and treatment of MetS. Benefits to Ontario will include improved health of its residents and reduced healthcare cost
Keyword: Nutrigenomics, obesity, adipose tissue, adipocyte, omega-3 fats, inflammation, fatty acid desaturases, clinical trial, translational research

Project_Title: The adaptation of the protein synthesis machinery to low oxygen availability
Project_Description: The environments in which cells grow often change rapidly. Consequently, cells have evolved mechanisms to regulate their biochemistry in response to environmental change. A critical question in cellular biology is how cells selectively synthesize proteins to aid in the adaptive response to stress while the canonical protein synthesis machinery is repressed. My research program explores this question in human cells exposed to low oxygen stress (hypoxia). The proposed study focuses on an alternative protein synthesis mechanism that is activated by hypoxia, which is an important contributor to tumor progression. This mechanism would make an ideal target for anti-tumor therapies.
Keyword: Translation, cancer, hypoxia, tumor microenvironment, mRNA, oxygen, protein synthesis

Project_Title: Energy Harvesting from Low Potential Sources
Project_Description: The major focus of the proposed research is to develop novel materials and technologies for energy harvesting from low potential sources (e.g., solar, sound, waste heat, vibration, etc.). The materials  include bio-based thermoelectric materials (for clean energy production and environmentally friendly cooling) and nano phase change materials (for efficient thermal energy storage) among others. The  technologies include micro power generator (for vibration energy harvesting), clean thermoacoustic systems (for pest control, cooling, and imaging), and solar thermoelectric air-conditioning (for automobile and remote applications) among others. The underlying approach will be material preparation,  characterization, modeling, optimization,  prototype development, and testing.
Keyword: bio-material; clean-technology; energy-conversion; energy-efficiency; energy-harvesting; low-potential-source; nano-material;thermoacoustic; thermoelectric; waste-to-energy;

Project_Title: Science Policy and Public Values
Project_Description: Some areas of science and technology are controversial. In a pluralistic society where diversity is valued, it is often not clear how to deal with conflicting opinions and values. An important element to resolving such conflict is to have meaningful public engagement that can inform sound policy. In this project, we will conduct public deliberation on three controversial topics: vaccine hesitancy; hydraulic fracturing; funding of rare diseases. Public forums will be recruited for diversity, informed about the issues, and guided toward developing collective policy input. The project contributes to Ontarioâ€™s innovation agenda by facilitating translation of S&T into public domain
Keyword: science policy; public deliberation; values; science and technology studies; ethics; vaccine hesitancy; fracking; rare diseases

Project_Title: Investigating distributed neural contributions to voluntary goal-directed action
Project_Description: While many movements are thought to be primarily driven by primary motor cortex, some recent research suggests that other brain areas may play a crucial role depending on the functional and/or anatomical demands of the task. The proposed research will investigate the contribution of various distributed neural networks to voluntary action in humans. Neural stimulation techniques as well as frequency domain electrophysiological analysis will be used to determine the brain areas involved in the production of movements. Once identified, these regions can be targeted for learning and/or rehabilitation interventions.
Keyword: Neuroscience, moto programming, nervous system, movement, motor cortex, reticular formation, tms, eletrophsiology

Project_Title: Addressing the Access to Justice Crisis for Homeless People: The potential for new communications technologies
Project_Description: This research aims to provide direct social and legal benefits to homeless people in Ontario who are facing a crisis in access to justice.  Using new media and communications technologies, it aims to enhance their digital literacy and increase their access to necessary legal information.  The project will explore how Social Networking Sites (SNSs) can be used to provide vital and timely legal information to the homeless; and whether SNSs may increase homeless people's engagement with law as agents, exercising their rights, rather than simply as people who experience legal regulation on a daily basis.
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development
Keyword: access to justice; homeless; social networking sites; poverty reduction; digital economy

Project_Title: The Cell Biology of RNA: from Mechanism to Disease
Project_Description: We study how novel mechanisms of RNA degradation, regulation and trafficking between cells contribute to diseases ranging from cancer, to Parkinsonâ€™s and Lou Gehrigâ€™s disease. We propose to study a novel mechanism of RNA degradation that prevents genetic mutation and potentially many cancers. Our second goal is to overcome a major hurdle preventing use of many promising drugs â€“ drug delivery into cells â€“ by harnessing an endogenous system that communicates RNA between cells using small extracellular vesicles. With the goal of attaining maximum clinical and economic impact, our research begins with fundamental biology and continues to mouse models and human p
Keyword: cell biology, RNA biology, microRNA, exosomes, extracellular vesicles, autophagy, drug delivery, cancer, neurodegenerative disease, biomarker

Project_Title: Understanding Context in Knowledge Translation
Project_Description: My research program will generate knowledge about the role of context (work environment) in facilitating or hindering knowledge translation (KT) activities to improve healthcare professionals' research use in clinical practice. I will first identify the key features of context that are important to research use to produce a comprehensive framework of context. I will then conduct a systematic review of instruments that measure the identified key features of context, and assess the reporting of context in publications of KT interventions. These three studies collectively will result in much needed practical guidance for researchers and stakeholders undertaking clinical KT activities.
Keyword: context, knowledge translation, research use, behavior change

Project_Title: Tectonic and anthropogenic deformation of the Earth's crust and mantle
Project_Description: The objective of the proposed research is to improve our understanding of the structure and deformation of the Earth's crust and upper mantle, to provide information on potential hazards and natural resources. More specifically, the proposed research will address how the crust and mantle deform in response to the action of plate tectonic forces and large-scale industrial processes. The outcomes from this work will provide significant benefits to Ontario by helping identify mineral targets, developing monitoring capabilities of industrial activity related to large-scale resource extraction and exploitation and establishing baseline estimates for their impact on natural hazards.
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development
Keyword: Geophysics, seismology, plate tectonics, fault zones, Earth's crust, deformation, earthquakes, industrial activity

Project_Title: Designer biocatalysts for the direct synthesis of enantiopure Î²-amino acid
Project_Description: ²-Amino acids are essential building blocks for the preparation of pharmaceuticals and fine chemicals. Currently, most ²-amino acids are either unavailable as commodity chemicals or are prohibitively expensive because they are difficult to synthesize in enantiopure form. To address this issue, Dr. Roberto Chica is developing state-of-the-art multistate computational protein design techniques and applying them towards the creation of novel biocatalysts for economical and environmentally-friendly ²-amino acid synthesis. These designer biocatalysts will enable the production of a variety of highly valuable ²-amino acids thereby contributing to the bio-economy and the application of clean technologies in Ontario.
Keyword: Protein engineering, biocatalysis, enzymes, computational protein design, mutagenesis, high-throughput screening

Project_Title: Solar Everywhere: Novel high-efficiency cell designs for solar energy systems costing less than $1/W
Project_Description: Highest efficiency photovoltaic devices commercially available achieve over 40% but are costly. This research aims to provide low-cost, manufacturable device architectures delivering efficiencies >50%. Combining these two goals will yield a lower cost of energy, bringing solar capability to grid-parity. We will consider a wider range of materials and designs for multi-junction solar cell structures, including those with very different crystalline lattice constants for use in wafer-bonded, spectrally-split, or mechanically-stacked devices. The devices designed within this program will be integrated in concentrated photovoltaic systems that are part of a reconfigurable nanogrid testbed enabling a SOLAR EVERYWHERE system concept.
Keyword: Photovoltaics, solar-generated electricity, compound semiconductors, concentrator solar systems, flat panels, solar cell design, photonics, electronic device physics, electrical engineering, nanotechnology.

Project_Title: Geochemical characterization and geochronology of Earth's oldest crust and early mantle
Project_Description: Our knowledge of the early Earth is limited by the scarcity of old rocks preserved. This research will investigate the early geologic history of the oldest Canadian terrains, including the Western Superior Province (Ontario). Combining field studies with the latest high-precision isotopic tools, this research will help understand the formation and stabilization of ancient cratons including Ontarioâ€™s oldest geological terrains.  This project will develop an Ontarian expertise in high-precision analysis of short-lived isotopic systematics, which recently became the technique of choice for early Earth and cosmochemistry studies. It will also contribute in the development of Highly Qualified Personnel in Ontari
Keyword: Early Earth, Hadean, Eoarchean, Early crust formation, Early mantle reservoirs, Canadian Archean cratons, Crust-mantle differentiation, Geochronology,  Geochemistry, Radiogenic isotope geochemistry

Project_Title: Arctic Marine Use and Transportation (AMUT): informing decisions, governance and policy
Project_Description: Improved navigability of Canadian Arctic waters due to climate change has influenced an increase in ship traffic by 75% since 2005, testing Canadian sovereignty and security and bringing new challenges to Indigenous society. This research investigates the opportunities and risks of increased shipping in the region by analyzing historic ship patterns, projecting future scenarios, and developing policy alternatives through extensive consultation with Inuit communities, regional policy makers and industry. Project outcomes translate into benefits for Ontario through university collaborations involving training of youth in Ottawa and internationally as well as the sharing of evidence-based policy options for northern transportation planning.
Keyword: Arctic shipping, economic development, evidence-based policy, decision-making, Inuit, Iqaluit, student training

Project_Title: Response of physical and biogeochemical processes in permafrost to warmer-wetter Arctic.
Project_Description: Northern permafrost regions are experiencing dramatic transformation in response to climate changes, human development and natural disturbances. This proposal aims to determine the response of physical and biogeochemical processes in permafrost to a warmer-wetter Arctic. This will be accomplished by 11 HQPs working on 3 inter-related projects in various regions in northern Canada, from northern Ontario to Ellesmere Island. The proposal will baseline information for predicting the fluxes of solutes, nutrients, and carbon throughout the landscape of northern Canada and the outcome will provide innovative solutions to mitigate these consequences.
Keyword: permafrost, thermokarst, soil carbon, hydrology, environmental geochemistry, remote sensing, north Ontario, Arctic Canada

Project_Title: Broadening the Horizons of Personality:  The Scarborough Multi-Rater Personality Project (SMuRPP)
Project_Description: When forecasting who will be a successful employee, others have more accurate insights about our personality traits than we do ourselves.  However, little is known about how organizations can harness these observer-reports of personality for choosing job applicants.  The proposed studies will use co-operative employment students to test how the unique personality insight afforded by observers (a) contributes to predicting performance, (b) may be susceptible to stereotypes, (c) could be faked, and (d) can facilitate employeesâ€™ self-awareness.  Findings from these studies will transform not only how we think about personnel selection but what we understand personality measures to mea
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development
Keyword: Personality, observer-reports, self-deception, applicant faking, stereotypes, feedback

Project_Title: Comparison of emerging in-vehicle technologies with respect to driver distraction and potential to improve safety when information content is driving related
Project_Description: In Canada, traffic crashes result in 2,500 fatalities and 15,000 serious injuries every year. Distraction is estimated to cause 13 to 50% of all crashes. In-vehicle devices such as smartphones raises additional concerns regarding driver distraction. However, these  devices also have the potential to improve safety by informing drivers of risky driving behaviours or upcoming roadway events. This project will compare different in-vehicle technologies (dashboard displays, smartphones, smartwatches, and Google Glass) with respect to driver distraction as well as their potential to improve safety when information content is driving related. Students will be trained for careers in traffic safety.
Keyword: Human factors engineering, Operator interface design, Traffic safety, Driver behaviour, Driver performance, Driver distraction, Driving simulator studies, Instrumented vehicle studies, Eye tracking, On-road experimentation.

Project_Title: Flow-Induced Noise and Vibration Control in Engineering Structures via Geometric Modifications
Project_Description: The proposed research program will experimentally investigate the passive control of adverse flow effects in the context of two major engineering problems: The first problem is the control of flow-induced vibration in cylindrical structures, such as offshore risers. This campaign will investigate various flow control means involving surface protrusion devices on stationary, forced- and free-vibrating rigid cylinders to generate a knowledge base for designers. The other research problem is the flow-induced noise issue associated with aircraft landing gears. The proposed research will search the possible causes of noise in these systems and will work towards developing realistic noise mitigation solutions.
OIA_AREA: Development and creation of investigation spots
Keyword: flow-induced noise, flow-induced vibration, landing gear noise, bluff bodies, cylinder flows, passive flow control

Project_Title: Dissecting the mechanisms of collective cell migration in vivo using quantitative imaging
Project_Description: Collective cell migration drives tissue development and repair, but also metastatic invasion, which kills 25,000 Ontarians each year. However, the mechanisms by which cells coordinate their movements in living animals are not understood. We will model collective cell migration in vivo during Drosophila embryonic wound repair, which allows live imaging and genetic, pharmacological and biophysical manipulations that are harder to conduct in vertebrate animals. Combining these techniques with quantitative image analysis, we will determine how metastasis-associated genes regulate collective cell migration. Our research will provide candidate therapeutic targets to disrupt metastasis, thus contributing to reduce cancer-associated deaths and health-care costs.
Keyword: collective cell migration, wound healing, metastasis, junctional dynamics, cytoskeletal networks, mechanical forces, trafficking, Drosophila, fluorescence microscopy, quantitative image analysis

Project_Title: Development of UAV-based hyperspectral monitoring system to assess ash tree decline in emerald ash borer-infested regions
Project_Description: The rapid spread of the invasive invertebrate pest, the Emerald Ash borer (EAB), has reached near epidemic proportions and native ash trees populations are experiencing extensive mortality in Ontario. A current region-wide map identifying the locations of ash trees and the early to late stages of EAB infestation is urgently needed to inform and more effectively target current EAB control measures. The goal of this project is thus to develop a long term unmanned aerial vehicle-based hyperspectral monitoring system, applicable to the EAB invasion but also potentially other initiatives requiring an efficient and cost-effective method of monitoring large areas.
Keyword: Forest health, emerald ash borer, remote sensing, invasive species, forest conservation strategies, time-series mapping

Project_Title: Conserving biodiversity in the era of global change: testing the impacts of fragmentation and warming climate in southern Ontario
Project_Description: Ontario hosts an incredible diversity of plants, insects and animals. However, global environmental changes, such as climate warming and habitat fragmentation, threaten many species both directly and by altering their interactions with each other. The proposed research will use experiments and modeling to test how these changes could impact species of concern, such as the monarch butterfly. It will determine the importance of two poorly-understood processes: how temperature alters insect development, and feeding, and how the functioning of species changes in small fragments.  The results will aid in developing conservation plans and generate recommendations for natural resource management.
Keyword: conservation, ecology, evolution, species interactions, climate change, fragmentation, species at risk, biodiversity

Project_Title: Understanding plasticity in the adult social brain
Project_Description: Perceived social status is directly related to health outcomes in humans, including depression and dementia. Adult neurogenesis, the birth of new neurons in the mature brain, is impaired in both depression and dementia and I have demonstrated that status influences neurogenesis in a rodent model. This proposal will determine the physiological mechanism(s) via which status controls neurogenesis and will explore how these new neurons are involved in status-specific social behaviours. This research provides new insight to the relationship between social interactions and adult brain function in highly social mammals, such as ourselves, and the regenerative potential of the mammalian brain.
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development
Keyword: Adult plasticity; comparative neurobiology; ethology; hippocampus; hormones; naked mole-rat; neurogenesis; social recognition; social status; psychosocial stress

Project_Title: Remotely activatable nanoscale contrast agents for smart cancer therapy
Project_Description: Cancer is the leading cause of premature death in Ontario. A major problem with current cancer drugs is their effective delivery to the tumour site, which cannot be independently verified during the course of the treatment. The Matsuura lab designs new nanometre-scale contrast agents that can be both tracked by medical imaging and be non-invasively and precisely activated to release an encapsulated drug only at the tumour site. This agent can help spare normal tissues and provide real-time verification that therapy was successfully delivered, saving patients months of difficult and expensive therapies that may otherwise ultimately fail.
Keyword: medical imaging, cancer, nanotechnology, contrast agents, ultrasound, HIFU, drug carriers

Project_Title: Ediacaran Fossils from Iran and the Dawn of Animal Life
Project_Description: The Ediacaran (635-542 Ma) represents a pivotal time in Earth history, marked by the transition from single-celled organisms into complex animals. Typifying this transition is the Ediacara biota, a group of enigmatic organisms whose disappearance prior to the Cambrian explosion of animals is perplexing. Three main hypotheses have been proposed: 1) a mass extinction, 2) competitive replacement by Cambrian animals, and 3) a preservational artefact. To test these hypotheses, I propose to conduct research in the Alborz ranges of Iran. Fossils have been previously reported, but this would represent the most comprehensive study of Ediacaran fossils in the region.
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development
Keyword: Ediacara Biota, Field Work, Cambrian Explosion, Paleoecology, Geobiology, Phylogeny, Early Life, Exceptional Fossils

Project_Title: The role of early life adversity on gene function and health
Project_Description: Early life experiences are pivotal for our health, yet critical knowledge is lacking on the impact of adversity on lifelong health problems. We need to know which genes, in interaction with the environment, put a person at the greatest risk. We will study adversityâ€™s impact on gene function using cutting-edge technology and analysis. The ultimate goal is to uncover new diagnostics and preventive interventions to enhance social, physical and mental health. This research will have several benefits: reduced chronic disease, reduced costs for judicial and prison systems, and more healthy adults who can make a positive social and economic contributio
Keyword: epigenetics, transcriptome, behaviour, social adversity, anxiety, stress, early life environment, health and disease, animal, human

Project_Title: Revealing the Biophysical Mechanisms that Transform Bacteria into Pathogens
Project_Description: The Ontario Medical Association estimates that over 12,000 Canadians die and hundreds of thousands fall ill each year from pathogenic bacteria, with a growing number of infections resistant to all antibiotics.  The transformation of a harmless microbe to a deadly pathogen is largely orchestrated by global regulatory proteins that activate or silence gene expression. We will apply super-resolution microscopy and single-molecule techniques to clarifying how virulence genes are switched on and off. With a better understanding of this mechanism; we will be poised to develop novel strategies for preventing the outbreak and spread of deadly pathogens.
Keyword: biophysics, super-resolution microscopy, optical tweezers, single-molecule, gene regulation, gene silencing, nucleoid associated proteins (NAPS), virulence

Project_Title: Echoes and Light: Audiovisual Integration and Sensory Dominance in Bats
Project_Description: When visual and auditory information contradict there is potential for confusion. When this happens, vertebrate brains often prioritize visual information. Echolocating bats provide an innovative window through which to study how vertebrates decide to rely on which sense. Cross-modal recognition in bats across vision and echolocation would suggest higher-order integration. I will use bats to test the hypotheses that vision trumps hearing and that both senses impart transferable internal representations. For Ontario, this research may improve understanding of why otherwise environmentally-friendly wind turbines kill bats. Long-term, it may improve understanding of autism and schizophrenia, disorders associated with sensory integration dysfunction.
Keyword: vision, hearing, information conflict, echolocation, cross-modal recognition, sensory integration

Project_Title: Neural systems dysfunctions underlying impulse control in borderline personality disorder
Project_Description: Borderline personality disorder (BPD) is a severe mental illness affecting thousands of individuals in Ontario. Whereas impulse control problems are central to the disorder, triggering disabling symptoms such as self-mutilation, substance abuse, and social difficulties, the causes of impulsivity in BPD are poorly understood. This research will investigate neural systems dysfunctions underlying impulse control in BPD using brain imaging to evaluate neural structures critical for controlling behaviour. The results of this research will illuminate patterns of brain dysfunction that may prompt impulsive behaviours in BPD, shedding new light on potential causes of self-destructive actions in individuals with the disorder.
Keyword: borderline personality disorder; impulse control; functional magnetic resonance imaging

Project_Title: Individual and Community Thriving in Diverse Societies
Project_Description: How do we build rich multicultural societies that maximize individual thriving and active community-building? My research investigates how thoughts and physiological responses during social interactions with people of diverse backgrounds affect the way we build social relationships and excel in diverse social environments. The proposed research tackles this question through a combination of self-report, behavioural, psychophysiological, dyadic, longitudinal, and quantitative methods. I employ both experimental lab designs and naturalistic field studies to investigate the causes of social behaviour in controlled environments while simultaneously considering the degree to which these processes are reflected in peopleâ€™s everyday live
Keyword: social psychology, intergroup relations, social interaction, dyadic psychophysiology, stress, thriving

Project_Title: Health and Social Networks among Older Adults
Project_Description: Social networks have a powerful impact on well-being, an impact that only increases with age. Changes in health status in old age, however, can limit older adultsâ€™ ability to maintain a broad and supportive pool of social resources. This research program seeks to understand how various aspects of older adultsâ€™ social networks shape their health and how different facets of physical and mental health shape different properties of their social networks. Though global in scope, the project will also give special attention to how social networks can help older adults in Toronto retain a high quality of l
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Keyword: aging, social networks, social support, health, neighbourhoods, life course, national context

Project_Title: Addressing Injustices: Teachers and Adolescents Coauthoring Social Justice-Oriented Literacy Curriculum
Project_Description: Addressing Injustices proposes an innovative collaboration involving adolescents and educators as partners in designing social justice-oriented literacy curriculum. Over five years Addressing Injustices will involve 80-100 teacher candidates at OISE and 150 students from a Toronto intermediate school in co-creating curriculum for five young adult novels that explore issues of identity, culture, and power. This project will use practitioner inquiry and participatory action research to improve outcomes. Benefits to Ontario will include increasing studentsâ€™ learning in literacy (Cummins, 2010; Ontario Literacy and Numeracy Secretariat, 2011) and their engagement with social issues, while supporting the professional development of new teacher
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development
Keyword: critical literacy, social justice education, practitioner research, youth participatory action research, critical curriculum studies, teacher education and professional deveoplment

Project_Title: Efficient Learning and Inference Algorithms for Affordable Autonomous Driving
Project_Description:
This research focus on developing cost-effective solutions to autonomous driving. 
The end product is a semantic GPS application, which can provide semantic level description by delivering well-timed early warnings in compact verbal descriptions. Towards this goal, multiple perception tasks need to be solved (e.g., sensing, recognition). Existing approaches try to solve a single task, ignoring the dependencies inherent to the problem. Here, we will develop  algorithms that are able to learn with minimal supervision effective complex representations that can be used to jointly perform many tasks efficiently.  Our methods will benefit Ontario's automotive related industry and the international academic community.
Keyword: Scene understanding, structure prediction, deep learning, autonomous driving, vision for robotics, artificial intelligence

Project_Title: Extreme quantum nonlinear optics with Rydberg polaritons
Project_Description: Building upon previous work of quantum networks with atomic ensembles, Dr. Choi will develop a novel quantum network based on dipolar interactions between highly excited (Rydberg) atoms and between lowly excited atoms wired by nanoscopic waveguides. The extreme nonlinear interatomic interaction provides the physical means for functional quantum memories, efficient quantum processors and emulation of emergent magnetic materials. By harnessing rich interactions of ultracold atoms and single photons, Dr. Choi and his team will build the foundation for scalable quantum computation and simulation, enabling Ontario's leadership in quantum technologies.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Keyword: Quantum Optics, Atomic Molecular Optical Physics, Quantum Information Science, Quantum Many-Body Physics, Single-Photon Generation, Quantum Networks, Collective Excitations, Entanglement, Rydberg Atoms, Laser Cooling

Project_Title: Measuring the Value and Impact of Open Data
Project_Description: Open data is government data that becomes shared publicly with citizens. In Ontario, delivering open data has become a major focus for provincial and municipal governments. Dr. Johnson will build partnerships with key open data stakeholders, developing case studies that measure the value and impact of open data initiatives, assessing how open data is used to generate economic and social benefits. This research will directly impact how governments provide open data and how stakeholders such as private software developers, other governments, non-profits, and citizens can build successful applications and businesses models that rely on open data.
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development
Keyword: open data, open government, data science, data management, technology adoption, enterprise information technology, citizen participation, crowdsourcing, organizational behaviour

Project_Title: Tropical Geometry: Structure and Degeneration
Project_Description: The mathematical area of algebraic geometry concerns algebraic varieties which are solution sets of systems of polynomial equations. These systems arise in engineering problems and cannot be solved directly. Given an algebraic variety, tropical geometry produces a simpler object, a tropical variety, made of points, line segments, and their higher-dimensional analogues. Tropical varieties capture a surprising amount of data about the original variety and encode ways of simplifying the polynomial system which is important for approximating solutions to the system. The focus of this proposal is furthering Ontario's strength in pure mathematics, scientific computation, and computer algebra.
OIA_AREA: Development and creation of investigation spots
Keyword: Solving Systems of Equations; Combinatorics; Algebra; Geometry; Visualizing Algebraic Varieties; Degeneration Methods; Discrete Mathematics; Computer Algebra

Project_Title: Hydraulic Fracturing: Modelling and Uncertainty Assessment in an Ontario Context
Project_Description: Hydraulic Fracturing (HF) is the enabling technology for shale gas development (SGD), with known Canadian reservoirs requiring about $3.2 trillion to develop. In Ontario, public concern for the environmental and health risks of developing its $12 billion reserve has been growing, in part, because the risks have not been evaluated in a systematic way. This project aims to develop powerful HF simulation and risk assessment tools to realize the economic potential of SGD, while protecting the environmental and public heath. With SGD likely to increase in Ontario, students trained will provide a qualified workforce for Ontario's government and Oil&Gas industry.
Keyword: Hydraulic Fracture, Modelling, Simulation, Computational Mechanics, Shale Gas, Extended Finite Element Method, Uncertainty, Risk

Project_Title: Probabilistic modeling of hip fracture risk and the effects of prevention strategies
Project_Description: Hip fractures are a significant public health concern. The objective of this project is to use mathematical models informed by experimental studies to estimate how factors including gender, age, and anthropometrics influence the loads applied to the hip during a fall, and hip (femur) strength. This model will then assess changes in hip fracture risk associated with a range of intervention approaches including safety flooring (primary), and those intended to increase bone strength (secondary). Such knowledge will inform Ontario policies and practices regarding hip fracture prevention, and will support innovation in Ontarioâ€™s flooring and injury prevention industrie
Keyword: Hip Fracture, Safety Floors, Falls, Impact Biomechanics, Bone Strength, Aging, Body Composition, Compliant Floors, Mathematical Modelling

Project_Title: Intelligent Energy Management of Electric Vehicles Under Driving Behavior Uncertainty
Project_Description:
The electric vehicle (EV) offers far greater energy efficiency over conventional gasoline-powered vehicles, making it a promising option for future sustainable transportation. However, limited driving range due to the low capacity of current battery technologies is a major deterrent to consumers.

For EVs, the driving range can be extended significantly by optimizing the use of battery energy. The proposed research will develop and experimentally evaluate an intelligent energy management strategy for EVs hybridized with supercapacitors that governs their battery usage to maximize driving range. This will allow Ontarioâ€™s car manufacturers to more successfully market their green fleet
Keyword: Energy Management, Electric Vehicles, Efficiency, Control, Modeling, Driving Behavior Prediction, Optimization, Battery, Supercapacitor, Hardware-in-the-Loop Simulations

Project_Title: Robust quantum computation from many-body physics
Project_Description: Realizing a working quantum computer is challenging due to the fragile nature of quantum information. To make progress towards this goal, this project will study many-body systems from a quantum computational viewpoint. Dr. Koenig will quantitatively assess robustness properties emerging from collective phenomena, and develop novel schemes for fault-tolerant information-processing based on many-body systems. By taking an operational approach rooted in fault-tolerance, this project will establish new theoretical and numerical tools for studying complex interacting many-body systems. These efforts will extend and complement current Ontario-based research, thus further solidifying  the region's positioning as a world-wide leader in quantum technologies.
Keyword: quantum computation, many-body physics, fault-tolerance, variational methods, error correction, computational physics, condensed matter physics, strongly interacting systems, entanglement theory

Project_Title: Development of 3D Cell Traction Force Miscroscopy
Project_Description:
Cell migration is essential to living organisms. Tissue formation, wound healing, and disease propagation are all driven by cell traction forces (CTF) that act on the extracellular matrix (ECM) for cell migration. The magnitude and direction of CTF cannot yet be precisely characterized since they are extremely small and difficult to measure. 
     Dr. Kwon will develop a new method to measure 3D CTF caused by cell migration in 3D physiological ECM. This will provided a more accurate tool for earlier diagnosis of cancer, cardiovascular disease and other devastating illnesses, helping Ontario reduce healthcare costs and improve the quality of life.
OIA_AREA: Chemical and biological experimentation for the future
Keyword: Cell Traction Force, Cell Migration, Cell Mechanics, Digital Volume Correlation, Cell Mechanical Bahaviour, Constitutive Modeling, Cell Traction Force Microscopy

Project_Title: Nanostructured material for new and enhanced devices: using geometry, flexibility & multi-functionality at nanoscale
Project_Description: Using the 3-D shape and flexibility of yeast cells, nanostructured materials for solar cells will be developed. These materials will lead to higher efficiency and omnidirectional response in the solar cells, addressing the challenge of making them cheaper, flexible and functioning uniformly irrespective of solar azimuth. Combining 0-1-2 dimensional nanomaterials in a composite, high surface area materials will be made. This material as a supercapacitor will store and deliver large amounts of energy at high power, critical for application in electric vehicles. This will ensure Ontraioâ€™s lead in clean energy technology applicable to automotive sector and solar powe
Keyword: nanoparticles, nanorods, cells, graphene, nanostructured, sensors, supercapacitors, flexible, large area

Project_Title: A Longitudinal Analysis of the Canadian World Wide Web as a Historical Resource, 1996â€“20
Project_Description: Big Data is reshaping the historical profession in ways we are only beginning to grasp. Web archives contain a veritable deluge of information, offering historians the ability to reconstruct the recent past, yet the sheer size of these primary sources presents significant challenges. This project, among the first of its kind, harnesses Internet data to enable present and future historians to usefully access, interpret, and curate born-digital primary sources that document our recent past. It will train humanities HQP to unlock and navigate digital archives, further strengthening Waterloo's - and Ontario's - reputation as a global innovator in digital technology.
Keyword: Digital history; web archives; digital technologies; digital humanities; world wide web; emerging technologies; information retrieval; data mining; textual analysis; big data

Project_Title: Security of quantum communications against hacking attacks
Project_Description: Communication security is crucial for our modern society. Quantum cryptography is a possible replacement for aging mathematical encryption methods threatened by the development of quantum computer. Quantum cryptography, being unbreakable in theory but a young and radically new security technology, currently needs to get rid of technical security loopholes in its implementations. The proposed research program comprehensively addresses all practical security aspects of the new technology, and develops hack-proof engineering approaches for all major types of quantum cryptosystems, in a world-leading experimental laboratory. This will attract talent to Ontario and create future economic opportunities in the emerging quantum technologies market.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Keyword: quantum-safe cryptography, quantum communications, quantum cryptography, quantum key distribution, quantum hacking

Project_Title: Optimal design of full-scale CO2 capture technologies for clean power generation
Project_Description: Each year, Ontario produces more than 50% of Canadaâ€™s total CO2 emissions from natural gas plants. To reduce emissions and advance Ontarioâ€™s fight against climate change, this project provides new critical insight on designing full-scale monoethanolamine (MEA) CO2 capture technologies to retrofit existing high-emissions fossil-fired power plants. Robust process synthesis, design and systems control methods will be developed to determine optimal commercial-scale designs to capture CO2 while maintaining system performance under varying operating conditions and process uncertainty. Ontarioâ€™s economic and ecological prosperity depend upon developing sustainable technologies that promote the efficient production of clean electricity from fossil-fuelled power p
Keyword: CO2 Capture; Process Systems Engineering; Optimal Design, Process Switchability, and Process Control; Parameter Uncertainty; Dynamic Modeling; Process Integration.

Project_Title: Novel small molecule therapies to treat Alzheimer's disease
Project_Description: The proposed research seeks to discover innovative therapies and diagnostic tools for treating Alzheimerâ€™s disease using a multidisciplinary approach. Ontario is home to 40% Canada's elderly population  and chronic diseases such as Alzheimer's are a major concern which mandates the need to develop a workforce skilled in combating  neurodegenerative diseases. The proposed research will lead to a paradigm shift by discovering  novel small molecules as treatment strategies and prepare HQPs with  research expertise  in Alzheimer's disease possessing scientific and entrepreneurial skills to foster sustainable growth and innovation of health, social and economic landscapes of Ontari
Keyword: Alzheimer's disease, cholinesterase enzymes, amyloid and tau aggregation, computational chemistry, synthetic chemistry, small molecules, pharmacophores, disease-modifying agents, transmission emission microscopy, animal studies

Project_Title: New algorithmic approaches for network design problems
Project_Description: Communication networks have dramatically changed the way we communicate, act, and live. They contribute heavily to growth and productivity of a country, as has been assessed by many research evaluations in recent years. For this reason, efficient network design techniques have a huge technological and economic impact for Ontario. Dr. Sanita and the HQP team will design new algorithms for network connectivity problems, investigate new models for technology diffusion problems and influence propagation processes though social networks, and develop efficient solvers for network routing problems. The techniques developed in this project will improve network efficiency for the benefit of Ontarians.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Keyword: Network Design, Approximation Algorithms, Social Networks, Technology Diffusion, Routing Protocols, Combinatorial Optimization, Integer and Linear Programming, Applied Optimization.

Project_Title: Document-Assisted Automated Software Testing
Project_Description: Inadequate software testing cost billions annually. The proposed project will dramatically improve software testing, software quality, and programming productivity to reduce software development cost.  It leverages natural language processing techniques, machine learning techniques, and heuristics to analyze programs' rich amount of documentation to extract input constraints. The input constraints will guide symbolic execution to test software more effectively and detect more software defects automatically.  These techniques will be developed in collaboration with Ontario's leading software companies, which will reduce software development costs, expedite programming capability of the 1,300+ Ontario software companies and improve Ontario's competitiveness in this vital sector.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Keyword: Software Development, Automated Software Testing, Software Bug Detection, Symbolic Execution, Software Quality, Programming Productivity, Software Engineering, Natural Language Processing, Machine Learning

Project_Title: Development of Nanothermite-based Micro-Joining Technology for Advanced Manufacturing and Clean Technology
Project_Description: New joining technologies are urgently needed to increase energy efficiency and reduce packaging costs of sustainable energy manufacturing. Nanomaterial-based joining solutions are rapidly emerging for solar, energy storage and microelectronic components; however, little is known about the thermochemistry and reaction characteristics of these technologies, which has hindered consistent, high performance joining and, subsequently, broad commercial adoption. We will directly address this gap through development of novel metastable intermolecular composites (nanothermite) that enable effective bonding of metallic and semiconducting solar panel and supercapacitor components. New, tightly controlled nanothermite-based joining applications will contribute to Ontarioâ€™s global leadership in micro-joining technology developmen
Keyword: Nanoparticles, Nanotechnology, Thermite, Composite, Synthesis, Fabrication, Reaction kinetics, Micro-joining, Heat transfer, Modeling

Project_Title: Thinking with our Bodies and World: Investigations into Cognitive Offloading
Project_Description: The proposed research will provide a deeper understanding of how we use our bodies and objects in our environments to help us think. It will focus on cognitive offloading and, through a series of experiments, test a novel theory of how offloading decisions are made and relate to our attentional limitations. In addition, a software tool to help students offload attentional demands while viewing digital lectures will be developed and its efficacy evaluated experimentally. The research will raise the provinceâ€™s stature in the academic community, increase Ontarioâ€™s human capital through training, and improve Ontarioâ€™s position in digital media techn
OIA_AREA: Research and study of the functioning of the human body
Keyword: embodied cognition, attention, cognitive offloading, experimental cognitive psychology, complex cognition, cognitive science, educational technology

Project_Title: The Life of Words: English Poetry and the Oxford English Dictionary
Project_Description: We think of lexicography as dealing in denotation, and poetry in connotative extension, but this distinction misses the rich complexity of the life of words.This project investigates poetry's interest in dictionaries, and dictionaries' uses of poetic writing. This will be done by enhancing the raw data of the Oxford English Dictionary (OED), and then submitting it and massive poetry databases to algorithmic comparison techniques. In training undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral researchers, this work will re-establish Waterloo as a key centre of study of the OED outside Oxford, and build on Waterloo's international reputation for digital innovation and digital media studies.
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development
Keyword: poetry, literary criticism, literary history, cultural history, lexicography, Oxford English Dictionary, Digital Humanities, digital media, big data

Project_Title: Mobilization of legacy metal contaminants during iron mineral transformations in soils and sediments
Project_Description: Metal contaminants arising from industrial activities will persist for an unknown time period in Ontarioâ€™s soils, sediments, and wetlands. Mobilization of these metal contaminants has become a major concern, particularly under global climate change. This work will use iron isotope biogeochemistry to interrogate dynamic interactions between metal contaminants and iron minerals in the presence of natural organic matter. This project will allow us to understand how iron, one of the most common soil elements, influences metal contaminants under different environmental conditions, and more critically, how we can possibly limit the release of metals from contaminated sites using iron biogeochemistr
Keyword: metal contamination, iron minerals, natural organic matter, iron isotopes, microorganisms, redox cycle, microbial reduction, electron transfer, atom exchange, flow through system

Project_Title: Functional Polymers for Next Generation Solar Cells
Project_Description: Polymers (or plastics) are an essential part of modern society and are vitally important to the development of emerging technologies, including solar cells. As part of the proposed research, Gilroy's  team will create tailor-made polymers with desirable light-absorbing and electron-transfer properties. The polymers will contain transition metals and stable radicals (i.e., molecules with unpaired electrons) and will be incorporated into cost-effective and highly efficient solar cells as the project proceeds. The outcomes of the proposed research will be the development of novel functional polymers and solar cells that will address Ontario's need for sustainable and green energy sources.
Keyword: polymer synthesis, polymer characterization, (multi)functional materials, coordination chemistry, metal-containing polymers, radical-containing polymers, Ï€-conjugated polymers, electrochemistry, nanomaterials, solar energy conversio

Project_Title: C.H.A.M.P. Families: Designing and implementing a community-based program of research targeting childhood obesity via health-related behaviours and literacy
Project_Description: The first purpose of the proposed research is to develop and implement a parent-focused lifestyle intervention for obese children and their families. Families with an obese child (aged 8-14) who are randomly assigned to the experimental group (versus a wait-list control group) will participate in a unique and interactive group-based and virtual program. The primary objective is to improve obese childrenâ€™s health-related quality of life; secondary objectives are to improve physical activity levels and body composition. The purpose of the second project is to develop a parent-focused advocacy network targeting food, physical, and civic literacy among families in Ontari
Keyword: Children; childhood obesity; community; parents; family; advocacy; physical activity; physical literacy; food literacy; political literacy

Project_Title: The Impact of Physician Mode of Remuneration on Health Care Utilization, Costs, and Quality of Care in Ontario
Project_Description: The past decade has witnessed major reforms in the primary healthcare in Ontario. The innovative aspect of these reforms are the introduction of capitation-based primary care delivery models as an alternative to the traditional fee-for-service model. These new models evolved with complex financial-incentive and organizational structures without evidence on costs and benefits. To date, knowledge on the performance of these models is lacking. The objective of this proposal is to fill this gap by undertaking a comprehensive analyses on healthcare utilization patterns, costs, and outcomes for individuals with chronic conditions in Ontarioâ€™s Family Health Group and Family Health Organization model
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Keyword: primary care; remuneration; healthcare utilization; costs; outcomes; chronic conditions; administrative data; econometric analysis; heterogeneity; health policy

Project_Title: Mouse models to study intervertebral disc development, health and disease
Project_Description: Back pain as a result of intervertebral disc degeneration is a cause of major disability, with a lifetime prevalence of over 80% in Canada. The development of disease-modifying treatments for disc pathologies is hampered by an incomplete understanding of disc development and degeneration. We have generated transgenic mouse models that permit disc-specific gene knockout, to identify key determinants of spine health. We have recently shown that loss of CCN2 in the intervertebral disc deregulates embryonic disc formation and accelerates age-associated degeneration. Our innovative strategy will employ cutting-edge genetic and molecular approaches to identify molecules with potential use as biological treatments.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Keyword: spine, intervertebral disc, notochord cells, matricellular proteins, development, disc aging / degeneration, tissue specific gene knockout, pain

Project_Title: Development of Wearable Mechatronic Devices for Rehabilitation
Project_Description: Millions of Canadians suffer from musculoskeletal disorders and, due to the complexity of the disorders and the large range of possible treatments, many struggle to find effective therapies. To address this problem, the proposed research focuses on developing patient-centred wearable mechatronic braces that track muscle performance and automatically adjust brace motion to implement therapeutic treatment. Research is required to identify design solutions, improve sensing ability, implement appropriate control systems and enhance humanâ€“device communication. The long-term goal is to revolutionize the field of rehabilitation by untethering patients from therapy centres, and reducing the burden on Canadaâ€™s overtaxed health care sys
Keyword: Wearable devices, Smart braces, Rehabilitation devices, Humanâ€“machine interface, Sensors and signal analysis, Mechatronic devices, Wearable mechatronics, Sensor integration, Musculoskeletal disorders, Multi-level control syste

Project_Title: Is Bitcoin the Future of the Digital Economy?
Project_Description: With a market capitalization around $8 billion, bitcoin embodies the digital economyâ€™s renewal. Bitcoin entrepreneurs are creating businesses in a sector that they see as a future pillar of capitalism. Yet, experts argue that bitcoinâ€™s economic value is unpredictable, regulators seem paralyzed by the risks associated with a currency without government control, and bitcoinâ€™s legitimacy remains contested. This research proposes to examine the challenges and opportunities that bitcoin represents for the economy. The goal is to develop HQP who are able to collect and analyze unique data on bitcoin's emergence, and become a leading source of expertise on the
Keyword: digital economy, bitcoin, cryptocurrency, internet, regulation, decentralization, piracy, government, entrepreneurship

Project_Title: Understanding how climate change will affect carbon and water dynamics, growth, and survival of boreal tree species
Project_Description: Climate change is reducing the productivity of Canadaâ€™s forests through reduced tree growth and increased mortality. This project seeks to understand how boreal trees respond to elevated temperatures, high CO2 concentrations and water stress. The research will assess how these factors alter carbon dynamics, drought tolerance, growth and survival in economically and ecologically important species. These data will be used to model forest productivity and vulnerability to stress under future climate scenarios. This work will benefit Ontario by providing information for mitigating climate change effects on our forests and adapting our $11.9 billion forestry sector to future condition
Keyword: climate change, CO2, drought, global change biology, hydraulics, photosynthesis, plant physiological ecology, respiration, temperature, water transport

Project_Title: Through Veterans' Eyes: Digital Approaches to the Hidden Histories of Veterans, Families, and the State 1918 2000
Project_Description: During the Great War, 620,000 Canadians began a life-long relationship with the Canadian state that was documented in files kept from birth to death containing regular home visit reports, yearly household balance sheets, detailed household inventories, and medical records as well as the voices of veterans and their families. In partnership with Veterans Affairs, we will digitize these records (which are slated for destruction), train highly qualified Ontario personnel for the new digital economy, and facilitate historical research in a number of fields on workforce mobility, the treatment of specific diseases, family stability, the household economy, and big data analysis.
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development
Keyword: First World War, Digital Humanities, History, Health, Veterans, Employment, Family, Childhood, PTSD, digital economy

Project_Title: Indigenous Knowledge Transfer: Gender and Life Stage Factors in Indigenous NGO Management Models
Project_Description: This research will increase understanding of Indigenous culture-based management models and in particular the role of gender and age in Indigenous NGO development. A primary deliverable will be documentation of the role of knowledge transfer through intergenerational collaboration and gender equity in the evolution of a large urban Indigenous NGO, the Ontario Federation of Indigenous Friendship Centres (OFIFC) as well as within three member Friendship Centres. This documentation will serve as a model for governance with the potential to generate interest and applciation worldwide in Indigenous and non-Indigenous communities alike.
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development
Keyword: Indigenous organizational development, gender based analysis, urban indigenous development, culture-based management, indigenous youth, life stages, indigenous knowledge transfer

Project_Title: Developing and evaluating health care quality improvement initiatives
Project_Description:
In an era where 30-40% of patients do not receive healthcare consistent with current evidence, the study of how to
build tools or services that reliably result in more effective healthcare practice is critical. The goal of this research
program is to build upon best practices from health psychology and human factors to design of healthcare quality
improvement interventions and to evaluate these initiatives in a rigorous fashion. Ultimately, this will contribute both
to the science of how to improve the health system, as well as provide a measurable impact for patients in the settings
where these projects are implemented.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Keyword: knowledge translation, implementation science, quality improvement, health services, program evaluation

Project_Title: Taking Space, Making Space: Digital Maps by Queers of Colour in Toronto
Project_Description: The study explores collective experiences of belonging and displacement among non-heterosexual people of colour who live, work or play in the gay Village or Toronto west end. Using digital maps, it sheds light on alternative forms of taking space and making space that are currently emerging in queer of colour communities. The project aims to give individuals who are marginalized in dominant maps opportunities to represent their own sense of the urban environments that surround them, and to produce alternative forms of placemaking that have the potential to inform wider conversations about just and sustainable ways of sharing space.
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development
Keyword: Toronto, LGBT, queer space, racism, gentrification, intersectionality, digital mapping, community development, placemaking, displacement

Project_Title: Enhancing research with uncertainty quantification: Assessing what we don't know about our results.
Project_Description: Statistical methodology in the social sciences (e.g., Psychology, Epidemiology, Education) is undergoing reform to address concerns about the verity of scientific conclusions. This unreliability of results is due in part to uncertainties in the modeling process (e.g., sampling error, model misspecification, influential cases). Supported by funding from SSHRC and NSERC, my research employs systematic reviews, simulation methodology, as well as software and graphical programming to develop methods for researchers to quantify, address, and communicate the many uncertainties inherent in the scientific process.  To draw strong and reliable scientific conclusions, all known aspects of uncertainty should be quantified and accounted for.
Keyword: Uncertainty quantification, case influence, parameter uncertainty, sensitivity analysis, exploratory data analysis, model calibration, model validation

Project_Title: Exploring the Atmospheres of Other Planets
Project_Description: Using the cameras and weather station aboard NASAâ€™s Curiosity Rover, the proposed research program will examine the lowest layer of the atmosphere on the planet Mars, known as the â€˜planetary boundary layerâ€™, to answer questions raised by the recent Mars Science Laboratory mission about the planetâ€™s climate. Outcomes of this research will include a description of the cycles of dust and methane and the variability of cloud formation on Mars. The research will expand our understanding of Mars and will contribute to Ontarioâ€™s $5.3 billion aerospace industry by demonstrating the advantages of high signal-to-nois
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Keyword: Atmospheric science, planetary science, planetary exploration, experimental simulations

Project_Title: Fundamental Physics with and without Colliders
Project_Description: Collider particle physics has yielded spectacular successes, yet profound questions about natureâ€™s fundamental forces and constituents remain: Why is gravity so weak? What is the nature of Dark Matter? Are there undiscovered long range forces? My research program, uniting theorists and experimentalists across several disciplines, will develop frameworks for new experiments using LHC data, atomic interferometry, NMR, and powerful quantum technologies to probe such questions. Thes"table-top" experiments are complementary to colliders, and can be developed faster, at far lower cost. Ontario could become a frontrunner in this new approach, which holds major discovery potential over a short time horizon.
Keyword: dark matter, new particles, precision frontier, table-top experiments, gravitational waves, collider physics, new forces

Project_Title: Targeting treatment resistance by modifying cancer cell identity in malignant brain tumours
Project_Description: Even with aggressive therapy, disease relapse is invariable in glioblastoma (GBM), the most common malignant brain tumour in adults. Patients succumb to their disease within one year. The failure of currently available therapies to produce a meaningful remission is due in part to the ability of glioblastoma cells to express genes that make them resistant to the effects of chemotherapy and radiation. In this proposal, we aim to identify the molecular mechanisms that mediate treatment resistance in GBM. We will identify targets to enhance the efficacy of current treatments in GBM and other currently incurable cancers.
Keyword: Cancer, glioblastoma, glioma, fate specification, differentiation therapy, long non-coding RNA, epigenetics, chemotherapy, disease resistance

Project_Title: The best medications for all Ontarians: a randomized control trial
Project_Description: More than a million Ontarians cannot afford their prescription medications. We will rigorously study an intervention that would provide everyone with essential medications, improve the quality of care and save the healthcare system money. We will conduct a randomized control trial of providing 784 primary care patients with a carefully selected set of medications that is based on the World Health Organization's list of essential medications. We will measure the impact on health outcomes (e.g. diabetes control) and costs of this scalable intervention using input from the community.
Keyword: health promotion, health equity, pharmaceuticals, RCT

Project_Title: New therapies for diabetes-induced kidney disease
Project_Description: With 10% of Ontarians diagnosed with diabetes, diabetic injury is the leading cause of kidney failure in the province. An early feature of diabetic kidney injury is hyperfiltration, when the kidney filters blood at an abnormally high rate. This hyperfiltration can accelerate kidney failure. Unfortunately, no therapies exist to target this process. In this proposal, we will use cutting edge techniques to test whether targeting Slit2-Robo signalling in kidney blood vessels can prevent hyperfiltration. Ultimately, our goal is to develop new therapies that will reduce the immense health, economic, and social burden of diabetic kidney disease in Ontario.
Keyword:
1) Chronic kidney disease
2) Diabetes
3) Diabetic nephropathy
4) Angiogenesis
5) Endothelium
6) Slit2
7) Robo
8) Hyperfiltration

Project_Title: Flow-sensing flying and swimming robots for effective environmental siting of wind and hydro power
Project_Description: Wind and small (run-of-the-river) hydro are two of the fastest growing renewable technologies in Ontario. Although energy extraction in such flows works well under idealized conditions, in practice the atmosphere (and river flows) are anything but uniform and steady. Instead, our lack of understanding of gusts and flow disturbances tends to hamper effective energy extraction. Furthermore, knowledge about this flow unsteadiness is critical to predict noise production, river-bed erosion as well as animal survival. Therefore, it is proposed to explore these flowfields through novel flying and swimming sensors in order to better inform siting and minimize health and environmental impact.
Keyword: aerodynamics; wind energy; Micro Aerial Vehicles; run-of-the-river hydropower; Autonomous Underwater Vehicles

Project_Title: Vascular Imaging as a Barometer for Early Detection of Heart Disease (VIBE Program)
Project_Description: We hypothesize that a novel carotid ultrasound protocol is an early warning clinical tool for the detection of heart disease. The proposed research consists of 2 projects reflecting each component of disease: Project A â€“ Hardening of the artery (Atherosis/Plaque) and Project B â€“ Stiffening of the artery (Sclerosis).   Participating HQP will learn specialized image acquisition protocols and sophisticated off-line analysis with correlation to global patient factors using state-of-the-art infrastructure provided by industry and peer-reviewed external grants. Given Ontarioâ€™s skyrocketing rate of cardiac risk factors, we have a tremendous need for experts adept at technological solutions to detect disease early and accur
Keyword: Cardiovascular disease, coronary artery disease, atherosclerosis, carotid, ultrasound, plaque, strain.

Project_Title: Advanced Health Technology: Your Pet Companion Holds the Keys to Veterinary and Human Regenerative Medicine
Project_Description: Joint cartilage damage and osteoarthritis (OA) affects more than 10% of Canadians and costs society more than $33 billion a year. New therapies for cartilage and OA are needed, but must be introduced in a safe and regulated manner. Dr. Kochâ€™s research program is focused on how to enhance joint health of horses and dogs using stem cell and microRNA technologies, and on using these animals and biomedical engineering approaches as important pre-clinical models of human joint disease. Novel biological joint therapies are expected to provide patients with life-long pain relief at reduced cost to societ
Keyword: Stem cells, horse, dog, microRNA, regenerative medicine, pre-clinical animal models, tissue-engineering, mechanobiology, chondrogenesis, immune-modulation

Project_Title: Inter-relationships between the lumbar spine and its muscles: implications for function and disorder
Project_Description: Low back pain is the number one source of disability worldwide and will directly affect 80% of the Canadian population. Muscles that attach to the spine apply forces to it, cause it to move, and stabilize it; thereby providing protection against injury while also having the potential to cause injury itself. Motivated by this importance and complexity, my research program is dedicated to examining the interplay between the spine and its muscles, and how spinal conditions related to back pain (intervertebral disc degeneration, facet osteoarthritis, instability) can be both causative, and an effect, of aberrant muscle structure and function.
Keyword: spine, muscle, low back, biomechanics, stability, injury, remodeling, adaptation, pain, musculoskeletal

Project_Title: Disruptive Innovation in Heart Disease Research- Randomized Registry Trials in Ontario
Project_Description: We are developing a platform to embed pragmatic trials of cardiovascular therapies leveraging infrastructure and data already collected during routine care. Our goal is to refine and select the right treatment for the right patient in the right contect (personalize care); and reduce a major cost and cause of disability in Ontario at a fraction of the cost of  the traditional clinical research. This proposal provides leading-edge training to produce hihgly qualified personnel; enhances Ontario's profile in the global academic community to host and perform cost-effective clinical trials; and implements knowledge transfer using advanced health and social technologies expertise from Ontario.
Keyword: Ischemic heart disease;heart faulure; risk factors; clinical trials; registries; knowledge translation; influenza

Project_Title: The specification of cell size in normal and malignant populations
Project_Description: How are cells regulated to have the â€œrightâ€ size? While pathways that promote growth in cell size have been elucidated, it remains unclear how the same common set of pathways can specify a different size for each of the different cell types.  Implications of cell size regulation to human pathology are numerous. For example, tumor grade in cancer is scored by the increased variability of cell size â€“ implicating loss of size regulation with disease pathology. My lab is determined to (a) understand the basic mechanisms that specify cell size and (b) establish first pharmacology of human pathologies relating to cell
Keyword: cell size, systems biology, cancer, cell cycle, computational biology, cell proliferation, cell signalling, growth factors, mitogens

Project_Title: Improving personalized medicine â€“ integrating multiple biological data sources to study variation in disea
Project_Description: Patients with the same disease are often biologically very different from each other and require different treatments. Recent technologies have made it cost-effective to collect various types of information on each individual including DNA, RNA, protein levels and other measurements. Dr. Goldenbergâ€™s lab has developed a fast and powerful computational method to combine this information in a single comprehensive personalized view of the disease in question. Her current goal is to build on this approach to predict the best treatment for each patient, thereby improving the quality of life of patients in Ontario and worldwid
Keyword: data integration; drug response prediction; Big Data; data science; disease heterogeneity; personalized medicine; cancer; complex human diseases; machine learning; method development

Project_Title: Understanding how heart and stroke related genes are controlled
Project_Description: Heart disease and stroke affect more than 5% of Ontarians, cause ~25% of all Canadian deaths and cost the Canadian economy more than $20 billion yearly. These diseases arise, in part, from inflammation in the cells that line blood vessels. When, where, and how much inflammation happens is influenced by genetics. Yet, the gene regulation mechanisms that control inflammation are not well described. We will find the DNA elements that control inflammation by building a multi-species gene regulation atlas of blood vessel inflammation. Finding these genetic controls will catalyze new ways to diagnose and treat heart disease and stroke.
Keyword: genomics, human genetics, molecular evolution, epigenetics, transcription factor, acute inflammation, chromatin, DNA sequencing, chromatin immuno-precipitation, endothelial cell

Project_Title: Systematic functional phenotyping of Mendelian disease alleles
Project_Description: Each rare disease affects only a small number of individuals, but together these disorders affect millions of patients in Canada. Most rare diseases have a firm genetic basis, and thousands of disease genes have already been reported. However, how these genetic variants cause disease at the molecular level is often unclear. I will take rare disease research to the genomic era and systematically characterize the subcellular localization of 2,500 mutant variants underlying over 1,100 rare Mendelian disorders. This project will transform our understanding of the molecular mechanisms underlying rare disorders and provide a springboard for drug discovery in neglected diseases.
Keyword: rare diseases, protein homeostasis, functional genomics, functional proteomics, cell biology

Project_Title: Integrated computational materials engineering of ultra-lightweight alloys with unprecedented ductility and mechanical strength for automotive and aerospace applications
Project_Description: The metals industry forms the backbone of Ontarioâ€™s manufacturing sector and its continued success is necessary for global competiveness. While being lightweight, structural alloys should possess high mechanical strength and good ductility so they can be easily shaped into commercial products. While alloy strength can be improved significantly by grain-size refinement, ductility is difficult to maintain. This proposal will use integrated computational materials engineering to develop novel nanostructured alloys that optimize these properties. The combined modeling and experimental approach will develop critical design tools for manufacturing new lightweight materials to achieve the 2025 Corporate Fuel Economy standard of 54.4 mp
Keyword: Nanocrystalline materials, nano-engineering, grain boundary, fracture toughness, mechanical strength, ductility, molecular dynamics (MD), multiscale modeling,  nano-indentation, in situ testing.

Project_Title: Laser-based gas-phase and surface thermometry for improved environmental performance of aerospace and power-generation combustors
Project_Description: Combustion provides about 85% of global energy. Gas turbine engines are ubiquitous in aviation and generate an increasingly large portion of our electricity. Temperature is the dominant parameter controlling pollutant emissions (NOx, CO, particulates, unburnt hydrocarbons), thermal efficiency, and robustness, but presently cannot be accurately measured in realistic combustors. This research will develop two laser-based techniques to measure gas-phase and surface temperatures, specifically applicable for conditions found in gas turbine combustors. The resultant measurements will allow Ontario-based companies to produce aeronautical and power generation engines with lower emissions, greater fuel-flexibility, and improved efficiency in less time and at lower cost.
Keyword: Aerospace; Gas turbine engines; Propulsion; Power generation; Turbulence; Combustion; Laser diagnostics; Alternative fuels; Air pollution

Project_Title: Improving emotion regulation and coping among youth sport and competitive athletes
Project_Description: Dr. Tamminenâ€™s research focuses on understanding stress, coping, and emotion regulation among youth sport athletes and among competitive, high-performance athletes alike.
