Her research aims are: 1) to uncover processes of interpersonal emotion regulation in sport, to understand how athletes regulate their own and othersâ€™ emotions during situations of acute stress, ultimately improving sport performance and interpersonal functioning; and 2) to improve coping and interactions between parents and young athletes, contributing to lifelong sport participation. This project includes qualitative and quantitative studies to help athletes to cope with stress in sport and to promote positive interactions between athletes, teammates, and pare
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development
Keyword: sport psychology, athletes, youth sport, emotion, coping, emotion regulation

Project_Title: Fast Simulation Techniques to Tackle the Design Complexity of Future 3D Integrated Circuits and Antennas
Project_Description: Integrated circuits and antennas enable mobile communication, navigation, e-commerce, multimedia. Next-generation circuits and antennas will be incredibly powerful, but also very complex to design. Existing design methods cannot handle the complexity of upcoming products, and start affecting the productivity of several companies in Ontario. We aim to develop a new approach to computer aided design that will meet industry needs. Fourteen students will receive advanced training in this crucial area. The proposed research directly involves four companies in Ontario (AMD, MDA, IDS, Siradel) and will contribute to the strategic area "Information and communication technology" of Ontario's Innovation Agenda.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Keyword: 3D integrated circuits, metasurface antennas, computer-aided design, computer simulation, fast algorithms

Project_Title: Biomicrofluidics for Cancer Research: Integrating 3D Spheroids and Angiogenic Blood Vessels
Project_Description: Current research in biology is hindered by a lack of laboratory tools that can precisely model cellular interactions found in living tissues. Consequently, use of existing tools often leads to spurious results that contradict clinical research outcomes. The goal of this project is to combine engineering principles and microfabrication techniques to create a novel platform capable of accurately modeling diseased human tissues, with a focus on developing a cancer tumor model comprised of infiltrating blood vessels. Development of this technology will advance basic and clinical cancer research, and will train students in a multi-disciplinary field that bridges engineering and biology.
Keyword: microfluidics, organs-on-chips, microfabrication, cell-based assays, cancer, angiogenesis, spheroids

Project_Title: A molecular and cellular understanding of the trophoblast and placenta
Project_Description: Twenty percent of all human pregnancies require medical assistance, largely due to poor development and function of the placenta. The placenta connects the mother and fetus and transfers oxygen and nutrients needed for development. Tragically, most placental pathologies cannot be detected early and there are no available therapies. My proposed research investigates the cell types and genes that regulate the development of the placenta to provide a clearer understanding of when and how problems with the placenta occur. The genes we identify may be early markers of pregnancy diseases and the cells are the targets for new therapies.
Keyword: Genes, Cells, Placenta, Human, Development, Pregnancy, Mother, Health, Organogenesis

Project_Title: Using Participatory Action Research to understand Sport and Social Development in Toronto, Ontario
Project_Description: The hosting of the 2015 Pan Am Games is evidence that the province of Ontario values and invests in sport. A major justification for this public investment is sport's presumed social and community benefits. However, recent research is equivocal about whether sport contributes to social development. Therefore, research is needed that specifically examines sport and social development in Ontario. Using Participatory Action Research, this project will examine the experiences, meanings and social implications of youth baseball in two Toronto neighbourhoods. The results will support Ontario's policy priorities by making recommendations for how to improve sport programs for Ontario's young people.
Keyword: Sport, Youth, Social Development, Participation, Action Research, Baseball, Public Policy, Social Change, Community

Project_Title: In Situ Studies of 2D Nanostructured Li-Ion Battery Electrodes
Project_Description: This project aims to guide the development of Lithium-ion (Li-ion) battery electrode materials needed for improving performance and lifetimes. The project will focus on studying nanostructured electrodes that address key limitations in current Li-ion batteries. The proposed research addresses the Ontario Innovation Agenda focus area of clean technologies as it will enable commercially viable nanostructured batteries for new products such as long-range electric vehicles, and will extend the battery lifetimes of everyday consumer goods. Ontario companies will benefit from the development of nanostructured electrodes, new in-situ testing approaches, and graduates with relevant skills for battery technologies, energy, aerospace and automotive.
Keyword:
Li-ion batteries, charge capacity, in situ mechanical testing, mechanics, structure-property
relationships, in situ AFM electrochemical testing, graphene, 2D nanostructures, battery cycle life

Project_Title: Advancing Sexually Transmitted Infections and HIV Prevention Among Young Women: Improving Young Women's Sexual Health
Project_Description: Sexually transmitted infections (STIs), including HIV, are increasing among women in Canada. Young women aged 20-24 had chlamydia infection rates 7 times the national average, and young women aged 15-19 had gonorhhea infection rates 4 times the national average. Gender differences in STI risk occur due to biological and social factors, yet knowledge gaps persist regarding efficacious STI prevention strategies for young women. This innovative investigation will use qualitative and quantitative methods to adapt and pilot test a STI prevention intervention with key populations of young women (Indigenous, African Caribbean) in 3 Ontario cities (Toronto, Hamilton, Thunder Bay).
Keyword: youth; women; sexually transmitted infections; HIV; prevention science

Project_Title: Identifying novel mechanisms of muscle stem cell regulation for skeletal muscle regenerative medicine
Project_Description: The leading cause of injury among Ontario seniors is falling and a risk factor for falling is skeletal muscle weakness. Many factors contribute to seniorsâ€™ diminished strength. In youth, muscle injuries are resolved and pre-injury strength restored, due to the repair ability of resident satellite stem cells. We found that satellite cells lose potency with age, resulting in poor repair and cumulative strength decline. Our research defines cues and molecules that guide satellite cells through muscle repair. This knowledge will provide the foundation for future regenerative medicine strategies that rejuvenate satellite cells to increase strength, health, and independence throughout lif
Keyword: Skeletal Muscle, Regenerative Medicine, Satellite Stem Cells, Cellular and Molecular Bioengineering, Cellular Mechanotransduction, Stem Cell Niche, Self-Renewal, LINC Complex, Transcription, Biophysics,

Project_Title: Using isotopic compositions of metals for ore deposit research and exploration
Project_Description: Global demand for minerals and metals is expected to continue to grow rapidly with emerging economies. Here, Dr Bouvier with her team will develop new geochemical methods for better tracing metal cycles in the Earth's crust and mantle, and establishing the processes and ages of metal ore formation. This research program will benefit Ontario by determining the sources, physical conditions, and timing of formation of a variety of mineral deposits. The research in this proposal will contribute to a $9.1 billion economy in Ontario by creating highly qualified personnel and new strategies for mineral exploration in Ontario and beyond.
Keyword: Geochemistry, Geochronology, Economic Geology, Metals, Isotopes, Ore deposits, Petrology, Planetary materials,  Petrology

Project_Title: Optimizing Knee Kinematics Following Anterior Cruciate Ligament Reconstruction
Project_Description: Surgical reconstruction of the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) is advocated to restore patients' normal function following injury; however, current surgical techniques still encounter complications such as graft failure and development of post traumatic osteoarthritis.  Standard reconstruction techniques have been shown to create abnormal knee kinematics with altered loading of the joint surface.  My team has built a novel robot that applies physiologic loads to cadaveric knees during microCT enabling high-resolution imaging and strain measurement of intra-articular tissues. This will enable accurate assessment of current ACL reconstruction techniques and the subsequent development of optimal procedures aimed at improving patient outcomes.
Keyword: Anterior Cruciate Ligament Reconstruction; Knee Kinematics; Robotics; MicroCT; Finite Element Modeling

Project_Title: Exploring Cultural Change through Archaeology at the Vindolanda North Field Project
Project_Description: This project brings students to a world-renowned archaeological site (Vindolanda) to investigate the processes of change after conquest in the border regions of the Roman Empire. Data is collected primarily through archaeological excavation with a focus on emerging digital technologies in archaeology and heritage management. Students are trained in the heritage sector broadly from field work to museum studies, turning them into highly qualified personnel on the leading edge of the heritage sector and education of past human groups. This training experience makes them highly competitive in Ontario for positions in curatorial work, academic research, and cultural resource management.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Keyword: Cultural change; heritage management; Archaeology; digital archaeology; Roman; Frontiers; Multicultural; Provincial; Conquest; Military.

Project_Title: Defective removal of damaged and dying cells drives cardiovascular disease.
Project_Description: Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is instigated by plaques of dead and dying cholesterol-filled immune cells which accumulate in the heart and can cause heart attack or stroke upon bursting.  Failure of efferocytosis, the bodyâ€™s natural process for removing cells, leads to plaque formation, but the reasons for this failure are not known. My lab investigates the underlying causes of efferocytosis failure in CVD and recently identified an antigen processing pathway which is altered during atherosclerosis. We propose to investigate the role of this pathway in efferocytosis failure in CVD, which could potentially lead to new targets to prevent or treat CV
Keyword: atherosclerosis, cardiovascular disease, macrophage, cell death, phagocytosis, inflammation, cholesterol, efferocytosis

Project_Title: Neural control of reaching, grasping and object manipulation
Project_Description: Motor behavior and sensory perception appear effortless but reflect many complex interactions between the brain and the body. My research program aims to unravel how the nervous system handles and exploits these interactions during reaching, grasping, and object manipulation. This knowledge is critical for developing new and better treatments for spinal cord injury, peripheral nerve injury and amputation, all of which disrupt these interactions. Critical to my effort is a multi-disciplinary and translational approach including neurophysiological studies, computational modeling efforts and patient work.
Keyword: neuroscience, motor control, sensory perception, tactile, somatosensory, reaching, grasping, electrophysiology

Project_Title: Enhanced Stability of Mine Waste Tailings Embankments
Project_Description: The safety and the environmental impact of mine waste tailings dams are important for the economical growth of Canada, and in particular, Ontario. In this research program, a microbiological method will be investigated to improve the strength and stiffness (bio-cementation) and reduce the permeability (bio-clogging) of mine waste tailings. These improvements will enhance the stability of new and existing tailings dams and reduce the leaching of toxic substances (heavy metals, arsenic, acids) from tailings. The proposed method is an innovative technology, with reduced cost and environmental impact for tailings stabilization and building self-sustaining mine waste tailings dam in Ontario.
Keyword: tailings dams, environment, liquefaction, stability, landslide, microbiology, earthquake, shear test, field test, cementation

Project_Title: Imaging and wearable sensors to direct and evaluate orthopaedic therapies
Project_Description: Total joint replacement is the current standard treatment for over 40,000 Ontarians per year with severe arthritis, but can have significant downsides. Supposed advances in implants have failed to translate to improved patient outcomes, and some have even been detrimental. Better methods are needed to identify optimal treatments for patients and assess outcomes. The proposed research will develop wearable sensors for assessing joint motion and implant function, validated using state-of-the-art imaging and motion analysis techniques. The measurements from wearable sensors will provide clinically meaningful data and could lead to improved treatments for patients with arthritis.
Keyword: Arthritis, joint replacement, wearable sensors, single-plane fluoroscopy, radiostereometric analysis, load-bearing computed tomography, 3D gait analysis

Project_Title: Supporting Physical Activity in the Childcare Environment (SPACE): The Impact of Outdoor Playtime and Playground Design
Project_Description: The SPACE study, a physical activity intervention targeting preschoolers in centre-based childcare (n = 11 experimental, n = 11 control) is underway. The intervention includes: shorter, more frequent bouts of outdoor playtime (4x30 minutes/day), new equipment, and staff training. The current proposal entails extending the SPACE study to enlist 11 additional centres to implement only the outdoor playtime portion to determine if this component alone, increases preschoolersâ€™ activity. Modifying the outdoor play periods is the most economical intervention component, and therefore, the most sustainable for childcare centres. This study will also evaluate the impact  of naturalizing childcare playgrounds on preschoolers' physical activit
Keyword: physical activity, preschool children, childcare, early learning, play, outdoor, accelerometer, playground

Project_Title: Creating a biological and psychological databank for advanced exploration of chronic pain mechanisms
Project_Description: It is estimated 20-60% of people experiencing acute traumatic injuries will report persistent problems one year after the event.  Investigations, treatment, litigation, and lost productivity represent massive cost to the sufferer and Ontarians.  There is currently little evidence to guide clinical decisions for preventing persistent problems.  In the absence of structural pathology, academics, clinicians and policy makers must look beyond traditional models.  This project will establish a longitudinal databank of biological, psychological and social factors starting from the acute injury through 1 year.  This will allow advanced statistical modeling of interactions to understand and prevent chronic pain and disability.
Keyword: Interdisciplinary, genomics, metabolomics, proteomics, biopsychosocial, pain, disability, longitudinal research

Project_Title: Precision Medicine for Prostate Cancer: MRI for Risk Stratification
Project_Description: Prostate cancer is usually treated with a whole-gland approach. For the many patients harbouring slow-growing disease this constitutes overtreatment, leading to serious quality of life consequences and economic burden on the Ontario health care system. Current clinical tools for assessing risk are error-prone. Consequently, thousands of men have their entire prostates surgically removed or irradiated every year to treat cancer that is discovered to be indolent during subsequent pathological assessment. The proposed research will develop technologies based on magnetic resonance imaging to provide accurate risk assessment and treatment selection for each patient, conquering the overtreatment problem.
Keyword: Oncology, imaging, histopathology, fusion, quantitative, biomarker, visualization, three-dimensional, computational, software

Project_Title: Elucidating the genetic basis for human cancer and a tumorâ€™s Achillesâ€™ heel by integrating human cancer genomics with mouse model
Project_Description: The hunt for the genetic alteration that cause cancer is extremely challenging, as patients carry hundreds of mutations, most of which form just randomly â€“ they are just bystanders without diagnostic or therapeutic relevance. The rare driver mutations that trigger tumor development as well as metastasis and could guide the design of new therapies hide like â€œneedles in the haystackâ€. To find those needles, I have developed a ground-breaking, new technique that quickly weeds out all the bystander mutations, unearths the critical driver mutations and allows me to test novel therapeutic strategies directly in well-established mouse models of human ca
Keyword: cancer, functional genomics, oncogenes, tumor suppressor genes, novel drug targets, metastasis, epithelium, genomics

Project_Title: Usable Privacy and Security for Children
Project_Description: Our goal is to design interfaces that influence, motivate and, help children be more secure online rather than putting themselves at risk by circumventing or inadvertently undermining security and privacy mechanisms. Our approach includes two primary directions: educational materials to help children navigate current online risks and the development of new tools and user authentication mechanisms to improve usable security and privacy for children. This research fits the provincial Digital Media and Knowledge Transfer focus areas and is expected to provide social benefits to Ontarians by empowering children to safely participate in online activities.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Keyword: Usable security, human-computer interaction, computer security, User studies, Human factors, design for children, user authentication, educational games, persuasive technology

Project_Title: Developing deformable user interfaces to improve manual dexterity
Project_Description: Upcoming flexible technology will enable users to squeeze a smartphone to answer a call, or bend a corner to change an eBookâ€™s page. Deformable devices offer an opportunity to improve manual dexterity for people with hand function limitations. The proposed research will fabricate and evaluate specialized deformable devices, applications and games, to assess if bend gestures are a suitable human computer interaction input technique for hand rehabilitation. Benefits to Ontario include improved hand dexterity for patients currently in rehabilitation, novel product development, and highly skilled workers in HCI, software development and hardware prototypin
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Keyword: Human Computer Interaction, Flexible Displays, Mobile Device, Input Technique, Bend Gesture, Sensing Technology, Games, Rehabilitation, Upper extremity

Project_Title: Indigenous mental health and addiction: Culture and context
Project_Description: Canadaâ€™s Indigenous peoples are diverse, with rich cultural traditions and methods of healing. Colonization and aggressive assimilation attempts have disrupted the health of individuals, families, and communities - Indigenous peoples experience higher rates of mental health difficulties and addiction compared to non-Indigenous peoples. This research will identify appropriate targets of intervention, examine culture-based and western treatment approaches for mental health and addiction, and develop evaluation methods.  It involves collaborative partnerships grounded in community and respectful of Indigenous understandings of wellness. Importantly, it will improve wellness for Indigenous individuals, families, and communities so they can benefit from employment and economic development opportunitie
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development
Keyword: Indigenous, Aboriginal, First Nation, mental health, addiction, substance use, wellbeing

Project_Title: Work disability prevention in Ontario: testing a supervisor training intervention
Project_Description: Supervisors of injured and ill workers are crucial in preventing prolonged work absences. Providing supervisors with tools to improve their response to injury or illness may improve disability outcomes. The aim of this study is to determine if a supervisor training program can improve work disability outcomes for injured and ill workers. Supervisors within randomly selected work units will receive training. The training intends to increase problem solving skills to reduce absenteeism, improve supervisor response to injury and illness, and improve supervisor communication skills. Findings have the potential to impact the Ontario economy, employers, and the lives of Ontario workers.
Keyword: supervisor, training program, work accommodation, work disability prevention, randomized controlled trial, musculoskeletal disorders, chronic conditions

Project_Title: Nanoparticle arrays for light management an degradation control in organic devices (NanoLight)
Project_Description: The proposed research will address key concerns in the commercialization of organic photovoltaic devices - high costs, low efficiency and short lifetime - by using solution approaches that are simple, inexpensive, and unique to McMaster in order to introduce nanoparticles at critical interfaces in the device. The nanoparticles will be used for effective management of light to increase efficiency without sacrificing electrical performance; and for control of degradation to increase device lifetime. Such efforts are necessary in achieving 10-10 targets (10% efficiency, 10 year lifetime) required for widespread device commercialization, and to support a developing photovoltaic industry in Ontario.
Keyword: organic electronics,solar cells, nanoparticles, interface engineering, light management, degradation

Project_Title: Improving treatment of obesity by making stem cell models to understand how obesity develops
Project_Description: We are in the midst of an obesity epidemic with ~70% of Ontarians categorized as obese/overweight, posing a large socioeconomic problem for Ontario. For most obese individuals only 5-10% of weight can be managed by current treatments (pharmacotherapy, diet or exercise). Therefore, my proposed program focuses on understanding human fat development from stem cells in healthy and obese patients. Here I propose to use cutting-edge technologies to understand how obesity affects stem cells and how understanding disease development can help us establish better treatment strategies towards alleviating disease and economic burden and improve quality of life across Ontario and Canada.
Keyword: obesity, adipose tissue derived stem cell (ADSC), induced pluripotent stem cell (iPSC), brown/beige adipocyte, white adipocyte, metabolism, reprogramming, genetic inheritance, lipid transport, mitochondria

Project_Title: Virtual Hamilton: A Virtual Environment for Participatory Urban Planning
Project_Description: This research project proposes the design, implementation, and evaluation of the efficacy, of a participatory urban planning system. This research entails collaboration with a confirmed municipal research partner, the City of Hamilton, to develop and test an online 3D virtual world with integrated social media to facilitate stakeholder visualization, multiuser content creation, and multi-lateral communication. This cutting edge application of virtual world media to urban planning processes will benefit Hamilton and other Ontario urban planning stakeholders by providing a collaborative planning system that allows participants early and informed involvement in community building and planning processes.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Keyword: Virtual Environment; Virtual Cities; Participatory Urban Planning; Social Media; Data Visualization; Augmented Reality

Project_Title: Water Risks and Responses in the Great Lakes:  Principles and Indicators
Project_Description: Natural hazards are expected to cost Canadians up to $43 billion per year by 2050.  Innovations in public policy and technology will be needed to measure, map and manage these water risks. Working to support Ontario's Great Lakes Strategy, Water Innovation Act and billions in public and private infrastructure investment, I will assess policy options to manage  flooding, pollution, drinking water advisories and fluctuating water levels.  A Great Lakes Disturbance Database (GLaDD) will synthesize social, physical and governance data about different types of water risks and evaluate the private sector and public policy responses to manage these risks and trade-offs.
Keyword: Social-Ecological Systems, Risk Science, Decision Analysis, Environmental Policy, Water Governance, Great Lakes,  Connecting Science and Decision-Making, Comparative Methods, Database Development

Project_Title: Development of all-solution-processing methods for creating fully integrated biosensing platforms
Project_Description: Point-of-care diagnostics based on detecting specific DNA sequences have gained significant attention due to their potential use in preventive screening, early-stage diagnostics, personalized medicine, and home healthcare. However, there are currently no commercially-available handheld DNA biosensors applicable to these endeavors. This proposal aims at developing a unique, inexpensive and scalable all-solution-based manufacturing process for solving the miniaturization and integration challenges of fully-integrated DNA biosensors. This will enable the translation of several biosensing technologies to the market, placing Ontario researchers and industry in a leading position in the point-of-care diagnostic area, while providing major economic and health benefits for the Ontarians.
Keyword: All-solution-processing, printable electronics, multi-scale materials, high surface area electrodes, nanofabrication, biosensing, DNA detection, biological sample preparation, shrink memory polymers, rapid prototyping.

Project_Title: HPB CONCEPT:  An Integrated Program to Improve Outcomes Following Liver Surgery
Project_Description: My research aims to improve the outcomes of patients undergoing liver surgery through integrated, patient-centred, collaborative trials.  I have established a collaborative clinical trials group termed the HPB CONCEPT Team.  Through this group I am leading two multicentre, randomized controlled trials: The HELIX trial examining the impact of the drug tranexamic acid (TXA) on blood transfusion in patients undergoing liver resection; and the MOTAP trial assessing the effectiveness of a novel technique of pain management following liver surgery.  This award will support the expansion of these trials to other centres and improve the outcomes of patients undergoing liver surgery.
Keyword: Surgery, liver, hepatopancreaticobiliary, clinical trials, transfusion medicine, analgesia, regional anaesthesia

Project_Title: Improving the Triage and Quality of Care for Patients with Severe Aortic Stenosis undergoing Transcatheter Aortic Valve Implantation (TAVI)
Project_Description: Aortic stenosis is the most common acquired heart valve disease. When the resulting obstruction of blood flow from the heart to the rest of the body becomes severe, the outlook is grim â€“ half of patients dying within a year. Transcatheter aortic valve implantation (TAVI) is a minimally invasive alternative to traditional valve surgery.  Although life-saving, TAVIâ€™s capacity is limited by substantial expertise and resource requirements.  By incorporating data from Ontarioâ€™s healthcare system to assess the costs/benefits of TAVI, this proposed study will inform economic and policy models to improve the access of TAVI to Ontarians who need it the
Keyword:
wait-time management
quality indicators
administrative databases
aortic stenosis
trans-cathether aortic valve implantation (TAVI)

Project_Title: A good night's sleep to prevent type 2 diabetes in adolescents
Project_Description: Studies have shown that short sleep duration is associated with type 2 diabetes (T2D), especially in young people. Other research suggests that short-term sleep restriction leads to decreased insulin function, which could lead to T2D over time. However, whether increasing sleep duration may help to improve blood sugar control in youth is unknown despite the fact that chronic sleep deprivation is common in modern societies. Thus, the objective of this project is to examine the effect of experimental changes in sleep duration on markers of glucose metabolism in "high risk" adolescents. Finding new ways to prevent T2D is desperately needed.
Lead_Research_Institution: Children's Hospital of Eastern Ontario Research Institute Inc.
Keyword: Sleep; diabetes; obesity; adolescents; prevention

Project_Title: Evaluation of Blood Product Utilization, Healthcare Resource Consumption and Patient Outcomes in Novel Oral Antiocoagulant-Related hemorrhage
Project_Description: Blood thinning medications prevent stroke in patients with heart disease, but can cause life-threatening bleeding as a side-effect. Recently, Health Canada approved three new blood-thinners which, critics claim, cause bleeding that is not easily stopped, exposing patients to harm and increasing the economic burden on health-care. We will review all bleeds caused by blood-thinners in Ottawa, Hamilton and Kingston over a five-year period to determine outcomes and the total cost associated with the treatment of bleeding. We believe the results will show the new drugs will cause fewer bleeds, which will save lives and reduce health-care costs in Ontario.
Keyword: Orla anticoagulants, Stroke, Hemorrhage, Health Utilization, Health Economics, Outocme

Project_Title: High-resolution analysis of receptor tyrosine kinase function at the cell surface
Project_Description: Cells receive signals from many different hormones that bind to receptor proteins at the cell surface, thus controlling cell growth, survival and movement. These receptor proteins trigger many different proteins and lipids to achieve this control of cell function. Importantly, these hormone signals are altered in cancer, and drive cancer growth and metastasis. We propose to substantially advance our understanding of hormone receptors function by developing a high-resolution spatial map within cells of hormone receptors, and the cellular proteins and lipids through which they act.  This will greatly enhance our knowledge of how hormone signals control healthy cells and tumors.
Keyword: receptor signaling, phosphorylation, network, image analysis, microscopy, cancer, genomics, spatiotemorally-resolved genomics, context-specific biology

Project_Title: Islamophobia: The exacerbating and inhibiting functions of fear and humour
Project_Description: Disconcertingly, Islamophobia is on the rise in Canada, with the top four offending cities of hate crimes against Muslims in Ontario. Hence, there is a great need to identify the causes of Islamophobia and ways to reduce it. Research by Dr. Choma suggests that fear plays a fundamental role, and that avenues for reducing Islamophobia among people who support prejudice-endorsing sociopolitical ideologies is particularly important. Expanding on a recent SSRHC grant and her previous research, Dr. Choma will investigate how fear of Muslims leads to prejudice, whether humour can disarm fear and reduce prejudice, and the role of ideology.
Keyword: prejudice, discrimination, Islamophobia, ideology, fear, humour, prejudice-reduction, social psychology

Project_Title: Understanding and Mitigating Engine Emissions
Project_Description: Engine emissions of carbon particles are a serious problem because of their adverse impacts on climate change and respiratory health. Ontario companies in the aerospace and ground vehicle sectors are struggling to produce cleaner engines and meet ever-stricter government emissions regulations. This research will address these issues by developing a detailed numerical model for engine emissions. It will improve our fundamental understanding of how and why particles form. The new models will be implemented into engine simulations at Ontario companies and will predict emissions without the need for costly prototyping. This capability will enable manufacturing of next-generation ultra-low emitting engines.
Keyword: Engine Emissions, Soot Particle Formation, High Performance Computing, Parallel Computing, Numerical Analysis, Combustion Efficiency

Project_Title: The origins of individual differences in emotion processing
Project_Description: Fundamental to successful social interactions is our ability to â€œreadâ€ other peopleâ€™s emotions. Humans vary in how adept they are at deciphering this information (e.g., individuals with autism spectrum disorders have difficulty identifying emotions), but we know little about how individual differences in emotion processing arise. Using behavioural, electrophysiological, and neuroimaging techniques, the origins of individual differences in emotion processing will be explored in the first two years of life. Discovering factors that influence the development of emotion processing in typically-developing infants will provide targets for intervention in populations with deficits in this critical social ability (e.g., autism spectrum disor
Keyword: development, emotion, individual differences, face perception, emotion regulation, infancy, electrophysiology, neuroimaging

Project_Title: Coating and encapsulating biological cells using lab-on-a-chip technology
Project_Description: Cell transplantation therapy is promising for treating many diseases, but is hampered by immune system destruction of transplanted cells. Therefore, we are engineering an optical lab-on-a-chip technique to coat single cells, such as the cells used in cell transplantation therapies. Our goal is to protect cells from the immune system, and facilitate the transport of nutrients across the coating membrane. We are combining micro scale fluid mechanics, with optical manipulation, to develop the first optical lab-on-a-chip cell coating device. Our technology will improve the efficacy of cell transplants, which will positively contribute to Ontario's health care and biotechnology industries.
Keyword: lab-on-a-chip, microfluidics, fluid mechanics, biotechnology, cell coating, immunoisolation, optical trapping

Project_Title: The protectors: understanding innate antiviral immune responses in aquatic vertebrates
Project_Description: The innate immune response is the first line of defense against virus indections and type I interferons (IFNs) are its key effectors. This proposal aims to study frog virus 3 (FV3) and viral hemorrhagic septicemia virus (VHSV), two viruses that are serious threats to Ontario aquatic vertebrates, both of whom are strongly regulated by IFNs. The goal is to better understand how fish and frog cells respond to these viruses, and how the innate immune response is involved, in order to develop novel antiviral therapies for cultured fish and protective measures for awuatic vertebrates found in Ontario Waters.
Keyword: cell biology, virology, innate immunology, molecular biology, microscopy, tyle I interferons, double-stranded RNA, viral nucleic acids, RNAi

Project_Title: A double edged-sword of benevolent sexism: How benevolent sexist attitudes promote and undermine gender diversity in the workplace
Project_Description: Women continue to face barriers in the workplace that impede their careers and access to top positions. This research program advances our understanding of why women are underrepresented in top positions by examining the effects of benevolent sexism (characterizing women as wonderful, yet weak) on support for employment equity (EE) policies promoting the employment of women. I suggest that benevolent sexism, presumably harmless and socially accepted, may appear to promote general EE policies, while subtly undermining EE policies that promote the employment of women in top positions. This research supports Ontario's commitment to gender diversity in corporate leadership.
Keyword: Gender diversity; diversity and equality in the workplace; women in top positions; employment equity; sexism; benevolent sexism; compassion

Project_Title: Solvers for Security via a Combination of Machine Learning and Deduction
Project_Description: Inadequate software security is a grave threat to Ontario's economy and Canada's national security. The proposed project will dramatically improve the core infrastructure and tools on which software security depends. The security of software systems is ascertained via verification techniques that crucially depend on mathematical constraint solvers. The proposed project will develop new machine learning and deductive reasoning techniques, and combine them in novel ways to build next-generation highly scalable constraint solvers. Dr. Ganesh has active collaboration with many Ontario's leading software companies like BlackBerry, Google, and IBM, and will work with them to deploy these solutions in the real-world.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Keyword: Constraint (SAT/SMT) solvers, Computer Security, Exploit Construction, Vulnerability Detection, Program Analysis,  Software Testing, Machine Learning, Deductive Reasoning, Software Engineering, Automatic Bug-finding

Project_Title: Tourism and Indigenous Livelihoods in Ontario's Near North
Project_Description: This research examines intersections of indigenous livelihoods and contemporary tourism in Ontarioâ€™s â€œnear northâ€ in order to address social challenges associated with development. Utilizing a multi-case multi-method approach, research will illuminate how First Nations within the region actively engage, relate to, or may ultimately benefit from tourism. This will elevate voices of Ontario First Nations within development discourses, and translate into policy directions and service opportunities designed to foster reconciliation and enable all of Ontario to achieve sustainable and prosperous futures. HQP will be trained to further advance these social and cultural benefits in their research, career, or civic pur
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Keyword: Aboriginal research, tourism, cultural livelihoods, social justice, sustainability, communities, participatory research, qualitative inquiry, northern landscapes, development

Project_Title: Game and Interaction Science: Using Principles from Games to Design Novel Interfaces that Compel and Motivate
Project_Description: Many successful technologies, such as multitouch phones and tablets, are often described as â€œnaturalâ€ and â€œintuitiveâ€; however, there is little science behind what makes one technology motivating or compelling to use, and another uninteresting. This research will focus on the science of games and interactionâ€”using concepts from game design, such as engagement, immersion, and enjoyment, to inform the design of more motivating and compelling novel interfaces. The research will be done in collaboration with partners from Ontarioâ€™s growing interactive digital media industry, and train HQP to be leaders in the design of successful information & communications
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Keyword: Human-computer interaction, multitouch surfaces, 3D interaction, serious games, gamification, games for learning, touch experience, embodiment, interaction design.

Project_Title: Economic and Environmental Implications of Ancient Ocean Chemistry in Sedimentary Basins Containing Ontario's Major Reservoirs of Shale Gas
Project_Description: In Ontario, multiple organic-rich mudrocks represent promising shale gas plays. However, the mudrock and shale gas quality are poorly understood because new tracers of ancient ocean chemistry have not been applied to these mudrocks. The proposed research will combine redox-sensitive trace element concentrations (rhenium, molybdenum, uranium), isotope compositions (molybdenum, uranium, iron), and iron speciation data from multiple drillcores to infer the regional distribution of oxygenated, anoxic/sulfidic, and anoxic/non-sulfidic seawater during mudrock deposition. Locations where mudrocks were deposited from anoxic/non-sulfidic seawater are advantageous for shale gas development and benefit Ontario's economy and environment by minimizing extraction of hydrogen sulfide-rich sour gas.
Keyword: isotope geochemistry, ocean chemistry, sedimentary basins, Ordovician, Devonian, shale gas, molybdenum, uranium, iron, rhenium

Project_Title: Leveraging Advanced Microbial Electrochemical Cell Technologies for Sustainable Wastewater Treatment
Project_Description: Sustainable wastewater treatment solutions are essential to Ontarioâ€™s future economic and ecological prosperity. Conventional aerobic treatment technologies are both energy-hungry and exorbitantly expensive to operate, costing the province upwards of $1B each year. The proposed research program aims to advance anaerobic treatment systems that can simultaneously clean our wastewater and recover nutrients and chemicals that will become a new source of cheap, renewable energy. With the ability to capture the power they produce, these technologies represent an energy-efficient, sustainable wastewater management solution that will ultimately grow Ontarioâ€™s bio-economy and clean technology industries and save its taxpayers mo
Keyword: Microbial electrochemical cells, anaerobic wastewater treatment, extracellular electron transfer, biochemicals, nutrients recovery

Project_Title: Personalized Data-Driven Intensive Care Based on Electronic Medical Data, Patient Similarity Metrics, and High-Performance Computing
Project_Description: Clinical decision making in the intensive care unit (ICU) often resorts to subjective approaches due to a lack of decisive research results. This proposed research aims to generate personalized decision support by identifying and analyzing similar patients in electronic medical data. The research outcome will be a computing infrastructure that ICU physicians can visually interact with to aid their decision making. The research will not only train Ontarian leaders in the promising field of health data science but also lead to cost savings and improved patient outcomes in increasingly aging and resource-consuming Ontario ICUs via optimal decision making.
Keyword: health data science, medical informatics, clinical decision support, electronic medical data, high-performance computing, predictive analytics, machine learning, big data, statistical inference, information visualization

Project_Title: Information and Idea Diffusion in an Open Source Collaboration Network: The Case of Linux Kernel Developers
Project_Description: Open source developer communities have revolutionized the production of digital technologies and are responsible for some of the most widely used and important technologies in the world. Despite inspiring research on the benefits of open source, there is much we do not know about how successful open source communities work. Using social network analysis and a groundbreaking dataset, this project examines how information and ideas flow through a collaboration network of Linux developers from 1991-2015. It will train HQP to collect and analyze data on software production, strengthening Ontario's position as a world leader in producing innovative digital technologies.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Keyword: social networks, open source, software, brokerage, expertise, diffusion, information flow, collaboration, data mining, computational social science

Project_Title: Development of new fluorination strategies with applications in medicinal chemistry.
Project_Description: Countless advancements in the detection and treatment of disease states like Alzheimerâ€™s and cancer have resulted from fluorination of pharmaceuticals and radiochemical probes. Elemental fluorine is extremely reactive, and taming its reactivity is difficult, therefore there is a critical need for new fluorination techniques. The proposed research will develop reactions based on a stable, recyclable surrogate for fluorine gas, and provide a versatile and highly efficient means to fluorinate structures of antibacterial, medicinal, pharmaceutical and radiological interest. These objectives parallel Ontario Innovation Agendaâ€™s goals of promoting pharmaceutical, advanced medical and â€œgreenerâ€ technologies, and will reduce healthcare costs in
Keyword: synthetic methodology, fluorination,  hypervalent iodine, pharmaceuticals, antibacterials, radiotracer synthesis, medical imaging, green chemistry, solid supported reagents, flow chemistry

Project_Title: Maximum Average Degree, Chromatic Number and the 4-Flow Conjecture
Project_Description: This research will investigate several fundamental but long-standing conjectures about colourings and flows in the field of graph theory. This work will continue the tradition of Bill Tutte, Ontario's founding father of discrete mathematics, by seeking structural characterizations to make significant breakthroughs on these notoriously difficult problems. The research will benefit Ontario by raising the province's academic profile in discrete mathematics, by yielding new algorithms and heuristics for real-world problems in the information and communications sector, and by furthering Ontario's tradition of excellence in this area of mathematics.
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development
Keyword: Graph Colouring, Critical Graphs, 4-Flow Conjecture, Cyclically 5-Connected Graphs, Maximum Average Degree

Project_Title: Integrating Drones and Simulation to Estimate the Impacts of Climate, Technology, and Policy on Ontario Farming
Project_Description: The proposed research estimates the impacts of changes in climate, technology, and policy on farm livelihood, crop production, and ecosystem function across southern Ontario. Using the innovative combination of unmanned aerial vehicle equipment, survey, and ecological fieldwork, new kinds of data are collected and analyzed to improve our understanding of how agricultural decisions are made and can change over time and across space. By synthesizing these data in a model, the proposed research leverages simulated scenarios to evaluate potential farm responses and, in collaboration with farmers, identify land management strategies that can close the gap between potential and actual yields.
Keyword: nmanned Aerial Vehicle, Agent-Based Modelling, Ecosystem Function, Land Management, Land use, Social Survey, Ecological Fieldwork, Human Decision-Making

Project_Title: Flexible and Adaptive Motion Planning for Multi-Robot Teams
Project_Description: Multi-robot teams are making big impacts in industries ranging from warehouse automation to flexible manufacturing. However, current robots are far from being "plug-and-play" -- each new deployment requires a large effort in research and development to design robot control algorithms, to ensure safety, and to optimize robot performance.  This research seeks to reduce the barrier to adoption of automation by developing easy-to-use, flexible, and general-purpose multi-robot systems.  The research will enable Ontario's robotics companies to build complete autonomous robot solutions, increasing the adoption of automation and advancing Ontario's capacity in manufacturing, agriculture, and a variety of other application domains.
OIA_AREA: Development and creation of investigation spots
Keyword: Robotics, Motion Planning, Sensor Networks, Optimization, Combinatorics, Algorithms, Distributed Computation

Project_Title: Regulation of macrophage cholesterol metabolism in atherosclerosis
Project_Description: cardiovascular disease is a metabolic and inflammatory disorder that affects more than one in three individuals in Ontario. My research group at the University of Ottawa strives to understand how a key metabolic enzyme called AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) regulates cholesterol balance in immune cells called macrophages. These cells take up cholesterol and are retained in the artery wall to form plaque, which initiates atherosclerosis and heart disease. Understanding how AMPK may control pathways that protect against the progression of this process will provide new therapeutic targets for the treatment of diseases such as atherosclerosis, diabetes and heart disease.
Keyword: Atherosclerosis, AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK), macrophages, cholesterol, heart disease, inflammation, obesity, type 2 diabetes, insulin resistance

Project_Title: Access to Justice in Canada's Refugee System: Use of Evidence in the Refugee Status Determination Process
Project_Description: This research investigates the acquisition, presentation, and use of evidence in Canadaâ€™s recently reformed refugee system from an access to justice perspective. Researchers will apply a custom-designed access to justice framework to refugee case files (released through an information-sharing agreement with the Immigration and Refugee Board ) and conduct focused investigations into four particular procedures my research indicates create access to justice deficits. The ultimate goal is to identify and mitigate challenges facing some of the worldâ€™s most vulnerable persons, thousands of whom arrive in Ontario each year. Results will inform academic contributions and training for both decision-makers and support work
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development
Keyword: access to justice, refugees, evidence, refugee system reform, principles of fundamental justice, procedural fairness

Project_Title: The Economics of Fidelity in Social and Economic Networks
Project_Description: Fidelity, defined as an exclusive commitment to a partner or an organization, is desired in many types of relationships including marriage, business, and political relationships. However, the norm of fidelity is often violated, leading to the formation of secret and invisible networks, which in turn determine a wide range of social, epidemiological, and economic outcomes. My research goal is to analyze the formation of these networks, and study their implications for the functioning of real-world economies such as: (1) sexual markets; (2) business and political organizations; and (3) terrorist organizations. Findings will be tested using Canadian and other countries datasets.
Keyword: Fidelity networks, exclusivity relationships, two-sided economies, market segmentation, secret partnerships, invisible networks, anonymity, ethnicity, contagion, price

Project_Title: Nanomembranes and Nanopores for Biomedical Applications
Project_Description: The overall goal of this program is to advance the field of nanopore sensing and our understanding of the transport properties of polymers in nanoconfined environments, to develop reliable nanopore-based technologies for genomics and biomedical applications. More specifically, the proposed research will address how to control biomolecular passage speed for improved signal accuracy; how to develop robust devices that can remain functional in complex samples; and the need for analysis tools for extracting detailed biomolecular information from nanopore data. Strategies emerging from this research will find many technological applications to secure a global competitive edge for the Ontario healthcare industry.
Keyword: Nanopores, biosensors, nanofluidics, membrane, separation, sequencing, single-molecule, diagnostics, nano-biotechnologies, Biophysics.

Project_Title: Uncloneability in Quantum Information
Project_Description: The objective of this research proposal is to improve our understanding of the "uncloneability'' property of quantum information, and how it can be used in protocols for quantum cryptography. More specifically, Dr. Broadbent's research program will study the foundations of quantum uncloneability from the perspective of modern cryptography: can we formalize this property such that it can be incorporated as a cryptographic primitive, into known constructions? It is anticipated that this work will answer a number of open question related to uncloneability, e.g. by establishing public-key quantum money and uncloneable quantum programs, all based on standard cryptographic assumptions.
Keyword: Quantum Information, Cryptography, Quantum Complexity, Quantum Money, Quantum Copy-Protection, Quantum Proofs

Project_Title: Causes and consequences of sociality: the interplay between social information use, collective problem-solving, and life-history.
Project_Description: Group-living is a key component of the success of several species, including humans. Group members can benefit from collaborative interactions, but can also suffer costs from exploitation. Little is known on the effect of social interactions and group composition on collective problem-solving and social networks in wild animal populations, or on the impact of differences in sociability on survival and reproduction. This ornithology-based research will train highly qualified personnel in a multidisciplinary environment and will provide an evolutionary perspective on societal issues such as the role of diversity in group innovation and the impact of exploitative interactions on social networks.
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development
Keyword: behavioral ecology; animal cognition; animal personality; collective decision-making; social foraging games; social networks; survival; mate choice; field ornithology; passive integrated transponders

Project_Title: Novel Immune Mechanisms of Obesity Related Insulin Resistance and Non-alcoholic Fatty Liver Disease
Project_Description: Obesity, insulin resistance (IR) and fatty liver disease precede diabetes and are major global health concerns. Inflammation contributes to these diseases, but the mechanisms are unknown. Here we show that immune cells called CD8 T cells drive liver disease in obesity, and these cells are fueled by a â€œtype-1 Interferonâ€ immune axis elicited by metabolic disease. We will study: 1) how liver CD8 T cells worsen blood sugar, 2) what fuels their pathogenic function and 3) whether they can be stopped with innovative new approaches. These results could lead to new ways to diagnose and treat liver disease and diabe
Keyword: Obesity, high fat diet, insulin resistance, type 2 diabetes, inflammation, fatty liver disease, T cells, visceral fat, gut- liver axis, Type I interferons

Project_Title: Automatic remote assessment of dementia from speech
Project_Description: Assessing Alzheimerâ€™s disease (AD) and dementia is a very expensive and laborious process, an increasing burden on healthcare and on families, and is completely unsustainable given our aging population. Repeatable and remote assessment is essential. Many individuals with AD have measurable language deficits. By analyzing hundreds of linguistic features and using advanced artificial intelligence, I have developed software that is over 92% accurate in identifying Alzheimerâ€™s disease from short speech samples. I propose to make this software available over the phone with a â€˜1-800â€™ number. This assessment software will be developed and validated with healthcare and industrial p
Keyword: Natural language, speech, pattern recognition, health science, dementia, remote assessment

Project_Title: Functional Characterization of long noncoding RNAs in Prostate Cancer
Project_Description: To understand the causal mechanisms underlying genetic risk associated with prostate cancer, we have identified 60 long noncoding RNAs regulated by genetic risk-variants through computational prediction. The goal of this proposal is to validate the predictions and determine how the risk-associated long noncoding RNAs (lncRNAs) promote prostate cancer development and progression. By revealing the functional nature of specific genetic variants our proposed research may identify specific genetic and  lncRNA biomarkers and therapeutic targets. This will favor personalized/precision medicine where therapies are tailored to the unique genetic identity of each patient.
Keyword: rostate Cancer, risk SNP, Epigenetics, noncoding RNA, cancer development and progression, therapy

Project_Title: The expanded epigenetic alphabet: transcription factor binding in methylated DNA and beyond
Project_Description: Transcription factors drive mammalian gene expression programs, initiating transcription by binding DNA in specific sequence and epigenomic contexts. Some transcription factors preferentially bind specific sequences containing 5-methylcytosine rather than unmodified cytosine, or vice versa. No tools exist to predict transcription factor affinity for binding sites that consider 5-methylcytosine or other modified nucleobases. This prevents full understanding of the impact of cytosine modifications on gene regulation. We will develop and validate computational models and methods to determine transcription factor binding affinities in the context of epigenetic nucleobase modifications. This will lead to better understanding of how nucleobase modifications influence gene regulation.
Keyword:
computational genomics
sequence motifs
gene regulation
epigenetics
DNA methylation
transcription factors

Project_Title: The interplay between work and mental health in people living with HIV
Project_Description: Since the advent of combination antiretroviral therapy, living with HIV is as much about social integration and maintenance of independence as it is about optimizing access to medications and health care. My program of research seeks to: (1) deepen our understanding of the effects of labour force participation and psychosocial work conditions on health outcomes, access to care, and mortality; (2) evaluate the determinants of return to work and job retention to inform employment and health programs, services and policies in Ontario; and (3) work with stakeholders to improve workforce participation and health outcomes for people with HIV in Ontario.
Lead_Research_Institution: Centre for Addiction and Mental Health
Keyword: employment, psychosocial work environment, mental health outcomes, HIV prevention

Project_Title: Improving care and outcomes for surgical patients through knowledge translation
Project_Description: Between 30â€“50% of hospital patients do not receive recommended care, which endangers lives and wastes healthcare resources. In Ontario, approximately one patient dies every 50 major surgeries and about one in 14 surgical patients are readmitted to the hospital. Readmission alone costs Ontario $100M per year. While not all surgical complications can be avoided, the rate can be substantially reduced through better adherence to best practices. This research will collect information to improve the way that evidence is used in clinical practice. It has the potential to improve care for Ontarians and reinforce Ontarioâ€™s world leadership in practice changing resea
Keyword: Knowledge Translation; Patient Safety; Perioperative Period; Surgical Outcomes

Project_Title: Smart Electric Vehicle Energy Management System Technology
Project_Description: Ontario is building sustainable transportation systems to lower its carbon footprint through the new electric vehicle (EV) incentive program and EV deployment projects. However, Ontarioâ€™s power grid is not well prepared for the upcoming high penetration of EVs due to the infrastructure upgrade requirement for large- scale EV charging. In line with Ontarioâ€™s innovation strategy in energy, engineering and emerging technologies, this research will address the above EV charging challenge and train related HQP by developing analytical tools and exploring systems-engineering approaches for optimal energy management of grid-connected EVs. The research will be supported by the electric utility Hydro Ott
Keyword: Demand response, electric vehicle charging, smart grid, distributed energy sources, energy management optimization, multi-agent systems

Project_Title: Developing novel technologies for improved diagnosis and treatment of sleep apnea
Project_Description: Sleep apnea is a chronic respiratory disorder during sleep which is common in 10% of adults. It increases cardiovascular risks by three-fold and the risk of car and work accidents up to10 times.  Current diagnosis of sleep apnea has poor association with sleep apnea risks including sleepiness, cardiovascular or cognitive risks. Also, there is no reliable method to predict the optimum treatment for sleep apnea patients. I propose to improve sleep apnea diagnosis by developing robust algorithms which incorporate cardiovascular and cognitive risks of sleep apnea. The results will be used to predict the optimum individualized treatment for sleep apnea.
Keyword: Sleep apnea; Diagnosis; Treatment; Cardiovascular risk; Cognitive risk; Medical devices; Signal processing

Project_Title: Smarter Cities with Data-driven Decision-making and Deep Learned Representations
Project_Description: Despite recent significant advances in deep neural network learning in Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML), deep learning methods do not readily support efficient control methods that could be used to create Smarter Cities.  This research project will develop novel compilations of learned deep networks to alternate representations that enable efficient data-driven decision-making in applications ranging from improved HVAC controls for buildings to improved improved traffic light coordination for our cities.  This technology development will advance research in AI, ML, and Smart Cities and train highly-qualified students in an area of immense technology impact for both industry and society.
Keyword: artificial intelligence, machine learning, sequenctial decision-making, Bayesian networks, graphical models, probabilistic interference, planning, decision diagrams, data structures, algorithms

Project_Title: Cellular changes in the spinal cord underlying the development and resolution of chronic pain
Project_Description: Painful and non-painful sensations are transmitted from the skin to the spinal cord, where these sensory inputs are integrated and processed before being perceived by the brain. Abnormal sensory processing at the level of the spinal cord can lead to pathological pain perception in which non-painful sensation activates pain processing pathways. This project will explore how changes in cellular connections in the spinal cord contribute to pathological pain conditions, and how these changes can be modified to even erased to reverse pathological sensory processing. Overall, this work will indicate new therapeutic approaches for the treatment of pathological pain.
Keyword: pain, spinal cord, neuroscience, sensory processing, plasticity, analgesia

Project_Title: Development of new computational methods for modeling chemical reactions on metallic surfaces
Project_Description: I intend to develop computer-modeling techniques to determine how chemicals, at the molecular level, react on the surfaces of metals and metallic nanoparticles. Such theoretical modeling is crucial because chemical reactions on metallic surfaces are complex and their investigation by a trial-and-error approach would take decades. My computational techniques will unravel microscopic details of reaction mechanisms unattainable for experimental techniques and will enable development of control and optimization schemes. Better understanding of chemical reactions on metallic surfaces can lead to globally significant advances in clean and renewable energy, as well as the removal of excessive carbon dioxide from the atmosphere.
Keyword: Nonadiabatic dynamics, scanning tunneling microscopy, electronic structure theory, plasmonic photo-catalysis

Project_Title: Learning from Canada's first wave of pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) users: A mixed methods study of Ontario gay men's experiences using new HIV prevention technology
Project_Description: Despite decades of traditional prevention efforts, Canada continues to see unacceptable rates of HIV, at roughly 3000 infections annually since 2002. A disproportionate burden of new infections occurs among gay, bisexual, and other men who have sex with men (gbMSM). HIV pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP; daily oral use of the antiretroviral medications by uninfected persons at ongoing risk) is beginning to be used as part of a combination prevention approach. This mixed methods research (in-depth interviews, survey) is being conducted with Ontario's 'first wave' of PrEP users in Ontario and other gbMSM to understand barriers and experiences of PrEP use overtime.
Keyword: HIV/AIDS; health care access; HIV prevention; sexually transmitted infections (ST!s); gay, bisexual, and other men who have sex with men (gbMSM); pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP)

Project_Title: Learning to leverage flexible electric loads
Project_Description: Electric loads like air conditioners and electric vehicles can enhance the efficiency and reliability of power systems by allowing system operators to occasionally moderate their power consumption. This is called demand response, and is regarded as a key enabler of renewable energy. A major challenge to demand response is uncertainty â€“ precise information about loads like buildings and appliances is often unavailable. Hence, power system operators often can only precisely measure electric loads by utilizing them for demand response. This research aims to design machine learning algorithms that deploy loads for demand response while learning their uncertain characteristics for future u
Keyword: emand response, machine learning, renewable energy, povver systems, optimization

Project_Title: Employment Discrimination in Hiring People with Disabilities: An Audit Study
Project_Description: Disabled Ontarians are three times less likely to work than the non-disabled and earn considerably less when they do. Despite policy interventions, disabled Ontarians continue to experience job discrimination, a major obstacle in gaining entry into the labor market.  Yet, little direct evidence of disability employment discrimination exists. My team will conduct a field experiment by emailing rÃ©sumÃ©s to active job ads in the greater Toronto area, and analyze the responses for evidence of discrimination.  This evidence will shed light on labour market exclusion, an especially salient issue given Ontarioâ€™s continuing efforts to promote competitiveness in the global knowledge-based econ
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development
Keyword: Employment discrimination, disability, audit study, field experiment, labour market, occupational segregation, status characteristics, inequality, hiring practices, job skills

Project_Title: Magnetic Actuation for Miniature Wireless Medical Devices
Project_Description: This research proposes to design a new class of magnetically-driven surgical tools for complex tasks such as tumour resection and epilepsy surgery. Since traditional cable/pin tools are not sufficient to achieve required minimization of tools below 2 mm in size, a novel technique is required for tool design and actuation. The tools will be smaller and more dextrous than the currently available tools, enabling less invasive procedures and better outcomes. The long-term objective of this research is to realize a wirelessly-driven surgical tool system, consisting of magnetic field generation and high dexterity tools tips, for improved minimally-invasive surgery.
Keyword: robotics, magnetic actuation, medical robotics, microfabrication, controls

Project_Title: LIFFE for Cardiac Kids through Physical Activity (Learning, Independence, Friendships, Fitness, Emotional health)
Project_Description: Children with heart disease (cardiac kids) lead sedentary lives and have 3-10 times higher risk for health problems like obesity, diabetes, and depression. We know that physical activity can decrease these risks. Our study will evaluate whether a unique, home-based parent-led activity program can build more physically active lifestyles. We target cardiac kids because of their high risk, but our intervention could be used by any doctor or parent. Increasing daily activity would improve the physical & mental health of the 90% of Ontario children who  are not active enough for optimal  health; decreasing disease burden, healthcare utilization and treatment cost.
Lead_Research_Institution: Children's Hospital of Eastern Ontario Research Institute Inc.
Keyword: Physical activity; Paediatric cardiology; Physical. health; Mental health; Heallhy active lifestyles; Prevention; Rehabilitation; Motor skill; Physical fitness

Project_Title: Dark Matter in the inner Milky Way
Project_Description: Dark matter makes up 80% of the mass in the Universe, but little is known about its nature. The distribution of dark matter in the inner Milky Way is of fundamental importance to investigations into its nature, but it is largely unconstrained. My group will model data from the Gaia satellite on the velocities of stars in the disk of the Milky Way and in narrow streams of stars found outside of the disk to make unprecedented measurements of the dark-matter distribution. We will use this to place new astrophysical constraints on the properties of dark matter.
Keyword: Milky Way, dark matter, Galactic structure, Galactic dynamics, stellar dynamics, statistical inference, gravity

Project_Title: Digital Culture, Youth, and Policing: Risk-taking and police response in the information age
Project_Description: The proposed research program explores how young people understand and mitigate risks associated with the use of digital communication technologies. In line with the Ontario Innovation Agenda in the area of Digital media and information technology, this research will investigate youth's experiences of cyber crime and their interactions with police. This research will examine the experiences of Ontario police officers when â€˜policingâ€™ youth and responding to youth-related crimes associated with digital communication technologies. Project outcomes translate into benefits for Ontario by involving and training students, devising best practice in police response to youth cyber-risk, and educating youth about cyber ri
Keyword:
Youth, Risk, Police, Digital Cultures, Digital Communication Technologies. mixed methods research; grounded 
theory

Project_Title: Migration Management in a Comparative Perspective: Clusters in the Global Competition for STEM Labour
Project_Description: Innovation in Canada strongly depends on migrant workers with degrees and skills in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM). Ontarioâ€™s Innovation Agenda stresses the importance of attracting foreign talent in order to remain globally competitive. This project investigates how technology clusters utilize provincial and federal programs when recruiting STEM migrants. Analyzing and comparing clusters in Ontario, British Columbia and Quebec, the U.S., Europe, Asia and Australia, this project generates better academic and public understanding. It informs discussions regarding migration, and supports policy reforms towards an enhanced, more effective management of STEM migration for innovation and growth in Ontari
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development
Keyword:
Migration Policy, Labor Migration, Clusters, Government Innovation, Human Resources, Technology, Science, 
Mathematics, Engineering

Project_Title: Role of Wnt signaling in pathogenesis of heart rhythm disorders
Project_Description: Heart rhythm disorders (cardiac arrhythmias) affect over one million Canadians, and are a major health issue in Ontario and Canada. Current anti-arrhythmic drugs are not effective in most patients and have significant toxicities. Novel, more effective therapies are needed for better management of patients. Ion channels in the heart determine the rhythm of heart beats, and reduced ion channel levels cause cardiac arrhythmias. Dr. Liang recently discovered (2015) that activation of Wnt signalling reduces cardiac ion channel levels, and his group will investigate the roles of Wnt in cardiac arrhythmias, and explore new avenues for therapy.
Keyword: Heart rhythm disorders (cardiac arrhythmias); Heart failure; Ion channels; Wnt signalling; Cardiac electrophysiology;CRISPR/Cas9

Project_Title: Extracting value from environmental liabilities: using microbes to recover metals and reduce impacts from mine waste
Project_Description: Finding effective long-term strategies for mine waste treatment is a challenge for Ontarioâ€™s mining industry and government regulatory agencies. Standard approaches have focused on containment of the millions of tons of solid and liquid mine wastes stored at active or abandoned mines, but without eliminating the impacts permanently. In contrast, the research proposed by the new Industrial Research Chair at Laurentian University, will develop novel cost-effective ways of preventing the release of contaminants to aquatic systems, while using energy-efficient microbial methods to extract value from solid wastes (i.e. residual metals), and to reduce long-term liabilities by decreasing treatment cost
Keyword: bioremediation, bioleaching, bacteria, mining, waste treatment, environmental solutions, sustainable mining

Project_Title: Creating dance technologies for people with Parkinson's disease
Project_Description: Building upon cutting-edge research into the treatment of Parkinsonâ€™s disease (PD) using music and dance, this project is the first of its kind to blend technology, health, and the arts. My four goals are: (1) develop technological dance systems for people with PD; (2) assess how these systems mediate patientsâ€™ experiences; (3) investigate the integration of digital technologies with arts-based activities for therapeutic purposes; (4) study effects of music/dance on PD. The project has ethics clearance, enabling my team to work with PD patients. Benefits closely aligning with Ontario's Innovation Agenda, include training HQP in healthcare systems using digital me
Keyword:
Parkinson's Disease; Dance; Music; Palliative Care; Motion Capture; Avatar Technology; Motion-Sensing Cameras;
3D Rendering

Project_Title: Family-Friendly Community Resources for Better Balance
Project_Description: The proposed research will extract and analyze public data on family-friendly community resources (FFCR) across Canada with a particular focus on Ontario. These community-level data will be matched to existing individual-level longitudinal data from the Canadian Work Stress and Health Study (2010-2019), which includes measures of "work-family conflict"-a pernicious modern day health risk for parents and children. It will train HQP to extract unstandardized community data; create a unique repository for the combined data; and, write academic /technical papers. This project adds to Ontario's Open Data Vision and Innovation Agenda by making inaccessible data publicly available and meaningful.
Keyword: communities; families; work-family conflict; childcare; neighbourhood effects

Project_Title: Characterization of intestinal stem cells in colorectal cancer
Project_Description: Colorectal cancer (CRC) is the second leading cause of cancer death in Canada. A major risk factor for CRC is chronic inflammation; however, the precise mechanism by which inflammation predisposes to cancer is not known. In the rapidly dividing intestine, long-lived stem cells that are responsible for normal regeneration are also presumed to be the cell of origin for cancer. We recently developed a novel colitis-associated cancer model in which we identified the cell of cancer origin. We now aim to determine how inflammation targets these cells in cancer initiation and further identify novel targets for CRC therapy in Ontarians.
Keyword: stem cells, inflammation, cancer

Project_Title: Helping youth with arthritis and their parents to make informed and personalized decisions about pain management options: Development of a new tool
Project_Description: The medical world recognizes the importance of youth engagement in decision making and self-management. However, it is challenging for health providers to offer evidence-based information about a wide variety of treatment options to youth with chronic conditions and their families, and help them make decisions that are consistent with their needs. This is especially true for adolescents with juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA), who have to make complex decisions to manage pain, in order to lead a normal life. The goal of this research is to develop and evaluate a novel decision support intervention among adolescents with JIA and their caregivers.
Lead_Research_Institution: Children's Hospital of Eastern Ontario Research Institute Inc.
Keyword: juvenile idiopathic arthritis, pain management, decision support intervention, shared decision making

Project_Title: Building atomic gases, stars, and nuclei from scratch
Project_Description: This project will address many distinct areas of physics: the unifying thread is the presence of many strongly interacting particles. Theoretical questions will be tackled "from scratch", using high-performance computing. Thus, the problem of describing neutron stars (compact astrophysical objects), nuclei (especially those created in state-of-the-art experimental facilities), and cold atoms (the coldest systems on earth) will be attacked head-on. This will lead to the training of 10 persons on supercomputing and other technical skills (crucial to nuclear energy, the health & financial sectors, and communications technologies), directly contributing toward Ontario's profile as a global leader in nuclear physics.
OIA_AREA: Development and creation of investigation spots
Keyword: high-performance computing, nuclear physics, atomic physics, astrophysics, neutron stars, exotic nuclei, ultracold atomic gases, nuclear science

Project_Title: Extending access to neurorehabilitation care through wearable technology
Project_Description: Spinal cord injury (SCI) can severely reduce quality of life and be very costly for Ontario's health care system. Rehabilitation after SCI is a process that can extend over years, but patients are discharged from rehabilitation centers a few weeks after injury. Our research objective is to facilitate the delivery of neurorehabilitation care to individuals with SCI living in the community with limited in-person access to specialized services.
