Using wearable cameras, we will develop technology that automatically collects information about upper limb use, enables clinicians to remotely refine the plan of care, and helps patients to adhere to these plans.
Keyword: Neurorehabilitation, spinal cord injury, upper limb function, wearable sensors, egocentric video, computer vision, rehabilitation engineering, health services

Project_Title: Optimizing brain blood flow and function in cardiac arrest
Project_Description: Brain injury is the major cause of death and disability in two-thirds of Ontarians who collapse when their hearts suddenly stop beating (cardiac arrest). Despite CPR, brain cells quickly die from a lack of oxygen. We have developed and tested a novel light technology called hyperspectral near-infrared spectroscopy (hNIRS) that can monitor brain oxygen levels and brain cell metabolism to optimize CPR to decrease brain injury and brain death after cardiac arrest. We will develop, miniaturize and test a prototype hNIRS monitor in patients undergoing aortic repairs (mimics cardiac arrest physiology), and in both in-hospital and out-of-hospital cardiac arrest patients.
Keyword: caridac arrest, cardiopulmonary resuscitation, hyperspectral near-infared spectroscopy, hemoglobin oxygenation, cytochrome c oxidase

Project_Title: The Upstream Lab: Evaluating actions that address social determinants of health at the individual, practice and community level
Project_Description: The social determinants of health (SDOH) are the conditions in which people are born, grow, live, work and age. There has been a renewed interest globally in tackling SDOH to reduce health inequities. A number of organizations, including the Canadian Medical Association, funders and provincial and national government agencies, have called for research on interventions to address SDOH. My research team is called the Upstream Lab because we rigorously evaluate interventions that target social factors that are â€œupstreamâ€ of the illness and disease seen in clinics and hospitals. Studies include interventions at the individual-level, the practice-level and at the community-le
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development
Keyword: social determinants of health, family medicine, primary care, population health, public health, health promotion, evaluation, randomized control trials, community engagement, pragmatic trials

Project_Title: Preventing Injecting by Modifying Existing Responses (PRIMER)
Project_Description: This multi-country, mixed methods study will investigate structural approaches to reducing HIV risk by preventing injecting initiation. The study will seek to: 1) determine how people who inject drugs (PWID) initiate others into injecting; 2) assess factors potentially influencing the risk that PWID initiate others into injecting; 3) investigate drug scene roles (i.e., drug dealer) that increase the risk that PWID might initiate others into injecting; and 4) test the impact of an existing structural or biomedical intervention on the risk that PWID will initiate others into injecting.
Keyword: addication, gender, HIV prevention, incarceration, injection drug use, injection drug use initiation, mixed methods research, opiod substitution therapy, medically-supervised injection facilities

Project_Title: Building healthcare capacity to deliver evidence-based new HIV prevention technologies
Project_Description: Canada continues to see high, sustained rates of HIV transmission, resulting in considerable social and economic cost.  An estimated $229800-$338400 USD could be saved per infection averted.  Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) is a new HIV prevention technology involving a daily pill that can reduce HIV risk by nearly 100%, but the health system lacks capacity to appropriately deliver PrEP at scale.  My research will evaluate innovative strategies for decentralizing PrEP delivery through family physicians and sexual health clinic nurses, incorporate the preferences of at-risk communities and their healthcare providers, and project the population-level impact and cost-effectiveness of this new prevention technology.
Keyword: HIV prevention, pre-exposure prophylaxis, new prevention technologies, implementation science, health systems research, mathematical modeling

Project_Title: Investigating gene expression for RNA therapeutics
Project_Description: Healthy development requires each gene to be expressed in the right amount at the right place at the right time. Many different pathways work together to ensure each of the thousands of genes is expressed properly, but much of how gene expression is controlled remains unknown. This is a critical gap in knowledge that impacts nearly every aspect of modern-day medicineâ€”from how we interpret disease-associated mutations to designing new RNA-based drugs. Our goal is to understand gene expression, thus setting the stage for development of new therapeutics for a variety of diseases that afflict patients in Ontari
Keyword: Gene expression, mRNA, mRNA decay, translation, post-transcriptional gene regulation, mRNA stability, mRNA protein complexes, high throughput sequencing, bioinformatics, codon usage

Project_Title: Psychological and hormonal mechanisms of human aggression
Project_Description: Why do some people resort to aggression with the slightest amount of provocation? What are the factors that underlie one's prepensity to engage in sexual aggression? Dr. Carre's research examines the psychological, situational, and hermonal processes that give rise to indvidual differences in intra-and inter-sexual forms of human aggression. The proposed research combines theory and methodology from social, experimental, and personality psychology, endocrinology, neuroscience, and behavioural pharmacology, with the ultimate goal of detailing the complex mechanisms giving rise to indiviudal differences in human intra and inter sexual aggression.
Keyword: intra-secual aggression, sexual aggression, testosterone, dehumanization, dominance, risk-taking

Project_Title: Strains of pathological proteins in neurodegenerative diseases
Project_Description: Alzheimerâ€™s disease and Parkinsonâ€™s disease are devastating, incurable diseases of the brain whose incidence in Ontario is expected to skyrocket due to an ageing population. Considerable heterogeneity exists amongst patients; the biological basis for this variability remains unknown. In these disorders, proteins clump together in the brain to form aggregates. I hypothesize that distinct shapes, or â€œstrainsâ€ of aggregates underlie the clinical and pathological differences observed between patients. I propose to study the relationship between aggregate shape and the speed of disease progression using purified proteins, brain tissue, and transgenic mice. This work will uncover new therapeutic and diagnostic str
Keyword: neurodegeneration, alzheimer's disease, parkinson's disease, multiple system atrophy, prions, trangenic mice, protein aggregation, seeding, strains

Project_Title: The Wellbeing and Political Engagement of Northern Women and Young Women
Project_Description: Using a mixed methods approach (e.g., arts-based methods, case studies, surveys), this innovative community-engaged research answers: (1) How do young women in the north understand, and engage politically to create, wellbeing? (2) How is wellbeing changing for diverse northern women and girls? And (3) What are shared and unique features of wellbeing among diverse northern women? The research team, including community members and students, will fill knowledge gaps on impacts of resource development on diverse women; and about northern young womenâ€™s political engagement. The process and results will build community capacity and guide inclusive citizen engagemen
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development
Keyword: ommunity engaged research; women & Indigenous women; young women & political engagement; northern urbanization and resource extraction; intersectionality; social & cultural wellbeing

Project_Title: The Eyes Open/Ears On initiative for parents with children wearing hearing aids and/or cochlear implants
Project_Description: Many young children wear their hearing aids less than half their waking hours because parents lack awareness of the benefits of consistent use. Hearing aids enable auditory stimulation crucial for brain development especially in infancy. Children require consistent hearing aid use all waking hours to have access to the 20,000 hours of listening and hearing of 46 million words research says they need to be ready for school. We propose to develop/evaluate a video intervention (Eyes Open/Ears On) to promote consistent hearing aid use through parent and professional education and examine if positive parenting behaviour impacts hours of use.
Keyword: audiology, children, hearing loss, parent support, parent training, multimedia intervention, knowledge translation

Project_Title: The Ontario Sleep and Brain Health Study - An Extension of the Ontario Sleep Health Study to Examine the Links Between Sleep and Brain Health in Working-Age Ontarians
Project_Description: With sleep and circadian rhythm disruption affecting millions of Ontarians, the mounting evidence linking their contribution to impaired cognition and dementia cannot be disregarded in a province with an increasingly aging population. By leveraging an established â€œwearable-technologiesâ€ study assessing sleep/circadian rhythms in thousands of community-dwelling Ontarians in combination with brain imaging and cognitive evaluation, we aim to comprehensively reveal the impact of sleep/circadian disruption on cognition, dementia-related brain changes, and dementia risk.  This will provide the foundation to use minimally-invasive sleep/circadian screening to identify adults at risk for dementia, and ultimately support sleep/circadian-targeted interventions to prevent
Keyword: sleep, circadian rythms, dementia, alzheimer's disease, stroke, cerebrovascular disease, wearable technologies, magnetic resonance imaging, cognition, epidemiology

Project_Title: Efficient and Safe Learning Algorithms for Enhanced Robot Capabilities in Human-Centered Environments
Project_Description: Robotics is the fastest growing industry in the world. In contrast to their early industrial counterparts, the next generation of robots (such as autonomous cars, drones, and assistive robots) is expected to operate alongside humans in unpredictable and changing environments. This requires new robot algorithms that enable robots to adapt to the environment during operation.  The proposed research will combine key technologies from control theory, machine learning and optimization to enable safe, high-performance robot control for next-generation robotics applications. The resultant algorithms will allow Ontario-based companies to build service/personal robots with enhanced capabilities in less time and at lower cost.
Keyword: Robotics, control theory, machine learning, robot learning, safe learning-based control, learning from data, data efficiant learning, autonomous driving, unmanned aerial vehical (UAV) applications, human-robot interaction

Project_Title: Role of particulate matter in inducing airway hypersensitivity
Project_Description: Air pollution, including fine particulate matter, is a significant risk factor for respiratory and cardiovascular diseases. The specific components within particulate matter that cause lung diseases and their sources remain poorly understood, limiting the ability to design effective policies and intervention strategies. In this work, we investigate the role of different chemical composition in determining the ability to induce airway hypersensitivity. Specifically, we will: 1. determine which compounds in particulate matter cause oxidative stress and 2. identify chemical components responsible for airway hypersensitivity, a hallmark of asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.
Keyword: atmospheric chemistry, air quality, lung diseases, airway hypersensitivity, chemical composition

Project_Title: Accessibility and Participation: The Role of Transportation in Activity Making
Project_Description: While it is generally assumed that public transportation is vital to the social inclusion of low-income households in Ontario, the relationship between transit accessibility and activity participation is poorly understood, and many Ontarians suffer as a result. Using advanced geographic information systems, travel behaviour modelling, and qualitative data collection, I will investigate the participation and satisfaction outcomes associated with transportation provision, emphasizing outcomes for marginalized populations. The results will provide an improved understanding of the social benefits of public transportation investments and encourage a shift towards evidence-based decision making within the transportation sector.
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development
Keyword: accessibility, participation, public transportation, social inclusion, social equity, travel behaviour, geographic information systems

Project_Title: Creating conditions for social innovation: Organizational factors that support cross- and intra-sector partnerships
Project_Description: Socially innovative efforts undertaken through partnerships between the nonprofit, for-profit, and government sectors are necessary for improving social outcomes of vulnerable groups (such as new approaches to reduce incidences of housing loss or rates of poverty). This investigation will survey and conduct interviews with Executive Directors of direct social service nonprofits in Ontario to provide an analysis of the internal and external organizational factors that support the conditions of successful partnerships for undertaking socially innovative efforts. Understanding the conditions that support these partnerships can help support public policy development and strategies that maximize the social impact of  limited public resources.
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development
Keyword: N/A

Project_Title: Next Generation Probabilistic Programming for Data Science
Project_Description: There is tremendous demand for data analysis across science, industry, and the public sector, but the supply of experts cannot handle the big-data deluge. To keep pace, we must advance and revolutionize access to machine-learning and statistical technologies: My proposal aims to have significant impact in two ways: 1) by developing powerful new programming languages to describe data and serve experts as well as scientists, business people, and policy-makers; and 2) by developing efficient algorithms for these new languages, expanding access to data science and delivering rapid insight from modern big data.
Keyword: data science, machine learning, computational statistics, probabilistic programming, inference algorithms, big data

Project_Title: Understanding the social communication and comorbidities of pain
Project_Description: Pain is an extremely important health and economic problem. Patients with chronic pain conditions cost the Ontario economy billions of dollars each year. The current proposal aims to understand how pain is communicated between individuals and how chronic pain changes the brain to cause depression. Through the use of mouse models my research team and I will examine the cellular changes that modulate pain and mediate the co-occurrence of chronic pain and depression. Fundamentally understanding the modulation of  pain and the underlying etiology of chronic pain will lead us one step further towards harnessing the best treatments for patients.
Keyword: pain, empathy, communication, social, oxytocin, excitability, depression, endocrine, stress, brain

Project_Title: Nutraceuticals as anti-cancer therapeutics
Project_Description: The proposed research will look at how nutraceuticals effect cancer treatments. Nutraceuticals are food-derived bioactive compounds (i.e., dietary supplements) and are consumed by a large number of cancer patients (63-95%).  This research will define nutraceuticals as beneficial or detrimental to cancer therapy. This will improve the lives of Ontario's cancer patient population through improved recommendations (i.e., harmful nutraceuticals should be avoided) and enhanced therapies (i.e., beneficial nutraceuticals could be incorporated into treatment regimens). This will also benefit Ontario's health sector through improved health technologies (i.e., reduced health care spending by improved cancer treatments and job creation through start-up company creation).
Keyword: Apoptosis, Cell death, Nutraceuticals, Cancer, Leukemia, Drug discovery, Cell and molecular biology, Flow cytometry, High-throughput screening

Project_Title: Understanding pollinators to maintain resilience in Ontario agroecosystems
Project_Description: Insect pollinators, including many native bee species, play a major but unquantified role in the pollination of Ontario crops. Sustained production of pollinator-dependent crops-- in the face of climate change and honey bee declines -- will require the maintenance of diverse, resilient pollinator assemblages. The proposed research will investigate fundamental questions in the population and community ecology of wild bees, in an agricultural context. Using experiments and field observations, Dr. Forrest's research program will determine what factors limit bee populations in agroecosystems. This knowledge will permit forecasts of pollinator abundance, pollinator seasonality, and pollination services under climate change and different farm-management techniques.
Keyword: agriculture, biodiversity, climate change, limiting factors, native bees, parasites, phenology, pollination, population ecology, temperature-dependence

Project_Title: Rates and determinants of psychiatric readmission of youth
Project_Description: The enormous healthcare costs associated with youth mental health argue for careful study of psychiatric hospitalization to identify youth at-risk for readmission and inform hospitalization/discharge services to improve health and reduce psychiatric readmissions. We will estimate readmission rates after a first psychiatric hospitalization; identify multilevel determinants of readmission; and, model trajectories of health outcomes for readmitted and non-readmitted youth. Youth will be tracked for readmission by collecting data during their first psychiatric hospitalization and at 1, 3, 6, and 12 months post-discharge. Linkage with provincial databases will provide information on contextual determinants (e.g., low income neighbourhoods) and post-hospitalization service use.
Keyword: child & adolescent mental health, cohort study, data linkage, determinants of health, hospitalization, mental health services, psychiatric epidemiology, psychiatric readmission, trajectory modeling

Project_Title: Fiscal policy and population health: the case of tobacco control
Project_Description: In Canada, tobacco use is the leading preventable cause of death and responsible for nearly 40,000 deaths each year. Despite much progress in the past decades, youth smoking rates remain high and recent estimates suggest that rates may be on the increase once more. Of particular concern are the current popularity of both discount cigarette brands and contraband cigarettes. After linking several large datasets, econometric analysis will be used to examine the impact of fiscal policies on tobacco use and government tax revenue with a particular focus on onset, cessation, and on the influence of contraband and discount cigarettes.
Keyword: Population health; health policy; fiscal policy; tobacco; smoking; equity; contraband; tax avoidance; tax evasion.

Project_Title: Brain health in aging: Understanding how exercise promotes brain function to reduce the risk of dementia
Project_Description: Alzheimer's is a progressive neurodegenerative disease that causes severe cognitive impairment and compromises quality of life. By 2020, Alzheimerâ€™s disease will affect 255,000 Ontarians and cost Ontarioâ€™s healthcare in excess of $770 million. There is no cure for Alzheimerâ€™s disease and so there is urgent need for interventions that will reduce the risk. Physical exercise is the most promising and economical intervention, however, it is unclear how exercise is changing the brain to support cognition. My research will reveal regulatory mechanisms supporting exercise-cognition interactions to create an intervention model for brain health that is based in neuroscience res
Keyword: Aging, Dementia, Cognitive Neuroscience, Memory, Neuroimaging, Exercise, Cognitive Training

Project_Title: Heavy metal removal using microbial electrochemistry
Project_Description: Heavy metals in wastewater and wastewater biosolids are difficult to remove in conventional treatment processes. Wastewater reuse and land applications of wastewater biosolids can cause serious metal contamination. Bioelectrochemical systems are an emerging technology for sustainable wastewater treatment and heavy metals can be removed by electrode reactions. This research will investigate metal removal mechanisms in bioelectrochemical systems and develop pilot-scale reactors to demonstrate energy-efficient removal of toxic heavy metals from wastewater. Research outcomes will benefit various metal-processing industries with reduced costs for their wastewater treatment and encourage sustainable utilization of treated wastewater and wastewater biosolids in Ontario.
Keyword: Wastewater treatment; contaminated sediment remediation; heavy metal separation; metal recovery; cathodic reduction; electrodeposition; chemical precipitation; bioelectrochemical system; microbial electrolysis cell; water reclamation and reuse

Project_Title: Early exercise strategies in critically ill patients to accelerate recovery
Project_Description: The intensive care unit (ICU) provides the most costly service in the hospital, but physiotherapy can reduce ICU and hospital length of stay by 30% and 18%, respectively.  Patients in the ICU require life-support such as breathing machines to stay alive.  One in 2 survivors of critical illness have severe weakness impairing their function for up to 5 years.  My research will study early in-bed cycling for ICU patients while they are on breathing machines to accelerate their recovery. This research has the potential to reduce health care costs and improve patient quality of life in Ontario and beyond.
Keyword: Rehabilitation; critical care; quality of life; physiotherapy; mechanical ventilation; in-bed cycle ergometry; exercise

Project_Title: Advanced building systems integrating phase change materials and aerogels
Project_Description: This research project aims to develop and test some prototypes of building systems that integrate innovative materials with high thermal performance in order to achieve significant energy savings in Canadian buildings. In particular, the project will support research about the integration of several nanotechnologies, mainly phase change materials (PCMs) but also aerogels, in building elements such as concrete panels, glazing systems, and wallboards.
Keyword:
Energy saving in buildings; Nanotechnologies; Latent heat; Thermal energy storage; Phase change material; Aerogel; 
High Qerformance buildings

Project_Title: Techo-Regulation for Improving the Quality of Health News Articles
Project_Description: New media is one of the most prominent sources of health information, yet health news coverage is far from optimal. This means that individuals who rely on the media as a primary source of health information are often making decisions based on sub-optional information. We aim to identify and evaluate strategies for improving the quality of health news reporting in Canada. Specifically, we will conduct recognized controlled trials evaluating the impact of several high-quality health journalism practice, and we will develop a novel machine-learning algorithm to automatically rate the quality of health news in real-time.
Keyword: Public Health; Health News; Health Policy; Knowledge Translation; Mass Media

Project_Title: Evaluating the impact of social media technology on mental health awareness and health system use in youth
Project_Description: The rates of mental health system use in youth are currently increasing. The proposed research aims to evaluate the effectiveness of social media technology used for mental health promotion and its impact on health system utilization. Little is known regarding the efficacy of online mental health interventions, despite its increasing use. To address these issues, a multi-staged, pragmatic mixed-methods study will be conducted in order to develop: (1) a social media evaluation framework sensitive to outcome and system indicators; (2) evaluation of a social media-enabled, mental health literacy/first-aid intervention for youth, complemented with the Institute for Clinical Evaluative Sciences data.
Keyword: healthcare; social media; public health; mental health; evaluation; health system outcomes; clinical outcome; ICES; mental health first-aid; mental health literacy

Project_Title: Spatial and epidemiological approaches for maternal and child health research in Ethiopia
Project_Description: Ethiopia has one of the highest rates of maternal mortality worldwide. Access to the health services, a major maternal, newborn and child health (MNCH) determinant, varies signifigantly across the country particularily in rural areas. Building on a 5-year-project, we will apply epidemiological and spatial analyses to identify patterns in MNCH outcomes and health services access among rural households. Health services access will be associated with geographic factors and wealth to identify entry points for intervention. This work will enhance Ontario's global academic profile and build capacity in spatial epidemiology and global health.
Keyword: Geographic Information Systems (GIS), maternal health, global health, epidemiology, Africa

Project_Title: Human-Computer Interaction in Fully Interactive Physio-digital Spaces
Project_Description: We are at the dawn of the next computing paradigm where every surface and object can sense human input and display digital information. This research will train HQP in a purpose-built facility to explore human-computer interaction in these environments with three objectives: develop smart display methods to render digital content; invent interaction techniques using formative evaluations of touch input on irregular surfaces and tangible input when manipulating objects; and package these results into a development toolkit and realistic demonstration applications. This represents a radical departure in digital media and information & communications technology, and is poised to transform Ontario industry.
Keyword: human-computer interaction, digital media, ubiquitous computing, augmented reality, visualization, interaction techniques, interaction design, touch input, tangible input, development toolkits

Project_Title: Early detection of Postural Impairments and Gait Disturnaces phenotype in individuals with Parkinson's disease: new strategies to detect and slow the progression of PIGD
Project_Description: Postural instability and gair disturbances (PIGD) are among the most disabling symptoms in Parkinson's disease (PD). PIGD worsen as the disease progresses and are associated with high risk of falls. Current therapies have beneficial affects for some motor symptoms, however their effects on PIGD are inconsistent. Furthermore, there are currently no indicators predicting the risks of developing these symptoms. Therefore, our main objective is to develop and identify new metrics to detect PIGD in the early stage of the disease. This could lead to new strategies to slow the progression of PIGD and their adverse affect on quality of life.
Keyword: Parkinson's disease, movement disorders, postural instabiljty, gait disorders, motion analysis, mobility, quality of life . gait dynamics, gait variability, falls

Project_Title: Developing Indigenous Knowledge Translation to Improve Cancer Survivorship Transitions for First Nations Peoples in Ontario
Project_Description: First Nations (FN) people suffer disproportionate cancer burden and lower 5-year survival rates compared to the general Canadian population. Cancer survivorship strategies can increase survival rates and enhance quality of life. However, FN people underutilize survivorship supports and require approaches that are culturally safe and recognize their distinct survivorship needs. In partnership with FN communities and healthcare providers delivering Cancer Care Ontario's Aboriginal Cancer Strategy III, this research will integrate culturally responsive survivorship strategies into health systems. The approach (called Indigenous knowledge translation) will be documented and evaluated. Findings will improve quality of life and health outcomes for FN people.
Keyword:
Knowledge Translation; Indigenous Knowledge Translation; Cancer Survivorship; Implementation Science; 
Healthcare delivery

Project_Title: Improving Placental Function: Developing Individualized Screening Tools and Targeted Therapies for Preeclampsia
Project_Description: Preeclampsia is a hyperintensive disorder of pregnancy which impacts 5% of Ontario pregnancies, and has no cure.Our group has determined that there are different types of preeclampsia which result from different forms of disease within the placenta - the organ responsible for keep a fetus alive. The three research aims of the current proposal are to 1) better understand the different types of placental disease in preeclampsia; 2) develop novel clinical tests capable of identifying women at highest risk for these different types of preeclampsia; and 3) develop personalized treatment options for each of these different types of preeclampsia.
Keyword: preeclampsia, placenta, clinical pathology, pregnancy, molecular biology, cardiovascular disease, screening tools, mouse models, therapeutic interventions, fetal growth restriction

Project_Title: Harnessing a cellular target for the recovery of motor function following spinal cord injury
Project_Description: There are currently no effective treatments of spinal cord injury to effectively restore lost motor function. My work has shown that spinal neurons, named d13 interneurons, are important for the recovery of locomotor function in spinalized mice, a species that can relearn to walk on a treadmill following spinal cord injury. My proposal aims to determine how d13 interneurons drive locomotor recovery through changes in the spinal cord. These insights can be used to design new therapeutic strategies d13 interneurons; with the ultimate goal of providing sustained recovery of locomotor function for those living with spinal cord injury.
Keyword: Spinal cord injury, neurons. motor recovery, motor function, spinal locomotor networks, dl3 interneurons, locomotion, neural circuitry, sensory feedback. locomotor training

Project_Title: Does lake warming lead to poorer water quality?
Project_Description: Lakes are sensitive indicators of climate change.  They are experiencing higher water temperatures and reduced periods of ice cover. However, the implications of reduced ice cover and higher water temperatures for water quality remain unclear.  This research aims to understand how: 1) climate change may influence the duration of ice cover on inland and Great Lakes; 2) whether reduced ice cover leads to warmer lakes; and 3) which lakes are at highest risk of poor water quality under climate change. We will analyze long-term ecological datasets from Ontario lakes and relate them to lakes across the Northern Hemisphere.
Keyword: climate change, lake ice, lake water temperatures, primary productivity, water quality, long-term time series, empirical models, quantitative ecology, Ontario lakes

Project_Title: Collaboratively Creating Virtual Reality From Within Virtual Reality
Project_Description: Virtual Reality (VR) is poised to revolutionize creative industries, yet lacks refined VR-native authoring tools. Our research will develop novel interaction concepts and software tools that exploit the mediumâ€™s unique affordances for artists of all kinds to create worlds while fully immersed within them. We will augment continuous hand gestures with simulated physics for intuitive freeform modeling with rich, fluid complexity, and develop new paradigms of programming VR live utilizing directly manipulable and spatially meaningful representations for collaborative multi-user productivity. This research is ideally timed to address VRâ€™s vital needs and underpin Ontarioâ€™s rapidly growing digital media economy and commun
Keyword:
Virtual Reality, Computational Creativity, Human-Computer Interaction, Gesture, Motion Capture, Live Coding, 
Visual Programming

Project_Title: Exploring How Food Ambiguity Can Lead to Over-Consumption
Project_Description: There is growing concern over what is popularly referred to as 'dressed-up junk food' (fortified snacks positioned as healthy alternatives). Using real-world field experiments, the proposed research will explore how dressed-up junk food can lead to overconsumption by confusing category membership and thus hindering peoplesâ€™ ability to self-regulate consumption. The results will inform researchers and public policy makers in Ontario, as well as raise public awareness. Primarily, the findings will extend the discussion around food consumption beyond sedentary lifestyles, caloric deficits, and the lack of nutritional options, to the psychological consequences of what we refer to as market-driven food ambiguit
Keyword: New Product, Product Categorization, Consumer Welfare & Protection, Overconsumption, Self-Regulation

Project_Title: Regulation of conserved cellular functions by lysine post-translational modifications
Project_Description: Our innovative work seeks to understand how post-translational modifications regulate the functions of conserved proteins impolicated in human disease. We focues on acetylation of non-histone proteins and a completely new modification called polyphosphorylation. We use preteomic and genetic analysis in yeast and human cell culture to address: 1) which proteins are modified, 2) how these are chosen and 3) whether substrate targeting systems impact pathways that usually prevent disease. Out work will benefit Ontarians by providing essential molecular details of these pathways that can exploited in the design of safer and more effective therapies for cancer and other diseases.
Keyword: model systems of disease, cell signaling, post-translational modifications, proteomics, acetylation, polyphosphorylation, cell growth, genetics, histone acetyltransferase, cancer

Project_Title: Harnessing insights from psychology, physiology, and mobile technologies to improve emotion-regulation and mental health of Ontarians
Project_Description: Identification of susceptibility to stress/anxiety is critical for Ontariansâ€™ health cost management. However, tools for identifying stress susceptibility are underdeveloped. The proposed research will fill this void by developing innovative methods for identifying stress susceptibility from physiological signals of stress-reactivity, obtained from wearable activity trackers. Additionally, a newly-developed mobile stress regulation platform will promote stress coping and wise thinking. HQP will be trained to differentiate between situations that promote vs. inhibit stress by mapping psychological data to physiological signals, strengthening Ontario's reputation as a global innovator in digital media/health technologies, and yielding direct mental health benefits for Ontarian
Keyword: emotion regulation, stress, self-regulation, social context, well-being, psychophysiology, psychometrics, heart rate, mobile health technologies, big data

Project_Title: Haunting Threatened Landscapes with Augmented Reality
Project_Description: This project researches the development of hybrid technologies that use GPS, orientation sensors, and cameras embedded in mobile devices to create site-specific event installation "ghosts" that impose recorded events over their original location, creating a time-shifted interactive historical marker. The project will study the creation of performance artworks that may be replayed and which are viewable as originally intended in the landsape utilizing augmented and mixed reality. This offers an immersive experience of environmental change caused by development or climate change, and intrinsically ties events to their place.
Keyword: Augment Reality, Virtual Reality, Spherical Video, Climate Change, Performance Studies, Anthropocene, Site-specific Performance, Dance, Theatre

Project_Title: Radar remote sensing of the Earth and Planets
Project_Description: Radar remote sensing is a powerful tool for monitoring planetary surfaces. Since it is capable of observing landscapes at night and through thick cloud cover, it provides round-the-clock access to even the most remote areas, including the surface of other worlds in the solar system. One of the handful of experts in the field of planetary radar, Dr. Neish and her team will use radar images to remotely characterize the geology of the Earth and other planets. This research will benefit Ontario by training HQP in the growing field of remote sensing, and bring international visibility to the province.
Keyword: Earth Sciences, Remote Sensing, Synthetic Aperture Radar, Geomorphology, Planetary Geology, Terrestrial Analogues

Project_Title: A General Patient-Flow Model for Strategic Hospital Capacity and Operational Planning
Project_Description: Bottlenecks in hospital patient flow are costly to patient health and the healthcare system, which already accounts for 42% of Ontarioâ€™s annual budget.  However, managing patient flow remains an open challenge, comprising complex interactions between planned/unplanned arrivals, movement between departments and widely varying length of stays. Dr. Abouee-Mehrizi's team will develop a patient flow model that accounts for these dynamic interactions and their effects on key performance indicators (e.g., wait-times and readmissions).  Armed with evidence-based scheduling guidelines, Ontarioâ€™s hospitals will be well-positioned to make strategic resourcing decisions that dramatically reduce healthcare costs and enhance the quality of life for Ontari
Keyword: Waiting time, patient flow, emergency department, inpatient wards, planned returns, staffing, capacity, congestion, queueing networks

Project_Title: Simulation-based Design and Optimization of Next-Generation Liquid Crystal Display Technology
Project_Description: Simulation-based advanced manufacturing methods have driven advances in liquid crystal display (LCD) technology over the past decade, including decreased response times, contrast ratios, and viewing angles. However, emerging LCD applications, including mobile touchscreens and digital light sources for 3D printers, pose different design requirements. The proposed research will develop next-generation LCDs for these emerging applications through the development and application of simulation-based advanced manufacturing methods, in collaboration with BlackBerry Ltd and Xerox Corp. These simulation-based design and optimization methods will provide Ontario-based industrial partners with advantages, such as reduced development costs and time-to-market, in a >$20B global market.
Keyword: process optimization, simulation, liquid crystal displays, mobile devices, three-dimensional printing

Project_Title: Nano-photonic structures for generation, detection, manipulation, and storage of single photons on a chip
Project_Description: Information processing based on single photons offers advantages in speed and security but requires critical development of novel on-chip devices. Dr. Bajcsy's team will design and fabricate nano-photonic structures for controlling photons on platforms that are compact and compatible with semiconductor manufacturing. These structures will include dielectric metasurfaces and Bragg gratings in hollow-core fibres forming high-finesse optical resonators for implementing photon memories, novel types of lasers, and optical transistors switched with single photons; superconducting nanowires coupled to optical fibres and photonic-crystal and laser-written waveguides for implementing on-chip arrays of single-photon detectors; and planar photonic-crystal cavity arrays for  scalable quantum simulators.
Keyword: nano-photonics; dielectric metasurfaces; planar photonic crystals; superconducting nanowire single-photon detectors; hollow-core photonic-crystal fibres; fibre Bragg gratings; photon storage; single-photon transistors; single-photon sources

Project_Description: Urban spaces around the globe are seeking strategies to become more environmentally, socially, and economically sustainable. This research will explore the role of small- and medium-sized enterprises in the governance of sustainability using community-based fieldwork and key informant interviews.  Dr. Burchâ€™s team will analyze the effectiveness of tools (e.g., policies for multi-sectoral partnerships, web-based engagement) that may be used to trigger a pervasive shift towards more sustainable development pathways. This research will enhance the capacity of Ontarioâ€™s government to be a catalyst of positive social and environmental change, while deepening the competitiveness of Canadian small businesses in a changing econ

Project_Description: The proteins that allow microbes to colonize and/or degrade host or biofilm tissues have immense scientific and industrial value as potential antimicrobial targets, anti-fouling agents and medical enzymes. Despite their value, there are thousands of uncharacterized microbial proteolytic enzymes with potential new activities and applications that can be mined from genomes. The proposed research will use cutting-edge computational, biochemical and metagenomic techniques to predict and characterize functionally novel proteases and degradation mechanisms of pathogenic and predatory microbes. Keyword: Bioinformatics, genomics, data-mining, proteases, biodegradation, tissue decomposition, pathogens, biofilms, bacteria, microbiology

More importantly, four Influenza pandemics have occurred over the past 100 years alone. The 1918 â€œSpanish Fluâ€ killed more people in one year than AIDS has killed in 20 years. Keyword: influenza, vaccines, immunology, antibodies

Project_Title: Screening for movement capacity and competency: Tools for preventing musculoskeletal disorders in the workplace
Project_Description: Every two minutes someone in Canada suffers a work-related injury, emphasizing the need for injury prevention strategies. Functional capacity evaluation (FCE) offers a viable strategy by permitting assessment of workersâ€™ abilities such that they can be matched to a jobâ€™s demands. However, FCE only quantifies what a worker can do (e.g., can they lift a 20 kg box), not how they do it (i.e., technique), where â€œpoorâ€ technique is often blamed for many work-related injuries. Dr. Fischerâ€™s research will demonstrate how FCEs can be developed to include technique assessment, vastly enhancing the usefulness of FCE as an injury prevention
Keyword: Movement, Occupational Biomechanics, Injury Prevention, Work Capacity, Work-related Musculoskeletal Disorders, Ergonomics, Work Ability, Functional Capacity Evaluation

Project_Title: US-WASRI: Ultrasound Wall Shear Rate Imaging for High-Frame-Rate Vascular Diagnostics
Project_Description: Stroke is the third leading cause of death in Ontario. It is important to identify patients with high stroke risk to prescribe treatment in a timely manner. This research will address such clinical need by engineering new solutions to detect anomalies in the vascular wall shear rate - a hemodynamic risk factor for stroke. Dr. Yu will invent a novel ultrasound wall shear rate imaging (US-WASRI) tool with >1,000 fps frame rate to temporally resolve and visualize vascular wall shear rate dynamics. Success of this research will establish Ontario as a leader in vascular ultrasound technology and enhance stroke prevention diagnostics.
Keyword:

Project_Title: A New Tool for Drug Discovery
Project_Description: The proposed research employs differential mobility spectrometry to assess the properties of molecules that exhibit model chemistries which are pertinent to drug discovery. By identifying correlations between drug candidate clustering propensities and their bulk phase properties, this research will provide the fundamental underpinnings of a new, precise, high-throughput and environmentally-friendly tool for discovering new medications. This research will support members of Ontario's high-tech instrumentation and pharmaceutical industries by increasing sales and creating jobs. Outcomes from this work will also result in the development of new therapeutics which will improve the health and well-being of Ontarians.

Project_Title: Networked Expertise as a Novel Approach to Complex Problem Solving
Project_Description: Ontario researchers address complex problems that demand networked, multidisciplinary teams. Bringing together experts from different disciplines challenges how researchers determine if someone is an expert and in what area they have expertise. Much of this work is done through persuasive acts, such as demonstrating credibility or disciplinary knowledge. This novel research program uses rhetorical theory to investigate how expertise is established and assessed in multidisciplinary teams. Rhetoric reveals strategies for crafting and criteria for assessing one's expertise. Investigating the question of expert assessment, this research will improve multidisciplinary teams, placing Ontario HQP at the forefront of innovative collaborators and problem-solvers.
OIA_AREA: Development and creation of investigation spots

Project_Title: Scalable solid-state quantum information processors
Project_Description: Quantum computers (QC), a disruptive technology in the information and communication sector, represent the next innovative smart machines. Capable of efficiently solving many-body problems, which classical computers cannot, major challenges exist preventing the construction of functional QCs. Specifically, vulnerability to sources of error such as local ambient fluctuations, require resource-intensive error correction protocols. Therefore, to create fault-tolerant QCs, synthesis of robust quantum materials is necessary. Dr. Kim will build a scalable, controllable solid-state quantum simulator to study the underlying principle of topological quantum materials for fault-tolerance, enabling the creation of robust QCs leading to social and economic gains for Ontario.
Keyword: quantum simulator, fault-tolerant quantum computer, quantum information processing, cavity quantum electrodynamics, quantum optics, topological quantum material, Bose-Einstein condensation,  condensed matter physics, semiconductor

Project_Title: Advancement of Quantum Information Science and Technology
Project_Description: This proposal studies the processing of quantum information in still unexplored regimes in quantum theory, ultra-fast quantum optics and superconducting circuits where both Einstein's relativity and quantum theory are necessary to understand the processing and flow of information. These studies will advance our fundamental knowledge of quantum theory and relativity and, at the same time, will have a significant long-term impact on Ontarioâ€™s economy and industry with the prototyping of concrete technological applications in quantum computing, quantum-secured communication and the development of measurement devices with sensitivities much beyond the limits of current technologie
Keyword: Quantum Information, Quantum Science, Quantum Technologies, Quantum Communication, Quantum Cryptography, Quantum Optics, Foundations of Quantum Mechanics, Relativistic Quantum Information

Project_Title: Topological Quantum Computing on Scalable Quantum Material Platforms
Project_Description: This research aims to engineer high-quality, wafer-sized topological materials to produce nanodevices capable of fault-tolerant quantum information processing. The proposed devices will generate a type of otherwise-non-existing composite particles - Majorana fermions. Similar to electrons/holes in semiconductors laying the foundation for transistors, every two pairs of Majorana fermions produce one qubit - the core processing unit of a quantum computer.  Quantum information processing on this platform is innately immune to quantum errors - the throttling key factor for the scale-up and commercialization of quantum technologies. As such, this project will strengthen existing provincial quantum initiatives and attract global industries to Ontario.
Keyword: Topological protection; quantum computing; proximity effect; materials science; spintronic materials; topological insulator; magnetic insulator; molecular beam epitaxy;

Project_Title: Nanoscale photonic devices for quantum communication networks
Project_Description: Quantum photonic technologies are being developed to keep Canadian's personal information secure and communicate between remote quantum processors in a network. This research program will develop super-efficient quantum light sources at the nanoscale for secure communication. The program will overcome the present challenge of tuning two sources to the same energy, which is essential for long-distance implementations. These devices will also process quantum information using on-chip photonic circuits, and link quantum processors in a network via single photons. This program will develop HQP and generate knowledge transfer of cutting-edge photonic technologies and quantum devices, enhancing Ontarioâ€™s quantum-based technology commercialization effort
Keyword: Nanophotonics, entangled photon sources, semiconductor nanowires, quantum dots, integrated quantum photonic circuits, quantum communication, quantum repeater, quantum information, quantum computing

Project_Title: Drug targets at atomic resolution
Project_Description: After a century of structural determinations, radiation damage remains the limiting factor for routinely attaining atomic resolution in the study of labile molecular systems such as proteins. A fast electron microscope will be developed to mitigate sample degradation effects and bring electron microscopy to a new level. The project is supported by Hitachi High Technologies Canada and holds great promise in generating a large pool of currently inexistent images of relevant drug targets. The proposed method will provide atomically resolved views of the key molecular shapes and interactions, which are required to advance computer-aided drug discovery strategies.
Keyword: Ultrafast electron imaging, ultrafast cryo-electron microscopy, low-dose electron microscopy, high-resolution protein structure, structural biology

Project_Title: Development of Mechatronic Systems for Joint Replacement Surgical Applications
Project_Description: Orthopaedic joint replacements are becoming more frequent in our aging population, and patient-specific implants are gaining momentum. These can be highly successful, yet remain technically challenging. Computer and image guided methods can assist even the most experienced surgeon to achieve more accurate implant placement, translating into better joint function and durability. Goals of this research include: 1) Development of robotic and mechatronic systems for joint replacement procedures to improve treatment outcomes, 2) Design of virtual training simulations to improve learning and competency-based assessments, and 3) Development of minimally-invasive tools and techniques in order to reduce or eliminate post-surgical hospital stays.
Keyword: Orthopaedic, Computer-Assisted, Robotics, Surgery, Mechatronics, Joint Implants

Project_Title: Balancing security and human rights: A comparative study of immigration detention and border controls
Project_Description: Over the past decade, Canada has tightened its asylum and migration policy. It has increased immigration detention, strengthened border controls and enhanced its international cooperation against irregular migration. Important questions remain concerning the effectiveness of these measures and their impact on the human rights of irregular migrants and asylum seekers. Canada has not generated until now a comprehensive evaluation of these questions. This project seeks to fill this gap by examining the practical and human rights implications associated with the securitization (i.e., a process that pushes an area of regular politics into an area of security) of irregular migration and asylum in Canada. Two complementary methods are adopted: documentary research; interviews and focus groups with stakeholders. The project provides a comparative analysis of the implementation of immigration detention and border control measures, train students, formulate policy recommendations to inform the action of governments, legal institutions, practitioners, and community organizations.
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development
Keyword: immigration; refugee protection; asylum; securitization; human rights; detention; border controls; Canada; European Union

Project_Title: Beyond the laboratory: Novel strategies for evaluating the utility of pediatric genomics
Project_Description: Genome-wide sequencing (GWS) is an emerging technology that is poised to make major breakthroughs in clinical care, by ushering individualized medicine into routine practice. The potential for GWS is extensive yet unrealized, in part because evidence related to its clinical utility and cost effectiveness is limited. Dr. Robin Hayeemsâ€™ proposed research program will: 1) develop innovative strategies for measuring the informational value of genomic medicine, 2) determine the value and impact of pediatric genomic medicine from patient, provider, and system perspectives using those strategies, and 3) explore potential circumstances that would enable or impede successful implementation of GWS into community based practice.  Working in partnership with Ontario Ministries of Health and Advisory committees tasked with setting policy in this area, research outputs will be well-positioned to guide provincial decisions related to the appropriate use, funding, and reimbursement of GWS technolog
Keyword: health services and policy research, outcomes evaluation, genomic medicine, mixed methods, genome wide sequencing, pediatrics

Project_Title: Structural immunology approaches towards the development of vaccines and antibody interventions
Project_Description: Our immune system is made up of a network of molecules, cells and organs that help defend us against the millions of microorganisms that bombard us in our daily lives. Dr. Jean-Philippe Julien's research program reveals how antibodies in our immune system effectively protect us against invading pathogens, and reduce the transmission of viruses, bacteria and parasites. The proposed research also develops molecular blueprints that can help design therapeutic antibodies to protect us against infectious diseases, autoimmune diseases and cancers - ailments that affect many Ontarians. The cutting-edge vaccine and antibody therapeutic development research explored in Dr. Julien's lab has gained significant momentum in the biopharmaceutical sector. Taken together, research results from the Julien lab will benefit the health of Ontarians and has economic impact in the biotherapeutic industry.
Keyword: Antibodies, immune receptors, pathogens, structural biology, protein engineering, vaccines, biologics

Project_Title: Developing the Pediatric Oncology Simulation Model
Project_Description: Exciting and promising novel strategies are being developed for the screening and management of pediatric cancers. Due to their novelty, clinical effectiveness is based on short term evidence while  their cost-effectiveness is largely unknown. Therefore, decision makers are challenged with making hugely impactful decisions on such strategies under enormous clinical and economic uncertainty. I propose to develop the Pediatric Oncology Simulation Model (POSIM), a comprehensive pediatric cancer simulation model that can assist with clinical and policy decision making in Ontario. This model will rely on our extensive expertise and will follow cohorts of pediatric patients over their lifetime and will estimate, for a variety of management strategies, the corresponding costs, life expectancy and  quality of life. POSIM will be modular, open-source, user-friendly and accessible, which will help policy makers decide on the value of current and future strategies for the screening and management of pediatric cancers.
Keyword: Cancer, pediatric, lifetime effect, cost-effectiveness, policy making

Project_Title: Understanding and Improving Long-Term Outcomes for Survivors of Sudden Cardiac Arrest and their Families
Project_Description: Surviving a cardiac arrest is an amazing medical feat in itself - however, once discharged from hospital, survivors begin the real work of getting used to their new â€˜normalâ€™ including significant health and social changes.  To date resuscitation science has largely focused on clinical treatments to improve a victimâ€™s chances of leaving the hospital; at the exclusion of developing a good understanding of what long-term â€œsurvivalâ€ entails.  I propose to leverage experience-based co-design research methods to inform the development of a mobile health solution to collect and monitor long-term survival data that will inform improvements to the care, support and outcomes of this unique population.  In addition to creating several job opportunities, the research and app development we propose will position Ontario to be a global leader in cardiac arrest survival outcomes, providing more patient-centred health services and helping survivors live long, productive lives in our co
Keyword: mobile health, survivorship, cardiac arrest, patient-centred outcomes, patient engagement, qualitative social science

Project_Title: Regional Foot Care and Amputation Prevention Pathways For All Ontarians
Project_Description: Leg amputation is a devastating complication of diabetes and poor blood circulation. Unfortunately, regular foot care and amputation prevention efforts remain shockingly disjointed across Ontario, if not outright neglected. In order to reduce amputations across the province, Dr de Mestral's research program will inform the development of regional foot care and amputation prevention pathways. The research team will evaluate the region-specific clinical and economic burden of amputation, as well as explore existing local facilitators and barriers to optimal foot care. These data will allow the team to predict, through statistical models, the real-world impact on quality of life, amputation rates, survival and health care costs associated with regional care pathways integrating sustained prevention efforts, multidisciplinary care of foot complications and rehabilitation.
Keyword: Preventative Health Services, Integrated Care Pathways, Economic Evaluation, Diabetes, Peripheral Arterial Disease, Amputation, Limb Preservation, Diabetic Foot Care.

Project_Title: Defining the Natural History and Predictors of Disease Progression in Mild Degenerative Cervical Myelopathy: Project Proposal for a Prospective Multi-Center Cohort Study
Project_Description: Degenerative Cervical Myelopathy (DCM) is the most common cause of spinal cord dysfunction internationally; while patients with moderate and severe DCM require surgery, there is debate surrounding the optimal management of mildly affected patients due to an unclear understanding of their natural history. We propose a multi-center prospective longitudinal observational study to define the natural history/clinical outcomes for patients with mild DCM treated without surgery.  Advanced imaging studies, clinical exam/gait analysis and genetic biomarker collection will be performed at enrollment to help identify variables predictive of disease progression. Study results will allow for a personalized treatment approach for DCM patients aimed at offering surgery to those who are likely to deteriorate, while allowing for continued non-operative care of those who are unlikely to deteriorate. Adoption of such a treatment approach would place Ontario at the forefront of innovation for management of spinal disorders and potentially lead to system-wide cost savings.
Keyword: Musculoskeletal Health; Spinal Cord Disease; Degenerative Cervical Myelopathy; Natural History; Treatment Decision Making; Magnetic Resonance Imaging/Diffusion Tensor Imaging; Serum Biomarkers; Clinical Epidemiology; Central Nervous System

Project_Title: Organ- and Organism-on-a-Chip Platform Technologies for Neurodegenerative Disease Studies and Drug Screening
Project_Description: Neurodegeneration is a rapidly-growing health and economy concern in aging population of Ontario. For example, in Parkinsonâ€™s disease (PD), aggregation of Î±-synuclein protein is associated with neuron degeneration and motor dysfunction. Studying PD in search of drugs requires models on which neuro-behavioral investigations and chemical screening can be performed from cellular to whole-organism level. The need for high-throughput assays restricts the use of conventional mammalian models. The proposed research will introduce novel and low-cost engineered solutions for pre-clinical PD investigations via integration of microfluidics with simple small-scale model organisms of PD. Lab-on-a-chip devices will be developed for screening of neurodegeneration and movement impairments in PD worm models. Protein aggregation mechanisms will be investigated in parallel on neuron-on-a-chip devices using extracted cells from worms and other organisms. This research can lead to introduction of efficient chemical screening tnologies, amenable to high-throughput-screening, to help understand PD pathology and search for effective drugs.
Keyword: Microfluidics, Lab-on-a-Chip, Organism-on-a-Chip, Organ-on-a-Chip, Alpha-synuclein, High Throughput Bioassay, Protein aggregation, Neuronal Imaging, Behavioral Screening, Chemical Screening

Project_Title: Improvising Machine Agents for Ensemble Musical Performance
Project_Description: The field of artificial intelligence has dramatically advanced in recent years, and is now poised to revolutionize the ways that humans interact with technology and with one another. This research project contributes to the sub-field of musical AI, by developing a system that can improvise new musical content in partnership with human performers. The system will be designed using principles from â€œbig dataâ€ analytics and deep learning, drawing on both real-time performer data as well as a performance database. The project will invite professional musicians to perform with the system in order to assess its musical quality, and it will be used in high-profile public events in order to assess whether it passes a musical â€œturing testâ€ relative to audience perception. This project contributes to Ontarioâ€™s groundbreaking work in AI research, and will provide timely new technologies that will enhance human creativity while providing insights into the creative proce
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Keyword: Digital Performance, Computational Creativity, Music, Metacreation, Artificial Intelligence, Computational Arts, Digital Media, Improvisation

Project_Title: Preventing falls in challenging environments through improved environmental design
Project_Description: For decades, falls in Canada have remained consistently high. Many strategies have been proposed to address falls. However, environmental changes have the potential to impact fall rates on a population level, because these risk factors are amenable to correction and do not require modifications in individual behavior or physical function. Although such environmental changes can occur through modifications to building codes and standards, guidance towards changes to building features is limited considering older adults with and without impairment. Thus, high fall risk remains. This proposed research uses biomechanical evaluation to understand how individuals interact with environmental features during normal activities and in response to slips or missteps. Knowledge generated will provide insight into the impact of environmental design on fall risk reduction. This research program will fill knowledge gaps needed to advocate for safer buildings in Ontario, support aging-in-place strategies, and ultimately reduce the risk of falls.
Keyword: Fall prevention, Ergonomics, Biomechanics, Population Health, Aging-in-Place, Accessibility, Movement Control, Public Health, Occupational Therapy, Mobility

Project_Title: Let's Get you Home: Understanding Patient Experience and Health Outcomes from Hospital to Home
Project_Description: For patients and families, the transition home from hospital can be a time of significant stress, due to poor communication, limited understanding and retention of discharge instructions.  One in five hospitalizations are complicated by an adverse event following discharge, and at least 10% of acute care patients have an avoidable readmission to hospital within 30 days of their initial hospitalization. We have developed a novel and unique tool, PODS, to support patient communication during this stressful period.  PODS has been adopted locally and spread across Ontario hospitals. Using a combination of data sources, our study will address the short-term and system impact of PODS on patient experience, adherence to instructions, emergency room visits, readmissions and costs. This research will benefit Ontario by providing evidence on which interventions have the greatest impact, resulting in reduced rates of readmission and health care utilization.
Keyword: Patient experience, Health-care utilization, Transitions in care, Health outcomes, Disparities

Project_Title: Improving the Assessment of Cognitive Function in Systemic Lupus Erythematosus: Screening and Measurement of Change in Cognitive Impairment over Time and Determination of its Implications on Patient Quality of Life and Productivity
Project_Description: Dr. Toumaâ€™s  systematic review showed a 40% prevalence of cognitive impairment (CI). The diagnosis of CI in lupus is delayed and its monitoring is poor. This proposal identifies a shortfall of the Ontario Health Insurance Plan by not covering the cost of the recommended battery of tests required to diagnose CI. Currently the battery of tests are time consuming, costly to patients (~$1500.00) and require specialists to administer. Therefore, it is important to identify tools that are cost and time efficient for Ontarioâ€™s lupus population. Dr. Touma will identify the most efficient screening, diagnostic and evaluative tool(s) to assess lupus CI and his results can be expanded to other rheumatic diseases. This proposal will provide innovative training to produce HQPs by exposing trainees to latest statistical approaches in machine learning, network and trajectory analyses. By providing this innovative training, Dr. Touma will enhance Ontarioâ€™s profile in the global academic comm
Keyword: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus, Cognitive Impairment, Measurement, Outcomes

Project_Title: Transgender Worldmaking through Film and Media
Project_Description: Media acts as a staging ground for the types of life that are permitted to become real and to shape reality in turn. When transgender people create audiovisual media, rather than simply being represented in it, their worldmaking helps change our collective world. This project investigates the films, web series, and film festivals created by Canadian and U.S. transgender artists from the 1990s through today, using interviews, archival research, and aesthetic analysis. This grant would support the emerging field of transgender film and media studies.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Keyword: transgender, transsexual, Two Spirit, queer, trans of color, film, media, web series, film festivals, cultural history

Project_Title: Conservation and novelty in the evolutionary development of the amphibian skull
Project_Description: This proposal strives to find new knowledge regarding fundamental aspects of the development and evolution of the skull. This knowledge has far-reaching significance particularly in the broad understanding of how skull morphology originated and diversified during evolution. Two projects within this proposal will use living and fossil amphibians as models to: 1) explore constrained versus novel patterns of skull bone developmental origin in species with variable developmental pathways, and investigate the mechanistic basis of anatomical variation from the perspective of bone origin and correspondences to the brain in deep- and real-time, and 2) gain insights into the source and evolutionary significance of changes in the posterior limit of the skull. The projects will train HQPs in cutting-edge skills and enhance their knowledge in areas transferable to research and development careers (e.g. biomedical disciplines), thereby improving the quality and success of Ontarioâ€™s workforce in numerous relevant sector
Keyword: Tetrapod, skull, development, evolution, neural crest, mesoderm, brain, conservation, novelty, evo-devo

Project_Title: The Cadaveric Response to Concussive Impact: Tracking brain tissue displacement and strain fields with high-speed X-ray imaging
Project_Description: Despite years of research and the development of superior helmets, the prevalence of concussion remains high. One concern among experts is the lack of adequate datasets relating the response of the human brain to impact events, particularly the response of injury-susceptible anatomical features, which are required for proper validation of injury models. The proposed research will use a high-speed X-ray imaging system, designed and built by the applicant, to investigate the response of the brain and skull of post-mortem human surrogates to linear impacts at extremely high capture rates (10,000 fps). The data will be used to design and calibrate advanced injury investigation tools, such as a tissue-simulating head surrogate for helmet evaluation, and a thorough validation of computational head injury models. This work will provide the underlying knowledge required to design superior helmets, reducing the prevalence of concussion, and improving the quality of life for Ontarians.
Keyword: Injury biomechanics, concussion, cadaveric studies, anthropomorphic headform, high-strain-rate deformation, high-speed x-ray imaging, impact dynamics.

Project_Title: Patient Experiences of High Health System Users in Rural Canada
Project_Description: A small proportion of health system users are associated with the majority of public health system costs. These individuals are often categorised as being older, with lower incomes, having poorer self-reported health, multiple diagnosed (or undiagnosed) chronic conditions, and reduced access to primary health care. There are also geographic differences, with some areas exhibiting higher concentrations of high system users than others, suggesting that there are unmet health needs that vary between communities as well as individuals. Despite the depth of research in urban Ontario, little research has examined this issue in rural communities. Drawing from prior patient consultation, we will combine analysis of linked and unlined health administrative data with a patient- and community-engaged process to â€˜mapâ€™ patient trajectories in the health system. The results of this research program will directly relate to health service planning and our understanding of health inequities in rural communities of Ont
Keyword: not available

Project_Title: Adaptive Algorithms for Autonomous Rendezvous and Docking with Uncooperative Targets
Project_Description: The space debris population has reached the point where collisions of large fragments will likely lead to cascade debris growth, and thereby hinder access to space. To stabilize the growth, spacecraft must autonomously approach, capture and de-orbit space debris. In line with Ontarioâ€™s Innovation Strategy in ICT, this research addresses this challenging problem by developing and experimentally validating innovative adaptation algorithms applied to path planning, computer vision and feedback control systems that enable a robotic spacecraft to autonomously and safely interact with space debris, thereby pushing the frontiers of autonomous robotics. This research will strengthen Ontario's aerospace sector, namely through the commercialization of the research result
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Keyword: adaptive path planning, Lyapunov vector fields, nonlinear stability, direct adaptive control, adaptive computer vision, morphing algorithms, spacecraft, rendezvous and docking, autonomous robotics

Project_Title: Of Comics and Comic Cons
Project_Description: Comic cons now exert a massive influence on pop culture and the entertainment industry, but the place that comic books, their creators and their audiences hold within these events, ostensibly organized by and/or for comic book fans, is unclear. Is the growing popularity of comic cons leading to a resurgence in comic book reading, or are comics being left behind in the rush to celebrate blockbuster movies? This project examines comic book reading as a cultural practice within the context of con events using a mixed-methods approach that combines in-depth interviews and participant observation with "netnographic" methods for analyzing communication on social media. Student collaborators will gain hands-on experience in media industries and audience research. The research will benefit Ontario's creative sector, including its numerous con events, and create a hub for comics research at an Ontario university.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Keyword: comic books; media industries; media audiences; comic cons; media ethnography; netnography; mixed methods

Project_Title: Bioenergy production from wastes
Project_Description: With increased interest in renewable energy, anaerobic digestion of waste can be a sustainable source for biogas production. This research aims to improve our understanding of the effect of changing the wasteâ€™s characteristics on the energy recovery from wastes. The proposed solution is to develop three techniques to improve the anaerobic digestibility of municipal solid wastes for renewable natural gas production. The feasibility of coupling anaerobic digestion with microbial electrochemical cells processes in one reactor will be investigated. A simple excel-based software model to estimate the biogas production from various wastes and their mixture will be developed, and a low-cost pretreatment technique to improve the biogas production will be tested. The proposed program will train 7HQP (1 PhD, 2 MAScs, and 4 undergraduates) and attract several young talents through its youth outreach program to the field of environmental engineering, empowering them with the skillsets highly attractive to Ontarioâ€™s eonmental sector.
Keyword: Anaerobic digestion, Biogas production, Sludge reduction, Pretreatment, Co-digestion, Microbial electrochemical  cells, Feedstock's characteristics

Project_Title: Intelligent predictive maintenance and production scheduling for Industry 4.0
Project_Description: Industry 4.0 driven by many emerging technologies, such as Internet of Things, robotics and artificial intelligence is underway, which takes manufacturing quality and productivity to new levels. Currently, there are no mature scientific and engineering solutions available to address the challenges of autonomous predictive and prescriptive maintenance as well as joint planning of maintenance and production in the context of Industry 4.0. The purpose of this ERA application is to address this gap using state-of-the-art methods of data science, artificial intelligence and operations research.              The proposed research will help Ontarioâ€™s manufacturers in transition towards Industry 4.0 by providing analytics tools for smart planning of maintenance and production scheduling. The tools will enhance manufacturing efficiency and performance, and will reduce manufacturing costs and downtime. These will result in enormous cost-saving for manufacturers, and thus, will have a significant positive impact on theconomy of Ontario, as Canadaâ€™s leading manufacturing provinc

Project_Title: Defining Home: First Nations strategies to address the housing and homelessness crisis
Project_Description: On-reserve housing crises have been declared by First Nations and governments alike. However, the definition of crises and proposed solutions vary widely, in part due to the lack of a distinct evaluation framework for First Nations housing. Defining Home documents community-created alternatives to the policies and programs currently dictating on-reserve housing by creating and testing local evaluation strategies within the Nishnawbe Aski Nation territory. Expanding on field-leading work in reimagining housing systems with First Nations partners across northern Ontario, an immersive process will document the lived experiences of First Nations peoples. Bridging gaps between north and south, First Nations voices are centered in sharing the distinct impacts of crowding, homelessness and inappropriate housing. Beyond measuring deficiency, Defining Home moves from locally-defined metrics to actions plans supporting and measuring immediate change. Student training focuses on the importance of cross-cultural and interdisciplinary practice, critical skills in the emerging field of Indigenous planning.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Keyword: housing, First Nations, community-based planning, Indigenous planning, decolonization, community wellness, architecture

Project_Title: Secure Information Transfer and Processing with Light
Project_Description: Modern communication systems rely on electronic signal processing.  However, this technology has been found to have fundamental limitations associated with the bandwidth which is responsible for the information transfer capacity as well as the switching speed, responsible for the speed of computations. Electronic information processing will only be able to respond to the growing demand on bandwidth consumption and switching speed for a few more years. Dr. Dolgalevaâ€™s primary research goal is to develop a fundamentally different approach that relies on all-optical signal processing. She will develop integrated photonic devices capable of demonstrating excellent performance through the design and careful selection of new semiconductor compounds. Successful outputs are expected to revolutionize telecommunications technology. The development of new material compounds and fabrication procedures will directly enhance manufacturing and processing techniques in telecommunications products. Compact integrated opticadevices and new functionalities would also have a significant impact in medicine with further development.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
