Keyword: all-optical signal processing, wavelength conversion, nonlinear photonics, integrated optics, semiconductor photonic devices, quantum communications, quantum circuits on-a-chip

Project_Title: Exercise Training for Managing Mobility Disability in People with Multiple Sclerosis
Project_Description: Mobility impairment is one of the most common, poorly managed, and life-altering consequences of multiple sclerosis (MS). Current therapies for managing MS do not prevent long-term accumulation of mobility disability, highlighting the need for alternative strategies that prevent or slow mobility loss. Rehabilitation has been recommended as the only practical means of preserving function in MS. The proposed research will examine the potential of adapted exercise rehabilitation for managing mobility impairment and associated consequences in MS. This research will enhance Ontarioâ€™s Innovation Agenda on advanced health technologies through the development of novel exercise rehabilitation solutions. These approaches can be extended to other populations who experience mobility loss, with the goal of improving health outcomes and reducing socioeconomic costs in Ontario. The proposed program will develop highly skilled personnel who are prepared to tackle complex health problems. This research will heighten Ontario profile as a global leader in advanced health technologies.
Keyword: exercise; rehabilitation; neuroscience; multiple sclerosis; disability

Project_Title: Anishinaabe nibi inaakonigewin onje biimaadiziwin - living Anishinaabe water law in context
Project_Description: In an era of water scarcity and resource disputes, obligations and responsibilities relating to lands and waters must be better understood.  With a changing legal landscape where Crown consultation and accommodation of Treaty and Aboriginal rights meets the recognition of rights of self-determination of Indigenous peoples internationally and domestically, the laws and governance systems of Indigenous Nations have a vital role to play - particularly Indigenous laws relating to lands and waters. Ontario is rich in fresh water and resources that are drawn from the land.  However, the relationship between the Crown and Indigenous Nations in Ontario regarding lands and waters continues to be tenuous.  This research will consider the normative values and treaty obligations that arise in relation to water and land, jurisdiction, processes and principles for decision-making.  This will assist Indigenous and non-Indigenous governments and decision-makers in navigating their relationships with lands and waters, and amongst each other.
Keyword: Indigenous; Law; Governance; Land; Water; Relationships

Project_Title: Deciphering the entry pathways of emerging viruses
Project_Description: Emerging diseases are those who have appeared in a population for the first time, or whose incidence has rapidly increased or spread in geographic range. An example of emerging viruses is the lassa fever virus (LFV) that causes an increasing number of high mortality rates outbreaks and has now sparked an unprecedented outbreak in Nigeria of staggering proportions. Other emerging viruses include the Ebola, Marburg, middle-east respiratory syndrome (MERS) coronavirus, and severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) coronavirus; these cause severe diseases in humans, with lethality rates as high as 90% (for Ebola). There are currently no vaccines or effective antiviral therapies against these viruses. The proposed research focuses on the discovery of cellular host factors essential for LFV viral infection and the use of these factors for the development of novel antiviral therapies against emerging viruses.
Keyword: Emerging viruses, Lassa fever virus, Ebola virus, viral entry, vesicular trafficking, small molecule inhibitors

Project_Title: Investigating the safety and therapeutic potential of cannabis and related plant products
Project_Description: The legalization and commercialization of cannabis for medicinal and recreational use in Canada is evolving rapidly with a lack of evidence to support the safety and effectiveness of different products and means of consumption (or exposure) increasingly available to the public. The proposed research will investigate the chemistry and related therapeutic and toxic potential of different varieties of cannabis, in order to assess the contributions of delta-9 tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) and cannabidiol (CBD), and other active compounds to cannabis pharmacology. Because cannabis is now sold in different forms and consumed in different ways, the research will also evaluate how chemistry and pharmacology change with product type (e.g., from flowers to oil) and method of use (e.g., smoking, vaporizing, eating). This program will help fill knowledge gaps, address training needs, and drive innovation essential to both public health and the emerging cannabis industry in Ontario.
Keyword: pharmacology, toxicology, endocannabinoid system, medicinal plants, cannabis, analytical chemistry, mode of delivery, herb-drug interactions, knowledge transfer and translation

Project_Title: Decoding animal locomotory performance using sensory feedback and mechanical dynamics
Project_Description: Constrained by tissue mechanical properties and guided by sensory signals, the brain and spinal cord control locomotion. Computer models and robots attempt to copy motor control systems using brain and spinal cord without body mechanics or sensory feedback - components that facilitate versatility in natural systems. This biomechanically-based research program will train highly qualified personnel in a multidisciplinary environment to understand how sensory feedback and temporal variation in tissue mechanics underscore functional plasticity and contribute to the control of biological locomotion. This research will give Ontario a global presence allowing Dr. Standen to continue developing international and cross-disciplinary collaborations with world renowned modelers and robotics engineers.
Keyword: motor control; biomechanics; sensory feedback; mechanical properties of tissues; muscle physiology; electromyography; work loops; central pattern generation; histology; plasticity

Project_Title: Translational Molecular Imaging Paired With Point-of-care Diagnostics
Project_Description: Imaging has changed medicine, contributing to the ability to diagnose and treat the specific disease of each individual. In our lab, we develop chemical tools to monitor fundamental biochemical processes driving disease and injury towards this goal of personalizing medicine. Specifically, we will continue to develop tools to image aldehydes, a key molecular signal of â€˜cell stressâ€™ with untapped diagnostic and prognostic potential for atherosclerosis, concussion, and Alzheimer's disease. In parallel, we are developing point-of-care tests for aldehydes that could inform on disease or injury prior to hospital visit, increasing the efficacy of time-sensitive diagnostic tools and therapeutic interventi
Keyword: Magnetic Resonance Imaging, Positron Emission Tomography, Radiotracers, Contrast Agents, Point-of-care Diagnostic Device, Reactive Aldehydes, Atherosclerosis, Concussion

Project_Title: Novel Organic Materials with Useful Electronic, Magnetic, and Optical Properties
Project_Description: Advances in materials science took humanity from the Stone Age into the Bronze Age, and more recently, from the â€˜Steel Ageâ€™ (1800-1900s) to the age of semiconductors that form the basis of todayâ€™s optoelectronic and computing technologies. Dr. Chanâ€™s proposed research seeks to discover next-generation materials that possess physical properties with the technological potential to improve quality of life for Canadians. Specifically, the Chan Lab uses synthetic chemistry to create new organic (i.e., carbon-based) materials with unique electronic, magnetic, and/or optical properties that are relevant to optoelectronic and biomedical applications. The success of the research program will pave the way towards low-cost, lightweight, and environmentally-friendly materials for information storage and consumer electronics (e.g., energy-efficient flexible displays, wearable devices), as well as designer materials for healthcare applications (e.g., bio-imaging, therapeutic
Keyword: Organic materials; Chemical synthesis; Organic electronics; Polymers; Conductive materials; Functional molecules; Functional materials; Organic semiconductors; Fluorescent materials

Project_Title: Innovating new chemistry to solve problems in biomedicine and materials science.
Project_Description: The Trant research group focuses on applying our synthetic chemistry discovery science to biomedicine. We combine innovations in total synthesis and organic methodology development with computer modeling, materials science and molecular biology to develop solutions to current medical challenges. These include developing innovative anti-cancer vaccines and developing new materials that will allow us to deliver chemotherapeutic drugs and our vaccines specifically only to cancer cells. This program will benefit Ontario, both economically and in improved health-outcomes for our residents. Our highly multidisciplinary program provides excellent training for the next generation of Ontario scientists, and has already attracted significant interest and some investment from both Ontario and non-Ontario businesses. It may also lead to new treatments for some of the diseases burdening the Ontario population including cancer and autoimmune diseases.
Keyword: Organic Chemistry; Computational Chemistry; Materials Science; Biomedical Engineering; Peptide Synthesis; Bioorganic Chemistry; Self-Immolative Materials; Supramolecular Chemsitry; Bio-Applied Chemistry.

Project_Title: Robust Geometry Processing for Digital Fabrication
Project_Description: Advanced manufacturing is enabling unprecedented complexity in the geometric objects we can fabricate, from cost-effective 3D printing to freeform architecture.  Unfortunately, these technological  advances have outpaced our mathematical understanding of fabricable geometries and our algorithmic ability to help people design such shapes.  The scope of designs and analyses are limited by our patience with difficult-to-use or poor-performance tools rather than our creativity or scientific expertise.  These problems are confounded by poor robustness of core routines for processing geometric data.  I will develop new algorithms and computer interfaces to help people create, study, and fabricate geometry.
Keyword: Geometry Processing, Computational Geometry, Advanced Manufacturing, 3D Printing, Geometric Modeling, Partial Differential Equations, Interactive Design

Project_Title: Teaching Machines with Humans in the Loop
Project_Description: Robots are and will become an essential part of our lives. As such, it is important to enable interaction between an AI agent and humans that is natural, expectable and conforms to social norms imposed by the environment. We propose machine learning models for understanding scenes and social situations from visual and verbal data, and common-sense knowledge about human behavior. We aim to build a virtual simulated environment where artificial agents can learn to act alongside other agents, and propose ways to transfer these learned policies to unseen environments that contain humans. We further aim to exploit language as a means for humans to guide machine learning algorithms to continuously learn, and correct/adapt their behavior if needed.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Keyword: Deep Learning, Computer Vision, Image and Video Understanding, Language

Project_Title: Chromatin dynamics in memory formation and Alzheimer's disease
Project_Description: Memory disorders, particularly Alzheimerâ€™s disease and dementia, are on the rise and represent a growing health and economic concern in Canada. Despite extensive research into this area, availability of effective therapies is lacking. We recently discovered that a novel epigenetic factor, the histone variant H2A.Z, is a memory suppressor whose levels increase with aging, suggesting that H2A.Z may precipitate memory decline. However, little is known about the mechanism by which H2A.Z removal promotes memory under normal conditions, such that the goal of the proposed research is to determine: 1) if H2A.Z accumulation precipitates memory loss and pathology in mouse models of AD; 2) if H2A.Z and the proteins that regulate its levels are effective therapeutic targets for AD; and 3) identify the mechanism by which H2A.Z depletion promotes memory. These studies provide vital steps toward developing histone variants as a novel category of potential therapies for A
Keyword: chromatin, histones,  epigenetics, learning, memory, fear conditioning, Alzheimer's disease, mouse models

Project_Title: Developing a precise clock using atoms trapped in a crystal
Project_Description: Optical atomic clocks are the most precise and accurate tools available to us today. However there is an urgent need to develop portable and robust versions of these clocks, in order to enable new physics discoveries and technological applications. We propose to investigate a novel system, rare-earth ions doped into a transparent crystal, in order to develop an extremely precise atomic clock. We request funding to build up a research group with expertise in precision solid-state laser spectroscopy. This will allow us to thoroughly study this promising system and develop it into a precise and portable optical atomic clock.                Such solid-state optical atomic clocks will be the first of their kind in the world. This project will place the province of Ontario in a unique position to exploit the intellectual and commercial potential of precision optical atomic clocks.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Keyword: atomic clock, laser spectroscopy, rare-earth ions

Project_Title: Habitability of Super-Earth Planets around M dwarfs
Project_Description: Finding planets beyond our solar system that are hospitable to life is a major quest, capturing scientistsâ€™ attention and the general publicâ€™s imagination. Finding these â€˜exoplanetsâ€™ within the â€˜habitable zonesâ€™ of M-dwarf stars around which they orbit has become a reality. Two space telescope missions are set to assess the atmospheres of these planets for markers of habitability, but an interpretive framework is lacking. Many factors could affect their habitability including extreme tidal effects unlike those found on Earth; and how these might alter the pathways to habitability is unknown.                 Extending from my influential research in this area, we will assess the effects of tidal dissipation on key variables related to a planetâ€™s ability to sustain life. The key is to properly model tidal effects in mantle processes accounting for rock melt generation. This foundational research on habitability under extreme tidal forces will solidify Ontario's leading role in planetary
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Keyword: super-Earths, tidal dissipation,  habitability, melt, magma ocean, plate tectonics, atmosphere-interior coupling

Project_Title: Entropy in dynamics, geometry and probability
Project_Description: My proposed project focuses on understanding complex dynamical systems using methods from probability.  Dynamical systems are models of complex physical phenomena. Surprisingly, even simple models are hard to predict, since a small difference in the initial condition can result in extremely different behaviour after a long time (think about the weather or the stock market). A key question is how dynamical properties of systems, such as entropy, change as parameters change. The aim of this project is to train students and postdocs in order to solve several open problems in complex dynamics, and in particular in the new subject of core entropy which I contributed developing.  This will raise the academic standing of Ontario in the world community and attract top talent in the field.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Keyword: dynamical systems, holomorphic dynamics, entropy, Mandelbrot set, Teichmuller space, fractal geometry

Project_Title: Mobile Innovations to Support Health Services
Project_Description: Mobile technologies for health (mHealth) can support self-care and clinical management through real-time information exchange and interventions. This can be particularly beneficial for remote and underserved populations with limited access to health services. While there are over 325,000 health apps available [3], only a few are of high quality, evidence-based [4,5], and linked to providers or trusted organizations. These are essential criteria for achieving uptake, adherence, and health benefits. This program will investigate: How can evidence-based health apps that are linked to providers or trusted organizations improve health and health care? The initial focus will be on developing, evaluating, and implementing mHealth innovations related to three womenâ€™s health issues: 1) perinatal depression, 2) women at high-risk for pre-eclampsia, and 3) health and safety of sex workers. The potential program value includes improved health outcomes, healthcare system savings, commercializable products, and training  multiple students in cutting-edge health technology innovation.
Keyword: mHealth; evidence-based health apps; provider-linked; user-centred design; implementation; pilot trial; perinatal depression; pre-eclampsia; telemonitoring; sex workers

Project_Title: Understanding how neurochemicals shape human memory
Project_Description: Ontarioâ€™s aging population is fueling an epidemic of memory disorders, leaving residents to stand by helplessly while memory loss erodes loved oneâ€™s identity, relationships, and independence. Fundamental research into the neurobiology of human memory could hold the key to treatment innovation, but this research focuses on permanent changes to brain structures, which are not currently treatable. Memory disorders, like Alzheimerâ€™s Disease, however, also involve immediately treatable neurochemical changes.          Addressing this gap, the proposed research characterizes how a key neurochemical, acetylcholine, shapes human memory. Each project targets specific aspects of memory which Prof. Duncanâ€™s prior empirical and theoretical work has identified as most likely to depend on acetylcholine. Across projects, these behaviours are directly linked to acetylcholine in healthy, at risk aging, and patient populations using deep-brain stimulation in conjunction with functional and structural MRI. This work willely identify cognitive and neurobiological fingerprints of early cholinergic imbalances, enabling patient-tailored interventions.
Keyword: Memory, Cognition, Cognitive Neuroscience, Hippocampus, Acetylcholine, Neuroimaging, Aging, Neuromodulation

Project_Title: Designing better knowledge translation interventions
Project_Description: Currently in our health care system, only 55 â€“ 67% of patients actually receive recommended care, and 20 â€“ 25% receive care that is unnecessary or potentially harmful. The field of knowledge translation (KT) has emerged in force to decrease the size of these gaps however, the process has proven painfully slow. Minimal improvements have been seen in these gap percentages in the last two decades and KT interventions remain inconsistent and variably effective. I will advance the science of building better KT interventions, resulting in improved gap percentages, better KT science for all quality improvement activities, and better care for Ontarians. I will focus on the biggest drivers of success for KT intervention design: theory-based, determinant-driven, and knowledge-user focused. Developing better KT interventions designed to improve the alignment between desired and actual health care practices will decrease research waste and improve health outco
Keyword: knowledge translation, implementation science, quality improvement, health services

Project_Title: Enhancing theory of resiliency to enable adults with cognitive disability to achieve success in life
Project_Description: Traumatic brain injury [TBI], damage to the brain acquired after birth from an external force, is an enormous public health problem with >60% of individuals unable to work, and almost 40% reporting mental health problems (compared to only 8.6% of the general population). Despite these challenges, evidence indicates that individuals also have positive experiences, like returning to work, remaining connected to friends, and re-constructing their self-identity and setting new life goals. While resilience has been posited to explain how individuals have and maintain these positive outcomes, it has been greatly understudied. Thus, I propose to develop a measure of resiliency to capture the range of processes used to adapt to TBI, and to explore how the culture and practices of healthcare and social services influence resiliency. The findings from my research will inform the design of interventions to foster resiliency, and ultimately enhance the wellbeing of individuals with TBI.
Keyword: resiliency, participation, adaptation, qualitative, cognition, integrated knowledge translation, mental health

Project_Title: Aging and associative memory: Neural mechanisms and implications for everyday life
Project_Description: A primary concern of many older adults is that their memory is slipping. While there is some evidence to support this concern, it seems that memory processes themselves may not be the primary culprit. My work has shown that age differences in attention, or the ability to focus on relevant information and block out distraction, can give the impression that memory declines with age. Older adults pick-up on more distracting information and this can interfere with memory. What remains unclear is (i) how this distracting information is encoded in the brain, and (ii) does it also affect memory for events in everyday life? The proposed research will use functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) and eye-tracking to address these questions. This work will not only contribute to the skill base of the Ontario workforce, but has the potential to create actionable advice for Ontario seniors hoping to maintain good cognitive health.
Keyword: aging, memory, attention, cognition, fMRI, eye-tracking, effective connectivity, dynamic causal modeling

Project_Title: The mechanical role of the human foot
Project_Description: The human foot facilitates bipedal locomotion by absorbing energy during impact and providing a stable base of support during forward propulsion. With twenty-seven bones forming thirty-three distinct joints and surrounded by a network of supporting muscles and ligaments, it has been difficult to understand how the foot manages trade-offs between mobility and stability. Recent advances in 3D x-ray imaging provide can now measure the foot's complex function during walking and running. The purpose of this research is to examine whether the current, largely untested, models of foot function are sufficient or if new models are required. In this proposal we will measure foot mechanics using high-speed x-ray and ultrasound imaging to examine foot function during barefoot and shod activities. This work will provide fundamental information necessary to design more effective footwear, prosthetics, and orthotics for Ontarians. It also provides a framework to formulate and test new evolutionary hypotheses.
Keyword: Biomechanics, 3D Imaging, Foot and Ankle, Propulsion, Locomotion, Functional Morphology, Musculoskeletal Modeling, X-Ray Reconstruction of Moving Morphology (XROMM), Elastography

Project_Title: Advanced biomaterials to improve the integration and function of ocular implants
Project_Description: Over 2 million Canadians have cataracts resulting in decreased vision from clouding in a patientâ€™s lens.  This prevalent cause of vision loss is treated by surgically inserting a prostheses known as an intraocular lens.  In Ontario alone, there are 175, 000 cataract surgeries performed per year (2014) which is expected to grow by 46% by 2026.  Unfortunately, about one third of surgically treated cases develop posterior segment opacification (secondary cataracts) which often requires secondary interventions.  Furthermore, many of the patients in the pediatric and secondary disease population are ineligible for intraocular lenses due to worse outcomes and would benefit from new technologies. The material of the intraocular lens and local cells are considered primary causes of secondary cataracts.  Dr. Wells aims to decipher how cells interact with intraocular lenses and then use this information to develop new advanced materials improve outcomes for simple and complex patient
Keyword: biomaterials, cell-material interactions, ophthalmic, eye, aptamers, surface chemistry, neutrophils, macrophages, stimuli-responsive polymers

Project_Title: Oncogenic kinases regulate miRNA stability
Project_Description: Oncogenic kinases are proteins known to be the driving force in many cancers and are key targets in chemotherapy. My research team recently discovered that Akt1, a kinase that is overactive in ~50% of all cancer types, is regulated by a small RNA, the microRNA let-7a. Let-7a is also known to play a role in cancer development. Until now, researchers explored inhibitors of the pathological state of both microRNA let-7a and Akt1 metabolism. We now realize Akt1 and let-7a metabolism are tightly connected. We found that elevated Akt1 activity controls let-7a activity and vice versa. Our research aims to identify the mechanistic basis of the feedback loop between microRNAs and Akt1 signaling. We already identified a new cellular effect of two FDA-approved drugs that regulate oncogenic kinase activity by altering microRNA metabolism. Our research will benefit Ontario by investigating opportunities for drug repurposing in Akt1 or let-7a deregulated cancers.
Keyword: Cancer treatment, chemotherapeutics, microRNA, RNA deregulation, cell proliferation,  RNA degradation, uridylation, cancer metastasis, enzymes

Project_Title: The Effects of Thrombotic Thrombocytopenic Purpura on the Brain Structure and Function
Project_Description: Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) is a rare and life-threatening disease where blood clots are formed in the small blood vessels. These clots can block the blood flow to the bodyâ€™s organs, including the brain. TTP occurs in young patients with a median age of 30 years. While the effective treatment for TTP, which involves exchanging the patientâ€™s blood plasma with donor plasma, has improved 30-days survival rates to 80-90%, TTP is still associated with significant complications and death resulting from brain injury after several years. Our proposed research will be the first study to apply advanced imaging and functional tests to better understand the effect TTP has on the brain in these vulnerable young patients. With a better understanding of the disease, our ultimate goal is to improve its therapeutic treatm
Keyword: Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura, magnetic resonance imaging, cognitive function, cerebrovascular injuries, CT perfusion of the brain

Project_Title: Intranasal versus intravenous ketamine for procedural sedation in children: a randomized, controlled, non-inferiority, multicenter trial
Project_Description: Extremity fractures in children often require anatomic realignment. This is usually facilitated by procedural sedation. Sedation requires placement of an intravenous (IV) line for sedative administration. The most common sedative is ketamine. The suboptimal management of children's pain in acute care settings has short and long-term consequences is well described. Children rate IV placement as one of the most painful in-hospital experiences. Owing to age-related technical difficulties, multiple IV attempts are often needed. This consumes time and resources and poses a challenge to nurses' self-perception as alleviators of pain. Moreover, families are often uprooted as children may be transported long distances to tertiary care centers to facilitate IV placement. We aim to demonstrate that intranasal (IN) ketamine is no less effective that IV ketamine. This will provide an approach that is less painful and less invasive. Children can be cared for closer to home with greater caregiver satisfaction.
Keyword: Intranasal versus intravenous ketamine for procedural sedation in children: a randomized, controlled, non-inferiority, multicenter trial

Project_Title: A Novel Experimental and Computational Technique for Characterizing Ligament Behaviors at the Knee
Project_Description: Despite decades of study, ligament reconstructions still fail to restore the natural biomechanics of the intact knee. In Ontario, patients with surgically-treated cruciate ligament injuries are still seven times more likely than the uninjured population to eventually develop arthritis and require total knee replacement. These poor long-term outcomes place a costly burden upon our public healthcare services and could be improved if we had a better understanding of the individual contributions of knee ligaments to joint biomechanics, the effects of varying surgical parameters, and means to optimize these parameters. My research aims to (a) better understand this biomechanical system and to (b) apply rigorous design principles to improve it. Leveraging an innovative hybrid experimental-computational technique which virtualizes and parameterizes ligaments offers a new means to study their respective roles in knee motion. Furthermore, this proposal utilizes systematic design optimization approaches for discovering new and improved knee ligament reconstruction techniques.
Keyword: joint biomechanics, ligament modelling, ligament reconstruction, in vitro testing, finite element modelling

Project_Title: Bio-inspired Functional Nanomaterials for Tissue Engineering
Project_Description: We are developing the next generation of translatable regenerative platforms - by using surface engineering with novel peptide sequences anchored to nanometric silver. Our ultimate goal is to overcome the limitations faced in the clinic, including making regenerative materials  conductive, resistant to microbes, & not inducing an anti-inflammatory response. Our new materials will give rise to a novel array of functional materials for treating injury following a  heart attack, non-healing wounds, & chronically infected corneas. These new, innovative materials will help improve the quality of life for hundreds of thousands of Ontarians and have the potential to save billions of dollars for our health care system.
Keyword: Tissue engineering, nanotechnology, biopolymers, inflammation, antimicrobial, conductive materials

Project_Title: Harnessing the power of genomic data to understand population responses to environmental change
Project_Description: The human genome project led to important discoveries like the genes underlying common diseases, and unraveled the complex migration history of our ancestors across the globe. These tools and technology have now been extended to wild species, which allows for identifying the genes controlling important traits and quantifying vital demographic parameters. Specifically, identifying and monitoring key genes coding for traits targeted by hunters (e.g. antlers and horns) and quantifying population parameters like migration rate is essential for informed wildlife management and the long-term conservation of biodiversity. Dr. Shafer's proposed research focuses on an ecologically and economically vital species in Ontario, the white-tailed deer, and applies an innovative bioinformatics framework that will address the fundamental questions in wildlife genomics: how is hunting influencing the genes controlling for desirable phenotypes and how will populations respond to environmental change.
OIA_AREA: Research and study of the functioning of the human body
Keyword: Population genetics, demography, coalescent, population modeling, environmental change, climate change, adaptation, conservation, management

Project_Title: Innovation and Personalization of Surgical Care for High-Risk Older People
Project_Description: People >65 years are the fastest growing group of people needing surgery. Although many older people benefit from surgery, advanced age is strongly linked to bad outcomes. Issues like frailty, disability and memory problems are common, and are the underlying reason for 25-40% of bad outcomes after surgery in older people. Therefore, my research program focuses on 1) identifying, developing and evaluating personalized innovations in care to improve surgical outcomes of older people at high risk; and 2) using data science and patient-oriented research to guide optimization of the healthcare system to meet the needs of older surgical patients.
Keyword: Surgery, Geriatrics, Anesthesiology, Epidemiology, Outcomes, Health Services Research, Quality Improvement, Population Health

Project_Title: Integrated Parkinson Care Network: addressing complex care in Parkinson disease in Ontario
Project_Description: Care needs for chronic conditions are complex. Traditional physician-centred care delivery has limitations. How can we improve care in a manner that is cost-effective and sustainable NOW? We have started to develop an innovative care model using Parkinson disease (PD) as the test condition. The Integrated Parkinsonâ€™s disease Care Network (IPCN) shifts care to the home and community founded on principles of Integrated Care, Self-management support and Health Technology using a patient-centred approach and a sustainable development plan. In this project, we will build upon research of the IPCN conducted in a restricted group of PD patients and in a single center, and will evaluate the barriers and design solutions for a sustainable dissemination of the IPCN in Ontario and Canada. The IPCN can play a critical role in addressing effectively complex care, promoting patient dignity and care equity across Ontario, and Canad
Keyword: Chronic Care, Integrated Care, Digital Health Technology, Health System, Parkinson Disease, Home care

Project_Title: Families Under Fire: Practices, Rights, and Well-Being in Contexts of War, Displacement, and Resettlement
Project_Description: Research with war-affected populations tends to focus on individual effects, with family experience rarely considered. The proposed research project will use innovative place-based and family-centered methodologies to generate knowledge about the war, displacement, and resettlement experiences of 40 Syrian families now living in Canada. The research will examine three key areas: (1) family practices, including parenting, (2) family rights, including childrenâ€™s rights and the right to home, and (3) family well-being, including psychosocial outcomes and the role of social supports. Six ERA-funded students will be heavily involved in the research process, from start to finish, including recruitment, data collection, and analysis. ERA-funded students will also be engaged in knowledge mobilization activities including five conference presentations, five academic publications, an interactive website, and a webinar series targeting practitioners and policymaker
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development
Keyword: family; child protection; child rights; human rights; well-being; refugees; forced displacement; home

Project_Title: Closing the knowledge transfer gap: Improving dietary behaviours and reducing cardiovascular risk through novel e-health interventions
Project_Description: Hypertension is a major cause of disability and premature death in Canada, leading to cardiovascular disease and stroke, conditions that are incredibly costly to treat. Reducing dietary sodium intake is an effective way to prevent and treat high blood pressure; however Canadians with and without hypertension consume far too much sodium. This research aims to improve clinical outcomes for patients with hypertension by investigating the implementation of dietary eHealth tools (i.e., the Sodium Calculator) in busy primary care practices and for patients in Ontario. Specifically, this project will test innovative eHealth strategies to help doctors more easily and effectively advise patients about reducing sodium, and to assist patients in adhering to a low sodium diet. This will ultimately result in  improved health outcomes for Ontarians and reduced health care utilization and costs for hypertension management.
Lead_Research_Institution: University of Ontario Institute of Technology
Keyword: diet, nutrition, sodium, eHealth, hypertension, high blood pressure, technology, primary care, population health

Project_Title: Developing smart biointerfaces for applications in diagnostics and therapeutics
Project_Description: The negative effects of non-specific interactions between biomolecules/cells and synthetic surfaces can result in severe health effects in a variety of applications, from implant-induced blood clots to food recalls; thus there is an  urgent need for increased control over these interactions. The approach adopted by most researchers has been to develop highly repellent surfaces that blindly thwart adhesion, unable to interact with their surroundings. The research proposed here aims at developing smart, interactive interfaces that specifically bind desired biomolecules or cells, and simultaneously thwart attachment of non-desired entities by integrating bio-functional domains into lubricant-infused coatings. These interfaces will be integrated into biomedical devices (e.g., implants) and food monitoring devices for therapeutics and diagnostics applications. The developed technologies will enable the creation of smart interactive biomedical devices and monitoring systems that will contribute to advanced health technologies, and therefore will contribute to Ontario's economy and the quality of life for Ontarians.
Keyword: Biointerfaces, Advanced Healthcare technologies, Nanotechnology, Biotechnology, Surface Engineering, Micro/nano fabrication, Biosensing, Poin of Care Diagnosis, Implants, Anti-fouling surfaces

Project_Title: Precision Medicine for Chronic Lung Diseases - Discovery, Innovation, and Commercialization
Project_Description: Chronic lung diseases, including asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and cystic fibrosis, impact over 15% of Ontarians or 2 million people costing over $4 billion each year. Individuals that do not respond to current therapies drive the majority of costs, due to increased frequency of emergency room visits and hospitalizations. Presently, it is difficult to determine which patients are more likely to have emergency room visits/hospitalizations. Precision medicine efforts may reveal individual level differences that can help save lives and resources in the health care system. Our group is pursuing precision medicine by using airway epithelial cells from patients with chronic lung diseases and combining with novel tissue engineering and stem cell technologies to create individualized diagnostic tools that closely resemble the human lung. We have partnered with pharmaceutical companies, to create novel diagnostics of commercial value and healthcare efficiency, while simultaneously training biomedical engineers and precision medicine researchers.
Keyword: asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, cystic fibrosis, epithelial cells, tissue engineering, precision medicine

Project_Title: ADAPT Study: Application of integrateD Approaches to understanding Physical activity during the Transition from late adolescence to emerging adulthood.
Project_Description: My research program focuses on the late adolescents and emerging adulthood population and aims to: (a) identify population-level changes in physical activity; (b) apply a processed-based model to better understand the changing psychological, and socio-environmental factors influencing behaviour change; (c) use a real-time data capture method to assess momentary changes in cognitions; and (d) examine the impact of behaviour change on psychosocial health and wellness. The transition from adolescence into emerging adulthood represents a critical period in the development of healthy active lifestyles, and findings from this work will help to inform the development of effective interventions targeting physical activity maintenance of Ontarians as they enter this complex and dynamic life stage. This research will have upstream social and economic benefits, representing an important investment to counteract the increasing costs and burden on the health care system and to improve the overall health and wellbeing of emerging adults in Ontario.
Keyword: Physical activity; Longitudinal Cohort Study; Life Transition; Late Adolescence; Emerging Adulthood; Ecological Momentary Assessment; Behaviour Change; Psychological Well-being; Multi-Process Action Control Model

Project_Title: The PURE Frailty Study
Project_Description: Frailty is a state of vulnerability to poor health outcomes or dying when exposed to a stressor. Frailty will become increasingly important as our population ages, and as diagnostic and treatment advances lead to longer survival of individuals with chronic diseases. We have already shown that being frail doubles the risk of death, and that frailty is common, affecting 1 in 20 middle-aged adults. To understand how we can prevent or reverse frailty, we need to know what causes it. This proposal will identify potential causes of frailty. We will study >120,000 middle-aged non-frail adults from 24 countries worldwide to understand what led to them becoming frail (lifestyle factors such as diet, smoking; genetic changes). We will also study the impact of frailty on employment, physical disability and need for residential care.
Keyword: frailty; multi-morbidity; epidemiology; mortality; aging

Project_Title: Gender and Careers in the Gig Economy
Project_Description: In traditional organizations, men and women have different work experiences, divergent career pathways, and experience gender inequality in outcomes (e.g., wages, advancement). Careers in traditional organizations, however, are less common, as the "gig economy"--a world of work characterized by short-term roles and contract work--expands to an increasing number of industrial sectors. My research team and I will recruit a sample of men and women employed in the gig economy, and using interviews and survey methods, trace their work experiences, career pathways and outcomes over several years. This study will help build theory about the role of gender in peopleâ€™s careers in the gig economy. This research will provide socio-economic insights that will be useful for Ontario policy-makers, workers, and employers, as the gig economy is expected to continue to expand in the provinc
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development
Keyword: Gender, careers, sociology of work, inequality, precarious work, gig economy, qualitative, longitudinal

Project_Title: Characterization of a molecular nanomachine involved in bacterial warfare
Project_Description: The beneficial bacteria that live within us protect us from the harmful bacteria that make us sick by colonizing and protecting vulnerable sites within our body. The goal of the proposed research is to uncover how harmful bacteria deploy a bacteria-killing nanomachine to displace our beneficial bacteria and cause infection. By understanding how this nanomachine works at a molecular level, we will identify vulnerabilities that can be targeted by antimicrobials. Disabling the bacteria-killing nanomachine will allow our beneficial microbes to survive attack by deadly pathogens and thus substantially reduce their ability to cause infection. The knowledge gained from the proposed work has the potential to uncover a novel strategy for treating bacterial infections, which is of ever-increasing medical importance given the dramatic rise in the number of antibiotic-resistant pathogenic bacteria in Ontario and worldwide.
Keyword: Antibacterial toxins, enzymes, chaperones, bacterial protein secretion, type VI secretion system, effectors, interbacterial competition, biochemistry, structural biology, X-ray crystallography

Project_Title: Neural mechanisms of multisensory processing and aging
Project_Description: The number of Ontario seniors is expected to grow from 2.4 million today to 4.5 million by 2040. This rapid demographical shift, along with increased health-related costs, particularly neurodegeneration and escalating fall rates across Ontario, indicates that understanding biological change during aging is one of the major current medical and economic challenges for Ontario. Dr. Barnett-Cowan's research on aging and falls will advance with this project aimed at developing cost-effective multisensory fall risk assessment technology as well as innovating falls prevention initiatives so to reduce hospitalization and fall recurrence among Ontario's seniors. Building on key innovative discoveries from his NSERC, industry and locally funded research, this project will be essential for training the next generation of researchers as well as to develop cost-effective sensory assessments to improve the lives of older Ontarians, while making new discoveries and advancements relevant to Ontario's automotive, aviation, mobile computing, and healthcare industries.
Keyword: aging, audition, event-related potentials, falls, multisensory, psychophysics, self-motion, transcranial magnetic stimulation, vestibular, vision

Project_Title: Using biological tools to predict impacts of climate change and contaminants on aquatic health
Project_Description: Fisheries generate more than $2.2B annually for Ontario; as such it is essential that Canadians maintain the health and integrity of this economically essential area for future generations. Current threats of climate change, compounded with increased urbanization, wastewater runoff, and agriculture land use pose a significant threat to maintaining a healthy and diverse fish community within Ontario. This research is focused on understanding the impacts that these threats have on key economic species (brown, brook, and rainbow trout) by examining the molecular events that result in adverse outcomes for these populations. Harnessing this knowledge, innovative techniques (environmental DNA and RNA) will be developed for rapid identification of these species in Ontario watersheds, including an assessment of overall health of a given population. This research is critical for strategically directing water protection policy in Ontario watersheds, and ensuring that fish populations and diversity remain sustainable for future generations.
Keyword: Fish, aquatic health, wastewater contaminants, epigenetics, eDNA, eRNA, endangered species, next-generation sequencing, physiology

Project_Title: Practical Pluggable Properties (P3): Improving Software Reliability Using Gradual, Inferable, and Synthesizable Types
Project_Description: Ensuring the quality and security of softwareâ€”for the Internet-of-Things through to planet-scale cloud servicesâ€”is of paramount importance to the global Information and Communications Technology (ICT) economy and to governments on all levels.  An estimated 60% of software development costs are currently spent on testing and debugging. The goal of this project is to develop novel analyses to drastically reduce these costs while increasing reliability.                  Dr. Dietl's team will create a practical framework that enforces quality and security properties in a usable, yet correct, way, providing: 1) gradual enforcement, to adapt to evolving project needs; 2) property inference, to reduce developer effort; and 3) property synthesis, to produce custom analyses. A novel constraint system will unify these aspects into a practical approach to improve software quality. This project will be evaluated through case studies with industrial partners in Ontario, and trained HQP will become sought-after expertshigh-quality software development.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Keyword: Optional/pluggable/refinement types, gradual types, static & dynamic analysis, type inference, code synthesis, constraint systems, security, verification, programming languages, computer science.

Project_Title: Remote Controlled: New Technologies in the Mining Sector and the Future of Work in Northern Canada
Project_Description: The mining sector in Canada is entering an â€œage of disruptionâ€ where advances in technology, like autonomous vehicles and remote operations, have the potential to fundamentally reshape the future of work and the development of communities across Northern Canada. This research will: (1) determine what technologies are being used in the Canadian mining sector; (2) identify what is driving the adoption of these emerging technologies and how they are re-shaping the sector; and (3) explore the social and spatial impacts on Northern communities (including in Northern Ontario) and the responses from companies and governments, including Indigenous leaders, and organizations involved in economic development and skills training. Findings will highlight new opportunities for research and development that will raise the profile of Ontarioâ€™s mining sector, position Ontario as a leader in mining technology skills training, and discover new opportunities for business procurement in Northern On
Keyword: Automation, new technologies, social implications, mining sector, workforce development, northern development, innovation, Northern Ontario, Northern Canada

Project_Title: Building a trapped ion quantum simulator for studying arbitrarily connected spin models
Project_Description: Dr. Islam is building Canadaâ€™s first trapped ion-based quantum simulator, which is a well-controlled quantum system that can be programmed to simulate otherwise hard-to-solve quantum models. At the forefront of quantum technologies, quantum simulators may lead to the discovery of new phases of matter and solutions to hard optimization problems with practical relevance in logistics and in finding new drug molecules. By employing a novel holographic optical set up, Dr. Islamâ€™s team will gain programmable control over the interactions between qubits. This will enable simulations previously deemed impossible in a conventional linear chain of ions, such as 2D and 3D spin lattices, and hence enhance the usefulness of quantum simulators. HQP training provided by Dr. Islam will   increase the local academic and technical talent pool by arming students with knowledge and skills highly sought after in the field of quantum, atomic, and optical physics, and quantum information process
Keyword: quantum simulation, quantum information, many-body physics, AMO physics, trapped ions, atomic physics, quantum spin chains, entanglement, frustrated spin systems

Project_Title: Facilitating treatment seeking among postsecondary students with mental health problems: The impact of an Online intervention designed to increase self-compassion and lower feelings of shame
Project_Description: Only 20% of postsecondary students with mental health problems seek help. Untreated mental health problems can lead to long-term disability and too often suicide. To increase treatment-seeking, campuses have focused on raising studentsâ€™ awareness of mental health services. However, this approach has had limited success because it fails to target one of the strongest barriers to treatment-seeking - shame. Dr. Kelly has found that one of the most powerful antidotes to shame is self-compassion. This study will extend her work to examine whether, among students who screen positively for a mental disorder, a two-week online intervention that fosters self-compassion will reduce shame and thereby increase the likelihood of treatment-seeking over time. This project can improve Ontariansâ€™ quality of life, save the province millions in lost productivity and healthcare costs, and revolutionize the way campuses and communities across the world promote mental health treatment-seeking, making Ontario a global leader inovation.
Keyword: Facilitating treatment seeking among postsecondary students with mental health problems: The impact of an Online intervention designed to increase self-compassion and lower feelings of shame

Project_Title: Atmospherically-printed nanoscale thickness gradients for next-generation electronics
Project_Description: Thin films with thicknesses of nanometres (billionths of a metre) are integral components of virtually all modern sensing, computing, communication, and display devices. Their continued integration into many settings (e.g., flexible and wearable electronics) is prompting a transition from expensive, wafer-based manufacturing processes to scalable large-area and roll-to-roll techniques. As a result, new technology to rapidly prototype and optimize devices in these new manufacturing environments is urgently required. Leveraging Dr. Musselmanâ€™s spatial atomic layer deposition infrastructure, this research will develop novel technology that can quickly deposit nanoscale films with tunable thickness gradients in open-air, for rapid prototyping of next-generation electronics. It will be used to optimize semiconducting films for different devices, including perovskite photovoltaics, which have the potential to provide Ontario with affordable renewable energy. Advanced manufacturing companies can use the technologyo accelerate their product development and sales, generating jobs and prosperity in Ontario.
Keyword: thin films, spatial atomic layer deposition, chemical vapour deposition, photovoltaics, metal oxides, charge transporting layers, metal halide perovskites, thickness gradients, rapid prototyping, computational fluid dynamics

Project_Title: Organic Chemistry Solutions for Intractable Problems in Materials and Nano-Science
Project_Description: Transistors are at the core of virtually all modern electronics, and are considered by many to be one of the greatest inventions of the 20th century given the impact on economic growth and the well-being of humanity as a whole.  The inexorable progression in performance of digital devices has necessitated ever-shrinking transistor sizes. However, there are fundamental limits to current state-of-the-art silicon-based transistors. Therefore, the implementation of an alternative semiconducting material for transistors is critical. Single-walled carbon nanotubes are an ideal candidate for the next generation of transistors, yet have thus far gone unexploited due to the current inability to control every aspect of their deposition. This research will develop the paradigm-shifting Alignment Relay Technique into a robust process, which will realize long-sought technology. Benefits to Ontario include job creation in the high-tech sector, raising Ontarioâ€™s international research profile, and improving the well-beingf Ontarians.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Keyword: Conjugated polymers, Carbon Nanotubes, Organic Synthesis, Surface Science, Conjugated materials, Materials Chemistry, Materials Science, Supramolecular Chemistry, Nanoscience, Nanotechnology

Project_Title: 'Borderline': A mobile artwork to 'play' urban data
Project_Description: Borderline is a practice-led research inquiry that uses the sonification of algorithmic data to create new understandings of place. Algorithms have inextricably changed urban experience, identifying data patterns capable of creating new economies, but also, sometimes, reinforcing social and economic disparities. Using machine learning and neural networks, and drawing from Thompsons prior research-creation in the algorithmic identification of urban sound (SSHRC IDG, 2017), Borderline will locate uneven geographies in four of Ontarios largest urban centres and will make these areas audible through data-triggered musical systems embedded in mobile and wearable technologies. Audiences will be able to listen in place, discovering invisible borders in their communities that affect social and economic mobility. As Ontario cities become smarter, Borderline will generate important dialogues around inequality while training highly-skilled HQP to address these challenges. The project will enhance Ontarios profile as a centre for excellence in cultural production, digital media and information technologies.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Keyword: research-creation, media art, algorithms, urban data, gentrification, mobilities, urban inequality, locative media, sound studies, mobile technologies

Project_Title: Cryogenic CMOS technology: Enabling Low-cost, Compact Control of Large-scale Quantum Computers
Project_Description: Quantum computing (QC) promises unprecedented computing power and speed that will change the way we work, live and play. This will require millions of physical quantum bits (qubits) to work together at cryogenic temperatures. However, a major challenge is that the current electronic circuits to control and read out individual qubits are far too large and costly to scale to this degree. Complimentary-Metal-Oxide Semiconductors (CMOS) offer a potential solution given it can cheaply integrate billions of transistors on chips just nanometers large.           Dr. Wei aims to advance the design of cryogenic-capable CMOS integrated circuits and integrate these technologies with QC. Specifically, her team will develop the first cryogenic design kit (cryo-DK) for commercially available CMOS technology, then use the cryo-DK to design and demonstrate a cryo-CMOS controller for a QC system.             The will pave the way towards scalable QC systems and, in turn, help cement Ontarioâ€™s leadership in Q
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Keyword: cryogenic temperature, CMOS, semiconductor technology, device physics, device modeling, design kit, integrated circuit, nanoelectronics, quantum computing, control circuit

Project_Title: Radioactive heat generation in the Earthâ€™s crust through time and spa
Project_Description: Heat generated by radioactive decay is a fundamental driver of the evolution of continental crust on Earth and other planets. However, the mechanisms that mobilize radioactive elements in planetary crusts are poorly understood. This information is crucial for understanding the origin of the Earthâ€™s continents and understanding how geological processes have changed over time. This research program will be the first of its kind to integrate novel analytical and modelling approaches to determine the factors that concentrate and dilute heat producing radioactive elements in the Earthâ€™s continents. This will provide new insights into the evolution of early Earth as well as the growth and the stabilization of planetary crusts. Two PhDs will be trained in leading-edge and Ontario-specific geological skills applicable to understanding the Canadian Shield and finding its many untapped mineral resour
Keyword: Geology, radioactive, heat production, continental crust, metamorphic petrology, tectonics, geochemistry, planets

Project_Title: Engineering mineral-coated fertilizers to environmentally and economically benefit the Ontario agricultural sector
Project_Description: Climate change and algal blooms are two key environmental concerns in Ontario. Climate change due to infrared radiation-trapping gases necessitates immediate mitigation strategies. Algal blooms, particularly in Lake Erie, are associated with excess discharge of phosphates. These problems not only cause environmental damage/deterioration, but they generate economic losses in Ontario (such as soil erosion and nutrient losses from agricultural soils). The focus of this research is to develop an engineered fertilizer that can simultaneously address these two environmental challenges of Ontario, and also be economically feasible. A mineral-amended coating will be applied to traditional fertilizers to control fertilizer release. The aim is to change the carbon (C), nitrogen (N) and phosphorous (P) cycles in the soil to achieve permanent sequestration of CO2 from the atmosphere, reducing ammonia, methane and nitrous oxide emissions from soil, and retaining phosphates in soil in a plant-available, but erosion/washout resistant, form.
Keyword: Atmospheric CO2 capture, alkaline minerals, coated fertilizer, phosphate runoff, nitrogen emission, geochemical modelling, chemical speciation, agricultural soils

Project_Title: Understanding the regulation of peripheral sympathetic outflow in humans
Project_Description: The sympathetic nervous system is critical to the regulation of blood pressure during both rest and exercise, but found to be over-active in cardiovascular disease states. Even in healthy individuals, exaggerated sympathetic responses to stress are associated with heightened clinical risk. The mechanisms responsible for the dysregulation of sympathetic activity are not clear. Using gold-standard and highly technical single- and multi-unit microneurographic measures of muscle sympathetic activity, Dr. Millar will investigate the mechanisms regulating resting muscle sympathetic outflow in humans, as well as the mechanisms and functional consequences of inter-individual variations in muscle sympathetic responses during exercise. As cardiovascular diseases represent a leading cause of morbidity and death for Ontarians, the proposed project will investigate mechanisms responsible for controlling sympathetic outflow at rest and during stress, with the ultimate goal of developing more effective treatment targets for reducing sympathetic outflow and identifying individuals at heightened future clinical risk.
Keyword: Cardiovascular, sympathetic nervous system, exercise, blood pressure, microneurography

Project_Title: Muscle Weakness and Function in Older Adults: Moving from Cell to Society
Project_Description: Aging is associated with a loss of muscle mass, strength and motor control, making muscles in the elderly smaller, weaker and less coordinated than in younger adults.  This project will investigate the underlying age-related changes to muscle properties and determine how they contribute to overall muscle weakness and function with aging. Ontario is aging faster than ever before with older adults (65+ years of age) now outnumbering young adults for the first time in our history.  Dr. Powerâ€™s research will translate muscle function at the cellular level scaled up to the whole muscle level, and help determine the relationship with functional activities of daily living.  Ultimately, the long term goal of his research team, is to to identify potential targets to improve physical function and promote independence in one of Ontarioâ€™s most vulnerable populations: the elde
Keyword: Aging, Muscle, Sarcopenia, Biopsy, Strength, Power, Kinesiology, Dynamometry, Exercise Performance

Project_Title: Linking environmental exposure and genetic susceptibility in Parkinsonâ€™s Disease (P
Project_Description: While little is known of the combination of genetic and environmental factors (GxE) that trigger Parkinsonâ€™s Disease, there is a growing body of evidence to suggest that agrochemical exposure is linked to disease etiology. While the underlying reason for this association remains unclear, there is strong evidence linking pesticide exposure with the degeneration of neurons in the brain. Dr.Ryan's research program exploits stem cell technology to model Parkinsonâ€™s pathology in cells from patients. Using these systems, he aims to gain insight into the interaction between environmental and genetic stress that brings about cellular dysfunction in neurodegenerative disease. He works from the novel idea that pesticide exposure triggers PD through global changes in gene expression that mimic the effects of disease causing mutations. This program offers training opportunities for HQP that will promote skill sets highly desirable to Ontarioâ€™s growing Life Science industry, including bioinformatics, NextGen sequencd Stem Cell technology.
Keyword: neurodegeneration, human induced pluripotent stem cells, transcription, paraquat, maneb, chromatin, Parkinson's Disease

Project_Title: Civil Society Network Engagement in Food Systems Governance
Project_Description: This study of civil society networks and food systems governance will offer critical insight into understanding and acting on some of Ontarioâ€™s most pressing contemporary challenges â€“ from addressing food insecurity and diet-related disease to costly and unnecessary amounts of food waste and unsustainable levels of greenhouse gas emissions attributable to the food system. Engagement in food systems governance is a powerful vehicle for building more healthy, equitable and sustainable food systems. This community-based, action-oriented research will study the evolution of civil society networks from place-based initiatives to engaging in food systems governance through processes of participatory decision-making, policy interventions, and multi-stakeholder engagement. Beyond providing direct value to Ontarioâ€™s civil society networks, food studies scholars and policy makers, this research will also serve as the basis for a national and transnational exchange of knowledge and experiences leading to new capacr innovation in democratic and participatory food systems governance.
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development
Keyword: agroecology; civil society; food systems; governance; policy; social movements; sustainability; wellbeing

Project_Title: The impacts of microplastics to a whole lake ecosystem
Project_Description: Microplastics (plastics <5mm in size) have been acknowledged as a truly ubiquitous contaminant. Studies demonstrating the presence of microplastics in freshwater rivers, lakes and in atmospheric deposition have shown that microplastics are not just ocean contaminants, and thus extend beyond the realm of marine science. Several researchers are working to try to understand the ecological effects of microplastics across several levels of biological organization. Still, experiments in tanks and mesocosms are difficult to extrapolate to the real world. At IISD-ELA (the Experimental Lakes Area), I propose to do a series of experiments, including a whole lake manipulation, to measure the contamination, fate and ecological impacts of microplastics on aquatic ecosystems. This year, the Ontario government has brought microplastics to the forefront and has listed questions about ecological impacts of microplastics as a priority research question. My collaborative work will help close this knowledge gap and inform policies in Ontario.
Keyword: microplastic, lake ecosystem, ecotoxicology, food web, environmental fate, whole ecosystem

Project_Title: Identifying and characterizing genetic modifiers of ALS disease characteristics
Project_Description: Neurodegenerative diseases such as amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) are debilitating disorders that bring substantial cost and burden to the health care system in the province of Ontario. Therefore, research geared towards understanding factors causing and influencing these diseases is of strategic value. One class of genes frequently mutated in ALS patients encode RNA binding proteins, such as TDP-43 and FUS, which are key regulators of gene expression and nerve cell physiology. The activity of these RNA binding proteins is frequently modified by the actions of other members of the broader RNA binding protein family. The proposed research aims to identify RNA binding proteins that influence the defects caused by mutations in TDP-43 and FUS, using models of the disease established in the tiny roundworm C. elegans. This proposal will enable a deeper understanding of the genetic factors that influence neurodegenerative disorders, and provide possible avenues for the development of therapeutics.
Keyword: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis, RNA binding proteins, C. elegans, Gene expression

Project_Title: Improving Mental Health Care Transitions for Ontario Children and Youth
Project_Description: Although transition between health services is widely recognized as a problematic health systems hurdle, the factors necessary for successful transition out of child mental health services are poorly understood. Fragmentation between mental health services worsens mental illness and create unnecessary challenges for youth and their families at an incredibly vulnerable time in their lives. The objective of this study is to improve the outcomes of youth (ages 16-18) with psychiatric disorders by providing front-line mental health service providers and decision-makers with evidence on factors that facilitate or impede mental health care transitions and on the effect of transitioning between mental health services on youth and their families. This will be accomplished by completing a 5-year longitudinal cohort study to examine continuity of care, psychiatric symptoms, functioning, and service-use of youth aged 16-18 with mental illness as they transition out of child and adolescent mental health services at age 18.
Keyword: Mental Health, Transitions in Care, Transitional Aged Youth, Health Services, Child Psychiatry

Project_Title: Discovering Dark Matter by Understanding Dark Complexity
Project_Description: High energy physics deals with fundamental questions about the universe and its laws. For example: what is Dark Matter? It dominates galaxies, but we have no idea what it is. I am proposing a new approach to solve these mysteries: studying Dark Complexity. It is based on the simple idea that Dark Matter may be as complicated and rich as the visible matter we are made of. This is especially likely if Dark Matter is connected to other puzzles, like why gravity is so much weaker than the other forces. We will expand upon our groundbreaking initial work on Mirror Stars to investigate the underlying theories and the behavior of such complex Dark Matter, and determine how its hidden but possibly spectacular signals can be discovered in astronomical observations.  This will establish a  multi-disciplinary research program at UofT and help make Ontario an international hotspot for boundary-crossing  particle physics.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Keyword: Theoretical particle physics, dark matter, cosmology, astrophysics, discovering new physics

Project_Title: Building rich models of time series data with neural stochastic differential equations
Project_Description: The most common type of data produced by businesses and hospitals are time series data.  This data is difficult to work with because it's sampled at irregular times, different types of measurements are made, and this data only gives partial information about the true state of a customer, patient, or business.  We are developing a new class of latent-variable time series models based on stochastic differential equations whose dynamics are governed by neural networks, that can naturally model this type of data.  These models have previously been intractable to fit to data, but me and my students have recently generalized previous results to provide a scalable algorithm that can.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Keyword: machine learning, time series, generative models, differential equations

Project_Title: Robust Machine Learning for Health Risk Stratification and Healthcare Policy Understanding
Project_Description: Our goal is to develop health phenotypes that could be used to improve healthcare, identify similar patients, and quantify the impact of possible interventions. Targeting individual clinical questions with machine learning does not scale well; instead we focus on representation learning of physiological state - or phenotypes - because latent states are useful in multiple tasks. Because different data may be important for a particular patient and task, we integrate notes, procedures, diagnoses, vitals, labs and other signals. The proposed research will have a strong impact on our understanding of what it means to be healthy, and variance within the human phenotype.
Keyword: Medical artificial intelligence, clinical machine learning, health risk stratification, deep learning and health

Project_Title: Algorithms for the Design and Manufacture of Geometrically Complex, Dynamic Objects
Project_Description: The complex mechanisms that make up a surgical robot, the intricate patterns that allow an arterial stent to unfold in a blood vessel and the clever design that allows a childâ€™s stroller to fold away are examples of how dynamic mechanical designs can impact society. Designing and manufacturing such dynamic objects is a painstaking process, consisting of tedious and expensive cycles of trial and error. This is due to the lack of a well-posed, robust, computational methodology for approaching the design of functionally dynamic objects. This project will address this glaring technological gap by developing algorithms for the computational design of geometrically complex dynamic objects. The availability of such algorithms will enable state-of-the-art progress in robotics, medical equipment design, aeronautics and automotive engineering; further strengthening Ontarioâ€™s position as a world leader in manufacturing and technological innovat
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Keyword: Graphics, Simulation, Design, Fabrication, Digital Manufacturing, Additive Manufacturing

Project_Title: Biodiversity where people live: habitat creation, conservation and commercialization of wild bees
Project_Description: Bees are essential pollinators of crops and wild plants worldwide. More than 70% of the >20,000 species nest in the ground. Despite declining populations, we know little of the edaphic (soil) conditions preferred by different species. Great effort is expended to plant flowers as forage for bees, but how to implement their nesting habitat is a final and most-pressing step. Paving and compaction in cities, tilling in agriculture, all eliminate nest sites for ground-nesting bees. Using state-of-the-art analysis, the objectives are to determine edaphic preferences of various ground-nesting bees, then develop manufactured soil mixes to create habitat for them. This project weaves empirical research with citizen science and NGO participation, Ontario-based industry engagement for commercialization, and collaboration with landscape practitioners to refine products in an effort to advance fundamental knowledge and transform current practices for wild bee conservation in an era of food insecurity and uncertainty due to climate change.
Keyword: Pollination, Ecosystem services, Urban green space, Green infrastructure, Food security, Sustainable cities, Soil science, Landscape architecture, Insect-microbe interactions, Citizen science

Project_Title: Fast and Scalable Solutions for Big Data Applications
Project_Description: The performance of many large scientific and data analytics codes for applications in machine learning and physics simulations depend on the existence of high-performance frameworks. Often, efforts in developing mathematical algorithms are disjointed from performance engineering efforts that build the scientific software. The emergence of new applications and stupendously large data has rendered the classical approaches to building high-performance software inadequate in many situations. The research proposal demonstrates that large-scale problems can be solved significantly faster when mathematical methods and high-performance software are developed jointly because data dependencies in software programs often originate from the mathematics that formulates the problem. Building high-performance frameworks has a wide societal impact and obvious economic implications, with a direct impact on Ontario's start-ups and companies that deal with increasingly large amounts of data every day. Through impacting a wide variety of fields, this research will impact Ontario's industry and society as a whole.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Keyword: High-Performance Computing, Domain-Specific Compilers and Code Generation, Parallel and Distributed Computing, Numerical Methods, Machine Learning and Optimization, Systems

Project_Title: Portable, On-Demand Manufacturing of Protein-based Therapeutics Containing Post-translational Modifications
Project_Description: The molecular revolution in medicine is poised to deliver many paradigm-changing therapeutics; however, in many cases, logistic and economic barriers limit access to these technologies.  We have pioneered a new molecular technology that allows for protein-based therapeutics to be manufactured on-site and on-demand.  The system is freeze-dried so that it can be distributed at room temperature, and is cell-free, which makes the system biosafe for use outside the lab.  Proof-of-concept work has demonstrated the production of >50 different therapeutic molecules and, while exciting, challenges remain.  Here we propose to advance our efforts to automate the manufacturing process so that drug production can be done by scientists and non-scientists alike.  We also seek to develop capabilities for manufacturing more complex drugs.  We see tremendous potential benefit of this technology for the people of Ontario by improving access to therapeutics in northern communities, for personalized medicine and in response to disease outbreaks.
Keyword: Synthetic biology, cell-free protein expression, on-demand manufacturing, protein-based drugs, lab reagents, post-translational modifications

Project_Title: Benzotriazole transformation in green infrastructure
Project_Description: Human-derived chemicals such as pesticides and pharmaceuticals threaten human and ecosystem health. Controlling water pollution at its source, through the use of green infrastructure such as constructed wetlands and bioretention cells, contributes to a safer production of drinking water. These systems have shown promising â€“ though variable â€“ results at improving water quality. Therefore, a deeper understanding of contaminant fate in these systems is critically needed to inform on their design, operation, and maintenance. In particular, the role of plants, algae, and light in pollutant fate is unclear. This project will unravel the key fundamental contributions of plants, algae, and light in the transfer and transformation of a model toxic organic contaminant, the antifreeze chemical benzotriazole, in constructed wetlands and bioretention cells. By helping protect Ontarioâ€™s aquatic resources, this research will address Ontario Innovation Agendaâ€™s target investments in bio-economy and clean techn
Keyword: bioretention cells, wetlands, contaminants, water quality, treatment, transformation

Project_Title: Developing methods for integrative metabolomics in personalized medicine
Project_Description:
Personalized medicine entails a vision where biomedical data is used to generate both static individual risk profiles (through personalized genomes) and to track patientsâ€™ health longitudinally using dynamic data.
