The project will use a next-generation mass spectrometric instrument to develop a method capable of measuring thousands of molecules at once in a single blood sample. With this technology, doctors will be able to order a single test that performs thousands of traditional lab tests all at once. This will allow researchers to track patients' health on a molecular level over time, building the foundation for personalized medicine in the clinics and contributing to improved diagnosis, treatment monitoring and patient stratification.

The personalized aspect of medicine is especially relevant in Ontario, where patients with a wide variety of ethnic backgrounds present to doctors. The knowledge gained here will help to establish medical guidelines adapted to patient gender, ethnic background or ag
Keyword: personalized medicine, computational biology, mass spectrometry, metabolomics, genomics, systems biology, data analysis, data-independent acquisition, computational mass spectrometry

Project_Title: New Synthetic Transformations using Electrophilic Metal Homoenolates: Applications in the Synthesis of Cyclopropylamines and Other Biologically Active Molecules
Project_Description: The efficient preparation of biologically-active molecules has been a long-standing objective for chemists. In this context, reagents with atypical reactivity profiles are exciting since they provide opportunities for the development of new synthetic methods. My group has recently demonstrated that metal homoenolates, which have been typically used as electron-rich reagents, can also react as electron-deficient reagents. Based on this concept, we have prepared cyclopropylamines, a prevalent motif in pharmaceuticals and agrochemicals, from simple building blocks. The proposed research will capitalize on the exciting and unusual reactivity of homoenolates to access a variety of molecules relevant to the chemical industry. This has the potential to enhance the research and development capabilities of pharmaceutical companies and contract research organizations located in Ontario. The proposed research will also lead to the training of HQP who will become important contributors to the science and technology sector in Ontario.
Keyword: organic chemistry, cyclopropane, metal homoenolate, cyclopropylamine, reactive intermediates, method development

Project_Title: Language and Innovation: A Computational-Cognitive Approach
Project_Description: The proposed research aims to understand the processes of human innovation through language change and the extent to which these processes can be modelled by computer algorithms. It will build on and extend beyond the applicant's recent work on computational approaches to language change to examine the evolutionary processes of innovation in the domains of science, technology, and culture. The computational-cognitive framework presented is informed by theories of cognitive science and enriched by cutting-edge data-driven methodologies drawn from computer science. The outcome of this research will contribute to both theoretical and methodological advances on formal approaches toward characterizing the general principles of human innovation. As such, it will benefit societal understanding and facilitate efficient practices of innovation in Ontario, both in the academic and technology industries. The proposed research will also provide unique interdisciplinary training opportunities in the Greater Toronto Area and more broadly in Ontario.
Keyword: language, language change, innovation, science, technology, computational cognitive modelling, chaining, textual inference, natural language processing, big data

Project_Title: Building a Trusted Digital State: Canadians' Views on Data Governance and Digital Service Reforms
Project_Description: Governments are ambitiously reforming how they collect, share and use data in order to facilitate digital service innovations that they argue are necessary to meet the expectations and earn the confidence of today's digital citizenry. Yet, given evidence suggesting citizens are increasingly concerned about mass surveillance, opaque, data-driven decision-making and data leaks, there is a risk that public sector data governance reforms actually undermine citizen trust, rather than bolstering it. Our multidisciplinary, nine-person team of highly qualified personnel will use opinion surveys, randomized controlled trials and policy case studies to generate rich and novel insight into Canadians' views on public sector data governance, and into the relationship between data and digital service reforms and citizen trust. The research will break new ground in the study of public sector data governance and will provide much-needed evidence to strengthen data and digital reforms underway in the Government of Ontario and globally.
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development
Keyword: data governance; privacy; citizen trust; digital government; digital services; digital economy; randomized controlled trials; public opinion surveys; policy evaluation

Project_Title: Identifying and disrupting molecular signals governing insect chill tolerance
Project_Description: The ability to survive low temperatures is a critical determinant of insect distribution on this planet, and insect distribution is rapidly changing. The renal system that regulates water and salt balance is critical to determining whether or not insects survive the cold, but the specific cellular signals that regulate the function of this system at low temperatures is unclear. I endeavor to lead a research team to use a machine learning approach coupled with integrative organ-level physiology to uncover how microRNAs (small noncoding RNAs) program the physiology of fruit flies to modify their cold tolerance. Once we have built this understanding we will translate our knowledge to find new ways to control winter survival in a mosquito species that spreads dengue fever, yellow fever, and Zika virus (among others). This species has recently been detected in Windsor, Ontario and is spreading north as our climate warms.
Keyword: insect; cold tolerance; microRNA; integrative physiology; ionoregulation; chilling injury; cold adaptation

Project_Title: Disaster Migration at Home and Abroad: A Transnational History of Canadian Relief Efforts (1900 - present)
Project_Description: This new research program explores the history of displacement, disasters and migration. In an innovative turn, the program explores the history of disaster relief in the Canadian context through a transnational lens, investigating the relationship between domestic relief efforts and the growth of international humanitarianism, beginning with a critical investigation of data from the Canadian Disaster Database (CDD). Central to the programâ€™s publicly-oriented research, the ideas and activities of state actors (Public Safety Canada, provincial and municipal authorities) and non-state actors (Red Cross, Oxfam) are explored in tandem. Specifically, the program investigates how both categories of actors have used migration as a solution to respond to disasters historically and how notions of responsibility vis-a-vis citizens and non-citizens have changed over time. The empirical and analytical findings will speak directly to current issues around climate change, environmental disasters and global displacement, th key benefits for public dialogue and engagement in Ontario.
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development
Keyword: displacement, disaster, environment, responsibility, migration, citizenship, refugees, civil society, international humanitarianism

Project_Title: From Cybersecurity to Cyber Deterrence: Lessons for Non-state and Sub-state Actors
Project_Description: Can deterrence theory be used to defend state, non-state, and sub-state actors from malicious cyberattack? Cybersecurity underpins everything from Canadian governance to public safety and personal welfare. The 2017 Ontario Cyber Security Framework outlines how the Government of Ontario will ensure the province remains economically innovative, competitive, and secure. This project investigates how deterrence â€“ a theory long reserved for state-on-state interactions that stipulates the coercive relationship between threats and behavior â€“ can be reconceptualized and applied to cyberspace at all levels of analysis. The project explores cyber deterrence across five levels of analysis: international multilateral (North Atlantic Treaty Organization), provincial (Ontario), municipal (City of Ottawa), private sector (banking and public utilities), and individual (Canadian citizens). The project generates better academic understanding of cyber deterrence beyond interstate relations, trains HQP in cybersecurity policnd informs ongoing strategic debates on securing cyberspace to the benefit of Ontario and all Canadians.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Keyword: cybersecurity; deterrence; privacy; public policy; ransomware; cyberspace

Project_Title: Whole Muscle Tissue Engineering through the Innovative Combination of Microstructure Engineering and High Moisture Extrusion-a critical opportunity to add value to Ontario crops
Project_Description: In November 2017, 15,364 world scientists signed a Warning to Humanity calling for, among other recommendations, drastically diminishing global per capita consumption of meat and animal-derived foods. Unfortunately, most consumers enjoy the texture of meat and many are disappointed with traditional plant-based protein products, such as tofu, since they are colloidal aggregates that fracture easily under stress and shear. This project addresses specifically the textural shortcomings of plant protein products. A revolutionary approach to the manufacture of vegan protein products, where the formation of actual plant protein fibers (from the nanoscale up) will be induced using widely available plant proteins from Ontario crops. Different fibrous structures will produce beef-like, chicken-like and fish-like â€œtissuesâ€, which can be further supplemented with specific flavors for meat replication. In this proposal, we focus on novel extrusion-based technologies that could be implemented for the large-scale manufaing of nutritious, tasty, protein-rich foods at low costs.
Keyword: proteins; carbohydrates; high shear extrusion; high moisture extrusion; food nanotechnology; biopolymers; meat analogues; food science;

Project_Title: CRISPR-based strategies to study drug resistance in fungal pathogens
Project_Description: Combating infectious disease pathogens is a pressing global health challenge. Due to limited treatment options, fungal pathogens pose a unique challenge, and are emerging as a leading cause of human mortality. Dr. Shapiroâ€™s research program will develop and use cutting-edge CRISPR-based technologies to study key fungal pathogens and identify novel targets for treatment. Focusing on Candida albicans, the most common cause of fungal infections, and Candida auris, a growing public health threat, she will develop CRISPR systems to create genetic mutants on a large scale, and use these to explore genetic mechanisms by which Candida species tolerate antifungal drugs and cause disease. HQP at diverse levels of training will be involved in all aspects of this research, and develop cutting edge skills in microbiology, CRISPR editing, and functional genomics. This research program will make significant contributions to the Ontario research landscape by illuminating new strategies to tackle life-threatening fungal inftions.
Keyword: Fungal genetics, Candida, microbial genetics, fungal pathogens, genetic editing, CRISPR, microbial engineering, antifungal drug resistance

Project_Title: Improving the mobility of older Ontarians
Project_Description: Problems with everyday mobility are common in older adulthood and can lead to falls and other negative health outcomes.  This program of research is focused on 1) identifying the best mobility screening tool for fall prevention among community-living older adults and 2) using recent advancements in technology to understand early changes in older peoplesâ€™ mobility. In the first research arm, we are conducting a 1-year prospective cohort study in 520 older adults to measure falls. In the second arm, we are conducting three interrelated projects: (i) an analysis of predictors of early mobility problems in the Canadian Longitudinal Study On Aging (ii) a 2-year prospective cohort study using wearable sensors to track the everyday mobility of 2000 older adults and (iii) the development of a mobility monitoring tool for older adults. These projects represent innovative contributions to aging research with direct relevance for improving late-life mobility in Ontario and beyond
Keyword: Aging; Mobility; Balance; Falls; Risk assessment; Exercise; Rehabilitation; Measurement; Technology; Pre-clinical disability

Project_Title:
The EMBOLDEN study: Partnering with diverse older adults and communities to co-design and test a community
program that supports exercise, nutrition, social participation, and community connections
Project_Description: Dr. Ganannâ€™s EMBOLDEN research program seeks to promote physical and community mobility among people 55+ years of age living in Hamilton neighborhoods experiencing health inequities. The aim is to co-design and test a program that increases awareness and use of health and social services to support health and independence, leading to positive changes in physical mobility, social participation, and quality of life. Early Research Award support expands Dr. Ganannâ€™s research program, beyond the scope of what is currently funded, to explore accessibility and adaptability of the intervention with an intersectional lens (e.g., gender, ethnicity, class). These explorations will provide invaluable information when seeking to scale-out and scale-up the intervention. This research program will also enable Dr. Ganannâ€™s team to explore acceptability and feasibility of implementing technology-enabled and individually-tailored support for diverse older adults to access health and social services to meet their n
Keyword: Mobility, aging research, community-based intervention research, citizen engagement, physical activity, nutrition, social participation, system navigation, integrated care delivery, health equity

Project_Title: Advanced and Automated Protocols for Designing, Assessing and Managing Critical Infrastructure
Project_Description:
Our lives critically depend on civil infrastructure on an everyday basis. A large number of critical structures in Canada and worldwide are now presenting major distress signs caused by numerous deterioration mechanisms. To guarantee performance, engineers need efficient tools for correlating the reductions in mechanical properties, physical integrity and durability of affected materials with their structural consequences. The above information is critical in determining the potential for further deterioration and for selecting timely management protocols. 
On the other hand, considering the tight financial situation in the public sector, the progressive shortage of quality materials as well as the pressure to preserve natural resources, it is essential that new structures are built with environmentally friendly materials. The goal of this project is to develop 1) automated protocols for assessing and acting on critical infrastructure deterioration and; 2) advanced techniques to design sustainable materials towards a greener future in concrete construction.
Keyword: Concrete materials, diagnosis and prognosis of concrete, management of concrete infrastructure, artificial intelligence, advanced mechanical and microscopic techniques, sustainable materials, low-embodied materials.

Project_Title: Modelling the impact and cost-effectiveness of novel approaches for tuberculosis control in Nunavut
Project_Description: Rates of Tuberculosis (TB) among the Inuit are up to 296 times higher than the Canadian population, leading to significantly higher number of cases of disease and morbidity. TB is curable, but providing specialized health care in remote northern communities poses many challenges. We are working with our partners in the government of Nunavut and Nunavut Tunngavik Incorporated to model the potential epidemiological impact and cost-effectiveness of novel community wide TB screening programs. These programs are very expensive and not all approaches can be employed or studied. This modelling study will allow us to answer key questions on the affordability and cost-effectiveness of scaling up and optimizing community wide screening programs that incorporate new tests and treatment approaches. It will help inform evidence-based policies, allowing decision-makers to assess under what conditions community wide screening programs may be scaled up, based on value for money analysis reflecting local needs and experience.
Keyword: Tuberculosis among Inuit, Tuberculosis community wide screening programs, Modelling population level impact, Cost-effectiveness analysis, Tuberculosis elimination

Project_Title: From Topological Materials to Quantum Computing and Simulation
Project_Description: Central challenges in the field of quantum matter are: how can we build a quantum computer and utilize it in the near future?  My research develops alternative routes to achieve the new phases of matter required for a topological quantum computer by using existing topological materials as building blocks.  I will also develop new protocols for using quantum computers to simulate highly entangled quantum states, including topological matter.  A better understanding of topological phases and materials allows for more powerful quantum computers.  This agenda will involve close collaboration with quantum computing experimentalists within Ontarioâ€™s rapidly expanding quantum ecosystem.  Such a research program thus contributes to Ontarioâ€™s efforts to be at the forefront of quantum technologies and will endow students with a versatile quantum skillset useful for both academia and indust
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Keyword: Topological phases, quantum materials, quantum many-body systems, quantum computing

Project_Title: Neutron Stars as Thermal Dark Matter Detectors
Project_Description: Dark matter's imprint has been observed in galaxies, lensed starlight, and fluctuating photons from the early universe. However, the exact nature of dark matter remains a mystery. One of the primary goals of modern physics is to determine dark matter's interactions with visible particles like the proton and electron. Leading a team of researchers, Dr. Bramante recently discovered that dark matter falling into neutron stars would heat them to infrared temperatures, observable with upcoming telescopes. This has the potential to revolutionize the search for dark matter. By calculating how dark matter interacts with the superdense nuclear fluid in a neutron star, Dr. Bramante and his research team are developing theoretical tools necessary to transform neutron stars into world class dark matter detectors.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Keyword: Dark matter, pulsars, neutron stars, particles, phenomenology, astrophysics, quantum field theory

Project_Title: Genetics of range expansion in ticks and tick-borne pathogens
Project_Description: Global trade and anthropogenic changes to the environment can facilitate the spread of problematic species (e.g. pests, weeds, diseases). For example, the deer tick (a.k.a. blacklegged tick, Ixodes scapularis) has rapidly increased in abundance throughout Ontario, increasing risk of Lyme disease and other tick-borne illness. To help monitor and mitigate the health impacts of tick-borne diseases, this research project will develop a new database and field protocols to  rapidly identify ticks and tick-borne pathogens in order to address two main questions: First, what is the history of geographic spread of deer ticks in eastern Ontario and how is dispersal affected by landscape factors like roads, vegetation, and topography? Second, which ecological factors have the largest influence on pathogen prevalence? Answers to these questions will inform strategies to mitigate exposure to tick-borne pathogens in order to reduce future cases of Lyme disease and other tick-borne illness in Ontario.
Keyword: Lyme disease, range expansion, microbiome, high-throughput sequencing, nanopore

Project_Title: Functional mapping and enhancement of brain network function through multi-site neurostimulation
Project_Description: Deep brain stimulation (DBS) was introduced two decades ago as a revolutionary therapy for the treatment of the Parkinsonâ€™s disease (PD). Since then, it has been trialed as a potentially transformative therapeutic approach for a multitude of other neurological illnesses, ranging from Depression to Alzheimerâ€™s disease. Despite this promise, however, DBS has failed, in all but a few cases, to improve patient outcomes. This reflects the fact that we still know very little about the mechanisms by which DBS operates, or how it modifies the function of whole-brain networks. This huge gap in knowledge presents a major hurdle in improving the efficacy of DBS and also explains why its methods have remained largely unchanged since its inception. Using a multi-disciplinary approach, the goal of the proposed research is to map, in vivo, how DBS changes the activity of whole-brain networks and use this knowledge to improve the efficacy of D
Keyword: stimulation, functional neuroimaging, neural circuits, neuromodulation, brain activity, brain connectivity, cognition, motor

Project_Title: Medical Image Processing and Machine Learning for Neurological Disease Analysis in MRI
Project_Description: This project proposes the development of novel image analysis & machine-learning (ML) frameworks to analyze MRI and patient data to study neurodegenerative disease, which will affect 255,000 Ontarians by 2020. Automated approaches will significantly advance neurodegenerative disease research and diagnosis since a large number of samples can be analyzed objectively and efficiently leading to greater understanding of risks, causes and progression.  To enable this, this research proposal analyzes variability in multi-centre data, extracts neuroimaging biomarkers related to disease, and investigates tools that correlate imaging biomarkers to clinical data.  The result is improved quality of care & outcomes for patients with neurodegenerative disease and reduction of the $10.45B annual burden on Ontario healthcare systems. This research contributes in making Ontario a global leader in neurotechnology and ML. Knowledge translation and commercialization are cornerstones of this research, which will translate into high-quality jobs for Ontarians.
Keyword: Image Processing, Machine Learning, Neurodegenerative Disease, BigData, Analytics, Computer-aided prognosis

Project_Title: Quantitative Computed Tomography Imaging of Lung Disease
Project_Description: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is among the most prevalent chronic diseases in Ontario. Over the next 30 years, COPD is expected to cost Ontario over $310.7 billion. Effective strategies to reduce the burden of COPD requires new approaches to identify those at the greatest risk of progression for more careful monitoring, and to aid in the discovery of disease-modifying treatments. The objectives of this research program are to develop innovative medical imaging analysis tools, utilize those tools to predict patients at the greatest risk of disease progression and hospitalization, and translate tools to other lung diseases with urgent knowledge/healthcare gaps. This research program will train 39 HQP (1 PhD, 3 MSc, 35 undergraduates) over 5 years, communicate research through outreach activities, and contribute to the Ontario Ministry of Health and Long Term Care's mandate to constrain healthcare costs and preserve high standards of care in Ontario.
Keyword: imaging, biomarker, lung, COPD, emphysema, image processing

Project_Title: Improving attention and learning for lectures and training materials
Project_Description: One pervasive roadblock to learning is the difficulty that people experience in sustaining attention for long periods of time. Dr. Szpunar has developed a novel line of research demonstrating that the simple act of interspersing long sequences of study, such as lectures or training materials, with opportunities for learners to express what they have learned can reliably reduce inattentive bouts of mind wandering and improve learning. The proposed work will use controlled behavioral and neuroimaging techniques to delineate the cognitive and neural mechanisms of this intervention, the outcomes of which would greatly aid in optimizing the delivery of interspersed testing during learning in real world settings. The goal of this work will be the development of HQP who will be able to apply the methods of the science of learning to academic and industry-based jobs in Ontario that focus on improving the efficacy of learning in students and the workforce.
Keyword: Learning, memory, attention, mind wandering, knowledge integration, lectures, training materials

Project_Title: Mapping Ontario's Black Archive: Building an Inventory Through Storytelling
Project_Description: This study will create an inventory of Ontarioâ€™s Black archives. There is a long-standing challenge in Black Canadian Studies pertaining to archives that are scattered, hidden, incomplete, and inadequately catalogued. This study responds to this challenge by creating an inventory of African Ontarian archives and by developing a detailed framework for how to collect, describe, curate, and catalogue these collections. A comprehensive inventory of African Ontarian archival collections will enable examination of the current state of existing archival collections; bridging the knowledge gap between African Ontarian archival collections and African Ontarian oral history. This study will enable Ontario to have an impact on future scholarship across a broad range of fields in Black studies in the province. It will also connect academic researchers with librarians, archivists, students, artists (visual and performance) and citizens with African Ontarian histor
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Keyword: African Ontarians; archives; storytelling; critical race; mixed-methodology; digital content; case studies; photographs; documents; creative community

Project_Title: Targeting ion channels in brain cancer
Project_Description: Brain cancer is the number one cause of cancer-related death in Canadian children. Those who survive have lowered intellectual and physical capacities due to both the disease and conventional treatments including surgery, chemotherapy and radiation. Dr. Xi Huangâ€™s research program aims to improve treatments for children with brain cancer. He was first to prove that ion channels are pediatric brain tumour targets, and to use an existing drug to block ion channel activity to treat brain tumours in a patient. Since brain tumours are highly heterogeneous diseases, his group identifies novel roles of ion channels in different types of brain tumours, and provides critical knowledge to develop personalized therapies to treat patients. Ontario has world-leading expertise in basic brain tumour biology and clinical care. Dr. Huang works with this community to rapidly translate findings to benefit Ontarians and patients around the worl
Keyword: brain cancer, ion channel, therapeutic target, genetics, cell biology, Drosophila, mouse

Project_Title: Modeling Pancreatic Cancer Subtypes Using 3-D Culture System
Project_Description: In 2019, nearly 2,000 people in Ontario will die from pancreatic cancer. Although pancreatic cancer is considered a tumour that is resistant to chemotherapy, there are a few patients that do respond to therapy and have better survival outcomes. Efforts to understand the differences between these two groups have included DNA and RNA sequencing. Researchers have found no difference at the DNA level as both groups share the same genetic changes. However, differences at the RNA level have been detected and patients who do not respond show a different gene expression profile than patients who do respond. This proposal seeks to understand the differences between responders vs. non-responders. The goal is to find mechanisms that can help reduce the mortality rate of pancreatic cancer, especially in patients that are resistant to therapy. We will train high-quality personnel to enter the genomics field in the clinical settings of Ontario.
Keyword: Cancer, Pancreatic Cancer, Genomics, Transcriptomics, Transcription factors, Patient-derived organoids (PDO), Next generation sequencing, CRISPR/Cas9, Chemoresistance, Molecular subtypes

Project_Title: Precision Medicine Program for Long-term Complications in Liver Transplant Recipients
Project_Description: Short-term survival of Liver Transplant (LT) recipients has significantly improved over the last three decades, however longer-term survival has not. I have developed a research program centered on cancer and metabolic disease as long-term complications of transplantation (namely recurrent Hepatocellular Carcinoma (HCC), fatty liver disease (NAFLD) and post-transplant diabetes) using a precision medicine approach. Various risk factors including anti-rejection medications contribute to the increased risk of these conditions post-transplant. However, the underlying biological mechanisms of these complications after transplant are not well understood. I am using state of the art technologies and research tools in molecular/systems biology, bioinformatics and machine learning to study the basis of post-transplant complications. These findings will allow us to generate personalized preventive and therapeutic strategies that allow our liver transplant recipients to live complication-free for longer and fulfill the potential of their transplant, thereby directly decreasing healthcare costs in Ontario.
Keyword: Liver Transplantation, Hepatocellular Carcinoma, Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease, Post-transplant Diabetes

Project_Title: Defining and Targeting Autoimmune Liver Disease
Project_Description: Transplantation is often the only treatment for end stage liver disease and liver failure; however, transplanted livers tend to fail in the long term, resulting in the need for re-transplantation. This leads to poor quality of life for patients and places a strain on the limited number of organs available for transplantation. With access to valuable biospecimens from the University Health Network (UHN) Multi-Organ Transplant Program, Dr. Sonya MacParland will develop therapies to target the immune cells that cause a type of liver disease called primary sclerosing cholangitisâ€”a disease that leads to liver transplantation in the majority of cases. These therapies will reprogram the immune cells to reverse the injury and eliminate the need for a liver transplant
Keyword: liver transplantation, end-stage liver disease, immunology, single-cell RNA sequencing

Project_Title: Role of Lipophagy in Atherosclerosis
Project_Description: Atherosclerosis, a form of heart disease caused by the build-up of cholesterol deposits in the artery wall, is responsible for one in five deaths in Canada. Meanwhile, existing cholesterol-lowering drugs are only partially effective at reducing the risk of heart attacks and strokes. New therapies are urgently needed to combat this deadly disease. Dr. Ouimet is looking for new ways to improve the removal of cholesterol from atherosclerotic plaques, stop plaques from growing bigger, and reduce their size. Dr. Ouimet is testing whether increasing a process in cells called â€œautophagyâ€â€”which breaks down lipids and exports themâ€”could achie
Keyword: Heart disease, atherosclerosis, autophagy, lipid homeostasis, macrophage foam cells, reverse cholesterol transport

Project_Title: Sublinear-time algorithms for high-dimensional sets
Project_Description: Modern massive datasets offer many new opportunities but also significant new computational challenges: on extremely large amounts of data, the only algorithms that are practical are those that run in significantly less time than it takes to read their entire input. Sublinear-time algorithms are one class of such algorithms. Dr. Blais's research will develop new theoretical foundations for sublinear-time algorithms, providing new advances in our understanding of the nature of computation as well as new algorithm design techniques for the software industry and new computational tools for all sectors of Ontario research and industry that rely on efficient computation over large amounts of data.
OIA_AREA: Digital media and information and communications technologies
Keyword: Algorithm design, randomized algorithms, property testing, query complexity, convexity, set expansion, polytopes, high-dimensional geometry

Project_Title: Promoting Children's Mental Health in Ontario: A Whole Family Approach to Research and Practice
Project_Description:
Ontario is currently experiencing a children's mental health crisis, with one-in-five meeting diagnostic criteria for a mental disorder and only a third of these receiving treatment. Despite studies demonstrating the importance of family functioning in understanding children's mental health, research has largely overlooked the impact of whole- family dynamics, instead focusing on single children and/or caregivers. As such, there is a pressing need to (a) better understand the family-wide factors that contribute to childhood mental health, and (b) develop evidence- based, whole-family interventions (i.e. family therapies) that can be translated to practice. The proposed program of study will benefit Ontario through the development and dissemination of whole-family approaches to the treatment of childhood mental health problems. This will result in reduced economic and service-based burden on the Ontario health care system via reductions in hospitalization/emergency services, and the prevention and treatment of
mental illness across development.
Keyword: Mental health, stress, clinical psychology, children, development, family, relationships, assessment

Project_Title: Novelty and utility: identifying microbial populations transforming contaminants in municipal waste sites
Project_Description: Municipal landfills in Ontario are large, heterogeneously contaminated sites that often impact groundwater and drinking water systems. Microbes living in landfills play critical roles in transforming deposited waste, and represent an untapped resource for remediation efforts. The proposed research will identify microbial functions involved in decontaminating toxic and recalcitrant wastes in landfills. Over the five years, microbial cultures capable of contaminant remediation will be established and field tested, developing cultures into flexible tools for remediation efforts. These microbial cultures represent low-cost, non-disruptive solutions that allow efficient and cost-effective remediation of contaminated sites across Ontario, saving the provincial government, municipalities, and site owners money during contaminant clean-up. Effective remediation tools will mitigate the downstream environmental impacts of our waste management systems and help to ensure future water security for the province. These tools will be applicable in many countries, and will position Ontario as a leader in contaminant remediation strategies.
Keyword: municipal solid waste, groundwater, environmental microbiology, bioremediation, diversity, metagenomics, proteomics, bioinformatics

Project_Title: Conservation of amphibian populations by using biological tools to understand amphibian-virus-environment interactions and disease outcomes
Project_Description: 60% of Canadaâ€™s amphibian species are found in Ontario, with over 33% of them endangered. Amphibians are central to maintaining a healthy ecosystem and for pest control, yet pathogens (i.e. Frog Virus 3 (FV3)) are causing rapid decline in some species. Dr. Katzenbackâ€™s research develops new biological tools to uncover differences in frog antiviral immune responses and to understand and predict the impact of anthropogenic factors (climate change) on frog immune function. Conserving Ontarioâ€™s rich amphibian biodiversity requires active investigation of the underlying molecular and cellular mechanisms that are driving the susceptibility of native frog species to FV3. This new knowledge will lead to the development of innovative, rapid and non-invasive tools (cell lines, environmental DNA) to monitor the health of amphibian communities in Ontario. Research results will inform provincial government policy makers and conservation agencies to develop strategies to protect amphibians and their wet
Keyword: Amphibians, Innate Immunity, Antiviral Immunity, Skin Epithelial Cells, Frog Virus 3, Anthropogenic Stress, Environmental DNA (eDNA), High Throughput Sequencing, Biomonitoring, Conservation

Project_Title: Mobilizing IoT-Based Health and Environmental Data for Increased Public Awareness
Project_Description: Climate change and its cascading effects have severe direct impacts on human health, which is why the World Health Organization has set â€œThe health impacts of climate and environmental changeâ€ as a major priority. Current surveillance data ecosystems are outdated and complex, providing limited insights into individual exposure rates to air pollution and heatwaves, two significant consequences of climate change that are of high relevance to Ontario. This project focuses on improving access to real-time air pollution and heatwave surveillance data collected using IoT technologies. The proposed technology will enable public health officials (via data dashboards with embedded analytics tools) to monitor hazards in real-time and increase the awareness of the greater public to extreme events (via an interactive website). User-centered design and participatory co-design will guide the development of the platform, while leveraging rapid analytics and machine learning to improve the responsiveness public health ages in Ontario and Mongolia.
Keyword: Internet of things (IoT), Public health, Surveillance, Wearables, Smart home technology, Air pollution, User-centered design, Health informatics, Mobile health.

Project_Title: Additive manufacturing at the air-water interface for printing and patterning 1D and 2D material thin films and devices
Project_Description: Materials which are atomically thin or nanoscale in one or two dimensions (e.g., graphene, carbon nanotubes) have unique properties which lead to countless technologies from more efficient water purification membranes to the development of advanced optoelectronic devices like transparent conductors for touch screens, flexible solar cells, and more efficient lighting. However, commercialization has been slow due to the lack of scalable methods available for their controlled integration into devices. This research aims to develop new, low cost and scalable methods to deposit films with monolayer resolution using the concept that nanomaterials float on water and could be manipulated using simple convective or electric forces. The outcomes of this project will be several disruptive coating technologies capable of roll-to-roll deposition and patterning and the engineering of ultra-thin and large area membranes and devices that the approach enables. These marketable coatings will support growth in high tech manufacturing in Ontario.
Keyword: 2D materials, graphene, energy storage, colloids and interfaces, Langmuir films, thin films, roll-to-roll coatings

Project_Title: CO2 Capture & Utilization via Power-to-Gas Conversion to Renewable Synthetic Fuels
Project_Description: Although carbon dioxide (CO2) capture & storage (CCS) technologies are commercially available, storing captured CO2 in geological formations is prohibitively expensive. Therefore, research and development are urgently required on CO2 capture & utilization (CCU). In Ontario, large industrial emitters such as cement and steel manufacturing are responsible for releasing 10 megaton/year of CO2; only a small fraction of that amount can be absorbed by chemical and food industries. The proposed research program will develop innovative technologies for CO2 utilization via Power-to-Gas conversion which involves reacting CO2 with renewable hydrogen over a high-temperature catalytic bed reactor. This approach transforms renewable (or surplus) electricity into chemical energy of synthetic fuels, utilizing CO2 as an energy carrier. The proposed methodology relies on integrating state-of-the-art experimental and numerical methods. The ultimate goal is to help Ontario to meet its greenhouse gas emission reduction targets, raising Ontarioâ€™s profile as a leader in the clean-tech fiel
Keyword: CO2 utilization, renewable synthetic fuels, power-to-gas, thermo-catalytic conversion, heterogeneous catalysis, technoeconomic assessment, reaction engineering

Project_Title: Learning to control the electrochemical conversion of carbon dioxide into useful chemicals
Project_Description: The process of electrochemical CO2 reduction (ECR) can recycle CO2 into commodity chemicals such as ethylene and methanol, which are synthesized from fossil fuels on a 100-megaton annual scale. The displacement of fossil-fuel feedstocks and reduction in CO2 emissions enabled by commercialization of ECR would yield economic and environmental benefits, but poor efficiency and selectivity in currently known reaction systems impedes commercialization of ECR. Insufficient understanding of reaction mechanisms currently restricts development efforts to a trial-and-error approach. The proposed research will enable the development of rational strategies to resolve efficiency and selectivity issues by developing leading-edge experimental techniques to examine reaction systems during operation. The improved economic feasibility of ECR will facilitate translation of the technology to Ontarioâ€™s chemical manufacturing sector and improve Ontarioâ€™s ability to compete in emerging clean-technology markets. Being wholly elecity-powered, ECR will provide a dependable market to support growth of Ontarioâ€™s renewable energy industr
Keyword: electrocatalysis, surface science, spectroelectrochemistry, vibrational spectroscopy, carbon dioxide recycling, heterogeneous catalysis, reaction mechanisms

Project_Title: Design and development of Physiological REadiness for Therapy System (PRÃŠTS) for Motor Rehabilitatio
Project_Description: With Canadaâ€™s aging population and associated incidence in chronic conditions, demand for rehabilitation services is straining capacity. While emerging technologies (e.g., robotics) aim to expand service capacity, the lack of ways to measure effort during therapy limits their effectiveness. The planned research aims to develop the Physiological REadiness for Therapy System (PRÃŠTS) to quantify physical and cognitive effort during rehabilitation therapy. Specific objectives are to: I) design PRÃŠTS hardware incorporating multiple sensor technologies, including electroencephalography (EEG), electrocardiography (ECG), and eye-tracking, II) develop algorithms integrating sensor signals to quantify effort, and III) investigate PRÃŠTS application to optimize motor learning using a rehabilitation robot. Project outcomes includes PRÃŠTS prototypes, a database of PRÃŠTS-acquired data, and patent applications. Trainees will gain interdisciplinary, hands-on skills developing of rehabilitation technologies, expanding hualified employees to the Ontario workforce. Importantly, the planned research supports advancement of rehabilitation care capabilities to mitigate rising service demands.
Keyword: rehabilitation engineering, assistive technology, motor recovery, physiological measurement, electroencephalography (EEG), electrodermal response (EDR), eye-tracking, electrocardiography (ECG)

Project_Title: Aging Places: Exploring and Enhancing Older Adults' Inclusion in Neighbourhoods
Project_Description: Exclusion of older adults from community life is a growing issue that negatively impacts their health and well-being and is a key risk for morbidity and mortality. The proposed research will explore older adultsâ€™ inclusion and exclusion in neighbourhoods, followed by a participatory action research (PAR) cycle of collaboratively developing and implementing neighbourhood-based strategies to promote inclusion. Applying a novel qualitative-geospatial method that I previously developed will enable a deep understanding of how exclusion and inclusion are created and experienced, and point to ways to enhance inclusion. The project will enable excluded older adults to represent their own sense of neighbourhood and contribute to creating inclusive neighbourhood places that support their well-being. Evaluating the PAR process and impacts will enable replication in other neighbourhoods and findings will inform wider conversations about service, policy and neighbourhood developmen
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development
Keyword: aging, neighbourhoods, inclusion, social environment, built environment, community participation, qualitative research, geospatial methods, participatory action research

Project_Title: Developing Nanoengineered Bioinks for 3D Bioprinting Complex Osteochondral Tissue Structures
Project_Description:
Currently available treatment methods to treat musculoskeletal injuries largely depend on invasive techniques, where the drug-carrying prefabricated scaffolds are surgically implanted at defect sites. From clinical perspective, injectable hydrogels are preferred over prefabricated scaffolds due to their minimally invasive nature. This procedure has much lower risk of infection, blood loss and surgical scar formation. Furthermore, injectable hydrogels can fill up any desired shape and hence can be used to treat irregular defects.
However, weak mechanical properties of currently available injectable hydrogels result in limited control over structural stability, printability and degradation characteristics. Proposed research will introduce a novel family of nanocomposite hydrogels to strengthen the weak hydrogel networks. The formulated hydrogels will be mechanically resilient, 3D printable, and capable of delivering therapeutic molecules and cells. Additionally, the hydrogel will be used as bioinks to print complex osteochondral tissue structures for growing number of osteoarthritis patients who needs joint regeneration/replacement.
Keyword: biomaterials, nanomedicine, nanomaterials, tissue engineering, hydrogels, regenerative medicine

Project_Title: Artificial Intelligence-assisted Expert System for Bridge Health Management
Project_Description: Despite decades of research in construction materials, bridges in Ontario are rapidly aging due to adverse weather conditions and increasing traffic, posing a significant threat to Ontarioâ€™s growing population. Existing bridge monitoring methods are vastly outdated, relying on prescheduled visual inspections that are highly subjective, can vary between maintenance teams, and are error-prone in damage detection. Recent advances in sensing technology provide opportunities for engineers to recognize defects in bridges. However, they pose several challenges for remote and autonomous monitoring of bridges due to their limited access in major busy cities in Ontario. My team will address these challenges using a novel monitoring technique where inherent damage as well as recurring traffic overload will be identified using limited measurements by harnessing Artificial Intelligence. This proposal will develop a next-generation expert system for real-time surveillance of existing bridges to enhance safety, provide ze highway bottlenecks, and offer improved satisfaction to commuters.
Keyword: Bridge health monitoring, bridge inspection, damage detection, modern sensing, system identification, signal analysis, image processing, artificial intelligence

Project_Title: Wholesale cardiac Imaging Surveillance with Echocardiography and Radionuclide assays during breast cancer chemotherapy (WISER)
Project_Description:
Women who get breast cancer chemotherapy are at higher risk for heart problems. There are no reliable methods to predict who will get a weak heart from chemotherapy. Instead, physicians are compelled to order tests to check the strength of the heart before, during, and after chemotherapy. Most of these tests are likely normal. In a pilot study, we showed that doctors do not act on results from 97% of routinely ordered heart tests. Thus, we may be unnecessarily wasting health care dollars and precious patient time. 
We plan to study the medical records of women who got breast cancer chemotherapy at six Ontario hospitals. Using sophisticated analyses, we will develop models to predict when cardiac testing is likely to be useful and identify who is at greater risk of getting a weak heart. This will potentially save our health system millions of dollars while improving our patientsâ€™ experience
Keyword: cardiology, breast cancer, cardiac imaging, chemotherapy, anthracyclines, trastuzumab, cardiotoxicity, appropriate use, quality improvement, risk prediction

Project_Title: Identifying the consequential risks, benefits, and socio-technical strategies of diffusion of innovations in a low-carbon energy transition
Project_Description: An energy transition is underway in Ontario, and in other provinces in Canada. The emergence of 'smart grids' -- digitally enabled electricity infrastructure -- and flexible technologies on the distribution grid are entering energy markets and systems globally and changing relationships between consumers and producers of energy. There are many benefits to the widespread adoption of these low-carbon innovations and an energy transition, such as reducing greenhouse gas emissions and economic and industrial policy goals of market creation and new business lines, and improved quality of life in Ontario. However, there are also negative consequences, such as rising costs or localized reduction of reliable energy. This research takes both a technical and social science lens to understand the risks and benefits of the widespread adoption of these low-carbon innovations, and will provide analysis on how to track innovations risks, benefits, and design interventions to increase the benefits and mitigate risks.
Keyword: low carbon energy transition; innovation diffusion systems; consequential risks; benefits; energy justice; energy democracy; community energy; energy users

Project_Title: Smart quantitative imaging biomarkers for personalized breast cancer care
Project_Description: The overarching goal of this research is to develop an intelligent multi-modal quantitative imaging technology that can predict and rapidly evaluate how individual breast cancer patients will respond to chemotherapy. Our novel three-pronged approach transforms ultrasound, elastography and photoacoustic imaging techniques to characterize tumours from various microstructural/physiological perspectives and develop robust imaging-based biomarkers of cancer response to chemotherapy. These quantitative biomarkers will be integrated with innovative AI methods to predict/monitor chemotherapy response. Currently, standard clinical measures based on physical assessment and anatomical imaging can take months to determine whether a chemotherapy regimen is working effectively for individual patients. In contrast, our innovative technology, using inexpensive/portable imaging modalities, has the potential to predict treatment response before or within a few days after the treatment starts. Such early prediction would allow ineffective treatments to be switched to more effective ones, improving survival and sparing patients unnecessary side effects of futile treatments.
Keyword: Quantitative imaging, Prognostic biomarkers, Artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning, Therapy response prediction, Breast Cancer, Precision medicine

Project_Title: Using Data to Improve Care for the Dying
Project_Description: Contrary to the wishes of most, much end-of-life care in Ontario is provided in hospitals. Ontario has a wealth of linked, routinely collected health data. We will use this data to measure and evaluate how palliative and end-of-life care is delivered in Ontario â€“ to identify gaps in care. We will also build, implement, and evaluate world-leading prognostic models of end-of-life outcomes that will be translated into web-enabled tools. These tools will improve the ability of patients, clinicians, and caregivers to anticipate the dying process. It will improve the reach of palliative care to reduce unnecessary and costly hospital care, and strengthen care in the communit
Keyword: palliative care, end-of-life care, primary care, home care services, quality indicators, prognostic models, health services, population health

Project_Title: The Rhythms of the Roman City: Artefacts as Guides
Project_Description: This project explores the â€œrisingâ€ and â€œfallingâ€ rhythms of the ancient city of Gabii, one of the largest settlements in pre-Roman Italy. Unlike most cities in Italy, Gabiiâ€™s size decreased and population waned through the 1st century BC and there is no later city built on top. Thus, its ancient layers are unencumbered by later buildings making it an ideal place to explore the material record of urbanization. This project builds on 10 years of work at the site supporting further explorations through excavations and the close study of artefacts at a number of scales. The goal is to examine Roman urbanism through the study of ancient artefacts -- how they were used, re-used, and re-purposed -- and to train Ontario students in: modern archaeological excavation and research methods, and digital data management and 3D visualization for the promotion of cultural heritage to the broad
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development

Project_Title: Environmental toxins and diabetes
Project_Description: Diabetes is characterized by chronic high blood sugar levels resulting from insufficient insulin production by pancreatic Î²-cells. There are >1.6 million people in Ontario living with diabetes and nearly 1 in 3 adults with either diabetes or â€˜pre-diabetesâ€™. It is critical to understand how environmental factors contribute to the rising diabetes incidence in Ontario and worldwide.  My lab seeks to identify environmental toxins that cause pancreatic Î²-cell injury, such as dysregulated insulin secretion and/or Î²-cell death, and consequently increase diabetes susceptibility. I propose three complimentary projects. The first will explore molecular mechanisms by which dioxin, a persistent pollutant, impacts pancreatic Î²-cells and diabetes risk. The second project involves unbiased screening studies to discover new environmental pollutants, aside from dioxin, that impact human Î²-cell development, function, and survival. The final project expands my research program into a human study and explores the link buorinated pollutants and diabetes risk.

Project_Title: Real-Time Self-Monitoring Energy Storage Systems
Project_Description: Ontario is heavily reliant on an uninterrupted electric power supply for supporting its manufacturing sector and for maintaining a high quality of life for Ontarians. When electricity is unavailable during periods of extreme heat/cold, the result can range from uninhabitable buildings, damage due to frozen pipes, food spoilage, and extreme temperature-related deaths. The proposed research program will develop reliable self-monitoring energy systems by providing innovative condition monitoring tools that detect potential failure of energy storage devices. Since these devices are commonly used in various modern power grid topologies, their failure would have a significant consequence for communities relying on a reliable grid. Developing degradation models using key failure predictors is instrumental to recognize failure precursors and thus help reduce related losses to Ontario due to power failures. The tools developed here will be extended to other critical components of energy systems, such as wide band-gap power converters and electric generators.

Project_Title: The effects of noninvasive brain stimulation on treatment adherence in persons with schizophrenia
Project_Description: Medication nonadherence occurs in up to 60% of patients with schizophrenia (SCZ). One of the main factors of nonadherence is impaired illness awareness (IIA), occurring in up to 95% of patients with SCZ. This study is the first to investigate the clinical and functional brain imaging effects of transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) as an adjunctive treatment to improve medication adherence by targeting brain regions associated with IIA in SCZ. tDCS is a safe method of brain stimulation that will be combined with functional MRI to measure brain changes associated with IIA before and after tDCS and whether it is associated with better medication adherence. Improving individualsâ€™ acceptance of their illness would lead ultimately to greater illness recognition, improved antipsychotic medication adherence and better clinical outcomes, reducing the economic and personal burden of mental illness in Ontario and beyon
Lead_Research_Institution: Centre for Addiction and Mental Health

Project_Title: Substance Use In Pregnancy Epidemiology Research (SUPER) Group
Project_Description: The perinatal period is a critical window for lifelong development. It is the optimal time to intervene to reduce the prevalence and severity of neuropsychiatric disorders in the population. However, recent lifestyle behaviour changes, access to social media, and the ongoing opioid epidemic and COVID-19 pandemic mean many pregnant women face social isolation and behavioural pressure. Increased availability and marketing of substances such as cannabis due to legalization significantly impacts the prevalence and pattern of substance use in the obstetrical population. Contemporary data are urgently needed to understand the impact of prenatal cannabis, opioid, cocaine, and hallucinogen use on the health of mothers, neonates, the developmental trajectories of exposed children, and Ontario's society. We will generate novel data on the risks associated with perinatal substance use. We will build capacity for downstream research in this area by supporting Dr. Corsi and establishing the SUPER group.
Lead_Research_Institution: Children's Hospital of Eastern Ontario Research Institute

Project_Title: Carbon-based low-dimensional nanomaterials
Project_Description:
Low-dimensional nanomaterials exhibit remarkable electronic properties, mechanical, and chemical stability. The proposed research focuses on the construction of novel carbon-based nanomaterials and unveiling their properties. The properties of these nanomaterials are determined by their morphology, dimension, size, careful choice of their monomer building blocks, and the chemical nature of the bonds which hold them together. This research provides a novel approach towards the design of the next generation of graphene-like nanomaterials for carbon-based nanoelectronics, spintronics, and quantum technology applications.
Their tunable conductivity, charge mobility and/or electron spin-based structure, as well as their thermal and chemical stability, make them ideal for the nanoelectronics industry, viable plastic electronics and optoelectronic systems. The proposed nanomaterials with unique electronic properties will have significant impacts in science and technology in Ontario, with the resulting economic and social benefits. Lastly, training HQP will create a skilled workforce in an area of great importance to Ontarioâ€™s econom
OIA_AREA: Development and creation of investigation spots

Project_Title: Beyond the Scalpel: Optimizing Outcomes after Cardiac Surgery
Project_Description: My research program's focus is on improving the outcomes of patients after cardiac surgery through safer use of blood thinning drugs. These drugs are used to prevent stroke in patients who have a mechanical heart valve or who have an irregular heart rhythm (atrial fibrillation). My 2 studies evaluate different strategies to blood thinner use (lower intensity and more convenient agent) in patients who have undergone cardiac surgery. These studies, clinical trials, may lead to reductions in the risk of major bleeding events which increase healthcare use and  are associated with important costs. We will also ensure these strategies are safe from a stroke prevention standpoint. Therefore, these projects have the potential to decrease healthcare costs and to improve the outcomes of Ontarian patients after cardiac surgery.

Project_Title: Understanding the impact of new Ontario Ministry of Health funding for midwifery services on the integration of midwifery in inter-professional primary care settings
Project_Description: In 2018, Ontario introduced funding to support midwives to work in new ways within the Ontario health care system. The new funding was intended to improve access to midwifery care for Ontarians and to encourage innovative new ways for midwifery services to be integrated into inter-professional primary care teams. Our research will examine how successful this funding has been in supporting the integration of midwifery into inter-professional primary care teams and in improving access to midwifery services. We will conduct a multiple case study involving seven midwifery programs in inter-professional primary care settings supported by the new funding. Our research will generate new knowledge about how effective the new funding is in supporting its objectives. By comparing the different programs, we will identify lessons that will help the Ontario Ministry of Health make wise decisions about future midwifery funding to ensure the greatest access to high quality services for Ontarians.

Project_Title: Industrially scalable Methods to Make Electrically Conductive Membranes
Project_Description: The proposed research investigates industrially scalable coating methods to make electrified membranes. Membranes have transformed separations in diverse fields including wastewater, pharmaceutical purification, and beverage clarification. However, membranes passively separate solutes, suffer from fouling, and fail to treat rejected solutes. Electrified membranes are next-generation membranes, which enhance selectivity through electrochemical reactions, target specific solutes, adapt to changing solution conditions, detect and prevent adsorption of foulants, and catalytically degrade contaminants. Electrified membranes are usually formed by coating membranes with electrically conductive materials, which lack methods for scalability. Three scalable roll-to-roll coating methods will be compared in this research: bath coating, co-axial extrusion, and hierarchical metal plating which will coat membranes with carbonaceous nanomaterials for the first two techniques and with metal thin films in the third. Large-scale coating technology development, expertise, and IP are critical to maintain Ontarioâ€™s water technology dominance and to ensure leadership in smart membranes and materials manufacturin

Project_Title: Hybrid Modeling for Risk Assessment and Management of Water-related Hazards
Project_Description: Water-related hazards (e.g., floods, droughts, and pollution) have been imposing unprecedented challenges on Ontario, jeopardizing public health and hampering economic growth. For example, flooding is the costliest natural hazard in terms of property damage in Ontario (Government of Ontario, 2021). The prediction and management of water-related hazards are facing various challenges arising from climate change and enormous uncertainties, which lead to difficulties in formulating effective risk management strategies. In this research, innovative hybrid modeling approaches, which leverage state-of-the-art machine learning techniques, will be developed to analyze how likely a water hazard is to occur (risk assessment) and how its impact can be minimized (risk management). The developed tools will provide direct decision support for industries and different levels of government in Ontario, not only to improve their effectiveness in managing water-related risks, but also to enhance their preparedness for, response to, and resilience under, extreme events in an ever-changing world.

Project_Title: Development and pilot testing of a virtual reality cycling game for children receiving dialysis
Project_Description: Children with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) typically visit the hospital 3x/wk to receive 4-5 hours of dialysis. As a result, these youth are sedentary, present with low fitness, physical function and quality of life. Virtual reality (VR) may represent a novel tool to alleviate these burdens through an immersive environment. Combining VR and physical activity may allow children with ESRD to improve dialysis efficiency, fitness and function, while also providing a virtual 'escape' from the hospital environment and supporting peer interaction. Our objectives are to: 1) Develop a Google maps-based VR cycling game; 2) Assess user preferences for visual and gamification features; 3) Test the feasibility of VR cycling in a dialysis unit; and 4) Evaluate the effects intradialytic VR cycling on dialysis efficiency, fitness, physical activity, and quality of life. Our VR game can be scaled to support health in children with any chronic disease in Ontario and beyond.

Project_Title: Towards Decarbonizing Iron and Steelmaking Processes
Project_Description: With the ultimate goal of decarbonizing the iron and steel industry, the current proposal examines the application of hydrogen as a reducing agent in iron and steelmaking. As one of the biggest industrial carbon dioxide emitters, the iron and steel industry is responsible for over 8% of the greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions from all sectors in Ontario. With the current iron and steelmaking technologies, carbon dioxide emissions almost exclusively result from the use of fossil fuels such as coal or coke for either energy generation or chemical reduction. Focusing on the latter, this research investigates replacing carbon with hydrogen as a green reducing agent in iron and steelmaking processes. The findings will provide a path for mitigating the environmental impacts of Ontarioâ€™s iron and steel industry, a critical step towards reducing the province GHG emissions to 30 percent below 2005 levels by 2030, committed in the Made-in-Ontario Environment Pla

Project_Title: Platform Technology for High-throughput Drug Screening
Project_Description: Pharmaceutical companies spend over 150 billion dollars annually on drug development, while the success rate from phase I clinical trial to market approval is only 9.6%. Improving the outcome of drug discovery will require the use of more predictive preclinical models for testing. Existing cell-based assays and animal testing are either too simplistic or not based on human physiology, making drug testing results less predictive. Leveraging tissue engineering techniques and human stem cells, we aim to develop functional human tissue models that closely resemble human organs. Ontario is home to 40% of Canadaâ€™s pharmaceutical companies. This research will provide new tools and knowledge that can be integrated into the existing drug development pipeline to improve drug selection prior to clinical trials, allowing for faster delivery of new treatments and reducing the costs of drugs, to the benefit of Ontarians and the broader Ontario Healthcare syste

Project_Title: Improving disease resistance in Ontarioâ€™s cro
Project_Description: Microbial diseases and pests place major constraints on agriculture and have significant economic and social impacts. Every year, Ontario farmers battle a range of diseases affecting their crops by spraying fields with environmentally-unfriendly pesticides. Just like understanding our own immune system is important for the development of effective drugs and vaccines, understanding the plant immune system is important for effective disease management in crops. Closing this knowledge gap drives global research on plant immunology, including the innovative program run by our team in the Monaghan Lab at Queenâ€™s University. The proposed research will allow us to engineer enhanced disease resistance in crops important to Ontarioâ€™s economy by exploiting unique tools generated in our lab. Students will be trained in a breadth of molecular techniques that will prepare them for a wide range of careers in academic or government research, as well as careers in the biotechnology and agricultural sect
OIA_AREA: Chemical and biological experimentation for the future

Project_Title: Understanding and stimulating the production of natural products by marine bacteria
Project_Description: This proposal addresses the fundamental threat of Antibiotic Resistance to Healthcare in Ontario by generating and utilizing a platform for the discovery of new bacterially produced "Natural Product" (NP) molecules for drug development. Natural Products have long been an excellent source of drug leads, however, their discovery has been hampered by their limited production under laboratory bacterial cultivation conditions. This proposal describes three synergistic approaches we will use to access the full NP potential of Pseudoalteromonas, a family of Marine Bacteria. We will develop state of the art laboratory cultivation conditions that mimic the native habitat of the NP-producing bacteria in addition to several genetic approaches that allow production of molecules to be turned on by the flick of a genetic switch. We aim not only to discover therapeutically useful molecules but also to establish a general discovery platform for bioactive Natural Products.

Project_Title: Machine learning analysis of 400,000 CT scans to map cancer progression
Project_Description: My goal is to transform how clinicians treat patients with cancer using a data-driven approach to help move the field from the â€œtreat everyone to help a fewâ€ paradigm towards precision medicine, defining relevant biomarkers to guide targeted treatments and improve human health. Currently, cancer spread is only understood in the context of cancer trials where time-consuming measurements of tumour growth are required by radiologists. I will leverage state-of-the-art artificial intelligence technologies for large-scale analysis of 400,000 CT scans to map cancer progression and predict metastatic spread. Better understanding cancer progression is the first step toward developing targeted approaches to interrupt this devastating stage of the disease. Cancer is the leading cause of death in Ontario. Optimizing treatment pathways is key to improve patient outcomes, reducing the financial burden on the Ontario health care system and providing novel predictive and prognostic biomarkers for the $29B biomarker mar

Project_Title: Main Sequence Stars as Laboratories for Particle Physics
Project_Description: 85% of the matter in our Universe is in the form of Dark Matter (DM); we do not know its composition. Understanding the nature and properties of DM would represent a fundamental shift in how we understand the world in which we live. While significant experimental efforts are underway to detect DM in underground experiments, the first hints of its nature may come to us from astronomical observations of a billion stars by the Gaia satellite. I aim to perform theoretical calculations of small but measurable effects of dark matter on the Sun and Sun-like stars, by developing new numerical and analytical techniques. This grant will train students in theoretical physics and data analysis, constructing high-precision, large-scale computer simulation of the thermodynamics of exotic matter deep in stellar interiors, modeling the evolution of large populations of stars in the presence of DM, with the goal of discovering its true nature.

Project_Title: CHILD VULNERABLE ROAD USER MOTOR VEHICLE COLLISIONS AND ACTIVE TRANSPORTATION: THE EFFECTIVENESS OF ROAD SAFETY DESIGN INTERVENTIONS
Project_Description: Vulnerable road user (pedestrian and cyclist) collisions are an overlooked and emerging public health crisis. There has been an increasing trend for vulnerable road user fatalities in Ontario, with a simultaneous decrease in active transportation (walking and cycling), which is an important source of physical activity. The proposed research involves several interrelated studies investigating vulnerable road user motor vehicle collisions and evaluating the effectiveness of road safety environment interventions. The effects of COVID-19 on changes in transport mode and collisions and how they relate to social equity will be examined. This research involves unique multidisciplinary partnerships, including researchers, policy makers and knowledge users, to conduct high quality evaluation road safety research. The research can potentially have a large impact on the health of children in Ontario, as it will examine injury and active transportation with respect to equity in road safety interventions.
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development

Project_Title: Advancing Maternal-Fetal Diagnosis and Prognosis using Machine Learning
Project_Description: Placenta accreta spectrum disorders (PASDs) are conditions in which the placenta abnormally adheres to the uterine wall and does not separate spontaneously during birth. It occurs at a high and increasing rate that currently costs $47M/year for the Ontario Healthcare System. Reducing the financial impact of PASDs requires new approaches for early and accurate diagnosis in pregnancy. The proposed 5-year research program will develop innovative automatic image analysis packages that provide both diagnosis and prognosis of PASDs, facilitating improved clinical management and planning and will train 34 HQP (2 PhD, 2 MASc, 5 MEng, 25 Undergraduates). The developed tools, disseminated through outreach activities, will provide the framework for and be translated to a comprehensive gestational prognostication package that accounts for both placental and fetal disease, maternal medical history, and demographic parameters, resulting in improved healthcare and lower healthcare costs in Ontario.

Project_Title: Enhancing food and water safety emergency preparedness among Ontario residents
Project_Description: Food-borne and water-borne illness cause a significant health and economic burden in Ontario, with most illnesses occurring due to contaminated food and water in peopleâ€™s homes. Climate change is expected to cause more frequent and intense extreme weather events, power outages, and flooding, increasing the risk of food-borne and water-borne illness in Ontario. There is a critical need to evaluate the impacts of and improve Ontario resident preparedness toward climate change and its effects (e.g., power outages) on food and water safety. This research will use an innovative, mixed-methods approach to achieve these aims. The project will involve a combination of epidemiologic modelling of illness rates, focus groups and surveys with Ontario residents, and an evaluation of a novel educational intervention. The research program will train 19 HQP (1 Post-Doctoral Fellow, 2 masterâ€™s, 16 undergraduates). Applied results will guide public health and emergency management policies and practice in Onta

Project_Title: Decreasing Emergency Department Visits Among Cancer Patients
Project_Description:
Head and neck cancer patients experience high rates of symptom burden and emergency department use. These events negatively impact the patient experience and place an already vulnerable population at increased risk of hospital-acquired complications and treatment interruptions. 

Efforts to reduce emergency department use carry profound importance for both patients and heath care systems. Through this proposal, we aim to enhance supportive care for Ontario patients with head and neck cancer. We will develop a risk prediction tool to identify patients at high risk of emergency department use. We will conduct semi-structured interviews with patients to identify the supports they need to better manage high symptom burden. We will also pilot a mobile app-based platform to enhance remote symptom monitoring.  Through this multi-methods approach, we hope to improve the patient experience, curb emergency department use and improve health outcomes for Ontario cancer patients.

Project_Title: Adaptive MR-Linac Guided Radiotherapy in Glioblastoma Multiforme
Project_Description: Sunnybrook is at the forefront of investigating the use of combined MRI and Linear Accelerator technology (radiation) to treat brain cancer â€“ with MR-Linac suitable for daily monitoring of tumour and surrounding brain tissue, a desired treatment improvement during a course of radiation. This project proposes new methodology to improve long-term radiotherapy outcomes in patients with glioblastoma, the most common brain tumour, specifically by developing advanced brain tumour imaging methods for the MR-Linac. Imaging will be advanced to find regions of active tumour where delivery of higher radiation doses will better kill tumour cells. In parallel, imaging will be developed to identify healthy functional brain regions for which radiation dose should be decreased â€“ sparing patients from undesired radiation toxicity. This research will enable personalized and precise treatments, improved outcomes and quality of life for Ontarians, while maintaining Ontarioâ€™s global position as a leader in radiotherapy resend development.

Project_Title: The Ontario Oxylipins Study: New prognostic markers and drug targets in dementia
Project_Description: As Ontarioâ€™s population ages, and with the recent failures of so-called â€œdisease-modifyingâ€ therapies for Alzheimerâ€™s disease (AD), focus has shifted urgently towards the need for preventative therapies. Damage to the small vessels that supply blood to the brain is the most commonly observed brain disease in aging, and it approximately doubles the risks of stroke and dementia. Using two large cohort studies this project aims to determine conclusively if certain lipids measured in blood, â€œoxylipinsâ€, can be used to predict the progression of 1) cognitive impairment, and 2) neuroimaging markers of small vessel disease in people with dementia. With a â€œsilver tsunamiâ€ ahead in Ontario, this proposal not only offers an opportunity to develop a new prognostic blood test, but also to determine whether emerging new drugs that target oxylipins might prevent or slow the progression of dementia by protecting the brainâ€™s most delic

Project_Title: The role of tandem repeat expansions in neurological disorders
Project_Description: Neurological disorders cause significant disruption to the body functions and movement governed by the nervous system. It is estimated that 3.6 million Canadians are living with at least one neurological disorder with over 60,000 people in Ontario diagnosed annually.
