Genome sequencing technology has allowed detection of causal genetic factors in a subset of these disorders, but the causes underlying most of the cases remain unknown. We hypothesize this is due to the neglection of repetitive DNA regions, which constitute most of our genetic information. Currently, there are over 50 genetic disorders linked to abnormality in repetitive sequence. They are mostly caused by increased length of the repeats (repeat expansions). We will develop and apply novel analytical strategies to discover disease-relevant repeat expansions, their modifying factors, and delineate their involvement in neurological disorders. Our research aims to improve the diagnosis, prognosis and potential treatment of neurological disorders.

Project_Title: Characterizing the neurobiology of treatment resistant depression
Project_Description: More than 400,000 Ontarians with major depression are not able to find a medication that relieves their symptoms, and have treatment resistant depression (TRD). Consequences for people with TRD are significant: poor social functioning, medical comorbidity, and increased mortality. TRDâ€™s personal burden doubles the health-associated costs compared to depression that is treatable. Dr. Rizviâ€™s goal is to identify what causes treatment resistance, discover new treatment targets, and feasible tests for TRD. As a world first, her well-resourced team uses advanced brain imaging to visualize changes in the brainâ€™s dopamine system that contribute to TRD, and develops tests that are markers for dopamine impairments. This work will strongly benefit Ontario by reducing the economic burden of TRD and improving clinical care through early identification of TRD, optimizing current treatment options and developing new treatment targets. As TRD is greatly understudied, her research positions Ontario as an innovative lea the field.

Project_Title: Topographic mapping of glioblastoma and treatment response at the protein level
Project_Description: Glioblastoma (GBM) is the most common form of brain cancer and has an extremely poor prognosis of approximately 15 months despite spirited research efforts. Traditional models of cancer biology have largely considered GBMs to be a uniform mass of cancer cells. New data, however, now suggests that spatial interactions between cancer cells and non-cancer components, found in the tumour environment, play an important role in GBM growth and therapy resistance. We will study GBM using approaches that better preserve and model these multiple components involved in the disease. Our team will use our expertise to isolate different cancer and non-cancer components of glioblastoma and use advanced protein and image analysis technologiesâ€”mass spectrometry and deep learningâ€”to individually monitor how different components evolve during therapy. We believe this approach will advance our fundamental knowledge of glioblastoma and in turn improve our ability to manage and treat this deadly dise

Project_Title: New strategies to combat fungal infections
Project_Description: Combating infectious diseases and drug-resistant microbial pathogens is vital to global health. Fungal pathogens are critical threats affecting over 300 million people globally, and nearly 2% of all Canadians. Treatment of these infections is a serious challenge due to a limited selection of clinically effective anti-fungal drugs with low toxicity to humans, and the emergence of drug resistant strains. To overcome these challenges, her research program will apply quantitative proteomics to identify and characterize novel infection-associated fungal proteins and their targets within a mammalian host to uncover new anti-virulence treatment options for fungal infections. This approach will also be useful to reverse anti-fungal resistance through the discovery of resistance-associated proteins that can be targeted to make current anti-fungals effective once again. The proposed research will identify innovative new strategies to overcome life-threatening fungal infections and generate significant health and economic benefits to Ontario.

Project_Title: University for First Nations Research Program
Project_Description: For all the significant actions taken in response to the Truth and Reconciliation Commissionâ€™s call on Canada to develop â€œculturally appropriate curricula,â€ one crucial omission is developing resources for First Nations that detail the inner workings of higher education and academic research. The proposed initiative recognizes First Nationsâ€™ right to information about academic processes and priorities to position them to participate in research collaborations on their own terms. Through extensive archival research and collaboration with First Nationsâ€™ communities, the research team will document power hierarchies within the academy, detail the creative ways First Nations have campaigned against their exclusion, and identify opportunities for transformative change in academic research processes. Ontario Universities have expressed commitments to decolonizing academic institutions and the time has come to provide First Nations with the information needed to negotiate solutions. The University for FirsResearch Program will fill that gap.

Project_Title: Identifying youth with FASD in Ontario and Improving Outcomes
Project_Description: Fetal alcohol spectrum disorder (FASD) is a common neurodevelopmental disorder caused by prenatal alcohol exposure impacting more than 1.4 million people in Canada. Youth with FASD experience a range of serious and complex deficits and needs, yet frequently go unrecognized and undiagnosed. Without appropriate identification and supports, they experience a range of difficulties, including overrepresentation in the criminal justice system, leading to high individual and societal costs, and revolving door cycles in the system. The proposed research aims to develop, implement, and evaluate an evidence-based toolkit for identifying and effectively responding to the needs of justice-involved youth with FASD in Ontario. Improved identification and screening, earlier in the criminal justice system process, coupled with improved case management and enhanced justice workforce skills, will facilitate the provision of effective supports to ensure improved outcomes for individuals and communities across the province.

Project_Title: Personalized Psychotherapy for Child Anxiety and Depression
Project_Description: Highly effective and efficient psychotherapy treatments for children are lacking; in fact, 40-50% of children receiving therapy do not improve. To enhance treatment effectiveness, Dr. Thomassin and her team will conduct an open trial of personalized psychotherapy for child anxiety and depression using data-driven algorithms. She will test whether personalized psychotherapy yields greater and faster improvements in symptoms than the improvements seen in non-personalized psychotherapies in established trials. By building capacity for research on personalized psychotherapy, Ontario, and Canada more broadly, stand to contribute in a significant way to these global efforts. Findings will inform patient-oriented care pathways that tailor therapy to patient mental health needs, rather than the current approaches that are not tailored. Patient-oriented care has the potential to lead to a stronger â€“ i.e., more effective and efficient â€“ mental healthcare system. Findings will also guide the training of future clinis and will contribute to Ontarioâ€™s mental healthcare workforc

Project_Title: Understanding the Molecular Architecture of DNA Repair Using Synthetic Proteins
Project_Description: Proteins are the building blocks of life. They deliver crucial messages and perform vital tasks to ensure cells function properly. Protein-protein interactions (PPIs) are essential to this process, and when these interactions go awry, such as during DNA repair, cancer and other diseases arise. Correcting the function of aberrant PPIs with synthetic molecules could provide enormous therapeutic benefits. Tremendous effort has been focused on this area but most existing inhibitory molecules fall short in terms of potency and selectivity. To tackle this problem, Dr. Zhang has built a protein engineering platform to enable rapid and effective development of protein-based PPI modulators. The proposed research will leverage this platform to identify and optimize intracellular probes to understand the molecular architecture of the DNA repair signaling network with unprecedented precision. This project will enhance Ontarioâ€™s bitoechnology sector by establishing a pipeline for the production, optimization, and delive of reagents with therapeutic potential.
OIA_AREA: Chemical and biological experimentation for the future

Project_Title: Blending of molecular science and traditional knowledge to create an Indigenous youth community science biological monitoring pilot program in Ontario's Ring of Fire mining region.
Project_Description: The goal of the proposed research is to develop a simple, efficient, and inexpensive environmental effects monitoring program to assess the health (and safety) of wild fish in the Ring of Fire mining region. We will accomplish this by developing a simple blood plasma sample collection protocol using a drop of fish blood and a small paper filtration card device that can be performed by young Indigenous community scientists, and then mailed in an envelope to the Aquatic Omics laboratory at Ontario Tech University (Oshawa, Ontario). There we will employ high-throughput analysis methods to assess those samples for molecular biomarkers of exposure and effect that are specific to toxic metals and adverse outcome pathways. We will infer the health of wild fish populations based upon the presence (or absence) of these biomarkers, and the information will be disseminated to local Indigenous communities, Industry stakeholders, and Government agencies.
Lead_Research_Institution: University of Ontario Institute of Technology

Project_Title: Controlling quantum systems with high-field terahertz pulses
Project_Description: Quantum technologies have an immense potential to revolutionize some of Ontarioâ€™s most promising areas of research and development, such as communications, security, and energy consumption efficiency. However, there are currently few efficient techniques to control quantum systems and harness their exceptional properties. Dr. MÃ©nardâ€™s research proposes an approach based on innovative photonics techniques to manipulate quantum states in solids and molecular systems. His plan relies on technological advances recently demonstrated in his Ultrafast Terahertz Lab; A high-field terahertz (THz) source and field-enhancing plasmonic resonators will allow his team to investigate and manipulate a dynamical Bose-Einstein condensate in a semiconductor, and chemical reactions of hybridized molecules. Dr. MÃ©nardâ€™s experiments on semiconductors pave the way to new quantum computation and communication technologies, while studies on hybridized molecules could revolutionize the field of green energy storage. His trainegain skills needed for employment in Ontarioâ€™s nascent quantum technologies secto
OIA_AREA: Development and creation of investigation spots

Project_Title: Exploring atomic-scale quantum states in 2D materials for quantum technologies
Project_Description: At the convergence of two burgeoning fields of research - two-dimensional (2D) materials and quantum science - 2D materials emerged as a solid-state platform with great potential for the development of next-generation quantum technologies. 2D crystals are the thinnest materials known - a few nanometres and below. At these thicknesses, quantum mechanical effects are so strong that such substances no longer behave like the macroscopic materials to which we are accustomed. Dr. Luican-Mayerâ€™s research goal is to harness 2D materialâ€™s unique properties to develop quantum devices. Specifically, her group will use microscopic techniques with atomic precision to uncover and control the properties of quantum defects. Successful outputs of this work will provide a novel platform for quantum sensing, communication, and computing, with great scientific and technological value for Ontario. These technologies are expected to radically transform the world we live in, solving important problems in energy, medicine, or phal sciences.
OIA_AREA: Development and creation of investigation spots

Project_Title: Scaffolding the Involvement of Parents in Their Childâ€™s Mathematics Educati
Project_Description: While parental involvement in childrenâ€™s education is often viewed as beneficial, when parents are anxious about math, and help their children with math homework, that help backfires. Their children learn less math and become more math anxious themselves. Dr. Maloneyâ€™s research program aims to develop theory-driven interventions to contribute to the improvement of math education. By observing pedagogical differences and analyzing homework-helping behaviors of parents who are higher vs lower in math anxiety, and through the implementation of knowledge mobilization efforts, her research outcomes have the potential to increase the number of children prepared to pursue math and science-related careers, which is particularly important given increasing demand in Ontario for a highly competent workforce educated in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (ST

Project_Title: Promoting Action in the Face of Racial Injustice: The Pitfalls and Promise of Emotion Regulation
Project_Description: Ontario has witnessed an unprecedented recent wave of protests for racial justice. There are many barriers to justice, however, and progress requires identifying them and developing tools to overcome them. I propose that one powerful barrier to systemic change is rooted in White individualsâ€™ emotional reactions to considering their role in racism and inequality. They often experience such moments as distressing and although this distress could motivate them to take action against racism, people are commonly motivated to reduce this distress in the service of a powerful instinct to protect well-being. In turn, a striking trade-off emerges: people protect their well-being but impair their motivation to address racism. The proposed research will systematically investigate this trade-off and identify strategies that may be effective for promoting both well-being and collective action. As such, this research lays the foundation for larger-scale interventions that can promote collective well-being in Ontario and yond.
OIA_AREA: Development and creation of investigation spots

Project_Title: A pathway to better bio-products: uncovering the molecular mechanisms of plant cell wall signaling.
Project_Description: Plant cell wall material is used by people everywhere: as wood for building; as textiles like cotton or paper; or as raw resources for next-generation renewable biofuels or bioplastics. Past research has identified the enzymes that make plant cell walls and research translation from model plants to crops has begun to develop â€œcustomâ€ plant cell walls for improved materials or biofuels. However, these attempts have exposed a critical gap in our understanding: plants perceive cell wall status via largely unknown mechanisms, called â€œcell wall signalingâ€ and typical plant responses are to limit growth, causing yield penalties that render these cell wall â€œimprovementsâ€ agriculturally/economically unviable. The McFarlane Lab has recently identified many new molecular components of cell wall signaling via a novel screen. This proposal aims to characterize these molecular components with a view to applying this new information to improve plant cell walls for renewable bioenergy and gree

Project_Title: EXPLORING NOVEL BRAIN CIRCUITS IN CHRONIC PAINFUL TEMPOROMANDIBULAR DISORDERS
Project_Description: Chronic pain affects one in six Canadians, costing $40.4 billion to the Canadian economy each year. Chronic pain affecting the jaw muscles (myofascial temporomandibular disorders; mTMD) are the most common cause of chronic pain affecting the face, and the second most common cause of musculoskeletal pain. These affect about 12% of Ontarians. Two recent studies have identified two novel neural circuits in the brain that are related to facial pain in mice. Using brain MRI scans, we have, for the first time, identified these circuits in humans. Here, we aim to determine whether these circuits are abnormal in mTMD, compared to healthy pain-free individuals, using brain MRI scans. We will also test whether they contribute to pain associated with mTMD. This study is important because it may provide us with new targets for treatment of mTMDâ€”and perhaps other chronic pain disordersâ€”reducing both patient suffering and healthcare co

Project_Title: Towards Machine Learning Governance
Project_Description: Ensuring that the benefits of machine learning (ML) outweigh the societal risks associated with its application (e.g., lack of privacy or fairness) remains an open challenge. In this proposal, Dr. Papernot addresses this problem with solutions for ML governance. The research team is structured around three milestones. First, they enable responsible ML from distributed data sources to mitigate privacy risks associated with collecting data centrally. Second, they invent techniques for auditing the guarantees provided by these ML algorithms. Third, they develop the concept of model ownership to increase accountability of model owners when their models fail. Key sectors of Ontarioâ€™s economy, e.g., healthcare and finance, will be more competitive because of their access to technology and HQP required to deploy responsible ML with strong governance mechanisms. Ontarians will be able to hold the private and public sector to higher degrees of accountability thus further nurturing trust in applications of M

Project_Title: Exposome-wide discovery of Indoor Contaminants
Project_Description: Over 350,000 chemicals have been manufactured worldwide. Human exposure to pollutants lead to 5,900 annual deaths in Ontario and >$3.6 billion annual disease costs in Canada. However, due to the limited capacity of current analytical methods, less than 1% of contaminants have been identified which severely underestimates the risks. The proposed research aims to employ a 'top-down' strategy by developing analytical toolboxes for high-throughput screening of previously unrecognized indoor contaminants, on an exposome-wide level. An in silico 'IndoorTransformer' database will be established to include numerous currently unknown indoor transformation products beyond the 350,000 manufactured compounds. Machine learning will be employed to predict concentrations. Hundreds of unrecognized indoor contaminants are expected to be detected and prioritized, and 3-6 of the most important contaminants will be selected for toxicity testing. The proposed research will provide a 'top-down' strategy to discover previously unrecognized contaminants and mitigate their adverse health impacts on Ontario's population.

Project_Title: Cultivating Trustworthiness in Global Health Research: Data-driven tools for equitable intervention design, implementation, and evaluation
Project_Description: Dr. Perez-Brumerâ€™s innovative ERA research will inform new data-driven tools to ensure more equitable design, adaptation, and evaluation of interventions targeting marginalized communities by (1) identifying sociopolitical factors that limit justice in how global prevention interventions are designed and implemented; (2) advancing methods and policy to promote trustworthiness in intervention design, implementation, and scale-up; and (3) creating a global network to support justice-informed global health practice. This timely research will examine conceptual and methodological aspects of justice that have been underexplored but are critical to improve equity in how global health interventions are designed and implemented. Dr. Perez-Brumerâ€™s utilization of community-based participatory methodologies aligns with Ontarioâ€™s support of projects seeking to redress systemic racism and promote trustworthiness. The creation of a virtual global health hub has the potential to strengthen Ontarioâ€™s e-learning commas online knowledge dissemination could be used in secondary and postsecondary educational settings in Ontario and abroad.
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development

Project_Title: Characterization of immune mechanisms and inhibitors that prevent infection by microsporidian parasites
Project_Description: Each year infections by microbial pathogens kill thousands of Ontario residents and make millions sick. One type of especially prevalent and vicious parasite is that which grows exclusively inside of host cells. These types of pathogens infect millions of humans every year, but they have been difficult to study, because they only grow inside of their hosts. We propose to study one of these pathogens, microsporidia, that infects immunocompromised patients as well as other animals such as honeybees, fish, and shrimp. We will study this pathogen by using the roundworm, which is a very convent and powerful model system. Using the roundworm, we will identify mechanisms of immunity against microsporidia and characterize small-molecule inhibitors of infection. This research will lead to a better understanding of how microsporidia and other pathogens are able to infect humans and animals, and lead to improved methods to be able to treat infectious diseases.

Project_Title: Accelerating discovery and additive manufacturing of novel metallic alloys for aerospace and automobile applications
Project_Description: Metallic components often need to withstand extreme operating conditions such as high stress and high temperature environments. As conventional alloys approach their limit of performance, new alloys with enhanced mechanical properties have been highly desired. Meanwhile, many metallic alloys are very expensive and difficult to process into components, leading to considerable materials and energy waste. Here the applicant proposes to design new metallic systems â€“ high-entropy alloys (HEAs). Such HEAs are expected to exhibit excellent mechanical properties, surpassing many conventional alloys. Moreover, the applicant aims to produce HEA prototypes and components using an additive manufacturing (AM) approach. The proposed AM of HEAs will allow Ontario manufacturers, especially aerospace and automobile companies, to use lighter-and-stronger and high-temperature stable materials in their products, consuming less of energy and reducing carbon emissions. This program will provide unique training opportunities for ght highly qualified personnel and strengthen Ontarioâ€™s competitive position in advanced materials and manufacturin

Project_Title: Fast Planar Graph Algorithms using Interior Point Methods
Project_Description: Important computational problems on networks can be captured by abstracting them as optimization problems on graphs. Many physical networks of interest are almost planar. Despite decades of research, many important problems on planar graphs do not have really fast algorithms that run in almost-linear time in the number of vertices. I propose to design almost-linear time algorithms for several problems on planar graphs. I propose to achieve this by combining planar graph structure with techniques from continuous optimization, specifically interior point methods. My previous works have pioneered a strongly coupled interaction between graph structure and optimization for general graphs. The anticipated results will be directly applicable to network optimization, responding rapidly to changing conditions, and helping remove capacity bottlenecks. The HQP trained will be highly skilled in algorithms and optimization â€” skills that are coveted in the industry because of their applications to big data and machine lening.
OIA_AREA: Development and creation of investigation spots

Project_Title: Activity Around the Clock: Human sleep flexibility in a changing world
Project_Description: Sleep is a crucial aspect of life and my recent research has demonstrated how deeply connected it is to the success of our species. The primary research challenge of my work is to provide a fundamentally new perspective on sleep-flexibility by investigating captive non-human primates, human hunter-gatherers, and small scale-societies, and apply our findings to human sleep in the Global North. Given the strong linkage between sleep and downstream physical and mental health outcomes, and the vulnerability of Canadian populations to high latitude seasonal affective disorder (SAD), my teamâ€™s output will positively impact Ontarians by demonstrating ways to improve sleep quality. Therefore, the aims of this proposal significantly advance the field by providing urgently needed data on human and non-human primate sleep architecture by integrating field, comparative, and theoretical projects under one research program that will ultimately transform our understanding of the evolution of human slee

Project_Title: Understanding and Reducing Motivational Barriers to Empathy
Project_Description: Empathy is critical to building a healthy society and helping individuals thrive. However, research suggests empathy is declining, documenting numerous instances of empathic failures. Although empathy is considered an ability, it also requires sufficient motivation. Here, I take a motivational approach to understand why individuals who are capable of empathizing sometimes fail to do so. I investigate two contexts in which people face significant motivational barriers to empathy: empathy burnout, which occurs after sustained exposure to others' suffering, and moral empathy gaps, which arise when engaging with others with different moral values. I develop laboratory paradigms to identify the emotional, cognitive, and physiological factors that contribute to reduced empathy in these contexts and test interventions aimed at increasing empathy. Combatting empathy burnout will help promote the health and well-being of Canadaâ€™s frontline workers. Closing moral empathy gaps will help address Canadaâ€™s widening groivisions grounded in morality, like political polarization.
OIA_AREA: Social and cultural investigation and development

Project_Title: Investing in Rents: The Impacts of Apartment Financialization in Canada
Project_Description: Since the late 1990s, financial firms have increasingly consolidated ownership of multi-family rental apartments in Canada. The rising dominance of finance in the global economy is linked with crises of both affordability and inequality, and in the apartment sector, financial ownership is driving rent increases, displacement, and patterns of gentrification. This research will develop an original 3-city ownership database (that includes Toronto, Vancouver, and Montreal) to identify patterns of financial ownership and examine how it is linked to eviction filings, rent increases, and displacement. The impact on tenants will be explored through longitudinal surveys with tenants in buildings acquired for financial investors, and through qualitative interviews at sites where financial firms exert monopoly control. These findings on the scope and impact of financial ownership will inform evidence-based policy recommendations for more inclusive housing in Ontario.

Project_Title: Modeling Crude Oil Shipments for Risk Assessment and Economic/Environmental Analysis
Project_Description:
Crude oil shipments and pipeline networks are absent from current freight forecasting models, resulting in a lack of evidence-based project planning and policy analysis for crude oil transportation decision-making. As the demand for crude oil increases subject to expanding global markets, the mode shift of Canadian crude oil from pipelines to rail is likely to become more pronounced in the future, and the risk implications of these pipeline to rail modal shifts are not well-understood.

Dr. Bachmannâ€™s team will study the behaviour of crude oil shippers and pipeline regulators to develop novel activity-based computer simulation models to predict the consequences of changes in pipeline and rail network connectivity on the expected pattern of crude oil shipments. Combined with Quantitative Risk Assessment (QRA), these models will make rail transportation plans safer for Ontario's residents, especially for hospitals and schools in rail corridors, by reducing the likelihood of catastrophic accidents (e.g., Lac-Mantic).

Project_Title: Designing electrocatalysts to convert waste small molecules into value-added products
Project_Description: Curbing carbon and nitrogen emissions is the central environmental challenge for the twenty-first century. Ammonia in wastewater discharge from human activities, including agriculture and landfill, is a growing concern due to its detrimental impact on aquatic ecosystems. Furthermore, both anthropogenic carbon and nitrogen emissions result in climate change: while CO2 is a well-recognized greenhouse gas, nitrous oxide produced by natural degradation of ammonia has a 298 times higher global warming potential compared to CO2. Electrochemical technologies provide potential solutions to converting harmful emissions and waste to fuel, however, poor efficiency and selectivity in currently known reaction systems impedes their wide-spread commercial adaptation. The proposed research will enable the development of breakthrough high-performance catalysts for an integrated electrochemical treatment of carbon and nitrogen wastes by establishing a leading-edge nanoscience framework for their rational design. The scientific and technological advances of this research will facilitate Ontarioâ€™s transition to a circular econom

Project_Title: Self-Sustaining Software Build Systems
Project_Description:
Build systems, i.e., the systems that specify how source code is translated into deliverables, play a critical role in software development. Unfortunately, build systems are often haphazardly maintained, leading to unreliable continuous integration and delivery services that produce a noisy signal of project status, or worse, that release defective software to users.

To mitigate this risk and lessen the burden of build maintenance, Dr. McIntosh's proposed research will explore the extent to which build systems can sustain themselves â€“Â a goal comprising two research objectives, which strive: (RO1) to detect when and classify which build maintenance actions might be needed; and (RO2) to formulate and apply repair strategies when build maintenance is required. By applying multi-modal language modelling approaches to build logs and incorporating program repair strategies, Dr. McIntosh will greatly reduce the risk and effort associated with build maintenance, which in turn, will contribute to the vibrant Ontartech sector.
OIA_AREA: Development and creation of investigation spots

Project_Title: Splitting algorithms for pathological optimization problems: Static results and dynamic behaviour.
Project_Description:
Splitting algorithms are powerful optimization methods which aim to solve constrained convex (not necessarily smooth) optimization problems.

Using tools from convex and variational analysis, Dr. Moursi and her research team will investigate the analytical behaviour of these methods in the absence of minimizers and/or convexity, and develop the algorithmic counterpart.
This research include numerical testing, comparison of the computational cost of these methods to existing ones and developing software packages. Areas of applications include image processing, data sciences, statistics and machine learning, and finance.

The progress Dr. Moursi and her team make will be of significant interest for scientists employing splitting methods and for the industrial and healthcare sectors, since the functions used to model industrial problems are often nonconvex. On the other hand, HQP working on this research will acquire a strong analytic and computational foundation. 
Both aspects will significantly contribute to Ontarioâ€™s leading role in sciences and industr

Project_Title: Quantum Simulations of Fundamental Particle Interactions
Project_Description:
The standard model of particle physics is the bedrock for our understanding of Nature. Numerical simulations of subatomic physics are restricted due to inherent limitations of classical computers to simulate quantum properties. Thus, there is an inescapable need to find new methods to address numerous open fundamental questions. Quantum computers can in principle overcome these roadblocks. However, to reap the rewards of this opportunity requires the development of new quantum simulation tools for so-called gauge theories which underlay the standard model.

Dr. Muschik will develop the theoretical concepts to build these new types of quantum simulators, she will work with experimental partners on proof-of-concept demonstrations, and she will employ hybrid quantum-classical simulations that benefit from on machine learning.

By applying quantum technology to problems in particle physics, she will bridge two strong fields in Ontario, while establishing industry connections for knowledge transfer with Google and IBM.

Project_Title: Partial readout of quantum information using trapped ions
Project_Description: Quantum computing is expected to revolutionize technology. However, a major challenge in building quantum computers is the difficulty of allowing them to make decisions: given this quantum information, what should the computer do next? This difficulty arises from the fact that reading the information that tells the computer which decision to make, often corrupts the remaining quantum data due to fundamental rules of quantum measurement. Dr. Senkoâ€™s team will develop novel techniques to protect some quantum information while other information is being read out. Their work will raise the profile of Ontario as a leader in quantum computing research, by informing the design of next-generation quantum computers that include decision-making capabilitie
OIA_AREA: Development and creation of investigation spots

Project_Title: Structure and algorithms in graph theory
Project_Description:
The proposed research centers around finding efficient algorithms for computational problems in graphs through structural considerations. Graphs are mathematical structures that model relationships in discrete systems, such as computer chips, networks, and power grids. Various resource management problems (such as assigning tasks to workers) can be expressed as problems on graphs; but real-world instances are too complex to be able to compute a solution in practice.

Dr Spirklâ€™s methods rely on analyzing the global effect of forbidden local patterns, a fundamental question in graph theory. Dr Spirklâ€™s team will work to fully classify those local structures that lead to efficient practical algorithms. The team will research and develop a repertoire of problem-solving techniques applicable to both academia and industry. Since local restrictions are frequently found in practical instances, solving them is relevant to many challenges (such as increasing efficiency by obtaining better, faster algorithms) in thchnology sector in Ontario.
OIA_AREA: Development and creation of investigation spots
